Early Access Review
								310 hours dedicated to this game so far and growing! This game has been one of the most entertaining and immersive games I've played yet and this is just the sandbox. I can only imagine what the final, released version will be like with the story included! This review for now will focus on the early access version of the game.I can't think of any other games like it. A quiet apocolypse has taken place, technology as we know it is gone. The lights went out, never to return. How long can you survive against nature and everything it has to throw at you? There are no zombies. There are no mutants or aliens. Just you, nature and the need to survive. Scavenge what you can from the abandoned regions, hunt for food and find a warm place to spend the night. Just be aware that beyond the safety of your fireglow, green eyes flash in darkness, waiting for you to give them a chance to send you into the long dark. No one is coming to save you, so you'd best be ready to save yourself.Features:=======+No Zombies, no supernatural, no aliens, no occult! Just nature, and it's brutally unforgiving.+ A gorgeous art style fairly reminiscent of the Group of Seven. Iconic, refreshing and engaging, it's a nice break from photorealism and proof that games can be beautiful and immersive without being overly heavy on realism.+ Four modes of difficulty with vastly different challenges for all types.+ Crafting of the basic survival needs, like torches and bows, and animal skin clothing+ Survival simulation with a unnervingly believable feel. Monitor your temperature, hunger, thirst and energy levels. Think carefully about your food choices and plan your routes carefully. even a small injury could lead to much worse if left ignored.+ Challenge modes for those who work better under pressure. Added in the newest update, these challenge modes give seasoned players a few scenarios to complete. Originally there were only 2 but it has since grown to 5.+Comfortably playable with Mouse and Keyboard or with a controller.+Extremely well done voiceovers for the basic sandbox characters.+An out of this world sound experience. Every little sound you hear, from the wind in the trees to the clattering of old shutters, has a purpose and has been meticulously planned. A crow flying overhead may alert you to an approaching storm, a strange clang or clatter in a whiteout can point the way to safety. A growl in the darkness can sound your doom.  All of this atmospheric and immersive sound is punctuated by music tracks that serve to elevate the feel of the moment. Rather than play constantly in the background, these short musical interludes kick in to emphasize something and just as quickly fade out again. (The coming of night, the sun rising, A particularly lonely place, or a Change of weather.)+The game offers no hand-holding. You are dropped in the world and left to figure it out. You will die many times before it starts to make sense, but each time you fail, you get a better idea of how you can apply what you've learned to the next run.It should be noted that the only real drawback aside fomr the learning curve to the game is the fact that death is permanent. When you die you start again from the beginning, but even that makes for good compelling gameplay as it pushes you to be more careful about how you go about your survival.Early access means the game is still undergoing serious developement, but even in this current form, it's hard to believe it's an alpha. It's polished and professional with smooth gameplay and challenge that's well worth the full price. If you like sandbox/survival games, this is a great choice. If you like to simply play the game at your own pace and observe the quiet apocolypse, this game is still a great choice. And when story mode releases, I am certain those who like to play games for the storyline will also love it too. Hinterland is making a great first impression with The Long Dark.A solid 8/10, most likely a 10 once it hits release.

								Not yet.(see 2nd paragraph for my real review) This game has plenty of potential but for now it's simply too lacking. Do you find yourself freezing in a cabin surrounded  by wooden furnitare and yet unable to find anything to burn? Why not break one of the chairs or the table or perhaps even the counter? But this game says no. Have a Jerrycan filled to the brim with karosen? That's great!  It's too bad you can't use it to start a fire. Find a dead deer and want to drag it back to your cabin? Nope, can't do that either. How about those pesky ever-breaking can openers; god knows I go through 15 of them a month... Or the breakable and weak hatchets and pry bars. Every summer I must spend $15,000 replacing all of them I break. Skinning an animal with a knife? watchout that knife will break into usless shards after four uses... How about using 3 coats to repair the one you're wearing? Nope, better cut those coats up into 1 scrap cloth peice each while needing 2 peices to add 15% more durability.Review: For a game that is focusing on realism it falls short in too many areas. The game sacrifices realisim for difficulty. The elements and lack of food should make the game hard enough; however, the game sees fit to give you a hatchet and hunting knife that you're not allowed to wield in defense; so you better punch that wolf lungeing for your jugular. The game also surrounds you with logs and wooden furnitare that you're not allowed to burn nor are you allowed to re-ignite fires from active coals from a recently dead fire. And don't even get me started on how quickly duribility on things like you clothes goes. In a matter of days(in-game) you'll see your equiped clothes lose duribility. There are way too many things that need to be fixed and added before this is remotely enjoyable / playable.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								So. I first bought The Long Dark during the 2014 Christmas Sale way back when because I saw a video from a YouTuber saying it was good and had far, far too much money to waste. (which was all wasted in that very same sale. DAMN YOU GABEN.)On March 8th, 2015, I finally decided to make my first attempt at playing this game. I had been binging on a number of other games recently and finally decided "Eh, I'll see what this whole thingamabobber is about."Now, I was essentially going into this thinking "indie survival simulator" and getting terrible flashbacks of all the BAD attempts at the same genre that the indie community (and even the professional community) have made in recent years. Yes, the screenshots looked pretty and stylized, but I wasn't about to judge a game by graphics alone; if I did, then most entries of Call of Duty would suddenly jump above everything else from the very bottom of my list.I was going into this expecting to laugh my♥♥♥♥♥off at a poor attempt at gameplay and quality and tension in general.I was so, so, SO wrong.This game. This. F***ing game. This game is AMAZING.My first sandbox playthrough lasted about a day and a half, at which point I had run out of resources, was stuck in the middle of a blizzard with no firewood or starters, and was freezing my♥♥♥♥♥off. I decided to go quietly, laid down my bedroll, went to sleep, and never woke up.In that moment, I felt a part of my soul die with my character.This is not a game to be laughed at. This is not a game where you play it and look for all the bugs and errors to make fun of. This is a game that, within the first half-hour, will have you so incredibly and undeniably hooked that you care about your character in such a way that the game over screen reads like a gravestone of a close friend.Three pieces of advice for new players:First, expect a challenge. Even on the lowest difficulty where the wolves DON'T attack you, this game is punishing for your mistakes. As stated above, my first playthrough lasted about a single in-game day because I failed to account for resources properly. My second playthrough has lasted about five days, but I still don't see myself living past fifteen. This is not a game to mess around with: make EVERY MINUTE COUNT. Otherwise, you won't last very long at all.Second, expect to be surpised and stunned by the visuals. This is not a game that has ULTRA-REALISTIC 3D where EVERY SNOWFLAKE IS RENDERED AND DRAWN DOWN TO THE ATOMIC LEVEL. No, this is a low-poly, low-res-texture game, even on ultra graphics settings. And yet, despite ALL of that, the style alone makes up for it. During my first playthrough, one of the very first things I did was climb the tallest mountain I could reach. I made it up there at sunset and... well, I just stood there. I broke my very own rule of making the time count, because I was so shocked at how GORGEOUS this game can be. In my second playthrough, with even more time to explore, I have had my mind blown over and over and over again as this game delivers stunning view after stunning view. Despite not having AAA ultra-complex graphics, I can easily say that TLD is more beautiful than any AAA game on the market.Third, expect to become attached to your character. Seriously, you WILL come to care about your character. And THIS is why I truly love this game so much. In my ENTIRE GAMING CAREER, there are less than five games to EVER make me shed a tear. But when my first playthrough ended and my character passed away in his sleep, I did indeed shed a tear. I shed MANY. This game forges such a strong emotional bond between player and protagonist that I simply can't praise it enough. You have to play it and EXPERIENCE it to understand.So play it. For the love of every god I can think of and/or name, fictional or otherwise, PLAY THIS GAME. In an industry filled with parody games and vanilla, generic copies of old classics, The Long Dark delivers such an original, strong, and emotional presence that it simply cannot be ignored. So, to Hinterland Studio Inc., I applaud you for creating an experience unlike anything else I have ever had the pleasure to enjoy.You will not be wasting your time playing a poorly-concieved indie game here; you, as a living being, DESERVE this game. Do not deny yourself this experience. Enjoy The Long Dark in all its frozen glory.Now, with that said, I'm going to go back inside my fishing hut and eat some more delicious rainbow trout.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is a thought provoking exploration-based survival game.  You find yourself stranded in the northern Canadian wilderness with only the clothes on your back and a few meager supplies that will last you for a short time.  The game's intersting hunger meter (a calorie counter) provides you with an accurate measure of your character's craving for food that makes you feel more determined to actually try and endure the cold.  Speaking of cold, the weather varies from absolute blizzards that can get as cold as -55ºC to crystal clear sunny days where you're lucky enought to get a temperature that's right around the freezing mark.  Just like most people in real life, you need to have clothes warm enough to bear the freezing weather if you plan on making a trek outside for a long period of time;  that is, unless you'd rather slowly freeze to death.  As an additional way to combat the cold, you create campfires, light fireplaces, and even use kerosene lamps to warm you if you are getting too cold.  An ever growing issue in this game is your thirst.  Water can either be unsafe or potable.  Clean water can be found relatively easy as it is  prevalent in the world (Ex: drinking out of toilets).  Unsanitary water can be boiled over a fire or fireplace to clean and be made drinkable.  Soda can be found in most abandoned homes, they contain both calories and help quench your thirst.  Coffee and tea can be made as an additioinal source of liquids as well as containg special properties that make them slightly better than water.  If you're ever unable to find any of these and you have the materials needed to create a fire, you can melt snow into clean water.  Your fatigue is an important factor in determining your survival.  The longer you go without sleep and the more strenuous the activities you do are, the more lethargic and slow your character becomes.  This can be remedied by taking a nap.  If you're lucky enough to find a weapon you can defend yourself from the wolves which are your only real predator in the game.  Wolves are a surprisingly terrifying adversary in a game such as this.  Ammo for your rifle (which is the only firearm available this early in the game) is scarce and you are required to conserve and effiectively use your ammunitions for hunting deer or other smaller game or to protect yourselves against wolves.  Flares are also an effective recource to use in defending yourself from animals.  The Long Dark is overall a great survival game.  This review was written during the alpha and I'm sure there are many more features to come.  I'd easily give this game a 9/10.

For those of us who have a game 100-200 days long you might expect some more warmer days.  But, again, lets just assume the world has changed in the game as we don't know what is going on.  Or maybe it could be in some high altitude mountains for all we know.ALL THAT SAIDI love the game.  I think it's outstanding and get excited whenever steam updates it.  I can't wait to jump in and see where it's been updated.The music is wonderful.  The graphics although stylized are more than satisfactory and seem to improve at every update.  The controls are fluid and became second nature almost immediately.  The menus are hit and miss.  I've been playing for long enough I've seen this change a few times.  Sometimes they improve although in my opinion the survival menu was a bit easier to understand before while now it has a kind of HUD thing going.  Personally I preferred the previous menu but I'll give it time.  I may grow to like this one.It may sound like I'm complaining but I'm simply pointing out some minor issues as the core of the game is outstanding.  Considering this is an unfinished game that's already quite impressive.  Bug-wise once in a blue moon I'll have the game crash but I can count on one hand how many times that's happened and I've had the game for months.It's a very good, original outstanding game.  I HIGHLY recommend it.  It's one of my favorite games, possibly ever, no lie.  I just hope they keep building on it.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
Early Access Review
The Long Dark is a 1st rate survival game, with a back story that already speaks; even while the game is in Alpha. Currently, you only play the game in "sandbox mode." This amounts to an open world survival experience, where you spawn at one of a variety of points on a predetermined map. A geomagnetic storm brings your small plane down in the Canadian wilderness. You are unprepared, and it's freezing cold. As if that weren't enough pressure to get you moving your worthless tennis shoes, you soon find you aren't the only creature slinking along using the hills to break the wind as you hunt for shelter before darkfall. Choosing Apocalypse: Though everyone is talking, and gaming, the demise of modern civilization, not everyone agrees on the possible scenarios. If you prefer an end like that described in the book The Road, by Cormac McCarthy, where you wander the beautiful countryside, quietly chronicling the passing of an era; you may choose the Pilgrim mode to sure starving and freezing.  If you subscribe to the idea of a countryside ravaged by wildlife gone mad in a frenzy for food, as in the book The China Pandemic by A.R. Shaw, then you would probably choose the Stalker mode. This is described as a punishingly challenging survival experience in the menu. There is a good middle road for those like myself who want a challenge that is somewhere in the middle. The Voyageur mode is described as equal parts hunter and hunted. Wolves and bears stalk you as you try to scavenge for food. This is the only mode I have played, as the Stalker seems a bit over-challenging for me right now. When you go out to find food, you are stalked by the wolves and bears. You try to hibernate as much as possible, but this won’t last long. Blizzards arise at any given moment. You don’t know when you leave your base whether or not a storm will appear, so you have to choose carefully what you will take with you. If a wolf is stalking nearby when you plan to return, you may not be able to get back to your base. This is the middle choice. You have been warned if you choose the Stalker mode. For the purposes of this review I will describe my 100 hours experience in the Voyageur route.Saving your hides: There is no forgiveness in this game. You will go out to find food with tools and weapons that you find. The shotgun takes a learning curve. The knife and axe are trusty. You can harvest meat and hides from carcasses you find, or you can kill your own meat. But, the game does not allow saving. It saves automatically when you enter the door of a building, and when you sleep in a bed, or fall into the Long Dark sleep of death. It’s too late when you are staring into the fangs of a wolf to use the alt-tab function and return to the last place you entered a door or slept. That route must be chosen before the wolf grabs you.Survival methods in this game mirror real-world survival methods. First, I load up for a trip. Then I go outside the door, and immediately back inside to initiate an autosave. While I was out there, I made a quick recon of the area to be sure no wolves or bears were nearby. Then, having good info, I make some final decisions about my trip, and I am ready to venture out into the unknown in search of sustenance and survival.  Crafting: Unlike many other survival games, TLD uses a more realistic crafting system. You must lay your collected hides out on the floor to cure them for an amount of time, before beginning to craft clothing. Then, you complete the crafting in your spare hours over a number of days, just as you would really make your own clothes. You must repair all your clothing and tools frequently, as they degrade in a realistic manner in the arctic cold winds. You are able to choose and change your clothing by degrees of warmth provided and by weight. Your stats are adversely affected by heavier weights over time, and your character is worn out by carrying too much. You must choose carefully or die sooner. You will die. But, it is better to survive and die, than to have never survived at all. NarrativeThe Story mode is not finished as the game is in early release. But, I believe from dev comments that it is almost finished. In the year I’ve had the game, they have made frequent updates. I am very excited to see the actual story, which is already “showing through the cracks” so to speak, in the sandbox. The achievements, as well, pull in stories of their own, and provide a sense of accomplishment that is unparalleled.Graphics & Sound: There are several new maps in the Sandbox mode, and each one features the most surreal and hauntingly lovely nature scenes, in an art style that is screaming for an artbook in the final release. I only hope they go all out with that idea, as the art is phenomenal! And, speaking of final release... the story mode is nearing completion. I've already spent months on end in Mystery Lake's map alone, so I can imagine the hours of game play the story mode will provide. Graphics are done in a realistic art that looks hand-drawn. The view is splendid from anywhere in the game. The music is great for this genre, as it doesn’t get in the way of game play, and yet appears at points of high-drama, like just as you near starving to death.Genre Comparison: I bought this at the same time I bought Stranded Deep, and a couple of other intensive survival games. The Long Dark far exceeds every other survival game I've played. Where you find a lack of resources to build anything substantive in SD, The Long Dark keeps you immersed in crafting weapons, curing animal hides to craft deerskin clothes, finding bunkers, exploring ever-changing scenery, and a realistic survival experience that promises to define a genre.There are many survival games. But, there is only one Long Dark. Where games like the Wasteland series and Sheltered come across slightly cheesy, (not to mention often clunky mechanics) TLD is realistic in concept and execution. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is a good game, with a great story, but it has more sci-fi elements to it, where TLD lives within the realm or today and tomorrow. And, some of those are not presented in life size action like in TLD’s silent apocalypse. Savage Lands is life size, and appreciable for its own unique crafting, and somewhat medieval look. Yet, I found it somewhat unbelievable that you would run-up to an unmoving deer and slay him on the spot. In TLD you must stalk your prey, as in the real world, because they will run when frightened. I think that sums up the effect: the wildlife AI is responsive to the player.Pros: * Unmatched Survival Realism* Dynamic Weather * Hibernation Simulation* Stats react to loads carried and the weather conditions* You craft your own meds and heal yourself* Ice Fishing, rabbit trapping, and hunting with bows that you craft* You can recycle tools and weapons to repair or build new equipment* Frequent UpdatesCons: *The cook stove or campfire interface is “locked in” and you can’t perform other tasks while cooking.  *The same locked-in interface stalls your view of the countryside while ice-fishing. I only hope they will improve this, but it doesn’t affect gameplay. * ATM, there is no ability to map your area. But, there are links to maps in the community hub. These are possibly created by the fan-base, and differ in degrees of accuracy.I recommend this game for those who enjoy a challenging survival experience with complex components. This is no simple game. Firing the shotgun takes a learning curve, and trial and error. But, once you learn to fire it, you find yourself bringing in multiple animals in one hunt. The more challenging achievements require you to survive without firing a gun, and live off the land. One simple mistake leaves you facing the fangs of a wolf, or freezing to death. This is definitely a game you won't want to miss.

Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is a lot of things, but most importantly: it's not another unfinished game on Early Access. This game is going places. The Devs work really hard, and this game has been virtually reinvented in the time I've owned it (about a year). Hinterland has laid out a roadmap for where they want the game to go in the future, and those ideas are being regularly implemented in updates every three to four months or so. What are in the updates? New features and additions to the Sandbox mode, the best part of the game at this point while we wait in anticipation for Story Mode. The Sandbox is amazing. The wildlife simulations aren't perfect, but the whole weather systems and the places you can explore (mountains, lakes, mines, dams, scenic overlooks and seemingly endless forests) and the things you can do (kill deer, wolves, bear, craft items, balance cans of soup on the corpse in the camp office of mystery lake) are what makes this game great. The sunsets are surprisingly beautiful at the end of the world.

Early Access Review
								A few of the many things I like about this game so far:- Extremely atmospheric environment and especially weather effects (wind, snow, fog etc)- Beautiful graphics, the lighting in particular (you don't often feel the need to spend 10 or 15 minutes enjoying an in-game sunset)- Nights are actually dark, there's no mysterious illumination from nowhere to help you get around as in most other games- All kinds of neat realistic touches: the more you carry the slower you can move; walking into a howling gale is slower than walking ahead of it; you can hide from the wind behind tree trunks; accidentally walking into your own campfire results in a burned foot (doh)Very absorbing and often quite tense despite the lack of conventional "action". It's easy to find yourself completely lost when the weather turns to fog and snow, changing a nice sunny stroll in the woods to "Oh crap it's -35C and I need to get a fire started ASAP or I'm going to freeze!". Interested to see where the story mode goes when that is complete, but the sandbox mode is worth paying for already.

Early Access Review
								It took twenty days, five hours and fifty-six minutes before I stared death in the eyes one final time. It happened slowly, painfully and has stuck with me since it happened forty-seven minutes ago. It started in the afternoon of the twentieth day. I hadn't had a thing to eat since the morning before, and the Canadian camp-site office building offered nothing more for my famished stomach. The fishing lines had broken and I had no rifle, yet I had twenty rounds of ammunition. With that being said, it was time to take my chance in the wilderness again. I took one step forward and planted my sockless feet down into the snow.I wandered down the traintracks until I encountered a wreck with two carriages. I snuck into the the first, wary of the several wolves patrolling the local area. By now my health had dropped to around 80%. I knew the risks of entering the carriage with a wolf so close by, but I would have done anything for a granola bar or the like. Unfortunatley the first carriage yielded nothing. As I left, the wolf howled and began chase. I immediately backtracked and sprinted roughly a hundred metres before running out of breath. He caught up, mauled me, and my health had dropped to 12% before I could fend him off with my hunting knife. I patched my wounds but the painkillers and antiseptic wouldn't bring my health back - only sleep would. I limped back from which I came, snuck past the wolf that had bitten me and the rest of his pack and continued up the train tracks until I discovered safety - a dam nestled between two snowy peaks.I entered with 6% health. It was looking grim, but I hadn't been here before so there was a high chance I would stumble onto some food. It was also dark, with visibility at a minimum. However, the torch at the entrance took care of that almost immediately. As I made my way further into the complex, I discovered what can only be described as a gift from God - it was a granola bar. 300 calories into the system, slight warmth from being inside - things were looking up. It didn't take longer than a minute for all my dreams to be taken away from me, however, as the devil himself decided to crush what hope I had left. It started as a growl, and grew into a nightmare as a came face-to-face with a wolf that seemed almost as large as I was. A wolf? Inside? Impossible. For a moment I thought it was a trick of the light, possibly a trick of the mind, but not a second later my doubts were gone as I felt the warm saliva of the beast as it tore into my throat and left me for dead in the dam, on a cold and frosty Canadian afternoon.9/10, a little performance upgrade possibly, (or maybe that's on my end) but this is one of the best survival games I have ever played. It felt complete, and I completely forgot it was in alpha. What these guys have now is a complete game, so whatever they decide to add will make it incomparable to anything on the market.

Early Access Review
								I was running across a frozen lake having just stocked up a few various shelters in the area with supplies. I had made it eleven days at this point. Food was plentiful, supplies were more than I could carry and I had a nice rifle and half a dozen rounds to go along with it.It was four hours from sundown. I was just a stones throw away from the base of the hill where my main shelter was. It was a glorious two story, wood panel cabin with a bed with my name on it. I could see it at this point from where I stood on the lake. But between myself and my gloriously warm bed, right at the base of the hill, crept a bear. It was a big, overbearing giant. It was easily three, even four times my size. But it was also a source of majestic food. Food, pelts and guts for curing.I lowered myself into a crouch and slowly approached it. Rifle drawn, crosshair as best I could place it with my shaky hands, I got within twenty meters of the beast. I slowed my breathing as best I could, placed the crosshair center mass and pulled the trigger. The crack echoed in the eerie cold silence, ripping the air apart as it reverberated. There was nothing at first. No movement, no accompanying growls or grunts, just nothing. I stood up, chambered another round and took aim once again. I approached the lifeless corpse hesitantly, still aware of the potential danger if it weren't to be fatally wounded. I got within an inspecting distance and peered at it. Still no movement. It was truly dead. I...this cold, hungry and very frightened woman shot this great beast with one measly round and killed it?HA! TAKE THAT NATURE! I WILL PREVAIL!With just over three hours of sunshine left I dug straight into the corpse, carving hide from flesh and tearing flesh from bone. There was so much it was just incredible, I mean the food alone could easily last another fortnight! I'll harvest as much as I can so the wolves don't take it. After all, the cabin is just up that small hill there. Hours ticked past and all the hacking and cutting was slowly tiring me while the sun slowly dipped further past the horizon.I wasn't even halfway through it all when I realised the sun had completely dropped from the sky and the chills of night had crept upon me. Its icy fingers had slid its way into my clothing and all down my extremities. My vision was numbing and my pack was too heavy to run with. I started the short climb towards the cabin with my lantern in front of me, my vision starting to fade. Suddenly, the snap of a twig, the howl of a wolf. He's just meters away. I drop my lantern and pull out my rifle. BANG! The bullet whizzes past the wolf's head and he squeals, turning heel and running the other way. Phew. I won't be that lucky again. I continue the short walk to my cabin. It's just up there. I can see it right ahead now. I can just about touch the doorknob, smell the fireplace. Then a loud growl and a sudden impact and another wolf is upon me. With my very last bit of energy I put my arm in front of myself and watch as the wolf rips into my throat and severs my jugular and sends me fading off into The Long Dark.

Early Access Review
								I have been playing The Long Dark for several hours now daily for the last several days. I think it is fair to call this game a "singleplayer survival experience." Here's what I find relevant to share with the Steam Community as of now:AboutThe paralleling concept of this game is based on the premise of you, a plane crash victim, surviving in a number of environments abandoned by humanity. With the object of survival /obviously/ in mind, you spawn in a random place on the map and must scavenge for food, water, shelter, and other assets of survival for as many days as possible.ImpressionsWhen I first dropped into the game world, I died within 17 hours. I was really edgy and tense playing this game for the first time, expecting wolves at every corner. I played with the lights out, and sure enough, I got a jumpscare when a wolf tackled me and tore my character apart (yay for wolves tearing characters apart!) My second game has been a lot better and I have survived just over a week so far.Time in the game passes slowly, a day in gameplay is almost a full hour. So with this game, you are guaranteed a great deal of hours that you can spend in the action.The graphics, as far as indie games go, are pretty good. Textures are occasionally just "O.K." But what is to yell about is the art direction. This said, the overall scenery and ambience that makes up this game is stunning. The sunrise and sunset is beautiful, the snow is pretty, the lighting of user-usable items is realistic and alludes well to the general game world. It is relevant to acknowledge that unlike some games in the "Survival-Adventure" genre title, this game is not procedurally generated. Meaning: it's not a new map everytime like games such as Minecraft. Despite this being so the case, the game has felt seemingly infinite. After playing a rather decent number of hours, I know I have only scratched the surface of the exploration on the map. Will I like it?Though it IS an early access title, I think many people will be very pleased by the definite unique style the game brings. It is a nice break from the generic multiplayer gameplay introduced and obviously found in games like DayZ and Unturned. Though it is a neccesity to acknowledge that these games are both fine titles, it is equally fair to acknowledge that their gameplays involve a number of crude dynamics turning other individuals, the environment, zombies, and other things against you in a constantly regenerating world. In the universe of "The Long Dark", once things are gone: they are gone, they will not come back. The realistic experience of limited resources and materials can only be broken by a number of actual renewable resources in the wild. The differences are fair and don't really subtract anything from the gameplay. If anything, they add a great deal of intensity and action to your experience.It's very fair to say that your only enemy in this game is how slow you move. Failure to keep moving means definite death. You will either certainly starve, freeze, or be torn to shreds by the wild wolves of the wilderness.Final WordsOverall, you will like this game, but only if you're up for taking long treks across big chunks of open world, exploring, potentially being attacked by wild animals, and playing with many basic survival game dynamics. At this point, as the game lies as an EAG, I would give it an 8/10. They've done a great deal of work to make this game a wonderful experience so far for myself and hundreds of others, however, there are certain things that could definitely be added, changed, edited, or completely removed.I look forward to seeing the future development of this game. I will refer back to this review as development progresses to update users here of the changes (game-wise, personally/opinion-wise, etc.) Shouts to Hinterland Studio, and best of luck!Thank you, hopefully this review has served you well. See you on the dark side!

Early Access Review
								I had survived for five long, cold days. At dawn I exited the little cabin by the lake and walked out onto the ice. This frozen expanse had provided me with valuable resources, so I made my camp in the lodge across the way. As I began to make my way back to camp, we spotted each other. A very large, very angry bear stood to my right. We locked eyes and everything stopped. I raised my rifle as he charged and fired. Direct hit, but still he came. As the remaining three bullets did little to slow him, I realized this was it. He hit with the force of a runaway truck. Teeth and claws thrashed and ripped by clothes and flesh. The attack lasted mere seconds, but the damage was done. I pulled myself, bleeding and bruised from the ice and administered what little first aid I had. With the last small ounce of adrenaline left in me, I began to run. Straight across for the lodge where all of my extra supplies, firewood and food were. The black crept into the edges of my vision. My staggering grew worse. I couldn't walk straight, but still I pushed on. After what seemed like a lifetime, I pulled myself to the door of the cabin and went inside. Slowly up the stairs, vision all but gone, I crept. Finally, I lit a fire with my last accelerant and a few books. Water, food, rest and pain killers pulled me back from the brink over the next day. When back at 100 percent, I ventured out for more ice fishing, only to be surrounded by wolves and killed; overtaken by hypothermia and blood loss. I survived six days, eight hours.

Early Access Review
								The Long Dark has come a long way since I last reviewed it. It strives to offer a unique realistic survival experience, but falls just short. It requires some balancing and is still lacking some content, which I really hope gets added before being considered finished. In it's current state I would recommend it on sale, but not full price. I will not be discussing the "Pros" in this review, because there are enough that do that already. For the record, this is all subjective and based on my opinion of the game in its EARLY ACCESS STATE, but I think many will agree.--- Lacking Content ---There are not very many craftable items yet(?) and as you play, you can't help feel that some are missing. Like literally needing to forge arrow heads in a furnace instead of rigging some using scrap metal, flint or even just sharpening the arrow shaft to a tip.You can find and read survival books that surely would teach how you to make and use a bow drill to start fires (while it is challanging, it's still possible) or pieces of flint.I know in Canada your options would be limited in terms of out door shelters, but you should be able to build a small temporary lean-to out of pine branches to protect you some from the weather while you harvest an animal.This is a minor complaint, but maybe another weapon or two? like some form of common pistol or compound bow, just to add some diversity instead of finding several identical rifles.---The Balance---Your chance to start a fire is too low for being indoors with an actual stove. Having matches, tinder and wood in those circumstances, should result in a chance of no less than 75%.You eat too much. Your character is suppose to be an average person I presume, but eats as much as an Olympic athlete. Frequently eating an entire wolf, entire deer or several 2lb fish in a day? I think that's excessive. Should get more meat from animals or burn less calories to balance that out.Tools break unrealistically fast yet and are repaired too slow.---Other---I understand not being able to chop down a large tree with a small hatchet, but I think you should still be able to break branches off with it?Not sure anything can be done about this, because of how the games mechanics are implemented, but it's frustrating to waste a precious 2 hrs watching snow melt or water boil. You should be able to put it on the stove and do something else while you're waiting like fishing, crafting, fixing items, harvesting, etc. - - - OUT DATED REVIEW - - -EARLY ACCESS REVIEW: Simplifying this review, because some people, apparently, didn't understand what I was saying.This is not a bad game, but it has a few problems that prevent me from recommending it, at the moment. It will likely improve over time.I'M AWARE THAT THE GAME IS NOT FINISHED. With that said, lets get down to business. . .You are not rewarded for critical thinking or your knowledge of the wilderness.Survival in this game, seems to be a matter of luck an learning to survive the games mechanics.Things break unrealisticly fast (e.g. Your clothes will break and fall off from walking). Want to craft a weapon, like sharpening a stick to defend yourself from wolves, like Liam Neeson in "The Grey"? Can't do that. . .  yet? Have to fist fight them with your bare hands (You lose). There is a gun, if you can find it and equally important, ammo. It's the only weapon in the game so far. I've plundered about 15 structures in my 2 hrs and didn't find it.It seems like there will eventually be some sort of crafting system (via work bench), but its definitely not finished.Plan on being hardcore and surviving the unforgiving canadian wilderness, by living off the land or out of a cave in a realistic way, without stealing supplies from people? No chance. You are FORCED to break into random structures and steal supplies.It's fine if you want to do that, but be aware, there is no way around it. I can only assume, based on the way everything is currently balanced, that there are no plans to support that. If it bothers you, as it does me, you may want to wait on purchasing.I'd like the option to survive off the land, because while thats impossible, I hardly consider it a survival game. You should not NEED to rely on buildings and the contents inside them. It's rather new, so most of these problems will likely be fixed over time, but as of now, I just can't recommend it. I'm not trying to bash the game, but give useful criticism to the developers so they can improve the game and to you, so that you know what you're buying.

Early Access Review
								Only in its alpha stage and already The Long Dark is the best survival game I've ever played.  Every choice you make matters.  Every second counts.  What I love most about this game is all the different elements that are combined in determining how long you can withstand the fight to survive.  There's the standard health, but that's really the least of your worries.  In a game where you can literally freeze to death, the thing you should be most concerned about is the unpredictable weather.  On top of that is the ever-present threat of hungry wolves and bears.  Sure, there's deer and rabbits, but if you're willing to downgrade to dog food as means for sustenance, then you can bet those wolves and bears won't even stop to think before trying to take a bite out of you.  Next on the list is the matter of shelter.  You're not always going to be able to hide away in cabins (and for those lucky enough to find them, bunkers).  No, there are going to be times when you're going to have to try and find somewhere to camp out at when fatigue has run you ragged.  The great thing is that fire isn't really an issue.  You have a multitude of options when it comes to making yourself your own little bonfire, and it's not all that hard to do.  Now I'm going to circle back around to that standard health deal.  Water?  Yeah, it's your lifeline.  You can survive a little while when you're starving, but dehydration will kill you swiftly.  Your source of water is melting snow at the fire.  However, just that isn't enough.  You need to boil the water to make it safe, or else you're at risk of getting sick.  Are we having fun yet?  You might be thinking, "This game has way too many factors working against me.  It's not even worth it."  Not entirely true (as far as the first part; the second is up to you to decide).  The funny thing is that food isn't as big a worry as you'd think.  Remember those deer and rabbits I mentioned earlier?  Sometimes you'll run across the frozen remains of a deer and be able to harvest some meat.  When you do find shelters, then you're guaranteed to find some kind of food (and no, not just dog food).  And if you get desperate enough, you can always eat cattails you find along the edges of waterways.  Of course the level of difficulty plays a big factor in just how hard it is to survive.  My favorite is the difficulty setting in where wolves and bears won't attack you!  Unless provoked... it's not that easy.All in all, this game is really just wonderful.  There's no such thing as too much praise.  The most exciting thing?  This game is still in the alpha stage, and there's still a story mode to be explored!

Early Access Review
								A brilliant Concept:Permadeath Survival in a beautiful DX11 Environment on the Unity Engine!2019 - A geothermal Disaster made you one of the last Survivors in Canadas Outback during Winter. -Massive Exploration combined with an infinite Replay Value due to random Starting Points on many different Region Maps (which are linked by Tunnels, Mines and other Gateways inside this Game, so you are able to wander all the Regions in one Playthrough).-Random Loot Appearance, random frozen Corpses, random Animal Placement at the Start of every new Game! Infinite Replay Value!-Deeply immersive Surround Sound!-Many Difficulty Settings, so you are able to play this Single-Player Experience your way.-A Sandbox Mode to dive into the Game, a Story Mode and several totally different Challenge Modes to play the Game endlessly. In those Challenge Modes the Game changes to a totally different Experience: Be hunted by a HUGE Bear and try to reach the Trappers Outpost to get a special Rifle, before this Being can find you on the large Maps.... or... try to survive the coming Blizzard of the Century by gathering as much Ressources as you can! You only got 30 Days for that!... and many more of these quest-like Game Enhancements!-No Aliens, Russians (no offense XD) or Nazi Zombies but starving Wolves, Cougars and aggressive Bears!Those "Enemies" got a beautiful and complex AI Behaviour and will not just simply attack you on Sight. It all depends on your Difficulty Settings and your Movement ingame. Tools and Weapons will also change your Experience with them, the Hunter can easily become the Hunted! (Which counts for both Sides: The AI and your Character itself!)But the real Enemy is your own Player Character:-The cold Weather, which can change in an instant during your Travels, can easily kill you! Stay warm by using Fires, Shelters you are building out of Snow and Ice or hide some Hours inside an abandoned House.-Calories are a large Factor of Survival! You got to hunt, gather and cook to stay alive! -Gather and maintain your Survival Gear!... but also consider the Weight of every Item!-Fight Infections, broken Wrists, craft Bandages for your Wounds... the Number of Things which can happen is nearly endless. No HP Regeneration a la CoD! XDRating: Minus 20 out of Minus 10 - The next Blizzard will freeze your dead Body to the Ground!A beautiful Exploration Game and the hardest and most complex, but extremely enjoyable Survival Game in your Steam Library!May the Peace and Grace of RNGsus be with you!

								After encountering hundreds of 'survival/craft' games, one thing remains constant. That is, the game's tendency to make things easier over time, to the point where you feel a little OP. Not with this little gem. you're character never adapts, only YOUR mind as the player. each waking day is a constant battle of survival. In other games, wolves are the weakest of enemies. You end up feeling for your charachter, willing them to make through another hour in a blizzard, or with only a few candy bars. As much edge-of-seat excitement as a brilliant novel or tv series with it's atmospheric music and sound, and it's constant near-death experiences. and the final blow comes when your little survivor finally succumbs to the cold whilst lost in a blizzard, or is ravaged by a wolf that has stalked them for days.. your only memoir that they existed.. their journal. detailing where they went, what they found, what their state of health was and what finally ended thier story. collect enough journals of survivors that never made it and you get a sneak peak into the final days of a few desperate individuals as the harsh, gritty wilderness swallowed them all up.

So I set up shop in the camp office for a day or two, then set out exploring again. Figured I'd better stop by the dam just to stock up on supplies before heading into the unknown. I was happily greeted by my two crates at the front door, spent my time with all the lockers in the first room, then made my way to the safe on the first floor. I was listening to music because the game sounds are a bit off putting at 2 in the morning, but I had to pause this in order to crack the safe. Got it open, dissapointed to find only more forsaken newspapers. I turn around to continue looting, when a deafening growl penetrates my earholes, startling me and making me try to light a lantern with no oil in it. As I look to the door I see two little beads floating mid air. After a second I realize it's giant ♥♥♥♥ing wolf, in my ♥♥♥♥ing safe space, and in the midst of trying to climb back into my desk chair and put my headphones back on, then trying to figure out how to light and throw a flare for the first time, the thing flies across the room and tackles me. I throw as many flares as I can everywhere, assuming the beast will just go back to wherever the hell it came from. I'm exhausted and carrying twice the appropriate amount of weight so it takes me a minute to get to the door, and despite the several flares creating what I thought was a shield around me, it returned and attacked me right as I was approaching the door. The sound of wolves was definite in the distance, making me nervous about the very obvious trail of footprints behind me until I finally stumbled upon a lumber camp. I went in the first building and realised with dismay this trailer would stop the wind, but I was still cold, and no useable food (just a can of peaches). Then hope came in the form of an object on a shelf across the room. I've never been happier to see a can opener in my life.On a more technical side, my 5 year old laptop handled this game remarkably well on moderate settings. I love the style of the art and the sound design is, well... it reminds me of delivering papers in the snow, and the crunch of knee high snow as I pushed my way to doorsteps, hoping to get done before my fingers went completely numb or too much snow reached the bottom of my boots. As I play more of this I may update but first impressions are very favorable.

Posted: January 15, 2015
Early Access Review
 Important advice when playing The Long Dark Hi guys, This is not a typical review, but it might give a very important hint to someone who is new to The Long Dark, supposed one wants to have the most possible fun and challenge when playing a game and I think this should be the claim in every game, isn't it. Please excuse my style of writing in English. It is not my native language but I wanted to do this "review" in English as I think it is important for everybody who is new to TLD. I supported TLD and bought it because I think the guys from Hinterland deserve it and I am really looking forward of getting much more out of this game. OK, I suppose you are interested in TLD or even played already a first round and tried your first steps.Now, start by asking yourself, "What do I expect from this game...?" It's obvious, TLD is a different kind of computer game. It has nothing to do with the common shooter type, hunting for enemies and zombies or similar kind of more or less realistic wild west style of games. And yes - the graphics are average compared to what is possible today. And to make it even worse, TLD is a single player game in times when in the gaming industry the economic success is mainly coming from games, which are programmed to be multiplayer or even MMOGs. I mean we have all seen complex games like BF and alike and know what's in fact possible. Sure I know that Hinterland as a small company is in no way comparable to DICE or the other big game producers, but at the end of the day, it's the  game user who decides what to play for a similar price.So you might ask yourself, what's the use of spending time in TLD? Well, TLD is in the alpha phase with only two playable maps so far and there are still a couple of bugs. But important as this all may appear, it's not if you know how to handle it and why you want to play this game. TLD is different, it's an indie type of game with the flavor of an exploration and survival simulation. You are a pilot and a victim of an airplane crash somewhere in the northern Canadian wilderness. You don't have much with you, nothing to eat or to drink, no weapon and especially no compass or gps or something what tells you, where you are. The only thing you know is, that you are in a huge forest. Your task in the game is to survive as long as it's possible. Why all the people you will find around are dead but not the animals is unknown. Maybe the storyline will bring this up one day and may even bring you back to the civilization, but for now just accept it, it's a fact in TLD and increases the suspense. So far, so good. Now, there are several ways how to succeed in this disquieting situation. I will not go deeper into this, as there are a couple of fine guides out there from some committed community members and there is no use for me to invent the wheel twice. Please refer to these guides, they are important for a new player in TLD and really help a lot. But you will also find some guides here and there which offer maps of the TLD landscape. And here it comes, my most PRECIOUS HINT: By all means, DON'T USE MAPS in The Long Dark or you will spoil yourself the most interesting part of this game. The idea of TLD is NOT to check a map, running to these known spots, finding all the stuff you need to survive, and at the end (hahaha)  complaining that the game is "easy, crap and boring".If we are really using maps to walk around and to find all the hidden secrets - I mean don't let's be ridiculous, that's kindergarten and as I said, not the idea of the game - why playing it then when there are others around? Try to stay honest to yourself, just stay the brave adventurer who crashed in a plane and play your role. Find yourself lying in the snow underneath or near a rock after spawning, not knowing where you are and where to go. Be bold and decide the direction where to go next and you will be fine after a while. Maybe you find the sun in the sky if the weather is favorable enough to allow it, this gives you at least a certain idea about the time of day. Never walk into the night or in a storm! Learn how to prepare food and drink. Just allow yourself the suspense of being lost in the wilderness, lost in the cold and really try to find your way through the game. After a couple of sandbox trials you will know better and find your path anyway, since the playable maps are still small. Beware of wolves, stay away or surpass them, they are really dangerous and can end the round in seconds. At this point there is even something of a simulation in the game. Just feel the situation, feel the idea of this game and it will be YOUR game. This is the little secret for me and those who love The Long DarkYou will soon see, it's not rocket science to find the first cabin or even a house and it is much more fun to play this unusual game as is instead of just looking into an offered community map, only to see that the next house is just around the next hill. These guys from Hinterland are still developing TLD but offered us the sensation to already being part of it. So, my advice is, if you really want to have most out of TLD, don't use maps - ahh - by the way, our pilot doesn't have maps neither, they all burned down in the crash :-) He is smart enough to find his way alone, will you also do it?  See you out there and lots of fun in The Long Dark ;-)

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Finally, a survival game without zombies, monsters, or aliens.Short VersionIs it worth $20?Abso-freaking-lutely. I invested much, much more than $20 over a year ago, and don't regret it.The game mechanics are constantly being tuned. It will only get better.Long VersionThe Long Dark makes you focus on the things that are vital to a person's personal survival.Food, Thirst, Warmth, Energy.This game is hard. Make no mistake. But survival is not easy. You are always battling having enough food and water, having enough materials to maintain your core temperature, and having enough energy to complete the tasks to provide for the aforementioned needs.The Long Dark captures the concept of this perfectly.Are the menchanics 100% realistic? No. Of course not. This is a game. It has to be fun and challenging. Despite what you see on TV, Survival is not fun. It's a lot of time consuming monotonous tasks. I would not want to play a game that requires me to only need food once a month, drink once a week, wait 20 mins for water to boil, etc. etc.So the game requires a bit of suspension of reality.  That being said, the focus on the core survival elements is spot on.One of the chief complaints is that you burn too many calories.I suspect those doing the complaining are trying to maintain 100% condition.In cold weather, the body needs 6000-8000 calories to mantain condition.  That's a crap ton of food. When's the last time you saw a well-fed survivor?In the game, if you eat nothing, and take care of everything else, you'll live for 4 days before condition drops to zero.  This captures the real-life aspect. Sure, you're hungry, but you can push on for a while before it serioulsy affects you.In real life lost survivors are never at 100% Maintaining 100% condition is not the goal of the game. Try this next time you play... take care of everything else, but don't worry about food until your condition drops.  Then feed yourself, ensure all other needs are met, and rest.I could drone on about this, but you get the idea. The Long Dark is not like other games where you can simply eat a snack and restore your health. It's much more real then that.About the DevsThe devs are all industry pros, and The Long Dark is their full time job, not something fly-by-night.They are constantly engaging the community, and putting community feedback into the game.Bugs are logged and fixed at blazing speed. (For example, a steam user reported a mouse sensitivity issue, and it was hotfixed within an hour)There will be a game. Baring a geomagnetic global event, or world war 3, Hinterland has guaranteed a game release.The only thing you need to ask yourself is, do you want to be part of developing this great game, and making it better?I hope so. I didn't regret it.

The wolf attacked and I mortally wounded it, but as it ran away, I saw a bear coming right at me.  I shot it directly in the chest and ran the opposite direction, but the bear caught me and mauled me.  I somehow survived the attack and got a brief glimpse of the bear walking away--bleeding heavily himself--then my character immediately died from blood loss.  I was sad, but I knew I'd taken down two apex predators in the last moments (I just bled out before the bear did), rather than die from starvation.  I think that's a good death!I survived just over 14 days, and I started a new adventure right away :)  You've really got to try The Long Dark!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let me share a story with you before my review. It's quite long, but it really was one heck of a ride and I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.>Crash plane in probably Canada. Cold as hell>Run down a hill trying to find shelter, fall and sprain various limbs. Limp towards a cabin. Find some stuff.>Keep walking forever until I see a logging camp. Find more stuff, keep walking. >Find a ranger outpost, find a few bits and bobs but not much.>Make a fire for the night and try to sleep under a train bridge. Wake up cold after my fire goes out during the night and I'm getting cold.>Wander until I find the enterance to a dam facility. Dark as all night inside. Remember I have flares, use one.>Find more flares and a lamp with fuel. Spend my night scouring the facility for supplies, find some useful stuff.>I need to find supplies so I don't sleep. Wander until I eventually find my way outside to a balcony of sorts on the other side of the dam.>Walk down the snowy path to a frozen river. Figure something must be nearby so I walk along it and eventually find a cave with some wood. Getting really, really tired but it's daytime and I don't want to waste daylight, but I sleep anyways. Wake up with a few hours of light left.>Keep walking until I find a cave system. Figure it leads somewhere, it doesn't. It gets dark so I spend the night there with a fire made of wood I found and chopped in the cave. I toil the hours away sewing my clothes, cooking meat I found on dead animals, melting snow. >Come daylight I'm ready to roll. Wander until I reach the end of the river. I can't find anywhere it leads to. Nothing.>Keep searching for some buildings or something, but can't find anything. Getting cold so I decide to backtrack to the dam and try my luck on the side I came from.>As I ascend the slope to the balcony it gets dark and I get sleepy. A blizzard starts to set in, but I don't think it will be an issue. >I see another balcony across the dam, so I cross the small ledge of the dams' wall to it. Find some palettes for firewood. >I start freezing to death. I make a fire, add the wood I found and figure it will last 5 hours like it says it will. >Tired, so I try to place my bed roll down. Not enough room on the ledge so I move it a few feet away into an alcove in the wall.>Think I'm close enough to the fire so I sleep for a few hours.>Wake up suddenly. I'm freezing to death. My vison is blurry and my movement is lurching. Frantically make a fire. It fails so I try again. It works. Maybe I won't die after all...>I heat some soup and make some snow water. Unbeknownst to me, my fire is dying and I'm still barely not dead from the cold. Fire dies. I walk over (Trying my best not to fall to my death) and chop a palette into wood. Takes 45 mins and now my vison is getting blurrier.>Run to the fire and add the wood. Watch it all get eaten up in a matter of seconds due to the cold. Panic and run towards the door to go inside the dam. >For some reason it won't let me open it when clicking. I think maybe somehow it's too dark for me to find the door and open it? I don't know what's going on. I frantically chop some wood and try to make a fire. It fails. Too windy. Light my lantern, but it doesn't help. Poof lantern dies. I click on the door like a madman, but to no avail. >I try to make another fire, it fails. I decide there's only one thing to do. I make my peace. The door has bested me.>Fling myself off of the dam and fall to my death. RIP. In conclusion, those 3 and a half hours were the most frighteningly intense and immersive I've ever experienced in any game. I felt the emotions as if they were real. Fear, desperation, hopelessness. I heard this game was good and it was on sale so I bought it. Nothing could have possibly prepared me for how great this game is. It is an absolute masterpiece. The art is beautiful, and the world feels believable. The gameplay is nearly seamless, and it's insanely fun. If you're considering this game, but it right now. I promise you'll love it. It's worth every penny. MY ONLY ISSUE- I would like to see an option for reviewing and/or saving your journal upon death. I kept a very detailed journal of my ordeal and I was sad to have it dissapear after I died.

Posted: April 9
Early Access Review
								Yeah I like this game but... It isn't very replayable imo- at this point of early access. Some people can play this for thousands of hours, I think most of us would be bored after our first successful run, which probably won't take you that many tries to figure out- unless you play stalker mode (not recommended). I personally have probably something like 100 combined hours so far, from this account and other sources.While The Long Dark is great fun to newcommers it has some serious cons that hurt the replay value.REALISM?People chime on about how the game is soo "realistic" but that's nonsense- here is some fine examples of that "REALISM" in TLD they defend.A wolf strong enough to chase us down and kill us, would not have only 15lbs of meat on it.And a deer strong enough to run away from us would not have 10lbs of meat on it.Wolves respawn quickly in the same locations no matter how many times killed cause #realism.So do deer.rabbits...Meat in such a cold climate would not spoil in only 2 days.Candy bars, jerky, and soda would not go bad for ages in about any climate.Rifles in good condition do not break in only 50 shots- even if 10 below outside.Solid steel hunting knives do not break, about ever, period.Who stares at a stove for 3 hours watching water boil? Our Character can't put a pot of snow on the stove and go do other things? Walking to a fish house and back on the lake ingame takes 2 minutes of real life time, but ingame like 2 hours passed, and loosing a lot of sleep, hunger and water stats.The character doesn't know how to swing an axe at wolves, and can only fight them by letting them pounce us first taking lots of damage to health and clothes.It takes the character 5 hours to get a couple of logs that burn for 2 hours- in an environment packed with trees and wooden structures.#REALISM NOOB!There is nothing realistic about the long dark... period.It fails at realism in almost any sense, yet I seen white knights justifying some bad design here under the false guise of "realism" such as claiming clothing wears out fast cause you are running through forests and working hard everyday.I grew up in the woods, in snowy climates... clothes do not break down this fast. And though I am not Paul Bunyan, even with a simple hatchet I am able to cut enough wood in a few hours to last days of continous burning in a stove.and the worst thing about all this is....All these cheap unrealistic mechanics to keep you busy and distracted from realizing, there isn't much to this game at all. And the reason you can't swing an axe at any time by pressing left mouse is probably cause the devs, despite bragging about how many of them were former AAA game devs, can't be bothered to animate the swing. So you kill wolves in a cheap quick time event animation, and you cut wood by a menu option and waiting for time to pass.This feels like a cheap engine and game cause it is, and the development, has managed to go very slow about this since launching the game years ago, though I've seen worse.                                                 -THE LONG DRAWN OUT DEATH-I loved this game the first few plays, but indeed once established, there is suprisingly little to do in this world but try to prolong your life with the few things you can do.... so you can... erm... just die later anyways... kinda saps any reason to play then doesn't it? No matter what you do, you will eventually run out of materials and die if you were wondering. A couple hundred days you can survive if played well... why anyone would want to though? It gets pretty boring to do with how little there is to this.              -IF YOU DON'T WANT US RUNNING, REMOVE SPRINT THEN-You can run, but it makes you so sleepy so fast you really shouldn't generally, so have fun slowly walking through miles and miles of landscape, making many trips cause of a low carry weight limit. Soooo boring after a while! Sadly it used to not be like this, and the game was much more fun when it first came out then it is now IMO.This game needs so very much more to it, but probably won't ever see it, and development has been crazy slow. The new maps make their fans happy but not me... it's just more of the same, the game needs more TO IT.... to the experience.. More maps won't help much.                                    -MODDERS TO THE RESCUE?!-Sadly this is the least moddable sandbox I know of.Seriously I could even not find mods to improve carry weight at all, and it needs it...Our character knows how to make a furry bear costume, but can't make a simple wooden sled to haul stuff on? We'd be overpowered if we could carry more? How so? Oh right, cause that's half the gameplay if not more, just hauling stuff to your safe house of choice. Thrilling...Trying to go anywhere is such a pain cause you can carry so little, everything spoils crazy fast, the character can't afford to carry much water yet somehow cannot drink freshly melted snow, which is nonsense! You don't need to boil snow in real life, it's safe enough to drink after melting. So many bad designs that hurt the fun, and are only there as a type of gate and grind to hide the fact here just isn't really that much to the long dark...                                                          -NOT ALL BAD-EVEN SO! The game is really fun when new to it. I know my review is quite scathing of their designs, but TLD was fantastic the first few days I owned it, I don't regret buying it. The exploration was intense, the graphics are simple but very appealing, and it was fun figuring out what to do. Definitely worth the low asking price, even if it doesn't have the best replay value, and has a lot of annoying design. Challanges and the coming story modes should help in the future.                                       -DEV TEAM- REPLAY VALUE THIS!!!-Just understand as you figure the game out, it erm... doesn't have the most sensible endgame design, nor does the replay value benefit from this design IMO. I have tried to startup new games every now n then, but just can't stick with it... all that slow walking with the run nerf, just to endlessly haul supplies with a low carry weight so I can sit around the farm house waiting to die isn't thrilling anymore.I never imagined when I bought this game 2 years ago or however long ago it was, it would have done so little and actually become less enjoyable to play. Hopefully in another 2 years I don't end up with the same opinion. Good luck Hinterlands, and please change your company logo from a fox to a turtle. =3

Amazing atmosphere, rare gem of a game.Still there are some problems.-There is still no storyline yet which means two things.   + It adds to the grim atmosphere of an inevitable end.   - When that feeling is getting old, it's difficult to be motivated to play non-stop. - The survival system is harsh. You're supposed to keep track of things every second, which ruins the discovery aspect a   bit. You get hungry, thirsty and tired - There are dumb rules like you can't start a fire indoors, but you can fish and do other stuff until you die.- The cooking system is poor.- The loot is still rather poor in quantity. I get the same items all the time.-  Why can't I craft an arrow head straight away or just sharpen one end? Seems dumb.- Why is there no mapping system? It would be great if you could make a map in-game.

Early Access Review
								Bold and realistic gem.  So glad I found this game.The Long Dark is a first-person sandbox about solo survival in extreme condions.  Every other human in the game world is dead, and for yourself it is very difficult to effect sustained survival, especially at higher difficulties.  But you do get better.  I say YOU, because what I like most about this game is that the player must learn and get better to succeed.  Kind of reminds you of, i don't know, that golden time when games took a fair measure of skill to beat.  Instead of a linear story with pre-planned power ups, instead of just a character leveling up to being practically untouchable, the player must learn to balance protection from the elements, water, food, and stamina, and keep respecting that balance for the entire game.  It doesn't matter how good you get at it, the world can still kill you at any time.  The game is VERY, VERY immersive.   It really gives the illusion that you inhabit your avatar's body and are truggling to survive.  For example, you might get attacked by a wolf before you have good weaponry, get the better of the wolf with your hunting knife, then you are chasing it down like a madman, following its blood trail, hoping it will bleed out where you can find it because you know this might be your first chance at meat and having a half-full belly in hours of gameplay.  You lliterally begin to think, feel, and act like you are some starving man in the woods, never mind all that lasagna you just ate!You might get lost in a blizzard and end up going in circles because you can't see 10 feet.  You just went out for firewood, but now you're lost in a blizzard!  You might find you are in an unsustainable location, realize a slow death is only a matter of time, head out in the middle of the night, go on some crazy multi-hour odyssey, and fist pump/air guitar when you at last stumble on some hunting cabin frozen, starving, with injuries and 5% of your health.   This game is well worth your time and you will end up making time for this game, trust me.  Shout out to the developers on such an outstanding product;  a true work of art.

content:
Posted: March 13
Early Access Review
								First of all: This is a mildly negative review.My first impression when playing The Long Dark was overwhelmingly positive. The first few hours of playing the game are amazing and if you are the kind of person who is satisfied with getting about 10 hours of entertainment out of a game, it might be the perfect purchase for you. But the more time you spent, the more you familiarise yourself with the mechanics of the game and the longer you survive, the more the games inherent, irreparable flaws become visible. What flaws you mean? I will provide a short list of the most glaring issues below, but let just preface this with a quick disclaimer about the way I approach survival games:To me, survival is all about realism. "It's a game, not a simulation!", you might interject, but no, I disagree. A survival game is always a simulation, otherwise, lacking the link to real-life survival, there would be no basis for immersion and identification with the survival situation. When you are confronted with a situation in a survival game and out the real-life solutions to this problem only a tiny fraction is available in-game, it just ends up being frustrating and disappointing. And here's how The Long Dark disappointed me in this regard.- you cannot sleep without a bed or bedroll; not on the floor, not on a couch, not using "old bedrolls" - you just can't- you can barely interact with your environment; you can't reclaim wood from buildings, piers and most furniture (e.g. containers), only from designated recyclable objects that then serve no other purpose. You can't even combine several beds to make one warmer bed.- you cannot move objects before interacting with them; you have to butcher deer where they died, even if that is just a couple of feet away from your warm and cozy home, you have to break up branches and limbs where they are, you cannot move chairs, crates, etc. to store them for disassembly later, all you can move is what you can pick up and carry like inventory items, but you should be able to drag larger objects around.- there is a severe lack of crafting recipes that are far more reasonable than the ones the game does offer; curtains, towels, even upholstry could all be turned into makeshift clothes, almost everything could be turned into a makeshift melee weapon, a whetstone and any bit of scrap metal could make a makeshift knife, etc.- with wildlife being as aggressive as it is in the games, there would be innumerable ways of luring them into traps- the game creates artificial scarcity in a number of ways:..- you need more food than would be realistic..- hunted animals yield hardly any meat/calories..- tools wear down at ludicrous rates..- several items are unnecessarily scarce (materials for bows/arrows, cloth)..- you cannot freeze food (!!!) to keep it fresh or conserve it any other way [Edit: apparently leaving food outdoors makes it more durable, but potentially exposes it to wildlife]..- fires are incredibly short lived and hard to maintain..- time passes way too fast in relation to how fast you can move / act in the game (and don't argue with map scale! stepping outside of the house to take is leak shouldn't take half an hour and going down to the lake from a lakeside cabin shouldn't take up all morning)- you cannot jump, which makes you take silly detours all the time because of less than 1 foot high obstacles- you get injured very easily when walking (!) downhill- animals respawn randomly rather than existing and reproducing in a realistic way- you cannot do more than one thing at a time (seriously, who needs to watch water boil for two hours straight?) This is probably the worst flaw, when you have to spend hours frying one steak at a time using massive amounts of firewood.Most of these, or at least the more important ones like interacting with the environment, moving objects, time management seem to be hard-wired into the game without any hope of them being addressed or changed as development progresses.Therefore, unfortunately, I cannot really enjoy this game as much as I would like to.

Early Access Review
								Even at this early stage in development, this game is brilliant. I won't deny that it can get boring fairly quickly, but that doesn't matter in my opinion. The few hours you spend playing the game before you get bored are magnificent.I start a new sandbox game. Mystery Lake. I know a few locations, but I don't know the map. I immediately begin exploring, hopefully coming across a jacket to ease the icy chill in the air. The weather isn't too bad, so I'm able to relax a little. I follow the train tracks, making a few slight detours when I spot a wolf skulking around. Eventually I come across a derailment, red cars toppled in front of me. The winds picked up now so I think it'll be a good time to huddle down and get warm for a few hours before continuing to find some decent shelter. I step into the train car and stare into the corner. A frozen body is in the corner. I quickly check his inventory, feeling slightly guilty, but I'm going to need whatever he's carry more than him now. Discovering an energy bar and a soda, I retreat to the opposite end of the car with my prize. Huddling down out of the wind I study the body. Will this soon be me?There's a snow storm outside now, and not even the car is protecting me. I need to move or die. I stumble out into the arctic temperatures and blindly pick a direction, praying to come across some decent shelter. Suddenly, I hear a howl. Black shapes materialise out of the snow and pad towards me. Wolves. I sprint now, the snow storm the least of my worries. I'm getting tired, hungry, and thirsty, but I can't stop. To stop would be suicide. I continue onwards, my vision starting to get blurry. My movements become sluggish. I'm going into the long dark.Suddenly, I see it. Almost right in front of me, a hut on a small hill. Hope flares inside me as I try and sprint up around the path to the front door. I can barely walk now, I know my conditions frighteningly low. But I made it. The Trappers Hut. I'm safe. Until the food runs out.
