Posted: January 19
Early Access Review
								The game's systems are too simple and the meaningful choices you have to make are to few and far between for the sandbox to hold any long term enjoyment.  The game is either monotonously easy, or frustratingly difficult, with the difficulty coming from the restrictiveness of the mechanics and a lack of the ability to improvise, not any actual challenge.  I rarely feel like I've made good decisions because there are virtually no decisions to make.  The majority of the game boils down to- Is there anything I can use here? and-  Can I safely travel to the next place with something to use yet?The lack of meaningful choices due to the simplistic nature of the gameplay kills any long term enjoyment because there's nothing to do or strive for in the sandbox mode.  You're either playing on a difficulty where everything falls into your lap or entire houses will have a single can of soup in them.  The problem with the higher 'difficulty' is that the simple systems don't allow for any improvisation.  You either have the item you need, or you don't.  Here's a fun example-I'm attempting to transition to a new zone while playing on the highest difficulty because there is only the aformentioned single can of soup, single pair of mittens, or single box of matches, etc for each individual building, and I'm starving and freezing to death just sitting around an empty zone.  Traveling to the next area requires me to traverse a cave system.  My only light source is 8 matches (because that's all I could find in an entire town).  Sure, I have a bunch of twigs, a few pieces of reclaimed wood, plenty of newspaper, and some lamp oil, however, I can't IMPROVISE a torch out of any of these things.  I'm 0.02 L short of lamp oil to be allowed to craft a proper torch.  I can't just light the newsprint or any of the wood on fire for a lower quality light source.  I'm not allowed to start a fire 'indoors' in the cave.  I can't start a fire outside in the raging blizzard to pull a flaming brand from.  So I'm left using my only firestarting materials, my matches, as a terrible light source because that's all the game allows for.My choices are needlessly restrictive despite having plenty of flammable items, but this follows through to virtually every other system in the game.  Want a knife?  Well, you better find one (which you can't on the highest difficulty, at all, they don't spawn, you must craft one) because there's only one place in the game you can even make one.  Got a hacksaw, scrap metal, some wood, a whetstone and access to a workbench with a vice?  Oh well.  There's no way to say, sacrifice some extra time and calories to make a makeshift knife.  You need the one forge in the game in order to make metal sharp.  And on top of that you need specific items that serve no other purpose to do that.  Don't have a hammer?  Well, there's no way to improvise using something else at the cost of time or effeciency.  Want a torch?  Better have the one type of allowable wood and minimum amount of oil required.  Want to open that can of soup?  A hacksaw capable of sawing through metal shelves is incapable of doing it.Want to craft a coat?  Only if you have wolf pelts.Want some gloves?  Only with rabbit skins.Improvise a scarf with some house curtains or a towel?  Not happening.Use a blanket, pillows, and sewing kit to make a bedroll?  Nope, gotta find one. (Also, it hasn't happened to me, but I'm fairly certain you can die from not being able to sleep due to not having access to a bedroll or bed, despite being satiated, warm, and indoors.  "Sleep on the floor?  Like an animal?!  I'd rather die!")Want a prybar?  Well, you better find one, because there's no way to cut any of the metal shelfs into something resembeling a makeshift prybar (nor can anything else substitute for a prybar.  I can reduce a metal shelf to a pile of scrap with a hacksaw, but can't use it to get into a metal locker.)There's no meaningful choices to make.  There's no improvisation to be had.  Sacrifice your extra coat so that you can use a sewing kit and some free time to make gloves you can't find?  Nope.  Risk damaging your hacksaw in order to open something that requires a prybar?  Nope.  Spend extra time and calories to improvise a knife out of scrap metal and a whetstone?  Nope.The systems are too rigid for the entirely sandbox (at this point in time) nature of the game, especially for a survival game.  It's too frustrating to be a drop of oil and the wrong type of wood away from being able to make a source of light not to mention any of the countless other ridiculous scenarios you'll find yourself shaking your head at.A few other gripes, there a now perks which after having ran for 10km or survived for 100 days give you stat bonuses to make the game easier.  Wut?  You'd think by the point you've done any of those things, a minor stat increase is borderline pointless.  Seems like some grindy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to attempt to keep you playing.  Tons of new clothing has been added as well, however, none of it adds to the gameplay.  Clothing is either better than what you currently have, or it isn't.  Again, there are no meaningful choices to be made.  There are stats like mobility and damage reduction, but they occur in 1-3% points and a virtually negligble.  I didn't even noticed them til looking at the wiki.  There's nothing that provides a meaningful choice like a big heavy, waterproof jacket that I would bother to carry around and change into only in certain weather.  You're just going to wear the best clothing you have available.  Nothing exists with meaningful trade-offs.  Again- THERE ARE VIRTUALLY NO MEANINGFUL CHOICES TO MAKEDon't get me wrong, I've wrung 160 hours of gameplay out of the game, but there's either no challenge or a rigid brick wall of not having the EXACT thing you need because the item spawns on the higher 'difficulties' have been reduced to virtually nothing.  You're supposed to be an experienced bush pilot surviving in the wilderness, when in reality you play a simpleton incapable of lighting a rolled up newspaper on fire.If you've made it this far, I'm not entirely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on the game, in fact I've gifted two copies of it to friends.  The game just hasn't had any of its gameplay sastistfyingly expanded on, despite 2 years of development.  Once you've seen all the areas, there's nothing to do anymore but settle into a boring routine of surviving (or dying on the higher difficulty because there are no items).   If I can be set for life with all the best equipment on day 20, why would I continue to play for another 80 game days?

Early Access Review
								After two days of foraging the woods around my trapper's cabin, I was running low on food and decided to strike out. I had uncovered a windfall of about 2kg worth of venison from a wolf kill the day before, and though I wasn't dressed for the weather, I needed to find any sort of food. On day three, I made my way over to the train tracks where I noticed a train that had derailed. A blizzard kicked up shortly after I arrived and I hear howling in the distance, so I lit a fire and huddled down by the derailed train.The howling came up again and I heard the sound of running. A wolf was right behind me! I grabbed a torch from my fire and ran away from the wolf. Unfortunately, I ran through my fire and burnt off my pants. Fleeing pantsless through the trackless wastelands, I ran across the railroad tracks and over a railway bridge. The wolf must have caught my scent again, or maybe it was one of its packmates - I noticed a wolf charging at me down a hill. I brandished my torch with all the fury I could muster whilst wearing my long underwear and then fled further afield.This is when I found an old dam. It happened to have two boxes of rifle ammunition, seven knitted wool caps, and no pants to speak of. Realizing that if I wanted to cover my junk, I would have to make my own pants, I loaded up my hunting rifle and set out for vengeance. Against mother nature herself.11/10

Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Okay, to start off, no, it's not as hard as people make it out to be.The thing about TLD is that you cannot really have a place to call "home" because often "home" ends up too far from civilization (or...another camp, in this case.) and that means that you have to cover more land to find food every day then come back home, when you could just go in one of the houses, start a fire, and spend the night there. You should get a quick grasp of the map based on your spawn points, seeing as they're for the most part pre-determined, if you don't know where you're going and plan ahead of time, your life will be miserable. Your character requires a lot of food and water, but getting it isn't hard, so long as you have an axe to harvest firewood (or move around a lot, like me.) you have to play very nomadish in this game because in order to get by you need to keep moving, every precious second can mean life or death, and I believe people hope to see the scenery too much and not focus on the main aspect, survival, and that makes people think "oh this game is too hard because I can't do this or that." It's not like that, it's a fun game, but you have to play in a way where you're a nomad, and always have a plan in case things don't go as planned (and that happens a LOT in this game.) make sure to use flares to your advantage, as well.Now what's the point of this review? Don't listen to the people saying the game is "too difficult" because it's NOT THAT HARD, you just have to have a plan for what you want to do, and from what I've seen, people aren't very good at planning ahead of time (really, go watch some of the youtube videos...) you have to expect nature to throw everything it has at you, and you have to be ready to have multiple routes if for any case one of them is blocked by wolves (which is not uncommon) you can't rely on only one plan, you have to have multiple, you have to know what you're planning to do, get a very in-depth understanding of your surroundings, make sure you have flares, bandages, and anti-septic. If for any reason you notice you're running low on food, you go out the next day, even if it's extremely windy (I literally ran through a blizzard to survive, you have to be ready to do anything to survive.) and make note, any mistake you make, can (and most likely will) cost you your life. A wolf is your worst enemy, if you get attacked by one, it's not unlikely you'll be brought to below 50% condition (health) so be ready for the worst of situations, and hope for your own sake that nature doesn't ♥♥♥♥ you over...or you can just bring a flare.Now onto the rating:Gameplay? I'd give it a 7/10 for now, it's all I want in a survival game but it's really lacking on things to do, but keep in mind it's early access.Sound? 8/10, they're realistic, they're not annoying.Music? ???/10, I have in-game music disabled, I feel it kills the atmosphere.Overall?: 7.5/10 for now, it's a good game but it really is missing a lot of things (not to mention your character eats and drinks like a god damned bear before hibernation, but hey, as long as you plan what you want to do out it's not too bad.)Note, SPOILERS below, if you want to find things yourself, DO NOT READ THIS:You'll need a game plan if you want to get far in this game, my usual game plan is to find the Trapper's Homestead and hope the rifle is there, if not, well, atleast scavenge up what's inside and go back out (granted that you're not freezing, if you are then take a break and get it together) I usually go from there to Max's Last Stand, and then to the trains (be careful of the wolves, there's often a few.) there's a camp office near there, and around there there's about 4-6 buildings which can all be looted, some have dead bodies, some don't, from there I usually head toward the big mountain to scale up it (by this point, if you have a rifle, you should have enough food to survive at least 3 days.) inside there's plenty of things to help you, can openers, food, water, medical supplies, and of course.. a fire place. Light a fire and hang out for the night, if there's a blizzard or heavy wind, don't go out the next day. Sleep until it blows over. Then you just gotta well...scavenge, you have enough food to go for quite a ways by this point (so long as you made sure to go over every place and grab things.)

content:
Posted: March 13
Early Access Review
								TL;DR - I'm giving a negative overall review to TLD mainly because the development of the game has not moved forward consistently towards a v1.0, and I feel like the developers are not up to the task of producing a finished version anytime soon. [As context, I backed TLD through Kickstarter on October 14, 2013.]Let me start by saying that I really love the game! The devs have created a rather different, yet encompassing, atmospheric experience I've come to enjoy, and that I think deserves it's current followship.On this review, I'm not going to delve into realistic vs. arbitrary game mechanics, real-life vs. artistic graphics, or any other of the gameplay issues mentioned both positively and negatively on these threads. I will focus exclusively on the implicit contract between gamers and developers that inexorably arises when supporting Early Access (EA) games.I've played TLD on and off for the past three years, starting when there was only one map (Mystery Lake) and rather limited and unbalanced game mechanics. Reviewing my logs, I backed TLD through Kickstarter on October 14, 2013!Back then, the state of the game was beyond my wildest dreams, especially for an EA game. There was only one map, but it was large, and gorgeous, and functional. Gameplay was still green, but you could see why and how the developers were going to benefit from the community's input. It really felt like I was given the chance to get in early, help the development of the game, and brag that I've known and played the game from the very beginning.And I was not alone. The game and team earned some positive accolades around this time, like ranking #9 on Gameranx's list of The Best PC Games of 2014 among other similar mentions, and allegedly raised over $260k from nearly 7,000 backers on both Kickstarter and Paypal. (Source: Project Update #30, October 16, 2013.)Everything seemed on track, from the constant game updates, to the energy and demeanor of the communications from the dev team, all the way to the enthusiasm of the community...But 2014 came and went, and then 2015, and just recently 2016, and there is still no finished game available. New content has been added in the last three years to the sandbox, but it has been only 5 new maps and very few gameplay additions.Moreover, the developers have announced that v1.0, or storymode, will be released by episodes as part of "Season One", on yet a future undisclosed date. The game currently available guarantees access only to this Season One. The first release, consisting of two episodes, apparently will account for only 6 gameplay hours. After the initial batch of the five episodes that will amount to Season One (and honestly, only adding insult to injury), devs are already planning the next installment as a new game that will be marketed separately. (Source: Story Mode Progress — December Community Update, December 19, 2016.)I feel like after 3 years from funding the game, plus any development done prior to that date, all the feedback and help provided by the community, and the additional funding the company has gotten from selling the game on Steam and other similar platforms (all this in addition to the initial funding mentioned above), should have been more than enough to produce a working v1.0. And it hasn't.Sad as it may be, I've decided to stop buying EA games...

Early Access Review
								An absolutely stunning experience, the game was a blind discount purchase just for the hahas, and now I can't force myself to turn it off. Over 33 hours played and I think I just only start to fully enjoy the game world.Cons:- No maps! Guys I badly need the maps! Of course, I can find them online, but it would be cheating. I think it is quite realistic when a lost man FINDS some maps in a car glovebox, desk or wherever. I personally believe that having at least fragmented (torn, burnt etc.) region maps would only make things more interesting. Otherwise, the signal pistol challenge is sooo unforgiving.- Some actions are often quite schematic and overly simplistic (especially behavior patterns of the wildlife and wolf atacks). But it's a game, not real life, so with all the following pros these two cons are utterly forgivable.Pros:- Really thick atmosphere, so thick you can cut it with a knife (if you ever find it, of course).- An unforgettable feeling of natural awe and helplessness when things go wrong.- Variety of weather conditions. It all depends on the weather, like they say!- Absolutely great maps and locations. I really enjoy all of them, Pleasant valley being the best!- Automatic and quite boring actions and processes suddenly become really interesting (I could never imagine I would love so much to collect firewood or sort-out bad chocolate bars by a campfire).-The skill improvement system is decent. It adds another dimension to the gameplay. Not an RPG, of course, but the idea that you can progress makes you feel even more aggrieved when you finally die.- The graphics are better than I expected. I really love how they did the lighting thing and the blizzards!To sum it up, The Long Dark looks like a really promising game for now, and it's already 100% playable (although being in Alpha). I wonder what the campaign mode will look like. And I really would love to have some extra content too (more new regions and please introduce the map orientation challenge too!)     :)

Early Access Review
								"POST CRASH LOG DAY 5:My sleep cycle got messed up while exploring, and I was forced to leave my shelter at 4AM in order to pace my fatigue and hunger with my distance from a safehouse. So I leave the trailer I had shacked up in, walk out into a foggy, dim haze only to slip off a slope and land on the ground below, suffering a sprained ankle. Even worse, mere yards away was a (presumably) cold and hungry wolf, growling and looking me dead in the eyes. The wolf approached, and with my ankle injured I wasn't able to outrun. With the wolf approaching more and more rapidly, I hastily take out my nearly broken hunting rifle, load it with the only bullet in my bag, and just as the wolf pounces I pull the trigger, hitting it right in the head, an instant kill. With the wolf dead, I calm down a bit, only to realize that, in my panic, I had run outside in -20 degree (celsius) weather, and I was suffering terribly from the cold. With no way to see through the fog, and a sprained ankle, no weapons, I was bound to die. Yet I brought myself to start limping forward, slowly. I slowly began to weaken, my condition getting worse and worse as the minutes passed. But just as all hope was lost, I faintly made out the shape of a tall structure. AN ABANDONED WATCHPOST! I crawled up the winding stairs to the top, and collapsed upon a shabby bed in the corner. After regaining my senses, and warming up a bit, I threw a log in the wood stove and warmed up with a can of beans and a much needed drink of water. There was still a long day ahead."I've had my eye on this for a while and I decided to give in and try it out. The game is early access which I've had 50-50 opinions on, due to buying into games that have still not really delivered.When I dropped into the sandbox mode(Only mode available so far), I felt a bit uneasy about this game as well. Highly stylized but low realism, it just seemed like another walkabout. But then as I figured out the mechanics, got mauled by wolves, froze to death, and walked off a cliff shattering my ankles, I REALLY got into it.The atmosphere is FANTASTIC. Once you start playing for a while, your mind goes into overdrive trying to think up a survival plan, looking out for danger, managing your vitals, and deciding if the space in your bag will be filled with food or materials. The gameplay itslef is not at all exciting, but the mood shifts from calm, to panic, to dread, to fear, back to calm in the space of a single minute.Fantastic, and it's still being worked on and improved. Definitely recommend, even in early access.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is a first-person survival game. A geomagnetic event has caused your character's plane to crash somewhere in the snowy Canadian wilderness, and armed with only a small handful of supplies, you must do what you can to stave off death for as long as possible. Unfortunately, death comes in many forms in this game. Due to the fictional geomagnetic catastrophe in-game, the weather has gone into a permanent winter, with random snow, fog and winds which vary in intensity from "mild" to "I literally cant see 5 feet in front of me". The event has affected wildlife as well, and some- especially of the 'wolf' and 'bear' variety- will attack you on sight. --BASICS--The elements arent the only thing out to get you. In The Long Dark, you are basically tasked with survival, and to do so you must satisfy 4 ever-decreasing statistic bars: Warmth, Sleep, Hunger and Thirst."Warmth" is affected in a number of ways. First, there is 'temperature', as well as 'wind chill'. Im not 100% certain how one affects the other, but needless to say, the lower the numbers, the faster your "warmth" meter will decrease. You can add 'warmth' by means of clothing (which some can be layered for additional temperature increase bonus), standing near fire or heat sources, eating hot food/drink, or going to an interior, closed location (in a cabin, etc). Sleeping will add warmth, but if the surrounding temperature is cold enough, you will still wake up freezing if you do so outdoors. "Sleep" stat will slowly drop as the day goes on, and can be hastened by carrying too much weight, thus making you tired earlier than usual. Sleep is possibly the stat with the least amount of worry involved with it, as you can pretty much sleep anywhere (so long as you have a sleeping bag, and you begin the game with one). It may not always be SMART to sleep, depending on circumstance, but it is about always possible. "Sleep" can be restored by... well, sleep. Hot tea can be consumed before rest to increase the effectiveness of your rest, and hot coffee can be consumed to reduce the rate at which the bar depletes. "Hunger" stat naturally drops as time progresses. In this game, hunger is represented by "calories". At the maximum 'full' level, your character has 2,500 calories. Items which you eat will replenish calories, and depending on what the item is, the recovery value will vary from 0-1000 calories per item use. If you eat something which would put your calorie count above 2500, the number caps and the remainder of that item will stay in your inventory, so you can eat the rest later. You are not going to be able to survive forever on the junk food you find in cabins, etc, so ultimately you will have to find a way to harvest those delicious animals running around the map....."Thirst" depletes as time progresses, or if you eat something salty (IE, a box of crackers). Not certain if it drops faster with strenuous labor. Water in this game is a commodity that is everywhere- literally. Your character's main source is from the snow itself, and while you have a fire built you can melt snow into water, then boil it for safe consumption. Water can be found in a number of places including bottles of the stuff and from a toilet bowl...and all can be consumed, but if you do not boil non-pure sources before drinking, you can stand to catch disease and die without treatment.Once any of the 4 stat bars reaches 1/4, an icon will appear in the corner letting you know it needs attention soon. If a bar reaches "empty", a percentage will appear next to the appropriate icon. It begins at 100%, and if it hits 0 your game is over. Multiple bars can be reduced to 'below empty' at once.--SURVIVE!--You dont begin with very many supplies, there is no map in the game as of yet, and the odds are stacked against you... yet you still have a fighting chance. Your first few games will find you learning the ropes, and-- due to the fact that the game is still in ALPHA and has no much-needed tutorial-- this will either involve you dying a lot, or referring to the Wiki a lot, which spoils a lot of the surprises to find. Once you have gotten a good feel for the game and begin to remember certain details of the maps ("if I follow these train tracks it'll take me to a bunch of cabins in a lumber yard!"), things will become much more fun, and you can concentrate on exploration rather than figuring out how the game's rules work. Find all sorts of gear to help you survive, from oil lamps, axes, knives and even a rifle, to clothes, food, firewood, medical supplies of all types and more. You can 'harvest' these items for basic materials to repair your other gear, or even to make new items altogether at a 'work bench'. No firewood, and youre indoors? Chop the tables, chairs and shelves up and burn em. Hunt for wildlife-- and then eat them, gut them and turn their skins into wearable coats, warmer sleeping bags, ETC. Loot corpses of other explorers who didnt make it. Pull a torch out of a fire and use it to swing at attacking wolves to scare em away. Find a hut on a frozen lake and do some ice fishing! Stagger blindly through a white-out blizzard with your stats all nearly bottomed-out, thinking youre about to die, when suddenly you see the shape of a house in the distance.....--THOUGHTS--The Long Dark could REALLY stand to use a tutorial, but seeing as how it is technically still in Alpha it can be forgiven. Other than that, the game feels very solid and is quite addicting to play. The elements against you and your meters constantly draining put an urgency on you to make progress in the game, but never to the point of it making the game obnoxious to play. Sometimes your stats may be struggling and there is tension in trying to 'beat the clock' before you die, but thats part of the fun. Will you make it?? *IS* that a house you see in the distance..??*YES!!!* .....is exactly how you will react when you DO find one. My favorite aspect about this game so far is the act of DISCOVERY. After staggering through the harsh wilderness for hours up to days, fending off animal attacks, cold and starvation, it feels extremely rewarding to find even the smallest of cabins dotted around the maps. Every one of them is loaded with goodies, and item locations/ "drops" are random in every playthrough so you never know what youll find, but you always know itll be good stuff. The graphics look nice, especially the skyboxes. Ive taken a number of screenshots of the game and for a title with "white snow everywhere" its amazing how much color gets packed in there. Weather effects look great- the snow will actually blow with the wind currents, spiral off rooftops and get sucked into the breeze... its nice attention to detail VS 'randomly falls from sky at various quantities'. Maps are massive and packed with things to see and discover, lots of interesting locations, and a widely-varying topography that will make you FEEL like youre standing on the top of a mountain, or at the very base looking up at one. Sound is very well done and is plenty convincing, from old panes of glass clattering in their window from howling winds hitting them, to the roar of a bear before he eats your face. Music is intermittant, but always pleasant to the ear. It sounds cool and mysterious, much like the game itself. Controls are solid, and the little bit of aiming which takes place is pretty accurate. Overall, I'm hooked. Its a lot of fun, presents a reasonable challenge and- most importantly- is still being worked on/updated by its developers. I purchased this game for $5.00 during the Steam Holiday Sale and it was totally worth it, but with 50+ hours already into the game and Im barely beyond map 1, I'd be willing to have paid full price. If you like survival sandboxes give this one a go!!

								This game is great! It really gives you the feeling that you are going to die. Lots of great effects and game mechanics. The devs put alot of care into the survival aspect of the game. There are plenty of things to be careful aboot. like spraining your ankle and getting lost in the cold dark fog of night as the wolves that smell your blood get closer, and closer and closer then BAM!!!!!!!!! GET OFF ME WOOOOLFFF AAAAAAHHH....GRRR ARRR GRRROOWL arroOoOooo...WHACK WHACK WHACK!!!! YIP YIP YIP!!!! TAKE THAT YOU SOB!!!! After such an encounter you look down at your invisible feet and see your blood staining the cold white snow...You find an underground bunker...Thankfuly theres a bed, some beans, water and a first aid kit. You patch yourself up just to squeeze some more time in your pathetic lonely life. You can hear the wind howling as you huddle in your bed and go to sleep. Its 7:47 a.m. Time to get moving. What a nice day! I should go find some more supplies. You stumble upon a watchtower that overlooks a frozen body of water. you find a rifle and a box of rifle rounds. Great! now I can defend against predators, Is it getting windy again?You WILL die! you WILL get lost...Oh boy will you get lost. There are 3 areas that connect to each other and lots of dead ends. I give this game a cool canadian 9/10. Will give 11/10 if they add ALOT of stuff. The devs have skills and they need to add as much as possible to this game. If you like suvival games you should buy it. I challenge you to try and make it 10 days on the hardest difficulty :P You will feel like survivor man but you will want to cry when you die! Get this game!--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Its Time to update my review! April 03 2015. I wrote my first review after some beer so it was a bit silly. Now I would like to make a better shorter review.First thing I'll say is the devs are very good at what they do. They care about the community and respond fast to bug fixes (barely any bugs :D) They recently updated the game giving it a really nice boost. It has become apperant to me that the game will grow at a happy and consistant rate. This game and its devs definitely deserve your support. It always leaves me wanting to go back to it to continue my playthrough or even restart if I fail to survive. I could go into detail about why this game is so good but I dont want to spoil anything for you. Just know that if you like survival games the $20 is 100% worth it.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								You can find yourself in some pretty nasty situations in this game. On my first trip to Pleasant Valley, I arrived exhausted, over-loaded, and the sun was going down. The wind started picking up, but I ignored it. My character was too busy checking abandoned cars for candy bars and matches. Before I knew it, he was in the middle of a ferocious blizzard. He hopped into the nearest car and tried to wait it out. The temperature dropped lower and lower as the storm persisted into nightfall. The wind howled all around, and my character began to freeze. Holy cow...he's going to die out here... I realized. I'd helped him survive for over 100 days, and I was about to lose it all. He lit his storm lantern to try to stay warm. He curled up in his sleeping bag and took little naps. The night crawled on, and his condition grew worse and worse by the minute. By the time the storm finally abated, hypothermia was setting in. He crawled from the car and used one of his precious matches to light a small fire with some sticks he had collected. He huddled beside that fire and fed it one stick at a time while the wind did its best to blow it out. When dawn came, he abandoned the fire and staggered along the road looking for better shelter - a shack, a house, a garage...anything.It was hard to see with his blurry vision, but he found what appeared to be some kind of an abandoned farm house. He made his way inside and stumbled around the house. Upstairs he found a bed, and crawled gratefully beneath the blankets.He slept on and off all that day and the next, and bit by bit, he recovered enough to leave the house and collect some kindling. It was a nice sunny day, and he was able to save the last of his matches by starting a fire with his magnifying glass. He melted snow and boiled enough water to stay hydrated for a few days, then decided he'd better do something about food. Luck was with him, and he was able to lure a wolf away from a fresh kill. As he leaned over the dead deer and pulled his hunting knife from his belt, I thought, alrighty - everything's falling into place. Looks like surviving in Pleasant Valley isn't going to be that tough after all. Five minutes later, he was dead. Another blizzard rolled in while he was breaking down the deer, and I was fiddling with my cell phone. I looked up just in time to see him fading into the long dark, and that was that. I stared at the screen in horror. There's no save to revert to... no retry button... no Phoenix Down to tickle his nose with. GAME OVER.That's The Long Dark in a nutshell. This isn't a game in which you frolic about the hills, or hit the save button just in case what you're about to do turns out to be as stupid as you think it is - but you want to try it anyway...There are no safety nets. No second chances. You have to constantly be on the lookout for danger. You relax, or get distracted… you die. So you listen to the wind. You keep an eye on the sky. You check the temperature. You look out for fallen trees you might be able to clamber up just in case there’s a hungry wolf over the next ridge. You hear one howl in the distance, and you crouch and count your bullets, or ready a torch and hope it’s more scared of fire than it is hungry. In the easiest mode, the wolves and bears act like they would in nature. If you leave them alone, they'll leave you alone. In the normal and hard modes, a geomagnetic event has made them loopy and aggressive. In Interloper, the hardest mode, the game is out to kill you however it can. There are far fewer tools and resources. The weather hates you, and the wolves are absolutely deadly. In their eyes - you're just a sloppy joe in pants - if you still have pants by that point. A few other points:- The graphics are stylized but attractive.- The community's pretty good. Most active players are helpful and friendly.- The developers are communicative and active. They still monitor the board to weed out jerks.- You can craft and cook items utilizing natural resources. - It’s a lonely, melancholy game.- After surviving for long periods, you can get stuck into routines. Fortunately there are six different regions at this point. You can travel to another region if you get tired of the one you’re in. Each one has its own personality and challenges. Also there are several challenge modes that are engaging, too.- Each game is different. You may have found a hatchet in a dilapidated little hut on your first run, but on your second run – there’s nothing there… Sometimes the cabin you squatted in last game is just a pile of burnt cinders in the next.- You rarely spawn in the same place twice. In Stalker, you may spawn twenty feet away from a wolf while it's still dark outside and the temperature is well below zero. Or maybe you get lucky and spawn in the Trapper's Homestead and find a rifle hanging from the gun rack. You never know.

								(Alpha Review, Sandbox Mode Only)     I've had this game for awhile now, I pledged enough money to get the alpha before it's early access on Steam. Personally I love this game, it's not your traditional survival game, there's no zombies or aliens, it's you agaisnt the elements and the wolfs. Currently the game is only sandbox mode but later the developer (Hinterland Studio) plans on adding a storyline campaign. Hinterland Stuidos are constantly updating the game, fixing bugs, and improving the overall experience. They're great when it comes to feedback and even personal dislikes.     Sandbox mode has a ton of replayability, every time I'm thrown into the world, I'm in a new area and I'm scrambling to find a familiar landmark. While attempting to survive you need to worry about food, water, wolfs, overall condition, and even clothing. Every decision you make, makes you second guess yourself. While trying to stay warm and keep your condition manageable, you also need to keep moving and find more supplies to keep yourself alive. It's part luck, part skill, and part making the right moves at the right time. While traversing through the beautifully done landscape you find yourself dodging wolfs, checking your condition, the time and even the weather. I personally can't get enough of this game, and I can't wait to see what the developers have instore for the storyline campaign.     I can say with confidence this game won't be left by the wayside like some other early access games. I've been a victim of developers abandoning games after they were released on early access Steam but I highly doubt this game is going anywhere. Hinterland Studios is a new company with this game being their first release but if you do your research into the team at Hinterland you will be blown away. Huge names that are worked on games like: The Far Cry series, the Saints Row series, Warhammer, Red Faction, Star Wars: Knights of The Old Republic, Mass Effect, God of War, and the list goes on and on. These people are NOT new to making games by any means, and it shows with The Long Dark. I've only had to opportunity to play the alpha but I'll say it's one of the best alpha experiences I've had.    I hope this review has persuaded you to purchase this game early access. I will do another review once it's fully released. Early Access Review
								[Posted: Jan 18 @ 1:40am]Of all of the "Early Access" games I have had the fortune to play, this is by far the most polished.  The developers seem to be very involved with the community as well.Now for the actual review:A survival game without zombies or other players hunting you down?  Impossible, you might think.  Some might also think, screw that, where is the real threat?  From nurishment to wolves, the biggest threat is the weather.  Shelter is a commodity, offering temporary reprieve from the frozen world outdoors.  God help you if you have to spend a couple nights outside.  I loaded up my makeshift fire with plenty of wood, only to awaken after a couple hours in the midst of violent winds.  Needless to say, my fire had been extinguished, and I spent the remainder of the night inside a ruined boxcar.  As morning broke, I was nearly dead from the cold, but I managed to find an outpost with plenty of supplies and a furnace.  Besides having to share the haven with the corpse of its former tenant, I was quickly able to thaw out, boil some drinkable water, and cook up something to eat.  I have probably a day or two worth of food, and will inevitably have to venture back out shortly to aquire more wood to keep that furnace running.  I dread my next trek, but in the best of ways.  Very few games immerse me in such a way as The Long Dark has managed, and it is merely in Early Access!The few complaints I have with the game look like they will be hashed out long before the game's official release.  And those complaints are very, very minor (as of writing this, the only thing that comes to mind is the rate at which your clothing wears down).  The developers are constantly asking for feedback, and have been quick to work out balancing issues.I have been burned by most other Early Access games, to the point that I was considering never buying one again.  I am so glad that I did some research on this game and saw exactly what it has to offer, right now, aside from the coming additions that it promises to offer.  Do some research, like I did.  Check Youtube for some gameplay.  Read up in the forums.  Anyone on the fence about this game should take a hatchet to that fence.  You're going to need all the firewood you can carry once you decide to brave the cold... ;)[Update: 05.24.15 @7:29am]I still stand behind everything I initially said, and am really satisfied with not only this, but several other indie developers I have since had the pleasure of watching their involvement with the community inparticular.  These guys are great at what they are doing with this.

								The concept of the game sounds amazing and is the reason why I purchased this game for 14.99 (Halloween Sale).The game started off fun for the first 30mins, however I realized how mundane and repetitive the game is after about an hour. Also, it doesn't feel like the game rewards me for my skill, critical thinking and creative ways of approaching the situation. Instead, it feels more luck based then anything. In regards to the mechanics. Starting with the hunger system, good lord man, no one can get that hungry and eat that much food in one day. Also, the conditioning mechanic on items......I've had knives, can openers, rifles, hachets and other items presented in the game. Those items do not break apart after a few times of me using them in real life. Lastly, the fact I can't wear multiple layers of clothing is quite fustrating, because if I were in that situation, I'd be wearing layers upon layers of clothing to the point where it is not cumbersome. Another thing which is quite annoying is how fast your hunger and thirst rise. If this character ate this much before the plane crash, his fatass wouldn't even survive the first hour.But, I do understand that the item condition mechanic of the game is suppose to be a way to make you go out and look for materials to repair your say, hunting rifle or knife.  Or that food supplies go out faster to give incentive to go out and hunt a deer or eat some canned goods. It's there to make you move about and explore more versus holing yourself up in a cabin and piling up a massive supply cache. (That's what I would try aiming for.)This game has the potential to be amazing, but as it stands it's not as realistic as it claims to be and gets way too reptitive too fast.I'm going to give this game a 5/10 atm, until futher notice. I do realize this game is in alpha so changes can definitely happen.P.S. The price of the game was reasonable so it doesn't bother me much. I hope the money I put towards this game helps the futher development of the game.

Early Access Review
								TLD is the definative survival game. Lightyears ahead of anything else.Well I bought TLD sometime back in 2014, just after they added the Coastal Highway map. For the purposes of this review, i've only ever played on Stalker difficulty.I still remember my first death.....I spawned, walked 20ft into a building and was mauled to death by a wolf that came running out of the darkness like some horror film whilst trying to work out how the inventory system worked 3 minutes into the game. I got better after that.TL;DRI'll say this and this only:The Long Dark is the only game where I thought I should have bought it twice for the amount of effort and content the dev team have put into it over the two years since I bought it originally. I'd gladly pay for the whole game again. TLD is not your run of the mill survival game, If you like an atmospheric survival where you think and make your own descisions about what you do next, you will like TLD.Full:This is not your run of the mill multiplayer survival etc. It's more of a carefully crafted atmospheric story that drives itself as you play through the sandbox. There is no guide, no hand holding, no tutorial. TLD makes you think to overcome problems. If you think that is what you would do in real life, there is a good chance that is what you would do in TLD. You're bleeding and have no bandages? What would you do IRL? The more you do this, the better you get at the game.The other thing is TLD can force you to make choices, There is a blizzard, you're slowly dieing of cold...do you hunker down?  or do you continue on? Will you make your safehouse?It's nasty out and you're out of food. Do I stay and wait it out? or do I try and make a run for it? Do I know the way back? How far is it? Will I get lost? Will I make it back before the sun sets? Is it safer to stay here?The above are all situations i've found myself in  within the game and made the right descisions to get out of them.There is no game like TLD currently and it's one of the best games and personally highly rated games in my collection. It is the definitive survival game.The devs are constantly updating the game and have added loads since bought it, including two new maps and mechanics changes and additions. The game has come a very long way.Hinterland are very receptive to player input and feedback, more than any other developer i've come across. After playing for a long time I made several posts on the Hinterland forums about how to possibly improve the game (imho) and several of them appeared in later builds, most notably the addition of skill books.A word on story mode. Yes it's been delayed several times but i've seen the changes that are being made and honestly, I had to pick my jaw up off the floor. I have every confidence in story mode being released and i'd rather it was delayed and highly polished than just released.TLD really is a unique single player game, It has so so much more depth than anything out there. So, if you're in doubt, or teetering on the edge or comparing it with another survival title, just buy TLD, you won't regret it.

Early Access Review
								This has to be one of the best games I have ever played. Yet, action-wise, there is very litle. This is all about survival and survival depends on the tactics you employ within the game. There are no 'buddies' to ask for help. No one you can telephone. Make a wrong turn, wonder off into the forest with night falling, and you are dead. Simple as that. It's all about decisions and making the correct one at the point you are at is the essence of the game.There are no real spoilers in the review - but there are a few tips that could be useful for beginners. Be warned.............In fact, the first few times you play, you are likely to end up dead very quickly... There is no real game help, as such, and it is a struggle to understand what is required of you. However, give it time and it starts to make sense. When the game first starts, you are dropped in a random location and it could be day or night. I suggest starting on the easy level as wolves don't attack you. In some respects, this is more accurate as wolves tend not to attack humans.The first thing to do is find shelter. You are unlikely to survive the cold of the night (or the day) if you are out for too long. This can then be used as a base.There are buildings scattered about to scavenge and hidden caves where you can find a few scraps.Journeys need to be planned. Never, ever, go out with just a couple of hours of light left. Darkness comes in rapidly and you are liable to get disorientated and die of hyperthermia. Also, weather can change rapidly and you need to know that you can make it back. Pay close attention to your surroundings and make a map ( I count steps).Explore each area thoroughly to find the exit. Carefully time when you leave the exit area.This is the beauty of the game. Everything needs to be calculated carefully to survive - just as in real life.Another nice feature is the lack of other people. Clearly, they were there at some point but for reasons not given, you could be the only person alive on the planet. To meet other people would spoil it and wisely, the developers know this.After all, what is more terrifying than being totally alone in a hostile environment? And that is the cleverest part of the game - the shear lonliness.So why is the game so compelling if there is no action, as such? Well, you live and die by your own actions and there can be no excuses if you do die. Therefore, everything is down to you the player and we all want to survive, right?I treat the game as a real life simulator. Should the big freeze ever come, I fancy my chances. Well, maybe a little bit more than most. Buy this and enjoy one of the most beautiful and yet scariest games ever written (without a monster - or is 'cold' the monster?).

								It's very difficult, but the mechanics are very intuitive for the most part. It's kind of like a survival game that is basically everything that DayZ's survival mechanics wanted to be, but the devs didn't get all caught up in needlessly complicated micro-interactions within your inventory. -TL;DR: Game has incredible depth of mechanics while still being relatively simple to interact with. -The game is more about planning and judgement than flick shots or reflexes. If you plan poorly, you will die very quickly.-No game has ever made me more afraid of simply freezing to death--Things you can expect-- -You will try to find firewood outside, a blizzard will start. you will become disoriented and lost and likely freeze to death about 50 feet from your shelter because you're wandering blindly in circles in a blizzard.-you will freeze to death again-you will begin to starve, so in desperation you'll try to find a new shelter and some loot. -you will get lost looking for new food.-freeze to death-fall to death because you are tired and can't see very well while hypothermic-be freezing and wandering desparately, get attacked by wolves. die.-attacked by bear. die. The game is brilliant because there are many mechanics that are not explicitly shown to you- things that if you're thinking in a good survival mindset will be natural, and likely reward you in some way... or punish your greed. CONS:The only thing I can really say that I don't like much about this game in its current build is the importance of reparing and maintaining items, and the fact that there is very limited ways in which to start a fire. Nothing in that capacity is truely renewable. Once you're out of matches and fail to be blessed by RNG to find a fire striker, you're basically ♥♥♥♥ed. I would like to see more emphasis on outoor survival/bushcraft type stuff as development continues. Early Access Review
								This game is an outstanding title in the survival genre. Why? It creates a unique atmosphere in an open-ended, realism based, beautiful environment with a challenging sandbox gameplay.Have you ever romantically thought about the experience of living in a lonely wooden cabin, far from the civilization, in the icy north of canada? Can you imagine this ambivalent mood, being in a beautiful, but also hazardous wild nature. Do you want to feel the pulse of the wilderness to experience your own limits? This is the atmosphere, the game is build around. It's not about fear or depression - it's about living at the limits and the willpower to survive.The game achieves this by a very unique and own game art, realistic game mechanics and the beautiful northern setting with stunning varying light based on weather and day-night cycle. The realism of the game adds more depths to the decisions you make. There is rarely a strict pattern or some kind of "best practice", that you can follow - it's truely up to you, to decide if a risk is worth the reward. Even your bad decisions may bring you an exciting experience. You will die often in the beginning. But everytime you start a new game, you will be enriched by this experience, getting a feeling for the dangers out there and how to withstand them.Still unsure? Check this points:You like to play in an open ended scenario, with no other goal, than to survive? If not, than better wait until the storymode is added.Bad experience with Early Access Games? This title is nearly bugfree and in a steady development by a small, but professional and experienced gamestudio.Does the current content justify the pricing? In my opinion it is more than enough and there are regular content updates, delivered mostly polished and bugfree. It's really high quality entertainment for an unbeatable low price.To come to an end.. If you like this genre in general you will not regret the purchase. Have fun and a lucky hunt :P

								I'm not too sure why I keep coming back to this game, whether its the cold atmosphere that makes me feel colder (i live in Australia and don't like the temperature), or whether I'm coming back purely because being alone and not having other people ruin my experience, I'm glad that I keep coming back, because every time I do it feels better.. Early Access Review
								The Long Dark, what a great game!  I've been waiting for someone to do something like this since I played Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater.  This game will get a curious person hooked instantly.  In my first play thorough I found myself on a hill next to the logging camp in Mystery Lake.  I ran to the trailers because I figured with all the snow I'd freeze to death fast with what little clothing my character spawned with.  I had great luck with gear in that play through.  I found two rifles, several knives and hatchets, but after 5 days I found 'the door' to Carter river. Unfortulately I didn't have much tinder and of course as soon as I walked out the door a storm hit.  My character survived 2 more days back there looking for a way out but ended up freezing to death lost on the river.  I've since earned my 50 day badge, I even came pretty close to 100 days before I played after a night of heavy drinking.  I ended up trying to see how high I could jump from ledges and ended up falling to my death on the side of a mountain.  Lesson learned, don't drink and survive.  :)There are several treacherous places on this map, if the wolves don't get you, the weather or starvation will your first few hours playing the game.  It's not one of those games that's so damn hard you'll get frustrated and lose interest either.  Patience is as much a virtue in the long dark as is caution.  Over time you'll craft clothes and collect what you need to make a bow and arrows.  You'll learn to conserve calories and let the wolves do the hunting for you by following one around crouched down until he takes a deer, and then you'll take him after he takes the deer to get a double meat, gut and hide harvest.  A few things to know if you want tips:1) The ravine takes you to the next area, don't go that way till you've explored Mystery lake and learned the game's survival basics.  2) A decent set of maps can be found here: 


Detailed Region Maps - The Long Dark 
A Guide for The Long Dark
By: Whiteberry

			Updated 2016-05-01. Detailed Maps of The Long Dark as I finish them in 3 different versions depending on level of spoilers. All are based on coordinates and should be fairly accurate.		


3) Snare traps are a great way to feed your charachter.  Make at least 10 snare traps but preferably 20 or more because after a while they break down, and need to be harvested and rebuilt with new cured gut.  Your return on the gut you use to build them is at least twice and more often 3 times what you'll spend to make them.  Easy calories, set where you see rabbits and forget, check them early the next day.  4) Fish are heavy and offer little calories for how much they weigh.  It's a good idea to cook the fish you catch right in the bob house and store the fish in the bob house so that you can have meat spread out on the map in case you run low on food while your out.  You won't be upset if you spread food out around the area you choose to make camp.  Storms come in fast and without warning.  Stashing food here and there will help you survive longer.  5) Save processed foods in good condition for as long as you can.  Processed foods are lighter in weight than the stuff you can catch and are great for traveling from zone to zone.  Eat the stuff that's going bad when you find if for easy calories, but save the good stuff if you can.  6) Rose hips are great for throwing on the ground in the snow.  They make for an easy to find trail if you're on your way home from your regular routes when a storm hits.  Rose hip trails saved my guy's tail more than once.  You'll need hundreds of them to make a full trail.  I managed to make a trail from the camp office to the first bob house in my last play through.  Other thoughts for the devs:Don't take the following negatively, you guys made a kick♥♥♥♥♥game, I love it.  But I'm a critical prick and need to voice my opinion so here it is:A zippo lighter, flint and lighter fluid would be nice.  Who uses matches these days anyway???  We should also be able to craft some sort of friction fire starting system out of sticks, birch bark and branches or find flint and use that with a knife or hatchet.  For more info see "Dual Survival" watch Codey the giant hippy make fire from almost nothing every time.  Google "Fire starting tools" you guys could add plenty of items for starting fires from flint magnesium blocks to those rods that shoot all the 3000f sparks (not flint) when struck with a knife.  Our charachters should level up and be able to carry more weight over time.  Adding a frame pack to the clothing and different levels of bags would be a nice addition to the game.  An adult human can survive 3 days with no water, and 3 weeks with no food if he/she is sitting around and was well fed before their starvation.  Please loosen up the food and water requirements, we're surviving in the cold not running marathons.  I'm aware that we burn more calories trying to stay warm in cold places, but three steaks a day?? Really?? I'm a ski bumb and ski in New England and Canada, it's not that cold.  I've been out skiing in -20F weather; after 8 hours of that you'll look forward to a hot Irish Coffee and a warm fire, but you won't die if you break the wind properly and keep moving.  Running and other strenous activities (work) should lower the effects of the cold weather.  Keeping active sould be another way to survive the cold.  MORE BULLETS PLEASE!!!The trapper's cabin should have reloading tools and supplies in addition to the work bench so that the old .303 bolt action fir stock rifle can be used more often or those prepper caches should have multiple cases (1000 rounds per case) of ammo.  Bullets come in boxes of 20, 50, 100, 250, 500 and 1000.  Black powder, caps, and shells should be stocked at the cabin, it would be another task for the survivor to complete.  Shells should be able to be recycled if picked up.  We should be able to harvest much more metal from cars to that entire hydro factory.  There are plenty of metal objects that we should be able to melt down for bullets, arrow heads, and tool repairs.  Either that or give us a pick and hammer and let us mine ore and coal.  Tips for noobs at Mystery lake:SAVE THE FOOD YOU FIND FOR AS LONG AS YOU CAN, JUST EAT IT BEFORE IT GOES BAD!!! I like to trap rabbits up the river, hunt for wolf and deer on the way out and back, and then catch a few fish on my way back to the Camp office at the bob house nearest the Camp office.  If you want your survival badges, do it like this.  You'll find yourself holed up for 30-40 days at a time eating the extra food you collected just passing time and chowing down.  I recomend collecting the materials you need for the bow and being patient, there aren't very many bullets for the rifle in my experience.  Once you've visited every cabin on the map above, check out the other areas.

Posted: December 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								For me, The Long Dark used to be a shining example of Early Access done right.Not quite so anymore.The game mechanics were released in Sandbox as a playground test for the development of The Long Dark, the game.It has now been 2 years and 3 months since the original EA release and the Sandbox is what the team focused on at the cost of the game promised.Some people find a sense of accomplishment in applying the mechanics of the Sandbox game to just long as last as possible. I personnally do not and it is the one question you should ask yourself before buying the game today.Without narrative, I personnally find it a waste of time. The survival aspect is just discovering mechanics (but they are really limited, do not expect complex crafting but a permanent damocles sword of  hunger/cold management) and applying/abusing the survival mechanics to last as long as possible.You might say Don't Starve does that somehow. But Don't Starve has loads of contents and crafting, TLD has 5 maps and very limited item interaction/crafting.Some very slow perk development has been introduced some time ago in a patch, making your characters getting better at making fire, repairing etc. to give each try a limited meaning but the lack of ambition on this part and the grindy aspect of it makes it more of a detail than something to look forward to.Without going full perks as in Everspace, a more satisfactory system would be needed to make the experience fun and rewarding. As it is, the only reward is your own satisfaction to have lasted some arbityrary days in a game with arbitrary mechanics for survival : once again this will determine if this game is for you.Hinterlands does a very good job at communicating, and they regularly release new patches and new mechanics to the game. But they also recognized that the focus on Sandbox impacted the development of the story, with episodes not being able to be fully based on what has been developped in Sandbox anymore.The graphic style is good in its choices and I appreciate the character and identity of it. But such a long development begins to make the game feel outdated in some aspects of the engine like animation, an interface that should be reiterated on some aspects etc.Some decisions such as mandatory permadeath for all can be bothersome to some players when simply giving the option would not break their game. The food decays for no good reason when you could use the outside cold to conserve it for a long time, matches will degrade for no good reason also.Some historical stubbnorness over such elements, a lack of flexibility in strictly defined mechanics and an absence of direction in the game make some of the experience feel slightly outdated when noticeable survival games have been released by the dozens now, innovating in the gameplay and the user interaction towards less grind and more variety.I feel Hinterland refuses to introduce some optional fun in their survival.It is interesting to compare TLD and Subnautica which were both released 3 months apart. As of now I really have a much better time playing Subnautica, who listened to the player base when introducing a mode without food/water for example, offers more content, and where the sense of discovery of the player is far more rewarding in the first playthrough.One could definitely say Subnautica's experience is around exploration and base building while TLD is focused on survival. In the end exploration and discovery provide a much more rewarding experience than the later for me. I just don't have enough awe with TLD past the first remarkably bleak but beautiful depiction of Alaska's white harsh environment.(edit : to be fair, after spending quite some time on Subnautica, the experience offers more variety but also a lot more bugs for now)It really feels as Hinterland, while doing a very good job at developping TLD, lost focus on the ultimate goal of it all.I do hope their future episodes will make me change my mind, but the recent announcement of 6 hours of gameplay for 2 episodes leaves me a bit perplexed as of now.TLD is a good software, but for the last time, you should ask yourself if you can find it satisfying to survive in a contrived space just for the sake of it, with some frustratingly limited mechanics after such a long development.ps : Also, as in any online community, the TLD steam forums have become too often toxic to different views. Try to find your information and make up your mind somewhere else.pps : I would add that in the end, this game costs 20 dollars, half that on promotion, and half of that if you use a different region thant the US or Europe for Steam ; a price well worth paying when discounted if you want to have the long dark experience for yourself. I have no regret buying the game whatsoever despite my criticisms.

Early Access Review
								This game is so immersive. At times, I have to just stop playing because it is exhausting being constantly focused on surviving for hours on end. Do I have enough food? Is my water supply sufficient? Will the weather turn foul while out exploring? Are there wolves in my path? Can I avoid them or must I fight?The game only saves when you sleep, enter a shelter/building or become injured. Death is permanent with all saves erasing when you do die. Save scumming is impossible so every time I venture outdoors I am looking out for possible dangers. It's been a learning experience as I have avoided reading guides or looking at videos. The first time I died venturing out in the wilderness at night. I quickly lost my sense of direction. It is much colder at night than during the day so I froze to death. All my other deaths have been due to wolves. Generally wolves are just a nuisance. They telegraph their intention to attack from a long ways off and are easily scared off by fire. It is when you are weak from hunger, thirst, fatigue or the cold that wolves can make an easy meal of you. Even when you are in good shape if your fight with a wolf leads to being wounded gravely you better have first aid gear available. If not you will likely bleed out.This game gets you thinking about what you would do if in the same situation. Would you end your life early to avoid the slow death of starvation or would you fight will all your might to survive no matter how much suffering you endured? You can't really hold it against the person in this situation who takes their own life. Starving or dying of thirst are horrible ways to die. Freezing to death is perhaps a bit less horrible but you do suffer quite a bit until hypothermia kicks in. No need to mention the horror of becoming the next meal of a predator.You are stranded in the Great White North. You have few supplies and must scavenge for anything which improves your lot.What would you be willing to do to survive?

								(First playthrough btw)Day 2, I was pretty geared up.  I had a rifle, and some food, however I had run out of water. I decided to trek out in the morning, as I was quite parched. I came upon a derailed train and spotted a wolf beside it, and I quickly thought to myself, "If I engage this wolf, will my rifle be enough?" He engaged me first, and he ran at me snarling, I fired off a shot and, "oh what a surprise, I missed!" He tackles me into the snowbank, I fight for my life, and eventually I win and throw him away. He began running but I wasn't having any of that. He tore my jacket wide open and sprained my ankle, why would I let him escape? I began chasing him, but he was ready. In retaliation for me chasing him he turned around and began counter-charging. Ofcourse I had my rifle ready this time, yet I barely managed to graze him, he went down! I started cutting him open, good eats tonight! However my conditions are worsening. I'm freezing, my ankles are broken, and I'm still thirsty. I begin running for about 10 seconds until I spot a small overhang. (7% Condition Overall Now) I put the last of my twigs together, and just barely managed to create a fire. I sat by the fire cooking my fish. As I'm about to eat the delightful lake trout, I hear something coming up behind me! I stumble backwards into my fire, and fall to the ground. (2% Condition!) I can barely see now, life is fading away... On the other side of the fire, a wolf stares at me. With a last moment memory, I pulled out a flare. "Flares can be used to scare away animals" as said in their descriptions; so I light this sucker up, and with my last breaths I throw it at the wolf. Success, he runs! I feel so achieved but so broken, and I know I have to find shelter. I begin sprinting, (Crawling on the ground fast at this rate.) It's so blurry, I can't see! Where should I go? I follow the tracks, but too my demise, they were the last things I ever saw...AMAZING GAME, I was genuinely scared by that wolf at the fire, the immersion is unreal.

Early Access Review
								I've been playing TLD for about six months now, and I figured it was time for a review.Survival games. When I think; "Early Access Survival Game" I think, half-baked half life 2 engine survival game piece of garbage that somehow still manages to attract stupid amounts of attention, with devs that are only there to make a quick buck, and a community of troll snipers that will KOS even if you have zero gear.The Long Dark throws all of that out the window. Half-Baked? In the literal sense, yes, but I think with just a few more tweaks you could bring it out of early access. Devs are supportive of the communty, and open to suggestions, KOS troll-snipers (a phenomenon which I like to call "Unturned Syndrome") are removed altogether by removing multiplayer altogether. No it's not the end of the world, belive it or not, not every video game is multiplayer.The art style and graphics are lovley, and all of this alone would be enough to set it apart from the crowd of indie survival developers, coughcoughRustH1Z17DaysToDieTheFifthDaycoughcough.But the gameplay goes further. All feels balanced, and while some argue for reduced calorie burn, some argue for increased, so I think it's best to just keep in the middle. There's no insta-craft, something I've wanted in a survival game forever, along with sleep deprivation (which this game has as well). It gives a real sense of acheivment when you finally finish the wolfskin coat you've been working on forever. I love the gunplay.(Because hip-firing dosen't work in real life. It just dosen't unless you're supressing, and why would you supress a deer?)There's no base building, and this might be my favorite part. I can't tell you how many times I've stumbled across someone's giant♥♥♥♥♥♥♥monument in Rust. Kinda breaks the survival aspect.Bullet balistics work, Animals are scary (at night more so) The map (when you consider that it's one giant linked map) is actually pretty bloody hugeI could just go on and on.I could talk to you all day of every thing I love about this game but I don't have the time or the patience. I definetley recommend this game, for anyone sick of every other reskinned survival game. I know there are some who prefer to troll-snipe bambies for fun, in which case, you can head to the featured page and see about twenty games for you.I bid you all adeiu.

Early Access Review
								Canadian wilderness survival after a geomagnetic disaster.  My longest survivor so far hit 100 days.  By day 4 was eating dogfood and the end of the week was stumbling through the woods with hypothermia when lucked upon a prepper's cache. On the other hand, I can guarantee you that starting a fire at 12000 foot (3658 m) is very difficult with wet wood and no kerosene.  The game is still in early release and they are coming out with a Story mode.  Most players already love their Sandbox with several maps.   Great community and check out Geltaz on Youtube for some interesting play.  Also like to thank Drifter Man for all his forum posts.  These two seem like opposite playstyles and I am somewhere in the middle.

Early Access Review
								An amazing survival game that is constantly updated and worked on, with plenty of content to keep you busy. Here are some pros/cons:Pros:- NO ZOMBIES: really, I'm sick and tired of this cliche that plagues this genre.- Not action/combat oriented: apart from wild animals you will only fight nature and your needs.- Amazing atmosphere: even if you know there's no zombie to jump on you, you'll still get uneasy feelings when going through an abbandoned place- Realism: there are very few other games that emulate real survival so well. Everything from hunger to weather or wildlife behavior is spot on.- Constant updates and feedback from developers: this is clearly not one of those alpha/EA games that is abbandoned after the first cash grab- Incentives to explore: the game is designed in such a way that you cannot jut bunker down in a cabin and live there indefinitely. You NEED to explore to survive and it's alaways a hard choice to leave your cozy "base" to brave the unknown.- The game is harsh: one moment your condition is 100%, everything is great, then you make 1-2 mistakes like you decide to butcher a deer even if it's frozen and there's only 1 hour of sunlight left, then a wolf attacks you and you're maimed and can't find your way to your precious shelter.  The cascade/butterfly effect can kill you even after 30-40 days of survivalCons:- No HUD to display the hunger/thirst/energy levels. While this is intentional (for immersion), I'd like to have it as an option.- Needs a bit more wildlife variety and more crafting recipes.

Early Access Review
								This game is brilliant.The game spawns you into a random location on a map, and then the clock starts ticking as you try to survive as long as possible. The catch is not only are you trying to find the important aspects of survival like food and drink, but you are also being hunted. The game spawns wolves who are just as hungry as you. The wolves will hunt in packs to try to find their next meal, which may be you. This keeps you on your toes constantly as you never know what may lurk behind you or around the corner. It is very unnerving and really gives the game a creepy atmosphere. The fight for finding food, water, and shelter, as well as trying to fend for your life give the game the desperate struggle for survival it was trying to achieve. The maps are big with plenty of places of interest, and the gameplay will keep you coming back for more!Oh, and don't die. The game has permadeath, and I mean PERMADEATH. It will delete your save the second you die automatically. Every second is a fight for survival, as well as for preserving all your hard work up to that point. I go back and forth if I like this feature or not, but the stressful and desperate atmosphere it creates is definitely worth it. Pick this game up now! I can't wait to see what the future holds for it already has enough to keep me occupied for months to come :)

Early Access Review
								I am most likely going to get downvotes and probably have my review marked as "funny" due to certain members of the community, but I'm here to say what I've been holding off on saying for the past few months. I bought The Long Dark primarily for the Story Mode; back when it was seemingly right around the corner. On the fence about purchasing, I was persuaded by the 90%(!) approval rating and endless amounts of positive reviews, so I thought I'd buy the game. While waiting for the Story Mode, I thought I might as well give Sandbox a try, so I'll start there.Sandbox mode started out fair enough - The visuals were amazing, the wolves felt like threats, and I was always on the edge of my seat, planning my next move. The atmosphere was great.However, after some hours, it became obvious that there was no point to surviving - There is simply nothing much to live for. Even with these new "challenges," the game's sandbox lifetime is disappointingly short. Simply put: It gets rather boring. Surviving for months is a tedious chore, not a fun adventure. There's no reason to live. If the game had been marketed as yet another sandbox survival, I wouldn't have bought it. There's a multitude of those already, most of which are better than this game.Moving on to the mess that was/is Story mode: 18 months and multiple failed release dates later, the devs have engaged in a rigorous "it's done when it's done" stance.  Waiting for months upon months for a story mode that was promised to be delivered months ago and may be at best only a few hours long is not my cup of tea. I have been holding off on writing this review, but as time passed I ended up feeling disappointed and angry as The Long Dark seemed to be traveling down a never-ending road of Early Access, sadly like so many other games. This is the first Hinterland product I have purchased, and it will also be my last. I've uninstalled the game, and it will most likely remain uninstalled for the rest of eternity.

Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is one of the best games I ever played (even if it's still in Early Access!).I can clearly recommend this game to all people who like survival games.Not survival like "you have to kill all the zombies to survive" (there are no zombies) more like you against nature (against extremely cold Canadian hinterland, against wolves and bears, against thirst and hunger, against your body that get's tired, against loneliness and declining tools). This game is for explorers and nature lovers, for romantics and survivalists, for art lovers (beautiful graphics) and sound freaks (amazing sounds, really rich in detail, voice acting of your own character is also great). At the moment you can only play the game in sandbox mode. The studio has planed this game as a story mode and released the sandbox to test the in game mechanics of the world. They constantly improve the mechanics always in close connection to the feed back of the community. (It's just amazing how fast they respond!) If you read this you can get the impression of the game is in an experimental state - belief me, it's not! I played this game in sandbox mode for more than 100 hours, I wouldn't  have if it wasn't playable and highly enjoyable. In the last update they also implanted a challenge mode where you have missions to accomplish under high pressure. This is great for all players that spend a lot of time in the game and wished for some change in their day to day survival. If you are new I recommend to first explore all regions and learn to survive in the wilderness before accepting the challenges. What I especially like as a female player is that you can choose between a female an a male character. It helps to merge in to the game even more. And you really get absorbed by the game: If you played it for a couple hours you will start to collect matches in real live. In short: Highly recommended for players who like to explore a beautiful landscape under extreme circumstances. Who like to collect food and stuff and build a base camp. Who like game mechanics that are oriented in real life (you can't run all day, you have to sleep or you can't sleep if you aren't tired). Who like to think of what happens if you are the last person after the apocalypse. Who like an apocalypse where nothing really changes but the weather gets more extreme, the wolves are more aggressive and you can't find other survivors (at the moment).
