content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								February 22nd (Day One)I knew it was a mistake when I did it, but I took her up anyway. That's the last time I ignore my gut. Hell, ignore my reason, my instinct. Every inch of me was saying, "hey, bad idea; let's not put five miles between you and the ground when every other plane crashed simultaneously four weeks ago." But that's what you do when you're desperate, you stop using your God-given common sense.If this does end up being read by anybody other than me, congrats! You are alive and I am dead. And you will probably be easier on me than I am being on myself. You might say, "Jack, you had to take that plane South. You were freezing to death. You had one good day to get the hell outta Dodge." Well, thank you. Maybe you are right, but it is what it is.Either way, my plane did what every other plane did: it crashed. By some combination of my incredible flying skills (and humility) and nothing short of a miracle, I put her down in a way that didn't crush any of my bones or major organs.I would take the time to tell you about all the crazy♥♥♥♥♥♥that's been happening to the world lately, but if you are alive enough to read this, then you know damn well what's going on. If, by some small chance someone deciphers this thing twenty thousand years from now, well...the world went to hell in a hurry. Some insane solar flare sent our magnetic field bonkers and managed to fry every piece of electric hardware ever (my plane is a rebuild from way back so no computer, lucky right?) Not sure what the warmer places in the globe are dealing with, but up north here the weather is about as predictable as a grapefruit squirt.So, I'm not dead...yet. In fact, I had the good fortune of crashing and not dying in a place that had been inhabited not too long ago; that, and salvaging a few items that, like me, were lucky enough not to be crushed in my plane, I might actually have a chance. I guess I have to look at it that way so I won't give up and die right now. What's that saying? Expect the worst, hope for the best? Well, I don't even know what to expect at this point but I'm sure there's some other saying for how it can always get worse... actually, I think that's the saying. Not the most creative people making these things up.As for what to hope for...how about another sunrise.Enough of the backstory, that's not what journals are for and I better get to it anyway before either this fire goes out or I pass out. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, I'm out of shape. Someone shoulda had the decency to mention the world was gonna end, I would've gone for a run or two. Who am I kidding? No I wouldn't've.* * *It's sometime mid-morning and I'm standing next to this wreck of a plane, scratching my head at how I'm not dead when I realize I might literally be freezing my♥♥♥♥♥off...like my actual♥♥♥♥♥my just fall off of me, land in the snow, and I might not realize it. So I manage to grab my survival pack with the few things I could salvage and I hoof it toward something that looks less mountain-ish and more building-ish in the distance (basically something more square and less pointy). I'm not really thinking thoughts at this point; I am just realizing how out of breath I am trudging about a hundred feet through snow and that if I stop to catch my breath I might become an icicle.But would you believe it? A poor, insignificant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like me gets lucky, like jackpot lucky, twice in one day. There is a building, which means I might have actually crashed near civilization, which means I might not freeze to death, which means I might find something that will keep me from starving after I chow down on this energy bar. Hell, I might even meet another person, and they might not even want to kill me and eat me. I should be dead, anything could happen at this point.I snapped a shot of the building[zeemodernnerdblog.files.wordpress.com] with the magically uncrushed Polaroid camera I had in my pack, though I would trade this camera and my left pinky for a hot burger right about now. Screw it, I'll give both pinkies for any amount of ground beef. Did I mention this is day 1 of me surviving out here? Not sure what limbs I'll be willing to trade if I make it ten days. I guess I'll let you know.This thing is some sort of dam. I assume it's hydro-electric, no one builds a dam without an opportunity to generate some cash flow from it. Ah, those were the days, when you could subjugate nature for your own personal gain. Well, thank you Mr. Dam-Builder you helped me live today.By the way, I say I assume it's hydro-electric now as I am writing this, but at the time my brain is still frozen and I believe I was thinking: "me cold, building less cold, me go."So "me went" and "me not freeze." Me actually almost trip over a dead guy holding a storm lantern as soon as I enter the thing. I was horrified at seeing the corpse at the time, but it's really crazy how different your brain acts when it knows you need to live. Let me clarify: when I'd realized I'd tripped over this corpse--this former person with a soul who died a terrible death that I might soon die--I was both horrified and relieved. Relieved because it was dark as hell and this guy is holding a lantern with fuel in it. I don't know how he didn't leave it on, I'm not sure how he died, but all I am thinking is, "thank the sweet Lord: I have light."Then, I turn the lantern on and see a giant gash in his side and a trail of blood and realize this guy made it about four feet in here before he passed out from blood loss. The snow outside must have covered whatever trail he left out there. But, I feel nothing.  It wasn't like the movies. I know I should have curled up in a ball and sobbed for the tragedy of it all. I should have puked because it's a body and I don't see those, but really, I'm feeling nothing. Call it shock. Call me a heartless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but unless you have been there, you can't know.The things I should've been thinking (and not doing so nearly got me killed) was, "what made that nasty huge gash in that man's side? Could it be a thing? A dangerous thing? Could it still be around? Do I need a weapon pronto so I don't end up like this unfortunate gentleman?"But anyway...Listen, my fire is dying down. I don't want to keep you on the edge of your seat, but I'm still alive, for today. I have enough stuff at the moment that I can write a bit in the morning before I have to go continue to try to live. I'm not sure why I care so much about writing this, but I hope if you are reading it you'll... yeah, I don't know what I hope.It is what it is.TO BE CONTINUEDCheck out my other Steam ReviewsFor more stories/reviews/articles check out My Blog[zeemodernnerdblog.wordpress.com]

Early Access Review
								First game ever. I'm outside. The snow storm is wreaking havoc. It's freezing, but happily I spot near me a large building. Lucky me. I enter the dam. It's dark. It's gloomy. I can hear many, too many, unknown noises in the distance, barely audible, which adds a shiver along my spine. It seems safe nevertheless. I walk slowly into the main room instead of going back outside in the cold ; I'd rather keep myself warm, like a fly desperately attracted by light. It's even gloomer here. Nothing happened... I feel safe now. I enter the room with the command panels. I scavange for food and supplys. After all, I know how to survive. Probably. I will need those things sooner than later anyway. I stop when I find a flare. I smile widely. I will be able to keep wolves at bay. I hear something. Footsteps. Not mine. I turn vividly my head ; I think I saw something, thought followed immediatly by a growl nearby. Adrenaline rushs through my veins, the heart is rapidly pulsating. I drop the flare.I see IT now. Large. Black. Running toward me. I scream and try to get out of here. I collide with one of the tables on my way out. The wolf jumps then on me, is jaw wide open. I feel bitten repeatedly. I bleed. I kick. I punch. I bite. Whatever ! Everything is a blur. I start to loose consciouness. I die.It's been all in all around five minutes of playtime. I cannot describe you how much I was immersed in the game and how much loud I screamed when I saw Fluffy, the iconic wolf. A tensed game time.I love The Long Dark ever since.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								What to say about The Long Dark that does it justice?Unlike most other 'survival' games out there in the market, do not be expecting to swing axes at Zombies and other supernatural beings. Your enemy in this game is the weather, wildlife (Wolves / Bears) , fatigue, thirst and hunger.Simply walking around with no enemy in sight can cause your health to start deteriorating if you are being careless about how cold the weather is. When you are starving, the sight of even a small handful of herbs or a degraded packet of candy will get you excited.Expect to build fires, evade wildlife, monitor the weather like a hawk, inspect every nook and cranny for food / water / medicine - expect to hurl yourself into a cabin with a wolf or bear on your tail like your life depended on it. (Which it does!) Expect to traverse up large mountains in the hope that there may be a shelter somewhere. Enjoy the beautiful sunlit and moonlit views of the Canadian forests whilst reminding yourself that you need to keep moving.Expect to flounder in the darkness and traverse through mines with the kerosene in your lamp trickling away. If you can plan ahead, if you can adapt to harsh situations and if you can handle doing as much as possible with as little as possible in your possession - you will relish this title. This is an intelligent game designed for intelligent gamers. It is a true masterpiece and example of not only what a survival game should truly be about, but also how an Early Access title should be developed.Hinterland Studios actively and consistently interact with their members on the forum and listen to inputs about any bugs and feedback about the game. And all along, they still remain true to their core vision of the game.I cannot recommend this game enough. There is plenty of content in the game and it barely feels like an Alpha release.------------------Some key notes about the title;* One life. When your game is over, it is over.* Ammo is scarce.* The weather WILL dictate how much you can explore at any given time.* You can craft gear, which includes warmer clothing, weapons and food harvesting.* There is item degradation. All repairable... if you have the materials.* There is no "map". You learn by exploring and memorising.* What you can carry is limited. Whilst you can go over your 'maximum' weight, be prepared for the fatigue, thirst, hunger and movement penalties.* The game has a learning curve which would be considered steeper than most other titles - there is a bit to take in, there is no game manual - and it can be unforgiving. This is a game that intuitively makes you discover by yourself.* You will be monitoring your four stat bars and your health bar a lot in this game if you want to succeed.* There will be a lot of exploring where you do not get attacked for long periods. This is normal. (And to be honest, a welcome thing!)------------------The only things I would consider as "CONS" for this title is that it's in Alpha - so you naturally want more content and there are pockets of bugs you can discover. (I don't come across very many though...) Also, once you get proficient at surviving (takes a while to get there) it can be a bit lonely and repetitive if you aren't exploring around the maps.Other than that - fantastic title. Do get it!If you're a patient, planning player - then this acquired taste is more than for you. A hidden gem of a title that already has amassed a cult following. http://www.hinterlandforums.com/

Early Access Review
A survival game that is pure survival. No zombies, no nuclear wastelands, none of that. Just you vs Mother Nature and her elements. In The Long Dark, you play as a bush pilot who crash lands in the middle of Canada's harsh wilderness in the event of a geomagnetic disaster. You'll need to scavenge for food, water, meds, and tools to help you stay alive to see the dawn of the next day while the wolves and bears nip at your heels.You'll also need to take account for body temperature, caloric intake, your hunger/thirst, fatigue, wind-chill, wildlife, and other environmental factors. This game will have you making decisions and one wrong decision will see to your death. Can you survive to see another day....or will you succumb to the long dark.

Early Access Review
								The absolute BEST survival game ever created. The immersion is absolutely stunning, there is just something about unreal engine that makes you completely absorbed into the game. The devs are some of the kindest, warmest canadians of all time, who listen intently to their community and are constantly involved with making the game as good as possible. This is the model Early Access game, and don't let heaps like dayZ or H1Z1 put a bad taste in your mouth, because these devs deserve every single bit of money they earn. The game itself completely breaks the monotony of regular survival games in that there is no end game item, or one that immediately makes the game easier to play. the focus is completely on the gameplay of survival, which is done incredibly well. It isn't the prospect of getting better guns or items that keeps you playing, but just the process of surviving day to day which makes me keep coming back to this game. The graphical style they chose for this game is just phenominal. The artstyle immediately draws you into the world, all without putting extreme intensity on your rig. The ambience and soundtrack are nothing short of perfect, adding to the immersion immensely. Now content-wise, I alone spent upwards of 30 hours just on the first realm, and by the date of this review, there are 5 regions available to explore. I just finished the second region in 20 hours, just in time for them to announce Storymode for 2016. I am sure that if I got back into it, I could easily top 150-200 hours on only sandbox. Now onto bugs, they are very, and I mean VERY rare. I don't even think I ever even got a CTD. In all my playtime I can't recall a single bug or glitch that took me out of the game, or messed with my progress. It is extremely well polished, which you don't get much of for Early Access.Bottom line, buy this game, but experience wise, I would reccomend you don't play it until 2016, when storymode comes out. I for one really wished I waited on playing it, because apparently Storymode will use many portions of the sandbox maps, which would spoil some exploration experience for me. waiting until storymode will promise you the best experience. Also, from my own personal experience, play the game on Stalker mode (the hardest). This is the only difficulty I've played on, and its one of the most punishing survival experiences out there, besides maybe Stalker Call of Pripyat's MISERY mod. You will be sneaking and fighting for you life every single day, and the rifle doesn't immediately promise to save you. This right here is an excellent game, and a model for all other survival games to take note from.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								TL;DR: A great survival game that pulls ahead of nearly every survival game I've played before. Worth every penny.My experiences in The Long Dark have all been entirely different (albeit always ending in my demise) despite picking the same map most of the time. The maps are quite large and connect to each other. The maps are NOT procedurely generated, allowing maps to be created and upon starting a new game, you can head in a familiar direction.The difficulty can be set depending on how you'd like to play, whether you prefer exploring or hardcore survival. Even playing on the "Pilgrim" (easy) difficulty it provides a solid challenge, eliminating only the threat of animals. My most recent experience was on the easiest difficulty and I still managed to die withing the first few days because I got carried away. Knowing when you have enough daylight to make it back to camp is essential. I decided to fish my last 2 hours of daylight, only a few hundred yards from what I decided to make my "base". That night of course turned out to be one of the darkest I've seen and of course I had ran out of fuel earlier, not expecting to need any. I lit my lantern that had very little keroseen and started to head towards my shack. Soon I realized I had went the wrong direction after getting turned around in the dark. It didn't take long for my lantern to go out, so I lit the only thing I had left, a flare. I wandered for what seemed like forever, not making any progress. Hypothermia ensued and I was becoming exhausted. I managed to find one of the many fishing huts on the lake I had been fishing on. I decided it'd be best to wait out the night in the shack rather than wandering around cold. To pass the time I decided to fish, there could only be around 4 hours of night left. 2 more hours of fishing and my situation was becoming dire. The night was still black and the temperatures had only become worse. I laid now my bedroll, hoping to rest and warm up inside the sleeping bag while in the fishing shack. Only needed to make it another hour and the sun would begin to rise, lighting the way to my base where I could be warm. As I rested my body temperature just continued to drop and I died in my sleep. This was on the easiest difficulty. (Yes, I obviously suck.)The game runs well, but can be demanding at times due to the large world and blizzards. The graphics are artistic, but nothing that will knock your socks off, but you can capture some pretty nice screenshots during sunrises or when the night isn't so dark. The game even has a nice soundtrack that can be quite ominous, but fits the setting. The music isn't constant so it doesn't take away from the immersion. Some animal sounds aren't great, such as deer running by, but others can be quite chilling. Hearing a pack of wolves begin to howl in the night while hearing the wind screaming throught the trees creates an amazing atmostphere.The game doesn't hold your hand. You're thrown in and survival begins the second you start. There are community made maps, but none in game. This is not to say that it has a sharp learning curve though. Crafting is simple and item descriptions tell you how to do certain things (such as curing hides).The developers are constantly putting out updates and doing everything to turn this into a finished product (even though it feels close to one now). Features such as story mode have yet to be added, but sandbox and challenges are more than enough to keep you entertained for more hours than many triple A titles can. The Long Dark is an excellent game and is well worth the small price tag. A game that shows no signs of ever being abandoned as many early access games have in the past. The game can be tough so if you're aren't a fan of survival games, it's probably safe to say you should stay away. If you are a fan of survival though, this is the perfect game for you. No zombies, no aliens, just you and the Canadian wilderness.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								When this game showed up on my Steam queue, the description was one that immediately piqued my interest (that and the beautiful artstyle). The promise of a "thoughtful, exploration-survival experience" was exactly what I'd been looking for since I've had time to pick up gaming as a pasttime once more. While I do have a few gripes with the game thus far, the duration of my experience in the game so far has been with answering a couple of questions that have been floating around since I was first introduced:Does it live up to what it claims to be (at least in terms of my playstyle)?Given that I've played the game almost exclusively on hard mode, and have recently reached day 30 on my current run, I'd consider myself at least a bit survivable and able to handle the game's mechanics pretty well. Did it challenge me? That's a given; my first four of five runs, each having been slightly longer than the last, each had their fun and challenging stories, which ultimately ended with my demise (to wolves every time). There seems to be a bit of a rough difficulty curve, as it starts off incredibly difficult and overwhelming, only to become basic knowledge to survive. Perhaps I haven't trying challenging myself, as my intuition within the game has been to reduced to "Gotta find buildings, gotta go fast." Judging from my experience, playing to live exclusively off the land seems impossible. Not that it should be the intended way of playing, but that I think it should be an option for the most daring of players. The game's mechanics do not allow for such a playstyle, as they do not for a lot of playstyles. A decently large game with so much potential ends up being disappointingly shallow at the end of the day. (I suppose that's the cause of Early Access, but I digress) There's a lot of room to expand and add depth.    TL;DR: Hell yeah, but could do with some improvements.Do the game's mechanics work well/properly? If there's anything I love, it's a game that you can't learn completely just from reading a couple pages on the wiki. A game that not only requires a strong sense of intuition and logic, but also experience to apply your knowledge properly. The only real sense of progression you have throughout the game is synthesized through the pseudo leveling system for repairing and firemaking. The game mechanics work properly, only, they become very predictable and boring over time. They are not, however, without merit. There are some unique mechanics within the game that deserve some credit. Let's start off with the the environment. In my opinion, the environment is very well done and is just naturally a challenging part of the game that is always a breath of fresh air. Air temperature and windchill are both very well done and fun elements of the game to play around. Not to mention how well the environment is aesthetically, though the night time could use a little polishing (snow and breath look awkward in the dark). The environment definitely does a lot better than it's living counterpart: the wolves. On the other end of the spectrum, wolves are what I have the biggest problem with. It's great to have a constantly looming threat, especially in the harder difficulty, but they have become more annoying than threatening at this point. Randomness is a very fickle element of survival games, and should be used only when necessary; ie. wolves should not be dictated by randomness. Being the BIG threat in most playthroughs, they should be challenging and something to think about, not annoying and something you just pray to avoid. I should be praying when I'm making a run for the cabin at midnight because I've run out of supplies, not when I'm leaving in the morning for a fresh expedition. The wolves are a very flawed gameplay mechanic, as they stand right now. With semi-random spawns, arbitrary movement, and aggro radius, they act pretty much exactly like a zombie would. I understand the suspension of disbelief that has to go into playing a videogames, but wolves should act as wolves do. There's very little room to play around the possibilities of wolf attacks, since they are so random, and once they're chasing you, they never let up. Of course, when they DO catch you, there's very little threat unless there are two or more to continuously pounce you, and then you're more than likely dead at that point. TL;DR: The elements are nice, the wolves are a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥br>Overall, the game so far has been a fantastic experience with lots of very high points where I've felt sheer awe from the beauty, pure relief from escaping the brink of death, or relaxation from sitting around a fire during a cold night. And, of course, there were some pretty frustrating low points. Wolves randomly become immune to flares, randomly become immune to torches, and randomly show up in packs right outside my door. Fun times in the Canadian wilderness. 8/10

								-Will redo another review for the next update-v0.196 ReviewSo, I feel the need to rewrite a new review because of the many changes occured in the game and I'm not happy with all of them !First, the good things.1/ A new area is available to exploration "pleasant valley". It consists of a bigger area representing a more "countryside" or "rural" feeling. This area provides some good feeling of what is really surviving in an isolated zone. You have to plan anything (where to go, what to do...) in advance because being caught in a blizzard or fog, or just be surprised by the night is a certain death coming to you very quick ! I really like this area because you have to be prepared before entering it and you can't rely on modern supplies because this area is almost made of empty fields and moutains (but you will find interesting things too if you explore the zone carefully)2/ there are now 3 difficulty mode. The standard one, an "pilgrim" mode (easy) where you can explore without caring of anything (I don't enjoy this mode because you can't die even if you go almost naked in the wirlds), but, it is a good point to try this mode and explore zones to learn where are the "safe zones". Also, the wolves will not attack you in this game mode.3/ New animal : The bear ! Very slow but massive, interesting but for now, it is overpowered and don't give enough meat to be considered like a valuable resource.4/ new crafts : you can now gpo hunt for mushrooms and plants to make bandages and tea (and some more things I don't discovered yet). Useful when you fall short of modern medical items.5/ I think there are some changes in food/drink consumption. but perhaps it's just me. It seems to me that food needs are now more realistics.Now the things I consider bad or I don't like (only one :D)1/ wolves are now mostly invincible. If they spot you and begin to run, it's over : they can't be scared anymore after that. I think this is a bug but it's really annoying...And that's all for my rating. I red on steam forums that there are bunkers hidden in the game, spawning randomly on start on each game. But I've never found one yet. And I don't want to see the maps created by the community (because I don't want to ruin all the exploration game). Another good feature I wasn't aware of.======================Original review below======================This game is very good and it's still in alpha stage.Explain why it's good will be a lot difficult but I'll try my chance to make you play this game.This game is a survival without any zombies or ennemies. The only thing you will fight is yourself and mother nature. when the game start, you are launched into the unknown, in a vast canadian land cover with ice and snow and the first thing you have to do is to find a shelter before dying in this cold country. The game is based on exploration, but you are limited by food, drink, fatigue and cold. You have to manage these 4 parameters (+ day/night cycle) to advance in the game, find better tools to survive and to be able to explore more.The weather can suddenly change to a mortal blizzard, the temperatures can go below -35°C, making you run to the nearest shelter or hill to try to protect yourself from the deadly winds, making a fire with your poor ressources to heat yourself a little... but wait, there's more : WOLFS !This terrible animal will be your biggest nightmare, it can kill you in seconds (you can fight back too but your chances are not very high) and very soon, you'll be out of "modern" supplies, you'll have to hunt too, making water from snow and making it safe to drink. And many more thing I can't tell you without spoiling the end game content (but it's still alpha stage so many more things will soon arrive). And oh, each new game randomizes all items, making each death a replay value.For now, the game has only two linked zones, a little one, easier to explore and memorise, and a larger one, more difficult, because of the distance between shelters (you have to plan all your moves before doing anything). Devs said a third zone will arrive soon but again, you'll have plenty of things to do and discover in the two zones provided with the game for now. Will you survive 50 days ?

Early Access Review
								This is a game that works for me on nearly every level. I've spent 25+ years working in the outdoors of the Pacific Northwest so this was like playing in my backyard. I am not going to talk about all the aspects of this game that are great but will highlight a few. Played now for over a year - the updates & changes have been awesome! Here's the only negatives (?) imo.-Some players may not be satisified with the art / graphics. Personally I think they work, are simple and quite beautiful.-There are some oddities with movement over snow drifts / ice that I think are just minor glitches. Why, occassionally, can't I step over a 4" drift on a road?-The rifle mechanics are a bit confusing. I have owned and used a .303 extensively so I'm not blowing smoke when I say a wolf shot in the chest at 10 feet is, at the minimum, going to be knocked off it's feet. EDIT: Since writing this review I have one-shot 23 wolves in a row. Curious...-Black bears normally do not attack when shot. 95% of the time they run away from the direction the pain originated from. In this game they attack 80% of the time. And they move at the speed of light. They cover 25 yards (the distance I typically shoot them) in about a second. ?? I've been charged 6 times in RL and as dangerous as that was I can tell you: bears are fast BUT not that fast.That's really all I can say that is remotely negative.I can tell you that the basic stats of keeping your body temperature up, monitoring your fatigue, keeping hydrated and watching your calorie intake is, in RL, critical to your survival outdoors. Reading the wind, clouds, type and intensity of snowfall, wildlife behaviour are also extremely important. The balance that this game has with making these characteristics important but not needlessly difficult to learn is brilliant.The crafting mechanic is simple and useful. The amount of steep and hazardous ground and easy going terrain is well balanced. The need for light sources is well thought out but not unduly taxing. After dying on day 1.5 on my first play through I was embarassed (stood too close to a fire and burned to death). My second play through I was mauled to death by a black bear on day 59 hour 22. I was equally embarassed, I KNOW bears extremely well - what the hell was I thinking? Now I am approaching 250 days of survival.Some advice to new players: Just like in the real outdoors there are the obvious needs of shelter, food and water. But the real key to survival is caution and patience. Don't push that extra two hours into the hills if the weather looks sketchy. Don't take a shot unless you have the near perfect or perfect angle. You can always go exploring the next day when the weather is better and there is always another deer or bear to take tomorrow.Great game Hinterland, love it. 9.5/10

Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is a survival-crafting game based somewhere in the Canadian Yukon where the player is dropped into a depopulated tundra when an unexpected magnetic resonance causes his plane to crash. Survival is the name of the game and you will need to carefully plan your movements and actions to conserve as much of your food, drink, energy, and warmth if you want to survive.The game is basically a metered survival mode that you might be familiar with if you’ve played games like Rust or DayZ. In addition to the typical food/drink/rest gauges, you also have a warmth meter that must be satisfied by keeping in warm places and/or wearing warm clothing, to prevent risk of hypothermia. Like the aforementioned games, there is an underlying crafting system where you collect various items and combine them to make different things or to repair tools and clothing, which are worn down through use or misuse.There are a few wandering packs of wolves and solitary bears who will make your life miserable if you are foolish enough to get close to them but generally they’re pretty easy to avoid and, unless you are overburdened, you should be able to sprint away from them to safety so long as there is a cabin nearby or if you have some bait to drop as a distraction. Other than that the main “combat” in this game is you versus nature and time. Smart players will plan the use of available daylight with maximum efficiency, leaving hours of darkness purely for resting and campfire-related activities.That’s really about it. I kind of wish there were more things to do in TLD or more ways of achieving the same effect. For example, in order to forge arrowheads you have to have coal, scrap metal, and a heavy hammer. I would have liked it if there was a more time consuming way of using a rock or some other improvised device so I would have something to carry me over until I found the requisite hammer. You also have to rely on snares to catch wildlife without weapons which in turn require that you kill or harvest guts from existing wildlife. Not a huge problem but with all the cotton and leather I kept finding, and random cars which clearly had their internals still present, you’d think I could make some sort of alternative trap. Just a bit of cleverness would be all that’s needed to turn this from an okay game into a really great game (that and maybe a co-op multiplayer function).  As it stands, most people will figure out how to survive practically forever, especially if they are lucky enough to kill a bear yielding massive amounts of raw meat. Once you get into that kind of situation, all the stress behind surviving goes right out the window and you end up spending your time making up your own goals instead of being guided by the game. I’m sure this is something that will be remedied by story mode but in the meantime I will have to regard this game as half-finished.I still recommend The Long Dark, though, as the devs have been pretty good at bringing in new content and the majority of my gripes will probably be resolved with story mode wherein tool scarcity and lack of alternatives won’t matter so much. Consider picking this one up on sale if you’d like to spend 10-15 hours roleplaying Tom Hanks’ Canadian cousin.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								How to Make Grizzly Adams WeepLike all well-designed games, the best gear in The Long Dark isn't looted, it's crafted. In a game where the weather is the biggest threat to survival, it makes good sense that animal hides will ultimately provide the best protection. It begins simply enough with rabbit skin mittens. Rabbits won't fight back or scar you mentally, despite what the Looney Tunes propaganda would have you believe. These require 4 pelts that have been cured by air drying indoors for 3 in-game days. This is followed by 5 hours of crafting time.Crafting progresses from there, the next obvious choice are deer skin pants and boots. The cure and crafting times are elevated and already you begin to see that planning ahead is a very real component for your survival. Once you have these 3 items you will notice much better protection from the elements and you are now prepared for the ultimate in survival fashion: the wolf skin jacket. You have to fell 4 wolves in order to have enough materials, and now your crafting time is up to 25 hours! With these 4 items equipped you feel pretty invulnerable to all but the most severe of weather, you have mastered your environment! Wait a minute, what's this? A schematic for a bear skin bedroll...Hunting bears with a bolt-action rifle with less than enough rounds to fill a six-shooter isn't going to be a walk in the park. But on top of the potential to survive outdoors during a blizzard there is an achievement for this. Never let it be said that achievement whoring is without it's merit!I spent a week frequenting areas where bears have been sighted in Mystery Lake (the beginner's map). I never saw or heard a bear, so I made some tough decisions regarding carry weight and made the long, dangerous trek to Pleasant Valley. The trip was relatively uneventful, exactly as I prefer it, aside from one accidental fight with my campfire which burned my left hand severely and reduced my health to 75% for days. I set up camp in a centrally-located farmhouse and intended to rest up and then begin gathering firewood, setting snares and generally preparing for a lengthy bear hunt.The next morning I go out to check the weather (no shrieking winds from indoors is always nice to wake up to) and lumbering directly towards me about 50 meters away was 300 pounds of black bear! I immediately crouch, line up a head shot, and have second thoughts wondering if I'll have time to get off a 2nd shot if the first one isn't enough to put him down. I relax my in-real-life breathing and hands, line up a perfect head shot... squeeze and immediately begin reloading when... the bear just drops. It was rather anti-climatic and I reckoned myself now a seasoned bear hunter. Hubris never hurt anyone right?The next day I could hear a bear far to my north or what I thought was north, I would need to confirm that at sunset. I had only been here less than a day and with no maps, compasses or moss on trees the only directional indicator is sunrise/set.The next day I woke up to such screeching sounds of wind I didn't even bother going outside to see for myself. The blizzard continued all through the next day as well. I was forced to risk a trip out to carve off more bear flesh, of which there was such a massive amount available it would ultimately begin to go moldy before I could consume it all.On day 3 I set out towards the direction the bear sounds had come from. It's no wonder I never saw a bear at Mystery Lake, they apparently all migrated here because in less than 2 hours I saw my second black bear on top of a ridge. I circled around to approach him from behind, the crouch is agonizingly slow but the only way to ensure you get the initiative. I shouldn't have been surprised when the bear pulled a Crazy Ivan, everyone knows all bears are originally indigenous to Russia. I repeated exactly what I'd done with bear number 1, squeezed and... the bear was charging right for me. I didn't realize TLD had a science fiction-y time slowing mechanic but I'm pretty sure I trigged one because it took about 4 times longer than normal to reload my rifle. The bear was so close when I fired my second shot I could only see his snout in my sights. He dropped and I only had to take a single shaky step forward to begin the long process of harvesting him.I now have the 2 required bear skins to make my fancy bedroll. I spent a couple days at a nearby barn before heading back to my farmhouse base of operations to check on the curing time of my first bear skin. I lost track but it was an incredible amount of time, more than a week. As I approached my base I couldn't believe what I saw: another black bear not 100 meters from where my first had been! Now a rational thought would be leave well enough alone, however another game mechanic sprung to mind the second I saw him: decay. All items decay and in the case of your crafted items they require like materials to repair. So felling a 3rd bear is just common sense, and I am quite the expert now.I repeat the process, crouch, line up so his travel is directly towards me. It was snowing at a good but not blizzard-like pace, so I allowed the bear to get a bit closer before squeezing the trigger. I immediately begin a reload this time, and good thing I did because once again it was going to take more than 1 shot. Damn, this bear is moving a little quicker and he was a little closer, this is going to be an epic last-second sho-- the bear is on me. He knocked the rifle out of my hands and pinned me to the ground. It was incredibly violent, the screen blurring and dimming at times, my body flung face-down into the snow at others. What was most disturbing was how long the assault went on for. I was certain when the screen began to fade that I was dying, which was partially true. Suddenly the bear lost interest for some reason and lumbered directly over my prone body. As soon as the game would let me I pulled myself into a crawling position and started making my way for the farm house only 25 meters away. Then I noticed my condition: I am bleeding out at an incredible rate, when I first checked my health was at 15% and now 30 seconds later it's at 9%. I pull up my medical supplies menu, quite thankful now I hadn't managed to talk myself out of devoting so much space to medical supplies, and had just enough to stop the bleedout and stabilize my condition.The devastation was real and not just medically. The bear shredded all of my animal skin gear, some of it as low as 25% condition and all of the protection ratings minimal. It took the better part of 2 weeks of hunting, curing, and crafting to get everything into the 80% range (whereas it had all been in the high 90s). I also managed to see why the bear had stopped mauling me: he bled out slightly faster than I did. I have nicknamed the Pleasant Valley Farmhouse location Bear Highway.So, no more hubris from this huntsman, I have learned my lesson very well. I'm not sure I'll hunt another black bear during this play through (where my goal now is 100 days of survival), instead I'll probably ask myself what would Grizzly Adams do? And then I won't do that either because none of these bears are interested in a relationship that doesn't end with you in their belly.

Early Access Review
								This is my edited review to commemorate the 1-year mark since The Long Dark (TLD) came out on early access. That's not to say that the game is neglected. Quite the opposite. In the year since the game first hit Steam Early Access there have been 49 major updates and hotfixes. That averages to nearly one update per week for a year. Hinterland (the devs) have done the opposite of abandoning TLD.The game is beautiful and immersive. The sounds are gorgeous and occasionally bone-chilling. The devs consistently look at what the players request while not doing anything that would compromise their artistic vision for a lovely game. They have said that they are working towards a thoughtful single player, story mode experience, and while TLD is still only available in sandbox alpha everything they do to the game appears to be moving towards that goal. You can die due to freezing, falling, failing to light a fire, wolf, bear, bear and then wolf, falling off a cliff while running from a wolf, falling through the ice, starving at your campfire, dehydration, exhaustion, food poisoning, dysentery, exhaustion or... you know, stuff and things. The game wont hold your hand and it's not a quick fix. And I love it. At almost 400 hours of of game time, I'm still not bored with the game.

Early Access Review
								1st attempt at survival-Everything was going well. It was 2 days since the event, and I had collected some decent clothing, had a good supply of food, and sodas, and was surviving well. I had come across an abandoned dam, so I scavenged it for anything I might be able to use and decided to make it my "base" for a short time, to aquaint myself with the surroundings and get an idea of where I might go next. 2 days passed of me scouting the general area and my supplies ran low so I decided to head out, following a set of train tracks into the unknown. I came to a collapsed tunnel just as night descended so I built a fire with what scraps I had and decided to sleep for an hour or two. I had ran out of sodas at this point and hadn't realized that I could melt snow for hydration. My health had deteriorated quickly. I froze to death in my sleep.2nd attempt at survival-Day 4 since the event and I've figured out how to melt snow for a water source. I have food, water, and my clothes are in great shape. I delve into a cave and come out the other end to a forested hillside. There was a wolf right in the middle, and I thought "I'll tangle with him, take his meat and hide, and be on my way". We struggled briefly and I injured him, so he ran over a small ridge to get away, and I got up and gave chase. I get to the top of the ridge and look down the other side to see him running straight at me. I'm like "You won't get away this time!". He runs right past me, bleeding everywhere. A giant bear comes running up shortly after, chasing the wolf, then turns on me and chews my stomach to shreds. I already took a good hit from my fight with the wolf, but I managed to survive the bear attack with 6% condition. I roll over bleeding and coughing and manage to get to my feet, and by the time I stood up and attempted first aid, the last bit of life force had drained from me, and I headed straight for The Long Dark.TL;DRGreat game, would definitely recommend to anyone.

Early Access Review
								I am in love.This is it. This is the game I've been looking for. And the best part, it isn't even complete yet.Let's get started.I've had this growing interest on survival games for quite a while now, and as such, I've been looking for survival games everywhere to try out, and not more than one or two have captivated me (I could name which, but doesn't feel right on a review of another game). The Long Dark gripped me in, and oh boy, did it grip me tight.The graphics are amazing, has a great feeling to it, and not too cartoonish, or too realistic. Very well polished.The soundtrack will keep you interested, and every sound will keep you on your toes, wondering if there's a wolf nearby, or a storm coming. Basically, death is on every corner.The design itself is just brilliant. I've had the chance to play about 6 sandbox games, and I decided to go in "blind", not reading anything or checking any maps. Survived 1h56mins the first time, and about 2h10mins the second time. Needless to say, wolves got me (and of those hours, one might have been sleeping!). I then decided to get some brains, and see how I could counter those wolves. Great success, stayed alive for 6hours! Until a storm killed me. From there on, I survived for days, being my current record nearly 8 days. I admit I could easily survive for a bit longer, by being smart and stashing "useless" stuff on a cabin locker, but I'm a hoarder! (all of the playthroughs were on medium difficulty, I can't even imagine the hard one!)I do have one suggestion, there should be a two player co-op mode, that would be amazing, for when you don't want to feel as lonely. Or else I'll just keep going (Hans) Solo, and immerse myself into this AMAZINGLY brutal and harsh game, that will leach the life out of me. Over and over again.TL;DR - I love this game. I recommend this game. You will love this game.PS. Wolves have a soft spot for me, and always seem to find me at the "right" time.This is it. This is the game. I am in love.

Posted: April 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a revamped review of The Long Dark.Like my Darkest Dungeon review, most early access games will either remain unpolished or the state of the game will become less shape than before.The Long Dark however is a different story, It's one of those early access games. That patches as you go along, while also providing the developers feedback along the way both good and bad. While there is no story mode, Sandbox mode provides you a glimpse as to what you will be experiencing within story mode once it's released.You can see just how "hardcore" the game is. This is in a sense a true Hardcore Surivial game. Sure people can play it on easy, but where is the fun in that? For the true Long Dark experience play on medium or hard. And you can see why The Long Dark remains a very highly postive game. All you have is your senses and wit as you surive the candian wilderness. There is no compass, no GPS, no fast travel, no general store to trade. Just you and mother nature. And your instinct to survive The artistic visuals in the game is amazing and detailed. Plus a very active translation steam workshop community in order to get the game out to other steam players who want to play this game but within their own native language. Hopefully, we will see somewhere down the line with more mods besides translations. Also like with the Darkes Dungeon it's a trial by error experience, you learn as you fail and vice versa. You need to be a critcal thinker and plan ahead in a game like this. Because if you don't, you will most likely die by the hands of nature. Or become deperived of food and drink supplies which by the way are randomly generated throughout the three maps. So don't expect each map to have the same stuff in the same location. You are also randomly teleported to a part of the map, while the terrain will remain the same, everything else will be different.There are two issues that i have with the game. The first issue is it's "struggle" mechanic. Maybe change it to tapping a particular key, instead of relying on the mouse button.How it goes, it goes like this....RMB (It could be LMB) is to charge upLMB (It could be RMB) to attackSure you could have weapons to give you an edge, but it won't do any much good. Use your brain power, rather than your weapons, this isn't Skyrim kiddies.The other issue is the lack of 'saves' now this question has been asked plenty of times and it is being considered. This game goes on the bases of Dragon's Dogma. Where it's one save per character, but it doesn't run like a typical Fallout or Elder Scroll game or just about any game with a mutiple save option. One save for everything basically, which sucks but that's the whole point of Hardcore survival you need to heavily rely on taking the game slowly and don't treat it like a typical RPG game.Lastly, The game doesn't hold your hand as well. So don't expect a tutorial. The Sandbox in every sense. IS the tutorial, since story mode isn't out yet. So pay close attention to your surroundings and you will be fine. Another thing is that the steam community has been very supportive in giving the tools you need to survive. Just hit up the guide section if your lost, because i can seriously tell you. You will need those guides.I recommend this game if you love a true Hardcore Survival Experience.

Early Access Review
The Long, Long, Long, Very Long Dark.OverviewThe Long Dark is single-handedly one of the best games I've ever played. Even in its Early Access state, it never fails to impress on the level of entertainment it provides. And boy, does it provide a lot of it.But like all great games, it's not without its flaws. Very few of them, but they are there.The PositivesCan I just say "everything"? No? Okay.1) Never had I played a game that awakened the empathetic man in me. When my character is cold, I feel freezing, even in the summer. As soon as he starts shivering, my toes go numb. When he yawns, my eyes go heavy. When he makes a fire, I suddenly want to cook s'mores. When a wolf bites him, it's biting me. I can feel the pain. I can feel the desperation of searching for that next pit stop in search of canned peaches. I connect so well with the protagonist that I fear for his life, for it's not only his, but ours I must save. When he's in danger, I want to protect him, and his ultimate demise fills me with dread. Rarely does a game make me feel this way, so... f***ing kudos, Hinterland.2) The graphics are unlike any I've ever seen. They resemble colorful construction paper, pasted on a vibrant charcoal background. The uniqueness of it provides a sense of overall joy. It feels real, and yet, doesn't. A very surreal take.3) The uncomplicated utilities menu, encumberance system, and status screen. I seriously hit tab constantly, even when I don't need to.4) Commander Shepard.5) The entire world map is expansive and daunting. Just when I think I'm about to pass out and die, I come across a cave, or hidden cabin. Again that feeling of hope and excitement when I actually find an abandoned house is unsurpassed.6) Commander Shepard.7) Random item placements to give an even bigger boost to survival for when you start a new game. There's no memorizing this one, folks. You're on your own.8) Did I mention Commander Shepard?9) Hunting and harvesting. Skill-ups in particular things, like stiching and making fire. I love the feeling of improvement and progression, and I think they nailed it.The Negatives1) Unfortunately, I have to address that this game has been out for, I think, years now? There's still no story mode, and I have no idea when it's going to be released. The sandbox is entertaining for a little while, and you'll be testing yourself to push it to the limit every time, but a story really would be great for a game like this. Especially when it comes to playing two separate roles.2) How I want to feel when a wolf comes near me:


YouTube™ Video: Bourne Legacy | The Wolf Scene | Jeremy Renner 

			Views: 194,953		

			Aaron Cross goes head to head with a wolf while simultaneously avoiding an attempted drone attack on his life. Double Take: film-loving duo James King and Karen Krizanovich get up close and personal...		

How it REALLY is when a wolf comes near me:


YouTube™ Video: Frozen Wolf Attack Scene 

			Views: 69,133		

			6th scariest movie moment midnightterrors		

Don't let me look, don't let me look-- OH GOD I LOOKED!Seriously though, when it comes to the wolf attacks-- which make up for about 98% of my deaths-- some of them are just plain ridiculous. I once found a wolf inside of a building. Yes, THE WOLF WAS CAMPING INSIDE OF A BUILDING. How did it get in? I have no idea. No shattered windows, all doors closed. It's a mystery. I could have made it that one time, if not for a f***ing wolf hiding in a building.Without wolf attacks, I seem to do just fine, really. I'm on my fifth game or so, and I've decided to wuss out and play it on Pilgrim. So far I've lived for over five days. It's still some pretty tough stuff, and still pretty threatening. Just in different ways. I almost died of hypothermia one night.ConclusionsThis game is awesome, and I definitely want to see more of it. I can't wait to play more. It's become almost a nightly ritual to huddle up at my computer, curl up in a blanket, listen to the sound of a looping crackling campfire and play The Long Dark!

Early Access Review
								TL;DR at the bottom-I don't even know where to begin with this game.I'd heard about it a while back and I saw it, thought it looked kinda interesting, and then never bothered picking it up. My friend recently gifted it to me and if I could I would have been willing to spend up to $45 or so for the experience this game tosses at you. The only thing I can say now is that I regret not picking it up sooner. It just hits me in such a way that I can't explain. Everytime I'm walking slowly down a road and there's nothing but cars to the side and burnt houses around, and that ♥♥♥♥ing guitar picks up I just get so into it and feel like I'm actually a survivor.The Long Dark is a gem among early access games and deserves so much attention. I knew this as soon as I'd put in a good hour. Let me start off by saying that the immersion that this game delivers is phenomenal. It has a great tone and world design to be used for story telling. While the game offers no tutorial and this can be a positive or negative thing, I personally loved it. All it did was make me genuinely want to learn about the game and the world itself more, and as I did, I felt myself get better at it and feel more confident about surviving. The longest time I've survived so far on a character is 30 days counting and there's been numerous points throughout that timespan in which I thought I was going to die and got anxious doing something because I genuinely felt like I was the person wandering through the world. Each time I spotted a bear in the distance or a pack of wolves, I felt like they were a genuine threat and therefore considered my options. Do I try to sneak around them? Do I head in the opposite direction? Do I have ammo or a weapon to fend them off just in case? This doesn't even just count with the wildlife but the environment as well which I cannot stress just how important in a survival game. Every time I saw a side road leading off of the main highway I seriously considered my options. Did I have enough food and water with me in case it's a dead end? Do I have enough daylight left to make it back to the main road if there's nothing down this way? Will I have enough firewood and tinder to create a fire if need be? When I would be staying in a cabin for the day due to a blizzard, I would genuinely consider my options then as well and think to myself if I had enough food to survive the night before I would be able to scavenge for more supplies? The game pushes you to think about these options in a way that I've never felt another survival game do before.The game does an incredible job at atmosphere and aesthetic and is downright GORGEOUS from every early sunrise and darkening sunset to each howling blizzard or each bright sunny day. The more you're willing to immerse yourself into believing you're truly surviving in the world, the better job it does at delivering a truly special experience. There was a point in which I'd found a safe and when I was trying to crack the code, I actually leaned in on my monitor as though I'd be able to hear the clicks better without realizing it. When there's a blizzard in the game and all you can hear is lonesome ambient guitar music playing and the wind howling in you ear, you feel genuinely alone and feel cold. When you enter a cabin and all you can hear is the wind beating against the house and the creaks of wood echoing, it creates a sense of fear and paranoia because you know that there were people who are probably long dead that used to live here. When you’re walking through a cave and all you can hear is the vast echoes of your footsteps against stone and the hiss of your flare, you feel genuinely cautious.The fact that the game is able to pull this off is absolutely stunning. And above all, you genuinely feel like you're a survivor in this new world. You begin to grow attached to your character and genuinely care for them and begin to wonder if you can truly survive the wilderness. The game does an excellent job at small little stories you can pick up on when you're not expecting it. For example you can find a cave in which there's a small campfire with food beside it, or you can be walking through the woods and find a frozen corpse of a man with an axe next to a deer corpse, insisting he died of hypothermia while trying to get food. It's all of these little things that come together that truly help create an enjoyable experience and make me want to get out there and explore the world in front of me. When you walk through a town you begin to really have thoughts of, "I wonder what happened to the people that lived here. I wonder what the story of the people who made it out is" and it's like that for nearly every place.The only two downsides to this game for me at least are there's been few bugs in which I would climb a rock and randomly sprain my ankles or wrists for no reason and it's pretty immersion breaking. And secondly, there's no randomly generated maps and all loot spawns are always the same regardless of if you were to make a new character or not. If they were to add randomly generated loot and maps, I could play this game for literal hundreds of hours not to say I already plan to, but it would definitely help with the game in the long run and keep me coming back to it.In short, this game is truly something special for the person that wants to immerse themselves in a world where they feel like they're truly a survivor in the wilderness with nothing but their own decisions on what's best to help you survive the long dark.TL;DRPros-Breathtakingly beautifulIncredible sound designIs a true to it's roots "you versus the wilderness" gameDownright one of the most immersive games I've ever playedDecent amount of replayability with new characters you can create and difficulties to choose fromDevs actually seem to care about this gameDependent on you-No tutorialPretty unforgiving, if you die it's over even if you survived over 100 daysCons-No story mode as of this review, only sandbox (though one is supposed to be added later)Few immersion breaking bugs such as randomly breaking ankles and wrists for no apparent reason

Early Access Review
								There are things that I like about this game, like the beautiful scenery and the brutally hash winter conditions, that feels very realistic for me, living in northern Sweden, where winter is hell on Earth and life is difficult enough even during the summer. I also appreciate the extreme difficulty the game offers and have spent some 60+ hours playing it. However, as much as I like some aspects of the game, I feel that this game is far from being finished (after 2 years in  EA!) as there is little or no point to playing it. After a few weeks of surviving it becomes boring and repetitive. You will soon get tired of just surviving without some higher goal to aim for.Something that I especially hate about this game is the extremly unrealistic behaivor of wolfs and the constant need to kill these fine animals because they act much more like mindless zombies or rabid dogs than like real wolfs. I think this is an unjustified shortcut for the developers to bring some kind of action to this game. I would much have prefered stray gangs of cannibals, or even zombies, since it would be much more realistic, and I don't even like zombies very much... To be attacked by one stray rabid dog after another even when I try my best to avoid them, often three dogs in a row, all with the same outcome - my cloths getting worn out and the dog dies - it is irritating and not much fun at all. And it happens over and over again, no matter how many you kill. This irritated me to the point when I finally decided to delete all saved games and completely uninstalled the product. It is a pity for an otherwise well made game product that the developers have made this in my mind bad design choice, probably only due to lack of action in the game. I saw a documentary once, about a guy who made a documentary film about wolfs and he spent 3 months without ever even seeing a wolf. Finally he got to film one wolf, but only far off in the distance. That is how rare wolfs are today and they will do anything they can to stay far away from humans.  This animal has been driven to the brink of extinction by the rentless and often cruel hunting and it is very sad to see a game in which the game play promotes the hunting and killing of wolfs at the same time as it is sold as a " realistic simluation". This feels totally obnoxious and breaks the suspence of disbelief that is so important to a good game.In summary, this is a game, not a simulation, that is in part very realistic and at the same time in some ways totally unrealistic. It is fun in the beginning, but becomes boring after a while, since there is little to do except surviving. Once you have explored the maps, it all is the same each time you play. Nothing much to craft either. The end game is when your cloths wear out and/or your tools break down, and then you die. That's it. A pity, since I feel that this game could be so much more. I would NOT recommend this game in its current state and I hope that it will be reworked and improved since it is still in EA.

Posted: March 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is a magnificent game, but beyond that, it's an engaging and fulfilling experience. You can put yourself in a frantic push for every minute of survival, or just soak in the aesthetic of the Canadian wilderness.  Each iteration plays and feels different, and the rogue-like style of death makes every decision matter.  The gameplay is exhilarating, the visual style gorgeous, and with regular updates from the good folks of Hinterland Studios, you can't go wrong.  I've enjoyed every minute I've put into this title and look forward to spending many more.  That said, this game isn't perfect.  A range of possible strategies for long term survival exists, but use of the rifle so thoroughly outclasses everything else that gameplay tends to revolve around it.  But this game is still in Early Access and the developers are quite active, so quite a bit can be changed and honed.The best part of this game though, and the reason I play, is that infinite survival is impossible.  That may seem a strange statement, and I know some people would love to see the game changed on that point, but hear me out.  Every time you begin, you know you will die.  There is nothing that can be done about that impermanence, about death.  Now, you can choose to curl into a ball, to let life pass you by, or you can choose to live, to fight, to find beauty in the harsh landscape and nobility in yourself.  I've never played with mechanics that so powerfully counterbalanced realistic nihilism with idealistic determination, and so I congratulate Hinterland on their work.  That got a little philosophically dramatic, but I stand by it.  Overall, I deeply enjoy this game and look forward to watching its progression, and offer my sincerest recommendation to potential buyers.

Early Access Review
								In the frozen wasteland of the formerly prosperous country of Canada, you alone must survive The Long Dark. This winter seems endless, so it's not a matter of if you survive it; it's a matter of how long. The Long Dark is a game developed and published by Hinterland Studio, focusing primarily on surviving in Canada after a climate disaster. Right now it's in early access and the story mode isn't complete, but its sandbox mode gives more than enough to talk about.The objective of the game is simple: you're abandoned out in the middle of nowhere in a random location and you must find a way to survive. The world is freezing and you must find food, shelter, water and keep yourself going for as long as you possibly can. While this sounds pretty straightforward, it isn't because there are plenty of factors in the game that can kill you and if you're unfamiliar with the game, and when starting out you're going to have a bad time.Full Preview[www.noobfeed.com]

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Man,I really like this game a lot. I know it's still in Early Access, and there will be a lot of changes still upcoming (the story mode is the one I am most looking to personally), but the game in its current state is still absolutely a ton of fun. You basically crash land in an Arctic area, that was previously inhabited but now abandoned (I expect the reasons for this will be revealed through the story mode). You are woefully unprepared for the weather conditions and have to find better clothing, equipment, food, and water in order to survive another day...and more days beyond that. The environment is reasonably vast. You can definitely explore all the areas the game has to offer, but since you also have to manage your food, sleep, water, and so on...it will take a while or many playthroughs to do so.The character management is pretty simple and yet clever. You basically monitor your calorie count, which indicates your need for food, your dehydration levels (need for water), your restfulness (as in, you will have to sleep sometime), and your body temperature. All factor in fairly equally as far as your survivability goes. You can find places to rest and recover, can find gear such as can openers, hatchets, etc...to increase your odds. You can also obviously find food (in various state of freshness....the worse condition your food is in, the more likely it is that you will get sick if you eat it). There is medicine to be found, and even some weapons (hatchet, knife, hunting rifle, flares), that will be necessary, as there are also wolves that view you as a tasty morsel, lol. Additionally, there is a pretty intuitive crafting system in the game which allows you to break down, repair, or create items. This becomes very important as the days progress.So, that just scratches the surface of what this game has to offer. You are fighting hunger, the cold, wolves, dehydration, and weariness in order to survive from one day to the next. The decisions you make will impact how long you survive each day and are very meaningful. Even the most mundane act can have real repercussions. The game does offer an easy mode so you can get the hang of things before going for full survival. Easy mode features more resources and you can turn off the wolves hostility as well (so they just run away from you instead). It's not a bad way to get your feelers out in this game. However, the game really shines as it is intended...resource management and survival.I very much recommend this game, even in its early access state. By far my favorite game in the genre presently, with a lot more potential to come on top of what is already provided.9 out of 10.

Don't get me wrong we need the challenge but killing people off after six days of survival is nuts. Just because people survive longer doesn't make the challenge of doing better than others go away.-Food posioning. Wow. I have never experienced food posioning before in rl thank goodness but the food posioning on here is crazzzzzy. I have about 30lbs of deer meat in my garage refrig and I cook it and eat it a lot. On here in one life I suffered from food posioning 7 times. 1 from a soda? 5 from cooked deer and once from cooked wolf. I understand it's a problem in real life but I think making it that bad is a little crazy...-Sleep cycle is just crazy, you will understand-I'm sure theres more of these too but due to a recent accident of nearly cutting my thumb off I am getting tired of one hand typing...My recommendations:-You are releasing a new map so if the progress keeps up I imagine map size won't dissapoint me.-Randomize spawns for containers and frozen bodies-Get rid of durability on metal tools that makes no sense on breakage ex. can opener, crowbar, hunting knife, and maybe make the hatchet a little less♥♥♥♥♥♥ I mean I cut wood on my tree farm couple times a year before winter with a axe and have only replaced it once every couple of years with maybe like 1 fix of the head for every 200 peices of firewood? Or you could increase the number of wood you gain?-Make the game real life experience. 3 days water 3 weeks food. This means yes you get dehydrated before 3 days and yes you begin to get frail increasing fatigue and impossibility of working on certain projects. Ultimately leading to bedrest if not prevnted. If I was dying of thirst in this game and actually lasted 2 days longer than when it began while laying on my bed I wouldn't be upset. Same with food.If you want illnesses to prevent easy survival then dull your current illnesses percentages to the %'s in real life and add things like you can't eat too much in one sitting or you will throw up or gain fatigue, same with water but different effects. Just extra research would make this mechanic much more survival like.-Sleep... I sleep for about 6 hours everyday and can last till night which is pretty good since 8 is recommended. I understand trekking through snow is tough and wastes energy but why is it that I can go to a bed sleep 8 hours and my exhaustion/fatigue is still not close to the minimum? I might understand if you are suffering from sleep deprivation and need to sleep longer to recover but most time I oversleep it has the same effects on me as if I undersleep. Also maybe add a slight like 1% chance to have a power nap? And make it so when your sleep is at the minimum its hard to get more sleep? Finally my last point and something I am actually not familiar with. Temperature in Canada. Is this literally winter? Can you survive in to spring? By a quick look on environmental sites posted I found that the temps this game show are way out of wack. Also Are blizzards this common? Don't know these answeres but I am hoping that this can be explained by a climate shift due to the nuclear strikes or whatever?Overall this game is fantastic for the stage it's in with an even more promising future. I understand that I nailed a lot of my dislikes and did not capitalize on the fun it has brought me but I only am doing that for a possibility of helping the future progression. I also understand this was not easy to create and my ideas may be too much time to put forth the effort again only suggestions.Get this game, play it when you aren't mad about it. Enjoy the tough survival aspect and show up all of your friends! Hope my review helps and please comment with what you think about it or the game. I would love to have some conversations!Update:Also in response to a new review up there on the charts. (Stormrhodos). This guy is only complaining because he once again did not follow what this game is about. Intelligence. Tinder can be found easily by newpaper and warming up is easy if you just sleep for around an hour or two inside. Also foraging for wood and freezing? Forage on a warm day and in a shelter to protect from wind. Better yet forage inside! You know that furniture you complain you cant break and use? That's reclaimed wood baby and thats exactly what you get from foraging inside! Oh and rifle is rare? Its 100% spawn rate in homestead which if you were intelligent while playing you would notice. This game has a lot of secrets and once again if you use your brain while playing you will find them out and probably have a pretty successful run. If you would do it in real life then think about it in the game chances are its smarter than the other option. Don't let these reviews fool you because this game is great! Just know it's still early access.

content:

Early Access Review
What is The Long Dark?The Long Dark is first-person open world exploration-survival game that occurs in the canadian wilderness after a global disaster.Your job is to survive as long as you can by gathering food and drink that you can find in the various cabins and huts scattered around the map. What am I surviving from?Nature and all its threats (What threats? -> Animals such as wolves & bears, and the most natural threat of them... the cold)Is there a crafting system?There is a crafting system, but as of now its quite simplistic.To craft items you'll have to find a workbench. (Some location spoilers: Trapper's Homestead, Camp Office, Carter Hydro Dam, Forestry Lookout (Mystery Lake) - The Fishing Camp, Quonset Gas Station, (Coastal Highway) - Pleasant Valley Farmstead (Pleasant Valley)) Workbenches are used to craft clothing, weapons and first aid, items such as coats, a bow, arrows, mittens, etc.Cooking systemTo cook, you must start a fire either outside or inside cabins/huts at stoves.You can also melt snow to water and boil it.First aidThis is needed when you have food poisoning or a wolf/bear has attacked you and caused injuries.To use first aid you'll have to press tab (default button) and click the medical kit in the selection menu that will open.Afterwards you can choose which injury you would like to treat first.Fatigue and ColdThese can be seen by pressing tab (default button) in the bottom right of the menu that opens up.FATIGUE:[/b]Your fatigue will be increased after performing various actions (such as crafting, harvesting, etc.) once the bar on the tab-menu is completely filled you will no longer have the ability to sprint, (untill you have slept and you are no longer exhausted) in extreme cases your vision will become blurry and condition will decline untill you have rested, theres also a slight chance of dying by fatigue.COLD:[/b] Cold consists of Air Temperature, Windchill, Insulation of clothing and Wind protection of clothing.Your overall temperature is the air temperature plus windchill minus the effects of clothing on windchill and temperature. As the cold bar on the tab-menu you will get warnings and verbal complaints of the cold. If the bar completely fills up you will start losing condition which can lead to death if not looked after.[/list]ClothingYou can craft clothing and find clothing.Repairing clothing requires cloth and a sewing kit and can be done while accessing your inventory, selecting the piece of clothing that needs to be repaired and pressing "action", this will bring up a menu saying harvest and repair. It speaks for itself that you'll have to click repair in order to repair the piece of clothing. Harvesting clothing will give you cloth.Thanks for reading trough my review.Please leave comments if you think I should have added even more :)~ Hobo
