Posted: November 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								I used to play this game when it first came out. I died. All. The. Time. And the world was much much smaller - 1 map to be exact. I liked the concept, but got bored and frustrated (frustored? borstrated?) and quit and haven't looked at it since.When it went on sale recently, my husband pointed it out to me as the type of game I usually like and asked if I owned it. I said I had and mumbled something about not bothering... He brought it up again the other day, asking if I had seen if there had been any changes or updates since I played it last.So I cracked it open...and have been obsessed with it for days on end. I had to apologize to hubby for advising him against getting it when it was on sale. But it's on his radar now. His only disappointment is that it is only single player and we can't survive together (we play 7 Days to Die together extensively, for example, as we favor co-op survival).The game is Alpha, so is under active development and some of the mechanics and balance may be off in some players' opinions. For myself, I find it enjoyable, and have found that the addition of the new maps, and three different game modes/difficulty levels, have given this game whole new life and an opportunity for gamers of many stripes to enjoy playing. If you are not a fan of inventory management as a primary element, then you may not like this game. Your inventory is weight based, food and tools spoil over time, and you are battling the elements and mother nature (wolve and bears, oh my!) for survival. A large chunk of the tension of survival in this game hinges on having to make tough choices about what to carry with you and what to leave behind, what to repair or to scrap and harvest the resources, what to use now or try and preserve for later (with the chance it will degrade beyond reasonable use in the meantime). It's a complex combination of factors to consider, which I find compelling, but is essentially inventory management. So just be aware.Also, this game will NOT offer you running around, banging out shiny items on the toolbench, hack n' slash melee, or shoot 'em up guns blazing. This game requires a lot of patience. Resources must be gathered over time, hides and wood cured before fashioning into needed clothes and tools. There are no endless bullet stashes, or a promise of ever finding a gun. But if you find a gun and bullets, you might have two rounds to your name and they are precious--you can't make any more bullets, and your gun will wear out eventually. Tools and clothing degrade with use and must be repaired often to maintain them. If your hatchet breaks, you can't make another. Animals are predatory and will tear your precious clothing and cause bleeding and infections--I need not tell you medicines are scarce and also lose efficacy/degrade with time, and natural remedies can be hard to procure. Eating spoiled food can give you severe food poisoning, leaving you bedridden for hours on end. Frequent blinding blizzards can turn you around, leaving you lost and struggling to stay warm enough. And if you can't find adequate wind shielding you can't start a fire to save your life (literally). Running will tire you out, make you hungry and thirsty faster, and resources are limited. If you're too tired and come across a hungry wolf, you won't be able to run away, so you preserve your energies should you need them in a pinch. Getting across this desolate, snowy terrain can be slow and even boring at times. Funny enough, it adds to the atmosphere for me that you must trudge, with purpose and restraint, toward your next shelter because to rush it risks death.The graphics are lovely--something between a watercolor painting and paper cutouts. The ambient sounds and occasional music really add to the atmosphere and are not at all intrusive. In fact, keep your ears pricked because you may be able to hear that storm whipping up. When you are indoors, you can hear the shutters rattle, indicating a blizzard has swept through, so stay inside if you want to live. Even the quietest snarl or howl can indicate a wold is on your tail, so drop some meat as a decoy and get outta there fast. Make no mistake, the weather is a character itself in this game, and you want to get to know her voice.I look forward to seeing how this game evolves. As of this review, Story Mode has not been released. They have been promising it would drop by the end of 2015, which is coming up fast, so I am keeping my eyes peeled for some storied content in the near future. In the meantime, the sandbox mode is more than entertaining, and I recommend survivalist gamers give it a try.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark (TLD) is, without a doubt, one of my favorite games of all time. The art and environment are beautiful. The audio work is masterfully created and constantly evolving. The game mechanics are refined, but could use further tweaking, which I have full confidence in Hinteland Studios to do.Although without currently a story mode, TLD sandbox mode provides a self-generated emotional experience that tickles your visceral senses. This is the perfect game for fans of survival-themed TV shows, which would be me, or those who simply appreciate the challenges that natures heaves. Your "enemies" in this game are the choices you make. Yes, there are wolves and bears, but you have the choice to completely avoid them. In TLD sandbox, you create the story and are rewarded or punished accordingly. Hinterland Studios has done an incredible job of bringing the Canadian wilderness to your desktop (I say this without ever spending a minute in the Canadian wilderness). The immersiveness of the environment is felt immediately. Audio cues, such as the music transitioning in when you come upon a key location or when the skies clear for the sun, is quite moving. This game literally gives me chills and startles me when either a wolf growls unexpectely (or you think one is growling) and chases you while you find shelter indoors. You constantly battle the sense of desperation, cold and fear against hope, warmth and relief; fighting and thinking about the former is key to survival. The graphics, or more appropriately the artwork, is very good albeit not AAA-esque (and it isn't meant to be). For example, the sheet of ice crystals that form on your screen when walking outside, as if they're forming over your eyes, reminds you how cold it is. I would love to see the graphics be further refined to imbue more realism, but overall, it's fantastic. Game mechanics are good. Inventory system is easy to navigate, but I wish more items were made stackable. Overall, it's a very simple game that doesn't require twitch reflexes or advanced skill. The most difficult action is to shoot the bow and arrow, but with practice, one can master this pretty quickly. As with any early access game, we should see a lot of new content coming our way, including the story mode. If sandbox is able to lure me in this much, I have high hopes that story mode will do the same and add some context to the actual gameplay. Highly, highly recommend this game.

Early Access Review
								UPDATED REVIEW JANUARY 2016In my original review I stated that this game had potential if the developers stuck to it. My 130+ hours of playtime show that it's a game that I managed to stick with - and the developers have not only met, but exceeded my every expectation so far. The game is still only sandbox at this point, but now has many regions, added wildlife, a crazy amount of added items, crafting and so much more. With story mode on the horizon, expect an updated-update-review in the future. This has now become one of my most played steam games, and is an example of early access done right. Slow and steady, with constant communication and updates.Even still in early access, the sandbox represents one of the most immersive, realistic and FUN single player survival games available. ORIGINAL REVIEW, WRITTEN SEPTEMBER 2014This game is early access and has little content to it right now. At the time of writing this, it has but one static map. The starting point and the loot that you can find is RNG, but from a small pool of locations and a small pool of items, survival is really not that difficult once you've had a few trial and errors. This game needs a lot of things. It needs more content, more maps, more items, more animals, it needs more realism and more balancing - but the foundation is absolutely rock solid.I don't usually like commenting on early access games, but in this case I'm recommending it for one main reason - I played 13 hours without even realising. I survived over 20 days (on my 4th playthrough) before I had to quit (I didn't die). It didn't feel like 13 hours. It felt like one or two. It is immersive, it is addictive, it has genuine atmopshere and had a weird combination of both being relaxing and gripping at the same time. I don't know how trudging through the snow for an hour became both challenging and fun - but it did!I also love the art style, the brief voiceovers and the very brief music on top of being one of the most bug free beta-games I've ever played. I think it's worth supporting these developers.Of all the early access games I've taken a risk on, I think this one has the most potential if the developers can stick with it. From the updates and forum interaction so far, I'm very hopeful.Even if you're not interesting in backing games in early access - keep an eye on this one for the future!

								The best survival game I've ever played. The atmosphere in this game is so thick that you could cut through it with a knife and then spread it on your toast, the frightening moments will have you sh*tting your pants (surrounded by a wolf pack and your last flare just ran out) and the rewarding moments will have you jumping out of your seat (finally found that elusive prepper cache chock full of supplies)Isolation is really what made this game for me, it's only you vs. the wild from the start and god knows you'll do whatever it takes to win. Another thing that really makes this game for me is the very realistic inventory, you have a finite amount of weight you can carry, but you can choose to go over it. Be warned though, an overencumbered character moves slower and tires faster, not to mention they are also an easier target for aggressive wildlife.TLD won't let you run through the forest swinging an axe to fell trees and strike down animals, every action consumes calories and time (two things that are in short supply most of your playthrough) and every action outsides adds the risk of exposure. Huge blizzards rip through the map every so often and gargantaun clouds of dense fog cloud everything, obscuring any potential hazards from your view. In the first two hours of my playthrough, my character was already cowering in an abandoned coal mine with his clothes torn to shreds and multiple bleeding wounds. He also had food poisoning and was crying about how death would be welcome compared to the hell he was going through. Two seconds later, he died of severe dehydration and acute "wolf-bit-my-face-off" syndrome.This game is brutal. Buy it.Also see if you can break my record for consecutive wolf attacks (mine's seven).

Early Access Review
								First of all, I am going to admit I do have a bias on this game already because living in Northern Canada and getting a game on surviving in it already makes it 10/10 for me. But, I digress and will try and keep this fair.The Long Dark was recommended to me by a friend and I have to say, I am not disappointed by it. I loved the artstyle from the get-go because it's minimalistic and aesthetically pleasing but it may not work for everyone. For example, the buildings have an almost comic-book style to them which I enjoy but your mileage may vary. As for the actual gameplay, it's very easy to get into - very straight forward on what you have to do - but it gets very difficult very fast.For example, I kept assuming you need a fire going when you rest so you don't freeze to death (using my real world logic) but this seems not to be the case. Within the first day I used all my accelerant and tinder plugs and no idea what to do after. I went out to forage, got hit with a blizzard and died. Cue clucking of tongue and an annoyance to make it past the first day.But I admit, once you get the hang of it, it does become fun. Some people may not find calorie counting and foraging wood and lighting fires to be all that exciting mind you. Which this game has so if you want something more fast-paced, this probably won't do it for you. But for me, taking notes on what I'm doing, planning for the day or even just poking around outside for a minute and running back to shelter is fun. The fact that it's located in the wilderness of Canada - a place used rarely in games - just makes it better and I cannot wait for the Story Mode.Overall, again, I give it 10/10. The game is getting more content as the days go on so that's a big plus as it has changed from when I first downloaded it.Also, Jennifer Hale. I mean... that right there. Alone.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								With story mode soon to be released, I thought I might actually sit down and write a review for this game. The Long Dark is the best survival game I've played in years. There's a certain sense of desperation that you sometimes feel when you're playing this game - you might be out in the cold, with your character's condition steadily decreasing, and you hear a howl. So you look around, and on the crest of a nearby ridge is a dark silhouette. It's a wolf, and suddenly the situation becomes more dire. Your character moves slowly when their stamina is drained, or if they are injured. Sometimes escaping from predators is not as easy as it sounds or seems. The elements are deadly too - navigating through fog or a snowstorm can be a challenge, if you aren't prepared.The world of the Long Dark is a lonely world indeed. Searching through abandoned houses is always interesting - while searching for clothing you might stumble across the empty bedroom of a child, toys still scattered across the floor. You'll walk along lonely coastlines and across frozen lakes, through deserted settlements and climb up windswept mountains. When exploring new areas, you never really know what you might discover. The frozen bodies of those who could not survive serve as a warning and reminder of the post-disaster world the Long Dark takes place in. Every major update adds something new and interesting to find. I look forward to the upcoming story mode. Thank you for this game, Hinterland. Thank you.10/10

UPDATE (5/31/15): As per the developer's comment below, I revisited this title, and even though they claim that many of my 'Cons' have been addressed, I did not find this to be the case - the review still stands as-is. Details for haters: Menus are still clunky (a few new ones were added, but its the same format). It is still a numbers game, and you still magically know all of your calories at any given time. Maybe the weather numbers were removed (I don't remember seeing them this time). To be fair - I did not melee fight any wolves - I killed some with a rifle, though.I got my money's worth out of this and all, but to tell you the truth, I am just not feeling it. ITS SOOO CLOSE to something I could love, but yet so far. I love the idea of surviving the environment, and not zombies, but this just feels too tedious to be much fun. The graphics are also amazing, and in fact, probably the high point. It really does make you feel like you are out there all alone. Pros1. Graphics are killer good2. Atmosphere is very submersive, best I've seen for this kind of game3. Fresh idea that is welcome in survival games (no horror or zombies, I'm in!)Cons1. Menus are terrible - all weird drop down boxes and statistics, and terrible for controller support to-boot2. This is too much of a 'numbers-game' where you have to fight counting calories and how much stove time you have left3. THINGS ARE SO COUNTER-INTUITIVE - you can dehydrate yourself to death while you sleep. I mean c'mon. I could go on and on for this point, but those that have played it certainly know what I am talking about4. The wolves are actual enemies that leave something to be desired for me. The combat is really silly, and is basically just spam-clicking5. You magically have statistics on the weather (degrees, etc.), and actual calories consumed, but do not have these numbers for other thingsOverall, it just feels too clunky and tedious to keep me coming back. I also started to really dislike the developers on the forums. They are *too* involved - they should stick to reading the stickied threads for ideas or troubleshooting. Early Access Review
								Every once in a while you stumble into a game that is just a pearl. With The Long Dark I struck gold and got 100% my cup of tea. I love survival and exploring games, making a base or in this case hoarding/starving simulator go apesh!t, I'm loving it. And the style is really special in breathtaking in my opinion.So you have your first try on the hardest setting with the "bring it on I'm made for this game" attitude, dying within the first 24 hours of hypothermia... Learning the game mechanics and the layout of the 1st map I made it a little further each try. Fist 2 days, then 5, then 11.I thought I had my act together then, at day 11. I found a preppers cache with food, made my base at camp office at the lake. Had a hunting rifle with ample of ammunition, axe, hunting knife etc. enough wood at the base, water, food, plenty stored for days to come. Went on a hunting trip, shot a dear, was going to skin it, not a care in the world, BLIZZARD! omfg I'm freezing and exhausted becuase of it. Collapsed about 30 meters from the camp office,... faded into the long dark.So I learned my lesson and now I make a campfire if I have to skin and gut something.My try after that was my best try after that. Same story, great gear, but I ran out of food and was beginning to starve. No Deer to be found where I usually found them for 3 days in a row so I went on for fishing. On my way to the fishing hut a wolf showed up between me and the hut, charging towards me lit flare to make the wolf stop hopefully. "Well, I guess wolf is back on the menu". Crouched for a better angle, aimed my rifle !BAM! and... missed! as the wolf went for my throat. "O crap get it off get it off get it oooooff nooooo my clothes. aaaaaaah it bit me crap that hurt bad omfg I didn't know they could huuuurt you sooo bad!!!!!!""I'm not sure if I'm going to make it" my character gasped" Bleeding bad I took care of the wounds at the spot and stumbled back to the camp office. I needed to rest, I needed calories to recuperate while I rested or I'd never wake up. Then I realized I still had some tea left!!!Down to 3% before passing out//dying.I grabbed my lantern "out of fuel"... Looked in my inventory to refuel it, no fuel left,... Lit another flare. Couldn't nearly see anything as I was close to death and walking and stopping at a spot was a great challenge. When I finally ended up in front of the fireplace I see I'm down TO MY LAST MATCH. This better work! "Come on little fire!" YES, the fire is burning and I'm making tea, 3 whole cups, 300 calories! Now to rest, I fire up another flare and stumble my way upstairs leaning to the left wall to not go all over the place. I rested, for like 2-3 hours if I remember correct. Just so the calories and the rest would patch me up a bit and I'd have a chance to get to the fishing hut. If I'd rested too long the starvation would kick in again and would kill me for sure! I was back up to 6%! I had a fighting change!I lit a flare, made my way downstairs, exit the camp office. I'm not sure if there was mist or I was just nearly completely blind of being nearly dead, but I could not see crap. Going from left to right as walking in a straight line was not possible in my current state. I walked around till my flare burnt up, lit my last flare and still could not find a friggin fishing hut, my last and only hope.Then an achievement popped up "You prep the preppers" I made it to live 30 days!! Tea ftw! As I walked on with my last strength I see the lake cabins. I already looted that place so no food in there for sure, but maybe if I just rest for one hour... and if I don't wake up, at least I did not die outside in the cold but in a warm bed. As I lay my tired and starving body down on the bed I set myself to sleep for one hour as I fade into the long dark.

Early Access Review
								So this is exactly the same experience that Skyrim and a couple of survival mods can provide me with. Maps are mostly linear (Only 2 of them ATM) and houses that you can explore are copy-pasted, there is actually like 6 types of them and you will get sick of exploring them pretty quickly. Whole gameplay is a dull grinding, check every small drawer, get from point A to point B at a snail's pace without something that can provide you with fun in the mean time , ETC. I wouldn't mind this kind of grind but it takes too long to perform ANY action. There's nothing to do outside except for traveling between locations and gathering wood (Wood is obtained without any axe through the "gathering" menu, which only consumes time and some of your stats while you remain at the same position.) And maybe hunting, but that's when you get a rifle, which is a very rare item. Wolves is the only hostile mobs in the game ATM and there is no melee system. When a wolf catches you, you have to spam your RMB, that's it. There is "Gain strength" button which has a purpose of... letting the wolf eat you in less than a second. Mashing RMB is the only efficient option, why bother with anything else then? Oh, and there's no story mode right now. This game is not very fun and has a small amount of content. But it IS pretty and promising. That's why i'm recommending this game. If you are willing to buy a fun game that you can put lots of hours into, it's too early for that. If you are willing to support this dev both with money and constructive critique, go ahead then and buy it. I'll update this review when this game recieves a major update.

Early Access Review
								The Long Dark captures an unusual feeling in modern videogames: a sense of isolation. Alone in a vast and inhospitable wilderness, with no zombies or mutants or assault-rifle-toting killers in sight, it's simply "Man (or Woman) vs Nature," like in classic survival stories from Jack London onwards. The eerie whistle of the wind, the terror of a blinding blizzard, the welcome warmth of a fire-stove while the storm howls outside... these are the moments The Long Dark captures best (and uniquely).

As a sign of good faith, they agreed to provide "regular updates[hinterlandgames.com]" on Story Mode progress, and they'd handle spoilers by way of an opt-out system. Early Access Review
								This game is everything you hope it will be when you watch the previews - immersive, engrossing, beautiful, and brutal. There are moments when you just stop in awe at what you are seeing! Best of all, this is survival done right. You don't get to "base up" and live safely after a few play-throughs of learning. Sure you get better, learn the tips, live longer, but you still fight to survive every day, sometimes every hour in this game.Yes I had a few hard deaths, some brutal moments where I wondered if I would ever last more than a few days, but the reward when you figure it out is that much better. And even when you die, the game has a hold on you. I remember fading out one time looking up at the most amazing night sky ever. I couldn't wait to start again.In terms of style, you need minimal hand-eye coordination. This is a game of constant decision making. EVERY decision has tradeoffs: run or walk, rest more or head out now, fight or flee, take a risk or wait out a storm, take the easy path or go up that ridge to see what's on the other side?  I'm hooked. I find myself thinking about this game at work. Wondering what I should do to eke out another day or two. I got this game on sale, but it would be easily worth it at major label prices. And it's still just Alpha. Amazing.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is a great game which has a funny way of sneaking up on you. Right now only the sandbox mode is available so your objective is to survive for as long as possible by gathering food, wood, tools, clothing, etc. and by STAYING AWAY FROM WOLVES. Seriously, don't get near those things, not even with your rifle. You'll get bitten to death. Oh, and don't go out at night, you'll get bitten to death IN THE DARK.All of these survival stunts take place in a beautifully portrayed Canadian winter, and I mean this seriously. The developers haven't gone for photorealistic graphics but for a more impressionist approach with vibrant colours and more simple shapes. The game has made me go "WOAH!" several times because the landscape was so beautiful that you forget the hunger and the wolves for some brief seconds.There are some very interesting game mechanics that are the core of the game. Temperature is of the utmost importance so you are able to rip some clothes in order to improve others, skin animals to get leather or fur, etc. All of these actions are done inmediatly in real time but require an investment of in-game time (Which can be optimized by using the right tools) and that's the main point of the game: Invest your time wisely because your hunger, thirst and fatigue are going up continuosly.My favourite mechanic of all is the climate. Let's say you're save in a cabin but then you need to go outside for resource gathering, well, you may go out to find a clear day which allows you to see up to the horizon or, if you can hear the wind while into the house, you can find a windy landscape with reduced visibility or a FREAKING STORM may arrive reducing your visibility to zero. Good luck finding the cabin again.I feel like I've only scratched the surface of a very rich, survival game in which you can feel like everything is under control one die just to die horrible the next day because you made some poor choices. Give it a try, for real.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Let me say that I will willingly change this review as is warranted if the game develops, but as of now, I wouldn't recommend it. Visually, the game is stunning- it is a work of art with an unparalleled level of immersion that draws you in...but it is not a good "game." Frankly, it becomes a stressful chore after awhile, and I never really felt like I was progressing (I acquired stuff, and my skill points went up, but with no appreciable effects).Probably the biggest negative is that I picked this title up a few months ago, played it over a couple of days, formed an initial impression, set it aside, only to pick it back up again now and...nothing has changed. To be fair, I'm sure the game world is bigger and richer now, and I noticed some UI polishing, but Story mode is still teased at, the UI is still clunky, the game still becomes the aforementioned chore, the bug where your character suddenly starts speaking in demonic tongues is still a thing (Linux) and modding still doesn't exist. A word on modding: I don't see it happening any time soon either, since the developer has stated they want to "wait till they can do it right" which is a complete blow off. This is a title based on the Unity game engine - tons of titles in Early Access (with Unity especially) have vibrant moding scenes, with tiny development teams (e.g. RimWorld). I predict (and I'm ready to eat this statement) that this game will languish in the EA development doldrums for quite some time. I would love to be proven wrong though.TLDR: Get it if you want to interact with an immersive work of art. Avoid if you want a survival game. Might be a title to hang onto though, if you get it on sale.

Early Access Review
								By far, one of my best purchases on Steam. I've had this game since pretty early in development, and I keep coming back to it. It's as much a staple as Skyrim is to many. Aspects of the game do need tweaking, but for $20, the game is a steal right now. Of every early access game I have played, this is by far the best, hands down. It is so well put together, its surprising its still in development. Sandbox is plenty of fun. And they added challenges, Story coming soon, and more. Multiplayer is not necessary for this type of game - the tone and pace of the game would need major changes to fit well with multiplayer in my opinion. This is a good thing, as it fits what they want, and they do it perfectly. Tone and environment add so much to this game.They have a vision, a plan of how to get there, and stick to it. They are some of the best and most open devs I have experienced. You can see their team members reaching out to the community and answering questions. A huge plus is they actually listen. I'm sure some devs would release this game as is -or even earlier in development- and charge you $40+ for it. But Hinterland has a vision and they will delay, tweak, update, and change until they are happy and the community is happy. I am excited to see where the game will go, and what they will do with it. This game is fun, its thoughtful, and it is satisfying. The only downside is the lategame can be boring, but really, if youre making it that far, you can start new files, play the challenges, or even take a break. The game is unforgiving, and can have a bit of a learning curve, but its satisfaction is through the roof when you accomplish something you set for yourself.Highly reccomend this game, 9/10.

content:
Posted: January 5
Early Access Review
								It's cozy, but there is pretty much nothing to do in this game.You wander and constantly fill up meters. You collect resources from buildings so you can afford to wander more. Unlike most survival games, this never changes. You're basically a permanent nomad. You can, at some point, craft hunting tools, and then you don't really need to wander anymore since you can just hunt for meat instead. Then what? Nothing. There's no base-building. There's no """quests.""" There's no higher-level of survival. As soon as you can sustain yourself via hunting, the game has nothing to offer you. The only threats the game offers you (beyond one of the meters falling too low) is bears/wolves. And these can't attack you in the safety of a house.Contrast this with something like Don't Starve. After establishing camp and farms and bee boxes and basically knowing that you aren't going to starve without anything happening to you, what is there to do? Well...Prepare for hounds. Or giants. Tree Giants. Caves. Deeper caves. Luxuries that allow you to still function (more-so than just surviving them) during the extreme seasons (winter, summer). Luxuries that allow you to not go insane. Establishing more efficient forms of food gathering. Etc.The base of the game is decent but there's a significant lack of content that makes this game just boring. This may change if they add more content, but at its current pace, it just seems far off from being an experience.If you want a good first-person survival game, I'd recommend Subnautica. Same price-tag, more active developers, and much more to do other than aimless wander.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark - AlphaSlowing fading away of hunger in an abandon car was not the way I was going to die.  The blizzard had been going for two hours, and only the sound of my stomach growling kept me from trying to wait it out.  The last shelter I had seen was half an hour ago and the chances of finding it in the pitch darkness were nil.  My shivering was becoming constant.  No, I would not die here in this car.  Opening the door and lighting my last flare, I knew I could end up a frozen slab of meat on the side of the highway, or worse; a warm slab of meat for a wolf or bear.  Who knows, maybe dying warm would be better...no, follow the road, there is always civilization at the end of a road, but which way?  To go back was certain death, but to go foward was to make progress.  To what exactly I could not say, but it was further from death, further from the dark.  Shivering and walking at a limping pace, the sight of my own breath was a constant reminder that I was freezing to death, and if I didn't stop my sprained ankle would never heal.  If only the storm would let up for a just minute I could find my way...my condition was only getting worse.  I did not bother to pick up fuel for a fire anymore, what was the point?  No, this would not be how it ends, this is not how I die.  I think of where I have been so far, what little I have learned about surviving in this barren wasteland.  How to start a fire, what wood is the best to use, and what clothes can protect me from the wind.  I thought about the last cabin that I last slept in, it had everything I needed.  A pot belly stove, bunks with thick sheets, and most importantly four walls and a roof to protect me from the wind.  There was so much food in it, the cans of soda, jerky, even a cooked fish.  The moment I walked in I knew I had been saved; most of the food was gone within the day.  There was no choice but to leave the cabin if I was going to survive, even had I known I was going to sprain my ankle I still had to leave.The flare has now died and I keep walking in the dark knowing there is no going back.  All of a sudden I was hung up on something in the darkness.  Remembering the matches, I lite one and see at my feet is an overturned row boat on a frozen lake.  There must be a cabin.  I rush around in the darkness lighting matches frantically and see the small simple structure.  Entering the cold room I rush to the stove and start an emergency fire with my last acclerant.  The fire starts quickly giving me my first respite from the cold.  The dimly lit room is bare of items but under the bunk is a dusty forgotten MRE, I have hit the lottery.  Eating the packaged meal immediately the darkness slowly begins to subsides.  I purify the melted snow on the fire and drink my fill of water.  The crackling fire's warm glow begins to fill the room with heat, but it will be out in a few hours without more fuel.  I need to rest if I am going to get more wood.  I go to sleep in the bunk taking in all of its warmth.  Upon waking up the fire is out but the room is filled with light.  Eleven hours of daylight left and I have survived for three days.  I go outside to find the storm has ended and the morning sky is now a pale gold.  There is a cabin is out in the middle of the lake and I am going to need more food and fuel if I am going to survive any longer.  I start walking towards it picking up whatever loose firewood I can find along the way before stepping onto the lake.  Today could be my last day here, then again it might be tommorow.  But with every day I spend out here, I find it easier and easier to live on the edge of 'The Long Dark'.  20 minutes later I was mauled by a wolf and bled to death.

Early Access Review
								I've been looking forward to this particular survival simulator for a good, long while.  "The Long Dark" plops you into a post-apocolyptic environment set in the northern wilderness (where everything has icicles growing off of it).  Instead of trying to avoid zombies and the like, you'll "simply" be tasked with battling the elements, starvation, and the occasional pack of wolves.  As you'll soon realize, there's nothing "simple" about it.  In its current state, only the sandbox mode is available.  With that said, you'll easily be able to pump 50+ hours into this mode.  While the map itself is fixed, the items and their spawn locations are not, making it a challenge to find the tools you'll need to stay alive.  Easily one of the best survival games I've played in a while.

"I can cook some meat", I almost can't heard my own voice in the loud whistle of the wind that stretched around the cabin. So I grabbed the knife and went out.Poor deer, torn by wolves. Hey .. a dead body over there! I started to be glad for these frozen guys, one may appreciate some more food or clothes. It was getting dark and cold so I had to return to the lookout. My stomach wasn't in good condition and also I started to starve again. Not mentioning that I was really freezing.                                                            🔥"I am the God of Hellfire and I bring you ... FIRE! ... I love you my dear stove."My love to this solid metal thing was warm as like its fire. But why I was so stupid?! While boiling some water I forgot to add more fuel and my fire burnt. Without that last tinder I wasn't able to start it again and cook some delicious deer meat. I barely stayed on my feet so I lay down and went to sleep.I fell asleep, long sleep as was a long dark there outside. I have died from exhaustion.                                                            ⛰This was my very first gameplay of The Long Dark in the early access sandbox mode. Game is running pretty smooth and player can experience so much game mechanics even at this moment. I hope that every small deficit or issue will be tunned by developers and game will be even much more realistic. I'm looking forward to the story mode as well, because even in the sandbox it's very atmospheric. As I said in the beginning, it's like a starving and freezing simulator and you'll find out how this game can be challenging and hard if you are lost and wandering in -20°C (-4°K) with a limited supplies in the small backpack, burning your calories and freezing maybe dying from food poisoning.Anyway If this will be your last day, believe you will die in the stunning nature!  ... or just torn apart by wolves! 🐺

Early Access Review
								This game is about survival in extreme conditions. You are left alone in the beautiful cold wilderness. There's no one alive to be found, and you'll require a lot of creativity to balance the use of the resource have, to avoid or respond to threats, and to adapt to the circumstances to make it to the next day.Yesterday a new update came out. Now we have a much wider area to explore, with a good number of improvements and fixes. I can see many of the improvements being taken directly from the community. The developers engage the community, explain how things works, and consider negative opinions. Future looks very promising for this Early Access game.As it's right now, you'll be able to gather resources from a wide range of places like a dam, a train wreckage, cabins, camps, or even a bunker (if you find it). You'll scavenge frozen corpses and abandoned backpacks, and you'll hunt for food with a rifle that will eventually break and with a limited number of bullets. You'll have to take care of your clothes, because you'll need them to get wood in the freezing open to cook meat and get drinkable water. You'll be able to repair your clothes for as long as you have materials to do so. You'll have to control the calories intake and it's burning to keep you healthy. Avoid dehydration and freezing. Running will burn more calories and raise fatigue, sleeping will save calories and better your general condition. Eventually your stored food will turn stale, and eating it would make you sick, so you'll have to make decisions on what to eat and what to store. But above all, the wild life is free from constraints, and there's no one keep the wolf population at bay, so you'll also be hunted down. You'll have to run for your life, to wait until it's safe to go out, or to use the harsh weather to be able to move from one place to another. As every single bullet counts, you'll have to make choices about how you defend yourself. Surviving a wolf attack with a bullet today will mean you won't be able to shot down a deer for food tomorrow.The game sounds great, looks great and feels great. Get it.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								I am inside the Forrest Lookout.  I have enough meat to last for a little bit, and some water as well.  I am out of firewood, though, and the temperature outside feels like -56 degrees. So, what's the plan? Do I go out and start my day exploring and gathering some wood? Or should I hunker down another few hours and see if this weather passes... one choice or the other could mean death.A true enough survival game with no visible bugs, but limited content.  It is relatively slow paced, which makes it more relaxing and calming until the wolf jumps out from behind you and tries to kill you. This game is quite enjoyable for what it is currently: a sandbox survival game with a pretty small, static map.  Your spawn is randomized, but the map is static. So, you will get used to it pretty quickly.The game features a lot of ways to die and is actually quite hard.  This is a good thing.  There are no zombies and/or other players to kill you, and it is still pretty hard. A lot of people are saying it is too hard and unrealistic.  In some ways, perhaps, but in other ways not so.  I think it is actually more realistic than people think because very few people have actually experienced any type of arctic survival before.I actually enjoy the game as it is.  A lot of people are calling for base building, MP, PvP, etc, to make yet another Rust/DayZ clone.  I am looking forward to the devs bringing out the SP story mode and additional maps, which already seem to be promised or in the works.Overall, a good alpha SP game that I hope stays SP and just adds more variety to the maps and adventures/stories in the future.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark drops you somewhere in the Canadian Wilderness with the simple goal: Survival. Explore an open world from the summit of the Timberwolf Mountain range to an old industrial whaling community. Navigate through caves, a dam, abandoned coal mines and broke down railroad tracks while discovering man-made and natural supplies littered throughout the locations. Travel expansive distances across multiple maps. Seek shelter from the elements in cabins, industrial buildings and abandoned vehicles. Keep a lookout for suspiciously aggressive wildlife while managing your always deteriorating supplies and condition. Simple yet rich with complexity, TLD becomes a reflection of your own decisions ultimately leading to your success or death.I absolutely love The Long Dark. The appeal is its simplicity - just you and nature. Hinterland takes liberties with the environment increasing the complexity in a positive way and strategic They have clearly established a well thought out; well executed game design. I enjoy the solitude of the experience and the discipline to carefully consider each move you make. Every play experience will be uniquely different and everyone who plays will find their own novel experiences. Although still in alpha testing, it is clear Hinterland revealed a new spin on the survival gaming model. No Zombies. No angry mobs. Just an angry wolf named Fluffy. Some Dislikes1.	Animal aggressiveness. All depends on the mode. As an example, in Stalker, behind the Pleasant Valley Farmhouse, 6 wolves and 1 bear skulked. Think they'd go for each other if they're so hungry?? Nope. Instead they sniffed me down like I was coated in BBQ sauce. It’s possible the aggressiveness will be explained in story mode. I generally enjoy the challenge of facing aggressive animals but, at times, it feels a bit overplayed for the sake of dramatic effect. 2.	Inability to start a fire without game specific materials (i.e. matches, magnify glass). I’d like to be able to craft a fire bow or a tinder bundle to carry embers to different locations. Yes, I know the difficulty in rubbing sticks together but it can be done…just not in TLD.  If man made items are not available or in very rare supply (Interloper), there should be a natural way for the task to be completed or at least attempted even if the failure rate is high.Wishlist:1.	Maps. There are stores, camp offices, forestry lookouts, cars and cabins with blurred pseudo maps on the walls but no discoverable maps!? I believe cartography is an age old practice to identify one’s location but surprisingly absent from TLD. Whomp. Whomp.2.	Compass. I guess if you don’t have maps then asking for a compass is like hoping to find Atlantis in Desolation Point. Even without maps, a craft-able compass would help to maintain an idea of where you are. 3.	Additional wildlife. Beavers, Raccoons and foxes oh my?? Umm now that I think of it, why can’t I craft a fur hat??4.	The ability to craft a blanket or bedroll. I’ve got a stash of 40+ cloths and I can’t make a quilt??5.	The possibility of eating raw freshly caught fish. Granted Lake Whitefish is not a staple in my local sushi joint but salmon certainly is…6.	Complexity sliders. Certainly a wish list feature but I’d love to see sliders for game settings like animal aggression, discoverable items, etc. This would truly make each gameplay a unique experience.

								I've noticed that the survival game genre has flourished in the last several years with many indie games coming along. I think part of that is the Zombie fad, but not entirely. There is a harder core sort of gamer that wants gritty realism whose not satisfied with guns guns guns.Welcome to The Long Dark.This game will kick your♥♥♥♥♥ If your stupid, you die, that simple. If you /think/ you have a chance at survival.I love the premise of the game, the sun sends along a gift and turns off all electrical things on Earth. You, a bush pilot, manage to land your plain in the remote Canadian wilderness. Now what? Now you survive, or you die, a lot, before you start to learn just how gritty and realistic this game gets.Personally I love that, don't cut me slack, I've done god mode enough its boring.The graphics are stylized and really lovely, theres an artistic flair here not found in other games in this genre. The sound is good, not spectacular. It will make you feel powerful lonely at times, and thats sort of the point.After four attempts I managed to survive 20 days and am working on deerskin boots. The crafting and repair system is good, you have to find items needed and a place to do the work, and the game doesn't drown you in items. Sure, at first you'll find lots of candy bars and cans of beans, but they only last so long and you have to start thinking long term. Also, fire making skills are key, as would be the case in RL. If you wan't a casual game, this is NOT for you.If you wan't a game you can chew on, pitbull like, just to make it past a week...this is for you.System Specs: CPU: i7 4790K, Graphics: GTX 770 Mem: 16 gigs

								I've been waiting for some time for this game to come out and saw that it was on sale on Steam for only $10.00. Kudos to Hinterland!My first experience with the game I played it on medium difficulty and lasted 20 or so days without any kind of problem as I have played many survival/ resource games before.I turned it up to stalker difficulty (Hardest difficulty). Now this is certainly my kind of game:  Real survival.Artistically it's beautiful, the dark unforgiving environment was exactly what I expected for a survival game I rate it a 10/10.  Emersion is about 8/10 and it is certainly a playable game even though it’s Alpha.  Out of 36 hours played- I’ve fallen though the world once- That happened after I sprained my ankle from a bump in the snow. This was the only real bug I’ve found and I was able to recover after multiple saved game loads.    The game has only crashed once on me so my rating for general game stability would be 8/10- which is great for an alpha.It isn’t a perfect balance… for example:  In Stalker mode you almost never find anything in file cabinets, you would think you would find just a little more paper….  Other than that you might find one item for every four boxes or containers you search though.I can tell you that after 36 hours- I’m not bored with it.   There’s lots of content and places to explore, and there are no quests in this game.  Simply surviving hour by hour and day by day and making it from point A to B is more than a challenge.  Getting down to 3% health in the middle of a blizzard with 99% fatigue all because of rusty can of pork and beans…  and surviving it with quick thinking…  Glorious/Rewarding.Frankly Speaking- I think this game has the potential to be the best realistic survival game on the market today.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's been a good year for fans of the "less zombies - more survival" theme, and this game is a nice addition to that theme. tl;dr: Scroll down for a short list of gameplay features that may help with decision making.Sandbox Gameplay:This is inherently a game about managing your resources and your condition and keeping yourself fed, warm, healthy and decently equipped. This specific iteration of the Canadian wilderness is empty of people but not of houses, cabins and other locations you can loot from, making this a game more about loot and less about base building or crafting. In fact crafting is minimal (at least at this stage of development), though repairing your equipment is an important aspect of the gameplay. The maps (both of which are relatively small) sport houses/lootable locations at regular, easily walkable distances and they are persistent. The loot however (the type and quantity of which also seems to be more or less persistent) is randomly distributed, offering at least some amount of replayability. The rest of the replayability comes from permadeath: Basically, you die often enough that it will take you a while to explore both maps, small though they may be. Hunting (or at least looting half frozen corpses the wolfs have killed for you) becomes necessary only in later game, when you have unearthed most of the loot and are slowly running low on food. There are at the moment three animals in the game: deer, the wolfs that hunt the deer (and you) and rabbits. You can use traps for the rabbits, and you can attack the wolfs and deer with your fists, a rifle or a hunting knife (both of which you have to find first, and both of which will degrade, so you need to be conservative about your hunting). You can apparently also fish, though I have yet to succeed in ever finding a hook, so there is little I can tell you about that.Wolves:You've heard about the wolves, and they deserve their own paragraph. Fighting them melee (when for example they attack you) is very much a twitchy experience of button mashing, one that feels equally "realistic" and annoying to me. Avoiding them (by using fire, flares or decoys, or by giving them a wide berth) is possible, but not always feasible/practical. Frankly, being stuck inside a house for two days because there's two wolves parked right outside and you have no weapons whatsoever isn't my idea of fun, yet it seems to keep happening to me. But I can see where the devs are coming from, and I have heard other players who enjoy that (and are apparently better than me in the twitchy button mashing), so ymmv.However, there is an easy mode of the game, which makes the wolves basically not an issue. Sadly, it also makes the rest of survival aspects a bit easier. I am still hoping better balance/alternative solution to this design choice will crop up before full release, but you shouldn't count on it. For now just know that if you are coming to this game for the snow and the exploration, you can feel free to play on easy mode and the wolves will ignore you.Story mode:This is a promised feature that will apparently get added pre-release, but it isn't here yet. Since this game feels somewhat limited as a sandbox, I am looking forward to the story mode. Theoretically, The Long Dark could be absolutely lifted to the next level with good story mode implementation, it's absolutely a great world to tell stories in. But at this point we have no clue what that's gonna look like, so for now buy it for the sandbox, or wait it out.Atmosphere:There is very little to say here, I absolutely love the art design. The screenshots you see are very representative of the real thing, so if that works for you, you won't be disappointed. The slightly stylized, less-than-realistic but incredibly evocative art style is gorgeous, atmospheric and immersive. The sound design also brilliantly contributes to the atmosphere. This is a beautiful game, even with lowered graphics.Technical stuff:For an early access game, this has been very much a bug free experience for me so far. And while playing this on a laptop not much above min specs, lowering the graphics from ultra to high was enough for a smooth experience, with no lag, small (hardly noticeable during play) fps drops and still stunning visuals.Finally, here's a list of features to keep in mind before you make your decision:Atmosphere: Walking around in the snow, listening to the howling wind is much of the appeal of this game.Permadeath: No way around it. Either you're okay with that, or you'll be very frustrated.Real time: The game doesn't stop while you're staring at your inventory trying to decide which socks to put on. When planning for a two hour tree cutting session, keep in mind the weather may have changed to howling winds and you may be dying of hypothermia when you emerge on the other side of it. (Not being able to break what you're doing in reaction to what's happening is one of my pet peeves with the game, btw.)Maps: This initially feels, but distinctly is NOT an open world survival game. There are two maps, and they are both small and persistent. You can basically learn where everything is in a couple of successful playthroughs. Also, some of the houses are too shame-y inside, which I find a pity for such small maps.Loot: There is a more or less set number of items you can find, spread randomly around the map in every new game. What you find when can easily make or break an early game.Hunting: This is not an FPS and it isn't Deer Hunter. You have a rifle with very limited ammo and a knife, and that's about it. And even those degrade btw.Difficulty: There are three difficulty modes to pick and choose from. It is a bit unfortunate imo that wanting to avoid the button mashing that constitutes fighting the wolves means also having to play in a mode that seriously nerfs the rest of the survival difficulty, but at least the option is there.Survival: The Long Dark is a decent, if rather limited, take on the "loot, craft (minimally), repair, manage your resources, manage your condition" type of gameplay. Because of the limited crafting and the reliance on findable loot, there is less flexibility of strategy here than in other games of the genre. And that inflexibility of viable strategies is for me this is the major negative of the game, the aspect that limits its sandbox mode the most. However, this could theoretically be completely offset with a decent story mode, effectively changing the whole feel of things. As a world to tell stories in, let me reiterate, this could potentially be an absolutely brilliant one. We'll have to wait and see.EDIT: Please add modding support! This game is screaming for it. :)

Early Access Review
								So far, The Long Dark is looking excellent. It's a proper survival horror game, as in: You might not survive and that's pretty horrible. Gameplay: At the time of writing, only Sandbox mode is available. The mechanics of interacting with the environment are exactly what I ache for in many games, i.e. When I do something that would be sensible in a situation in real life, it works in the game too. Freezing? Get in the lee of that rock to get out of the wind. Yay, it works!The game itself kind of includes its tutorial organically. At the start, you have no stuff, so you don't have to worry about what you can do with stuff. As you acquire stuff, you can play with it and learn what it does.It is a little frustrating that there are some features you'd hope will appear in the final version that apparently don't work yet - like fuelling and starting the oil generators with you can see attached to many of the cabins, but it's still alpha and there's plenty of time for more actions of this type - the ones that seem obvious and sensible to the player - to be added.If you're easily frustrated by death, you might dislike this game, but as it stands, competing against yourself to see how long you can last is a main mechanic of sandbox mode.Atmosphere: Really good atmosphere, especially through sound and lighting. The constant howling of the wind makes you feel cold and alone, while I got a couple of good jump-scares from a sudden burst of incidental music and my own character mumbling to herself.Story: Storyline-mode isn't available yet, but there is a lot of good potential for when it is. You can already surmise a number of things about what happened simply from what you can see in the game - dinner still in the ovens, oddly placed corpses... if they stick with the vibe of "Show don't tell" it will be excellent.In summary, pretty good as it stands and can only get better. The only reason I -wouldn't- recommend buying it on early access is that this game deserves to cost more - I think the devs may have underestimated what it will cost to do everything they will want to with the game.

Early Access Review
								Important note on realism: Hinterland does not aim for the game to be completely realistic, but rather a game that is balanced between game-play and realism. Some elements are therefore not in line with the real world (for example the degradation of items goes a lot faster). There is (currently) no intention of making a separate game mode that is as realistic as possible, although there are talks of mod support to enable this by the community.I bought The Long Dark because I have been searching for a realistic survival game / simulator for a long time. Even though it is not meant to be entirely realistic / simulator, it comes very close. So close that I can state it is the best game I have ever played. I have played a lot of games for many years (a lot outside Steam) so this is quite impressive considering it still is in early access. The game-play is fantastic and is a must for any gamer that is into survival games and crafting. I don't want to spoil it for you, but there are times where I am trembling of fear and excitement. The immersion is so great that I sometimes forget I am playing a game. It is visually stunning and the sound is even better.The game is constantly changing and new content is added regularly (big update each month and smaller ones in between). The developers are enthusiastic and committed and are willing to listen to the community, while maintaining their own vision. While there is currently only a sandbox, story mode is planned for release at the end of this year (which includes great voice actors like Jennifer Hale). The price will probably go up at that point, so buy it while it is still cheap.The Long Dark will not hold your hand and there are no tutorials. It is very intuitive, but you have to use your intellect. There are three game modes. One which is forgiving and primarily to explore (Pilgrim). One that is exactly in line with the vision of Hinterland, challenging but fair (Voyageur) and my personal favourite, brutal and unforgiving (Stalker). I love the challenge in the game (or any game) as there is nothing better than to recover from your near dead experiences. Most people will die, some a lot. As it is permadeath you will lose your hard work. If you don't like dying or to lose your progress, I would suggest waiting for story mode (but be ready to pay more if you don't buy it now). I however love permadeath and (almost) impossible games, which is why I play games that have this (Faster Than Light, XCOM, Don't Starve etc.). Always on the highest difficulty and with permadeath on if this is possible. The Long Dark has a difficulty mode for every kind of player, which is a big plus.To conclude, this game is so amazing that I bought a new Xbox One just to play The Long Dark. I bought the game for my low-end laptop, which was below the minimal requirements. Surprisingly I could play it extremely well until last big update. I felt so sad and empty when I could not play any more that I just had to do something about it. It is all worth it as I am 100% sure it will be a huge success (unlike other early access games). If there are any doubts or questions, feel free to send a message or post on the forum. Hinterland, me and the community are happy to help.

								"One of the most brutal, relentless, and unforgiving titles out there"The Long Dark is one of those games where if you (let's say, die) and quit for the day, you just come back tomorrow and start it all over again because of your need for accomplishment and progression. This game will make you question and value your decisions. In this game, everything you do has a price. That is, that last piece of wolf meat you ate? It's probably the last of food you'll have for days. That last piece of firewood? It will hold you out just enough to keep you warm and to boil you up half a liter of water. That run you want to make? It's getting dark out there. That last bullet in the rifle? It may end up saving your life, or end you.This game revolves around the concept of conservation. Of making wise decisions for your character's benefit. Of making sure you can make it through the day just so you can wake up tomorrow. Being just an early access title, at $20, with just the sandbox and two challenges playable at the moment, I couldn't have spent it on anything better.Remember to play your cards right because mother nature isn't planning on playing nice10/10 (Would get gang♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by two bears again)

Now the hunt is on, I take out my rifle and vow to remove the menace from the dam, and make it a new safe haven. I creep slowly down the hallway, the sights of my rifle in line with my eye. As I round the corner, I hear another growl, I aim, and I fire. I miss. The wolf attacks and I manage to kill it with my knife. Then I notice I only have one percent of life left and I'm bleeding out. I access my medical kit as the world starts to black out around me. I'm dead.

								Do Not Buy.  3 years Early Access, No progress. This is a last minute money grab before they abandon it.Censorship on the dev forums.  You are NOT allowed to criticize anything!This game had immense potential that was thrown away by Hinterland.The Pros:  Immersion, Artistry, Sound, Elements, Exploration, Map sizes.It had incredibly beautiful landscaping coupled with great element effects and sound affects which created intense Immersion.  Maps were HUGE with tons of things to find (if you could) while exploring.  The best challenge was when you were ready to move on, trying to figure out how to get to the next region could really leave you stumped.The Cons: UI, Mechanics and AI.The User Interface was very clunky Combat mechanics just insane.  Calories and weights were severely skewed.  Running was reduced to almost non existent.  The AI for wolves.. *facepalm* just.. BAD.As for Crafting.. im sorta on the fence on that one.  You love it, you Hate it... it needed work. Er.. more work that is.So what went wrong?Well, they just stopped creating new regions and kept tinkering with the UI, Mechanics, and AI.  Admittedly they atleast knew where they were comming up short, but instead of fixing it, they just kept making things worse.  They should have simply acknowledged their strengths and weaknesses and subcontracted another company to complete work on the UI, Mechanics and AI while they themselves fleshed out the rest of the game and worked on the Storyline.  This would have been the smart approach and clearly in the long run, the most economical one. But they didn't, and here they are with palms out 3 years later facing the harsh reality of having to scrap it.It really is sad.  The death of a game that had such amazing potential.At 50% off it probalby isn't a bad buy, just for the exploration / sandbox mode, but don't expect anything more than what you get when you buy it.

The Long Dark.No monster, pure survival. Yup, 4 kata itu merupakan kata kunci. The Long Dark merupakan game yang mengetes bagaimana kemampuan survival lo ditanah dingin Amerika bagian utara. Suhunya bahkan bisa mencapai -20 derajat celcius. Kalau lo terjun langsung kedalam game, lo MEMANG bakalan melihat scenery seperti itu, tapiiiii.... kalau lo liat objek yang ada disekitar lo, lo bakalan sadar bahwa tekstur dari objek disekitar lo bertekstur kartun. Mau minum? loading progress. Mau menyalakan api? loading progress. Mau looting? loading progress. Mau crafting? Loading progress. Emang sih terkesan simple tapi kalau hampir setiap action yang kita lakukan adalah loading progress, rada bete juga kan? Kalau lo gak masalah dengan loading progress, its okay. for me, its kinda big deal. Walau pun begitu, lo bakalan merasakan pengalaman yang cukup real. Badai saljunya itu bener bener DINGIN banget. Lo kerasa deh bagaimana angin berhembus dengan cepat dan jarak pandang lo berkurang akibat kabut. Serius. Gue hampir aja mati ditengah badai salju. Gue mencari rumah untuk berteduh dibawah derasnya badai salju. Nyawa gue udah 50%. Akhirnya gue duduk dibawah batu besar berharap badainya berhenti. Tapi karena nyawa gue udah turun drastis, gue nekat! Eh gak nyampe 20 detik, ternyata disebelah gue persis ada rumah. PERSIS lho. Badainya bener bener top banget.Sounds:Salah satu aspek paling keren di game ini. Suaranya bener bener ngebuat lo kerasa banget dinginnya. Badai, salju, jejak kaki, binatang liar, kayu yang terbakar, kabin yang ditiup angin kencang, semuanya itu bener bener keren dikuping gue. Gameplay:Survival, looting, and crafting. Yup, ini bumbu manis banget untuk para gamers di tahun 2013 keatas. Seperti yang lo tau, ini game bertemakan survival ditengah wilayah salju yang liar. Spoiler alert: Lo pasti mati. content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: The Long Dark Review -- Live or Die! 

			Views: 2,275		

			A Kickstarter Backer Review of The Long Dark. A hardcore, realistic survival simulator from Hinterland Games. ►►►Purchase on Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/305620/ Welcome to The Long Dark...		

TLD Credits:David Hayter (Solid Snake - Metal Gear)Mark Meer (Cmd. Shepard - Mass Effect)Jennifer Hale (Cmd. Shepard - Mass Effect)Marianne Crawcysk (writer of L.A. Noire, Driver, Far Cry 3, Appleseed Alpha)Raphael Van Lierop (Project Lead - Relic Games, Blacklight, Ubisoft, Activision)Alan Lawrence (Lead Designer - Saints Row 1-4, Freespace 1-2, Red Faction 1-2)David Chan (Audio Director - Bioware) Now that I have your attention...let's explain the credits more in depth and why The Long Dark is a great foundation for an amazing final product.I have been waiting for years, if not decades for a game that makes simple man vs. nature survival the primary focus rather than simply a secondary after-thought. The Long Dark by Hinterland Games delivers a the closest thing to being Survivorman that has ever appeared in a game. They also designed TLD from the ground-up to work seamlessly with the Oculus Rift. The have a dev kit in their studio as of last month in fact.As of this review the game is currently in Early Access (v.119). It was the result of a Kickstarter campaign less than a year ago by Hinterland Games. The concept is you are a small plane bush pilot in Northern Canada when a Coronal Mass Ejection occurs (CME - similar to a solar flare). This causes all electrical components worldwide to fail. Unfortunately, this also caused the plane you were flying in to fall out of the sky into an unknown area in the frigid winter of a forest. You lived through the crash...but will you live through The Long Dark?Hinterland Games was founded by Raphael Van Lierop. Raph, as he's known on the forums, has over a decade of AAA game creation experience. As a creative director, narrative director, producer, designer, and writer on multiple award-winning game titles including Company of Heroes and Warhammer 40,000. His former studios include Relic, Ubisoft Montreal, Blacklight and Activision.Rapheal had the desire to create a first-person raw and realistic survival simulation with a deep story mode. The big box studios said it wasn't "marketable" enough. So he took his skills and experience and left. After easily surpassing his Kickstarter goal with his vision of The Long Dark, he grabbed some other highly experienced industry professionals. This inclused David Chan as Audio Director from Bioware. Next to join the team was Alan Lawrence. Alan was the lead designer on Freespace, Freespace 2, Red Faction, Red Faction 2, Saints Row 1-4 and many more. Together the group started Hinterland Games. Their first project is The Long Dark. With plans for future expansions and sequels in the form of seasons. This should be similar to The Walking Dead game series in delivery.Raph didn't stop there, he wants a deep and rich story to go with the realistic survival experience. So he invested a substantial amount of the kickstarter funds into hiring Marianne Krawcyzk as the writer. She wrote L.A. Noire, Driver, Far Cry 3 and Appleseed Alpha. Together Raph and Mirianne will have the story mode out by the end of 2014 with many NPC's characters created from the original Kickstarter backers likenesses.What else did Raph want for his survival game experience?? How about GREAT voice acting... Mark Meer and Jennifer Hale from Mass Effect. And maybe even a guy named David Hayter the former Solid Snake from a little franchise called Metal Gear. I guess Sutherland wasn't available...his loss.So if you are jaded like I was/am on Early Alpha games that alway overpromise and underdeliver, I know this game design team will not disappoint you from experience. See as a kickstarter backer, I got a copy of the game many updates ago. The design team has a clearly defined goal, and future plans for this as a franchise. They are just looking to the community to give feed back to best reach that clear goal. Guess who has the most posts on the forums...each individual from the dev team! They are really that interactive and willing to hash-out and debate concepts with the players who are ultra motivated to help.This leads me to the community. The community is amazing. No trolls, only mature and constructive gamers. Need a question about survival tactics...ask Rob Doar. Have an issue with the forum...Bill Tarling is your guy. Need help re-creating a bug...TattooedMac is your answer. Want to see how long you can survive...how about the long-term survival masters Heather and LordMasterGaming. Want to check out some great videos/livestreams...I'm your guy, Accurize2. Oh but maybe I'm not good enough for you, how about DaSquirrelsNuts or MathasGames...yep they are in the community too!So to summarize this amazing survival game has a great goal. A professional team with decades of experience. And a community that is 100% supportive and helpful to the team and fellow players. The Long Dark is exactly how the indie dev process should be and The Long Dark is exactly how survival gaming will be.Thanks for reading my review, actaully my FIRST STEAM REVIEW EVER!! :DCheck out some TLD gameplay, check out my YouTube channel:www.youtube.com/accurize2Check out my livestreams also:www.twitch.tv/accurize

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have taken sometime to play this game myself and I decided that I should write a review here so that it would be helpful for those who read it and decide whether to purchase this game or not.Get to the point, right now the game is in 'Early Access' so it is not really complete. However, personally, only what the Early Access has offered now worths the money.The very first thing that can be accounted as pros is the the game's very own concept. It is a new dimension of 'survival game', unlike many mainstream survival game lists which involve zombies and mutants to horrify you, this game is another story: just you against the 'Mother Nature'. You are on your own, among the cold, hunger, thirst, tiredness, or even danger from wolves. All you need to do is 'survive'. It sounds simple and uninteresting, but believe me this game is well enough even with this simplicity in this game genre. No safe place with lots of supplies (unless you choose 'Pilgrim' mode). You need to take risks with your own actions. Everything is by yourself.The gameplay ... I don't know if I should classify it as a pro or con, but it is mixed. You can never expect anything from each playthrough; when you restart, everything except the regions will be resetted. This gives you the survival experience to some extends. For example, you might find a rifle, the only 'real' weapon in the game, without any bullets before you find one bullet miles away, or you need a can opener but still yet to be found; what will you do? which way? where is it going to be? Everything which other survival games may overlook matters in this game. You need clothes to keep you warm, raw food, if not cooked well, can be a threat when eaten, or you can even hurt your legs if you do not watch your steps (which happens to me a lot lol). These are some of the situations that I found and I need to give the 'thumb up' for the developer's careful planning so as to make this game as realistc as possible.However, there is something that still bugs me; the wolves. They still lack realistic movements: too repetitive and can be easy to deal with as you get get used to the game. Even though the developer has mentioned something about the wolves, their movements and some behaviors, such as how slow or fast it should be in different situations, are needed for consideration *for developers*. I hope if the wolves are readjusted in the right way it would gives me more exciting experience. Nevertheless, even with this comment I still find dealing with wolves sometimes hard anyway. (I heard that more wildlife will be added, so it might be the solution for this problem as well.)If you are fans of survival game and need a new dimension on survival experience, I suggest you that you buy this and try it once or wait for sometime until the full release comes (Story Mode, I'm really looking forward to that!). My last warning .."Beware of the wolves, the cold, or even yourself as you play this game". Good Job Hinterland!

Early Access Review
								I am fairly new to the survival game genre, but that doesn't mean i can't recognize a great game. The Long Dark, is freaking brilliant. It is one of those games that tries to be as realistic as possible. You need to watch your hunger, hydration, body temperature, and fatigue. The hardest of the 5 is temperature because the game drops you in the middle of a post appocolyptic arctic landscape with sub zero temperatures. You start with nothing but the clothes on your back and and an old sleeping bag. As soon as you start, it is a race to find shelter, food, water, warmer clothes, medical supplies, fire making supplies, etc. With a variety of maps, some will make this easier than others. The starting map, Mystery Lake, has plenty of man made shelters and cabins scattered throughout. Even so, you always need to be planning where you will spend your next night. If you stay in one shelter too long, you will run out of supplies or not have enough for your journy to the next shelter. Your best bet is taking off at first light so you have the whole day to find supplies and shelter. The game really throw a wrench in your plan though. Often, a storm will develope and eat away your daylight. Storms force you to seek shelter from the wind. You better hope that when a storm comes, you have the necessary supplies to stay in your shelter for however long it last. That means you should always have plenty of food, water, and fire supplies on hand. Storms aren't the only thing that can trap you though. Wolves are also scattered throughout the wilderness. You may find your self trapped in a broken down car waiting for the wolves to leave. Sometimes a flare can scare them off, but don't rely to heavy on that. Basically, this is an awesome game, and a must buy for any survival game enthusiast.
