content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								I might update this review as the game develops further. The TL;DR is at the bottom, if anybody's interested.First off, let me say that "The Long Dark" is one of the truest survival games to be produced in the year of 2014. Everything in the game is out to get you: the elements, the water, the wolves, sickness, hunger, dehydration, and fatigue, just to name a few. The game does a fantastic job proving how frail the human body is when exposed to these hardships, as well. One cannot go on a murderous rampage of kniving wolves and deer. One cannot travel miles in a blizzard. One cannot carry a rifle, six jackets, enough medical supplies to aid a hospital, and enough food to make people think you robbed a grocer. If one wants to survive, one must avoid wolves, travel light, and travel prepared. One wrong step and it could be one's last.The graphics are quite simple, yet unique for modern games. It's hard to describe, but it borders cartoon-y, in a sense. Finding a human corpse will reward you with a flat-faced man with hands lacking fingers, but it somehow does the game justice of displaying a bleak wilderness that is inhospitable.The gameplay is perfect, in such few words. Every day, one has to question oneself, "What do I need to do today?" One needs wood for a fire to stay warm, food and water to stay alive, clothes to stay warm while outside, medication to keep you alive when you're hurt, but one can only do so much per day. These needs will always keep one questioning if what one grabbed from that cabin was the right thing for tonight, or if one dodged that wolf on the railroads, will it have tracked them back to their camp? Every so often, these primal thoughts of food, water, and safety will even have the player making basic statements of "Need water" or cursing a wolf's presence. The game also praises (read: demands) players for taking risks and venturing away from one's safe camp to search abandoned vehicles and houses for more supplies, but remember: too much risk and one might run into a LOT of trouble.Some of the upcoming features include a story mode involving a Canadian bushman pilot who goes down after the freak electromagnetic surge which causes the events of "The Long Dark" to unfold, AI (and possibly human) survivor interation (which, as far as AI goes, has been teased that some AI are friendly, some are hostile, and some will pretend to be friendly to steal your supplies), and more undisclosed content that has yet to be revealed. After all, this is Early Access.Also, as a final note, the dev team is a new face on the development playing field, but they are certainly not green. With voice actors such as Mark Meer, Jennifer Hale, David Hayer, and Elias Toufexis providing their talents to the game's characters and devs including people who have worked on "TES: Morrowind", "League of Legends", "God of War", "Far Cry 3", and "Mass Effect". With such a team, not only will a quality game come out of "The Long Dark", but it will definitely be developed by a reputable team.TL;DR:"The Long Dark" is a diamond in the rough amongst all the other survival games of 2014 that is being headed by a great dev team. I would definitely recommend it for everybody masochist out there who wants more challenges.

Now then, let's take a closer look:

I have seen this game about a year ago. It hasn't had that many reviews back than and i had to make decisions. I had played a number of early access survival games back at that point and was generally disappointed in the genre as it didn't live up to my expectations. So i decided for another early access game which wasn't about survival and proved to be a perfect hit. I tried a couple more early access games but lost this one vastness of the steam store, while i turned more and more sour in my opinion towards early access, untill about 4 days ago. And I currently 40 hours in, I should get back to studying.

With all the heart that Hinterland is putting into this gem, The Long Dark feels cold, as cold as the land in which you are stranded. It's ruthless and death lurks about everywhere and everywhen. But after a day stalking and exploring your way from hut to hut (only applies to one map), running for your life, freezing half to death you finally take shelter. Dusk has already come and it is starting to get a lot colder. There, struggling to get a fire started, you hear your belly rumbling, your lips dry of dehydration. Finally you manage to light up a small fire. You melt some snow in the last light of the day and take a zip. You heat up your canned food just assuming that you wont have any meat yetand a feeling of gladness, relaxation sets in for a moment. Your struggles payed off. You are still alive. Alive but tired. And thus the moment passes. You go to bed to wake up to another day to explore the world. To gather what you need in order to be unbound from the luck of scavanging, to sustain yourself.

All in all i can only recomend this game. it is definitely worth the 19 € it is currently priced at and already feels like a solid game. But wait there is more! This game actually uses the alpha! I personally can't wait for story mode which is soon to come!

9.5/10 from me

Cheers!

Early Access Review
								I have taken sometime to play this game myself and I decided that I should write a review here so that it would be helpful for those who read it and decide whether to purchase this game or not.Get to the point, right now the game is in 'Early Access' so it is not really complete. However, personally, only what the Early Access has offered now worths the money.The very first thing that can be accounted as pros is the the game's very own concept. It is a new dimension of 'survival game', unlike many mainstream survival game lists which involve zombies and mutants to horrify you, this game is another story: just you against the 'Mother Nature'. You are on your own, among the cold, hunger, thirst, tiredness, or even danger from wolves. All you need to do is 'survive'. It sounds simple and uninteresting, but believe me this game is well enough even with this simplicity in this game genre. No safe place with lots of supplies (unless you choose 'Pilgrim' mode). You need to take risks with your own actions. Everything is by yourself.The gameplay ... I don't know if I should classify it as a pro or con, but it is mixed. You can never expect anything from each playthrough; when you restart, everything except the regions will be resetted. This gives you the survival experience to some extends. For example, you might find a rifle, the only 'real' weapon in the game, without any bullets before you find one bullet miles away, or you need a can opener but still yet to be found; what will you do? which way? where is it going to be? Everything which other survival games may overlook matters in this game. You need clothes to keep you warm, raw food, if not cooked well, can be a threat when eaten, or you can even hurt your legs if you do not watch your steps (which happens to me a lot lol). These are some of the situations that I found and I need to give the 'thumb up' for the developer's careful planning so as to make this game as realistc as possible.However, there is something that still bugs me; the wolves. They still lack realistic movements: too repetitive and can be easy to deal with as you get get used to the game. Even though the developer has mentioned something about the wolves, their movements and some behaviors, such as how slow or fast it should be in different situations, are needed for consideration *for developers*. I hope if the wolves are readjusted in the right way it would gives me more exciting experience. Nevertheless, even with this comment I still find dealing with wolves sometimes hard anyway. (I heard that more wildlife will be added, so it might be the solution for this problem as well.)If you are fans of survival game and need a new dimension on survival experience, I suggest you that you buy this and try it once or wait for sometime until the full release comes (Story Mode, I'm really looking forward to that!). My last warning .."Beware of the wolves, the cold, or even yourself as you play this game". Good Job Hinterland!

Early Access Review
								If you're looking to buy this game, here's a list of all the pros and cons.Pros:- Challenging to some extent- Beautiful art and sound combination - very imersive- Semi big maps (Sort of feels like the skyrim but instead of just having one huge main map and tiny sub maps, every map is linked together)- Quick access user interface (everything you need is in the screen when you open up the view you want)- There are moments when it is terrifying. There are no jumpscares, long dark uses that psychological horrorific fact that you're all alone.- Good crafting system (but need some improvements at some aspects)Cons- No tutorials. The game chucks you in there and says "good luck surviving". You would have no idea what to do at the beginning or where to go, which sometimes causes players to refund the game. If you're the type of person who likes to figure out things on the fly, this shouldn't matter too much.- Restricted crafting. What I mean by this is at the moment, arrow heads can only be crafted at the forge. A forge can ONLY be found at Desolation Point, which is one map out of the 4 maps. If you ever think about hunting with a bow and arrow because rifle rounds cannot be crafted and you started at Mystery Lake or some other map, you're out of luck. You HAVE to travel to desolation point. (Hopefully they add more forges in, but at the moment, 1 forge exists in the game).- There is a tendency to run out of things to do. If you are the type of person who just wants to stay in one place and hide inside a house, I warn you. If you have EVERYTHING you need, you have the tendency to stay in that safe haven and get bored because you run out of things to do. There's no base building mechanics (yet, I don't know if they think about adding it), but if you're just going to stay in one place, you'd get bored in around 9 hours of gameplay straight (because that's how long it takes to get all your stuff as well as getting enough food and everything you need to survive if you know your map enough).Conclusion: Every gaming experience is different. You never know how you'd find the game until you play it. I've listed all the pros and cons of the game and it's really up to you on whether you want it or not. If you do buy it, make sure you have heaps of flares and good luck surviving.EDIT: Nominated for the "Just five more minutes" Award

Posted: March 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game is early access and still in development. This review is based on build v375 and roughly 340 hours of gameplay. At the time of writing this review, only the sandbox mode and a number of "challenges" were available. A story mode which will feature a coherent story is announced, but the release has been postponed several times, and currently no release date has been set.It's a first person survival game set in a Canadian Winter wilderness after a geomagnetic disaster. All electric devices have ceased functioning, whether there are other survivors is unclear (NPCs have been announced for the sandbox for a future update). The player has to battle the adversities of cold, hunger, thirst, fatigue, wild animals and health issues, while exploring abandoned leftovers of civilization. No zombies, no arsenal of super-guns, no vehicles. Just the player against nature or, well, a model of nature.The game pleases with superb art style and sound effects. Sunrise, sunset, starry night skies and the snowy landscape in general are simply beautiful to behold and have been made to look a bit like oil paintings. Everything creates an atmosphere of beauty, but at the same time loneliness and urgency. The player needs to scavenge abandoned houses, cars, forestry lookouts, factories etc. to find means to survive as long as possible. And if you learn the mechanics of the world surrounding you, it is possible to survive for a very long time.The developers kept up a steady pace of updating and honing the sandbox mode, also adding new regions from time to time (there are now 5 major regions, each with its own "feel"), but have slowed down at some time in 2016. They are super-friendly and give feedback to even the strangest comments from players. There is a dedicated community at the developers homepage (Hinterland Games) which is worth checking out.This game is not for everyone - it does not take your hand. You have to explore it, and the higher difficulty modes may frustrate people not used to overcome obstacles with patience. But for me, only the sandbox mode is one of the best games I have ever played. And I have basically played almost all the landmark games since 1983. I can't believe I only payed 20  € for this gem. And it's not even finished.A number of players are becoming impatient, because the release of story mode has been postponed several times and development seems to have slowed down. However, I for one firmly believe the game will be finished in due time. Even if it weren't, I would still recommend to buy this for the full price. I think the time I have spent playing the game speaks for itself.

Early Access Review
								BUY THIS GAMEThis game is incredible, and its developers have put unparalleled effort into making it so unique. Everything from the graphics to the game mechanics contribute towards the game's unique atmosphere and mood. Honestly, I would pay 60 bucks to get this game in its final state. It inhabits a frightening, lonely, and unforgiving wilderness and forces you to make life and death decisions, take risks, and face your doom countless times in any given playthrough. Surviving and succeeding is difficult but feels extremely rewarding. The maps are large and diverse, offering room for nomadic play styles and more settling playing styles. There are too many good things to write in this review, so just play the game to find out. It is not without flaws, however. At its current state, it is lacking in some content, although I am confident that the addition of story mode (and hopefully co-op at some point maybe?) will fill in that gap. Sometimes, however, the games mostly successful "realism", ends up being a little bit too realistic. Wolves are a bit too aggressive, they should be more territorial and defensive. The hunger mechanics are a bit ridicoulous at times (aka I shouldn't be eating 2 deer, 3 fish, and 2 cans of beans a day...) The coastline highway map lacks workbenches and some much needed fireplaces (Why are their stoves in little fishing huts but not most of the houses?), and there is a very strange lack of roads in the mystery lake map.Overall, the game is an 8.5/10 for me, and thats in its early stages. Definitely buy this one

Early Access Review
								I want to preface this review by saying that I'm not normally one who writes reviews in the first place. But this game changed that.If you like survival games, this one seems to be the pinnacle. I've never before played a survival game that is as much fun or tense. Lemme give you a recount of my first three games.Game 1: Woke up in the middle of the night, in a blizzard. I had no idea where to go and began freezing fast. I realized I had a flare and popped it as quick as I could. I began to run through the woods. As I reached the end of my rope, I saw a small cottage in the distance and I ran for it as quick as I could. I made my way inside and found some food. I waited a day or so until I ran out of food then ventured outside once more.......and directly into the jaws of a wolf. I died, due to lack of food and preparation. I nearly♥♥♥♥♥♥myself when the wolf jumped on me.Game 2: Woke up during the day, afternoon I believe. The weather was relatively peaceful, and I managed to find a group of houses. I picked them apart then chose one for my own uses. Upon slightly stocking it over the course of a few days, I ended up making a fatal mistake by leaving to go exploring. A blizzard hit, and I couldn't find my way back in time before I froze to death.Game 3: By far my most successful one. Woke up around 9 am. I ventured from mystery lake to coastal highway along a set of railroad tracks. When I reached coastal highway I fell off of a cliff and ended up spraining my ankle. I hobbled along until I heard wolves behind me. I moved as quick as I could and at last spotted a cabin. I stayed there for a day, resting my ankle until it was functional once more. I began exploring a series of fishing villages, plundering what I could from the worn down houses. I found a gas station and began stockpiling it. A week passed in game, I had a good thing going. And then those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ wolves moved in. I don't know if there is a pack tendency, or if they are randomly placed, or if they aren't supposed to move from one zone to another. But suddenly I had four wolves scratching at my door. I had found a rifle, but only had three bullets. I knew flares would scare them off, but not for good. But then I realized that they were taking down deer in the area. Then I formed a sort of symbiotic relationship with them. I wouldn't kill them and they killed deer, soon after which I'd go and carve the carcass up. I began stockpiling more food, and more, until I had a hefty amount. Day eleven rolled by, and I decided that I wanted to check out some of those ice fishing shacks I had spotted on the horizon. I geared up and made my way out to one. So begins my fatal mistake.I arrived at one and was relatively unharmed for a day. Then a wolf happened by. I had one bullet left, at this point, and I used it on the wolf, figuring it was the only one. Not the case. Three more soon arrived, huddling around the ice fishing shack. I knew that I was on borrowed time by this point. I spent three nights holed up in that shack, (earning the achievement for spending three nights outdoors), then made my peace with whatever God is out there, and I stepped outside. The moment I did, I was pounced and killed. Surviving an epic 15 days and 7 hours.It was amazing. ProsGood survival aspects such as calorie count, which drains as you preform heavy tasks such as harvesting wood, skinning animals, running, etc., and a tempurature gauge (including windchill!) to help you monitor how much body heat you have.The game feels balanced enough (for an early access game, no less) that you don't feel helped along by the mechanics, but they are fair enough to where you can, if you're smart, find or steal enough food for yourself to survive. That's what it boils down to in the end, food. Weather effects are amazing, and there's something to be said for being trapped in a building for three days because there is a blizzard outside. The game is beautiful, it reminds me somewhat of The Telltale games. It has a sort of handpainted, almost comic book look to it. The sound design is fairly well done. Wind whips around buildings and wolves howl in the distance. At night it's peaceful, houses settle as you're in them. The sound design further helps the idea that you are indeed, very much alone in this world.A minor crafting system is implemented, meaning that it should expand further in the upcoming months. The dev community seems very into the game and seems to be actively working on it. Cons It is in early access, so the game is not completed, first off.Some bugs.Occasionally you'll be spawned somewhere, in the middle of the night, in a blizzard, with no way to survive.Animal behavior is erratic and, sometimes, downright weird. Though I imagine that'll be improved with time.Very small area to explore once you've done it.I am aware that this is early access, and I don't begrudge the game for it. At the end of the day it is an amazing early access game, and one that I would wholeheartedly tell everyone to support. It has an enormous amount of potential, and I would love to see this game be taken further.tl;dr: Great survival game, still in early access, buy it anyway.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is an early access game by Hinterland set in northern Canada. Although it's a survival game, death is inevitable and, in my opinion, inspires the game's title. There is a story mode planned for release by the end of this year, but for anyone who buys the game right now the sole experience will be the sandbox mode.Players find themselves randomly thrown into the wilderness with nothing but the clothes they wear, a few matches, a sleeping bag, and maybe a flare or accelerant if they're lucky. The time of day, location and weather conditions are random so it is even possible to start in the middle of the night during a blizzard. However, even starting in the middle of a sunny afternoon, it will still be cold and bleak, and the player will soon need to contend with freezing, starvation, dehydration and fatigue. All of this is represented in an intuitive status screen that players will refer to often. In order to manage these needs, players must seek shelter and find what remains of civilization, which has been devestated by a mysterious geomagnetic event. This event has also disturbed some of the natural wildlife, and wolves that roam the wilderness are unusually hostile and will attack if the player wanders too close.Even if the player does find shelter and supplies, almost everything found will degrade over time. This includes food, clothing, a hatchet everytime it is used to chop wood or butcher meat, a rifle whenever it is fired, or even a toolkit whenever it is used to try to maintain the hatchet and rifle. This degradation mechanic causes the player to value every decision and plan carefully to maximize resources while continuing the struggle to survive. Although the game is early access, this degradation mechanic has been in the game from the beginning and is considered a core mechanic, so this feature will almost certainly remain in the game all the way until its official launch.Above all, the reason why I love this game is its atmosphere. Because everything degrades, I always feel a sense of urgency. Even if I kill a deer, harvest and cook the meat, and have a whole locker full of venison steaks in my base, I know that it won't be long before I need more. On top of that, if I use a knife or hatchet to help with harvesting the deer, or a rifle or bow and arrows to kill it, I also know that eventually those tools will wear out, so I also must be vigilent in my search to find replacements. Ultimately, the player will run out of tools and materials to keep those tools in good repair. Although a player may struggle on beyond this point, the odds of survival will decrease further and further until, eventually, the player must face death. Although to some this may sound frustrating, on the contrary that challenge of pushing the boundaries is a large part of the appeal. Because tools are limited, the player is encouraged to think of creative solutions on how to minimize the drain of resources.Adding to the atmosphere are also the sound and graphic style. Especially since some of the recent updates, the Long Dark really is beatiful -- that is, when it isn't errie or terrifying. Because the time of day and weather both change, there are lots of different possible settings. It could be a bright and clear afternoon, or it might be midnight with a blizzard that has reduced visibility to three feet. It could be a beautiful sunrise looking out across the landscape from a lookout tower or it might be evening, a thick fog, and the errie sound of wolves howling somewhere beyond.Now, I will end this review with a few points of criticism. Although another wonderful aspect of this game is the sense of exploration and discovery, that does diminish over time. The regions generally have very little that is randomized in terms of the locations themselves. The result of this is that the player eventually learns all of the locations, has very little chance of becoming lost, and no longer sees anything new when traveling the map to gather supplies. I would love it if the game's world could be procedurally generated in the future, but that may be too much to ask because ultimately The Long Dark is being developed with a story mode in mind. Despite this criticism, the world is detailed and fun to re-explore.The other criticism concerns the wolves which, along with the weather, currently represent the primary antagonist to the player. To beginners, the wolves may seem insurmountable because the wolves roam the world in large numbers and are always hostile to the player except on the game's easiest difficulty setting (in which case they are never hostile and always run away). On the other hand, to experienced players wolves become easy to handle and a convenient source of food. I will address my own criticism by emphasizing that the game is still in early access and, unlike other early access titles, gets monthly, substantive updates. In sum, the wolves are generally a fun antagonist but still a work in progress that will continue to be improved.Bottomline: If you like survival games, you should pick this up. I understand some people have doubts about early access. If that describes yourself, you might also consider checking out a let's play to get a better sense of what the game is like. But if you do, be sure to find one that isn't more than a month old (although watch one that's a year old if you want to see how far the game has come in that time). Also, avoid watching too much footage so that you can enjoy that sense of discovery I discussed earlier as much as possible. Lastly, watch the movie The Grey, which bears some striking similiaries to The Long Dark in both its setting and theme.

								BUY THIS GAMEThis game is incredible, and its developers have put unparalleled effort into making it so unique. Everything from the graphics to the game mechanics contribute towards the game's unique atmosphere and mood. Honestly, I would pay 60 bucks to get this game in its final state. At its current state, it is lacking in some content, although I am confident that the addition of story mode (and hopefully co-op at some point maybe?) will fill in that gap. Sometimes, however, the games mostly successful "realism", ends up being a little bit too realistic. Wolves are a bit too aggressive, they should be more territorial and defensive. The hunger mechanics are a bit ridicoulous at times (aka I shouldn't be eating 2 deer, 3 fish, and 2 cans of beans a day...) The coastline highway map lacks workbenches and some much needed fireplaces (Why are their stoves in little fishing huts but not most of the houses?), and there is a very strange lack of roads in the mystery lake map.Overall, the game is an 8.5/10 for me, and thats in its early stages. Definitely buy this one

Early Access Review
								Gameplay is very well polished and I haven't encountered any game breakng bug (crashes and etc.). Also preferred the way they handle resource gathering (like chopping trees and transporting item), '7 days to die' and 'the forest' for e.g. has actual physics with the tree toppling and stuff but it usually ends up with really annoying physics game. The most important part of this game is that it actually feels like a survival game i.e. the world is always trying to kill you (the damn blizzard, the damn wolf or the damn bear). Initially you might survive on looting the abandoned world, but sooner or later you will need to start crafting your own stuff. Although your character gets more skilled overtime, making it easier to start a fire or gather resources, sooner or later you won't be able to maintain real world gear (knife/hatchet and etc.) and will have to start using makeshift gear (improvised knife, animal skin clothing or even magnifiying glass to start fire). Nothing is permanent in this world of TLD, eventually everything runs out, until then, you try and survive for as long as possible.TLDR:If you enjoy survival games that sorts of parallel real life survival, or if you are sick of incomplete and broken survival game out there, you will definitely enjoy this game. My only hope is that the dev don't rush it and properly finish TLD.

Early Access Review
								This is a first day review. I've only played TLD about 4 hours at this point. I had to quit out of my 3rd playthrough, in which I have been alive for about 3 days, in order to go to sleep (in real life). However, I didn't want to do this. In fact, I really wanted to keep playing... scavenging... scraping by...... surviving. This is the magic of The Long Dark. I was hesitant to make the initial purchase, but I went with my gut and I have not since, in any way, shape, or form regretted doing so. This game is unforgiving, ruthless, and requires constant thinking and moving - or you die. And die you will. But this, however pointless as it sounds, is what makes the sandbox mode (the only mode available for the early access) so damn appealing. Each time you start over, you begin to pick up on things you didn't previously. You learn how to manage your resources better, how to assess and prioritize which needs should be met, and all the while you watch the clock and count the hours that go by with intensity and hope, however small that hope is - to live just a bit longer... to hold on, to find a way. The Long Dark is absolutely amazing and simply downright a blast to play. I can honestly say that it has me excited and hooked already. I'm looking forward to the Story mode, but for the time being will be completely satisfied with hammering away at the Sandbox. As of this moment I'd probably give TLD an 8/10. Well done, Hinterland Studio. Well done.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Game makes you never wanna go on a hike ever again, 10/10Seriously though. I have NEVER played a more atmospheric survival game. The immersion factor of the world is unbelievable, and being in it not only has you on the lookout for its more wild inhabitants, but also has you looking for dangers like hunger, thirst, exhaustion and the weather itself. Speaking of weather, the game beautifully displays the changing of its many dynamic conditions available. These conditions, whether it be snow, fog or the powerful wind whistling in your ears as you trudge through the world, all convey the sense that it IS a fight for survival, and you'll need to do everything you can to win.In its current alpha state, the game is VERY good. Although some systems need refinining, some optimization issues are present, and some more stuff needs to be added to make it a complete package, the game is still VERY fun and worth a buy for anyone looking for a game that will make you consider every possible decision, regret every time your fire goes out, and make you dread every howl you hear at night. This was only on my first run, so if I come across anything else worth noting soon or in future updates, I will update my review. EDIT 1: So, I've put a lot more time into it. As I've played there are some more notable things I haven't talked about yet, and my opinions on what could make the game even better.The systems. There are systems in this game you'd struggle to find in a modern AAA games, such as the different things affecting your ability to buld a fire, the amount of calories you have in your system, and the likeliness you'll be able to succeed in crafting (although this feature is rather undercooked at the moment. When you're cold, you can't do things effectively. When you're tired, good luck carrying all the gear you picked up. Hungry? Better check how old that venison is or else you might succumb to food poisoning. Things like these make the systems in the game feel fleshed out and more realistic, for lack of a better word, than other survival games on the market.Now, as much as I sound like I have no problem with this game (though the features that are currently present DO undermine any problems I have) there are some cons to the game, and ways to make them better. 1. Map size- The map is not as big as I would have originally hoped. Now, I know this is only the first  map of many, but I had memorized the layout by my third life (which was very short). After you've memorized it, the exploration factor which I loved in my first couple hours started to fade.   2. Combat and item use- Combat in The Long Dark revolves either around taking your foe out at long-range with a rare hunting rifle, or letting them jump on you and hopefully building up you attack power, and punching them off this way. I feel there should be a way to use a hunting knife or hatchet during a close quarters situation to be able to kill a wolf. I know, in real life you probably wouldn't be able to react this way when a wolf starts chasing you, but it gives players with low health and other status effects, i.e. starvation, exhaustion or a sprained ankle, a chance to survive a wolf attack instead of running away. And it doesn't have to be easy, just something players can do for a last chance.3.  Inventory- Lastly, inventory can sometimes be a pain to manage. Although it gives you a feeling you need to take what you truly need to survive, I sometimes wish you had more of a carrying capacity, or maybe it could fluctuate depending on your condition. The capacity DOES however change based on what status you're at, but the change is only made between when you're exhausted and when you aren't. These things will change, I know, because it's still in Alpha. For the content you get right now, the game is still worth every cent you throw at it, and I'd highly recommend it in it's current state.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a solid framework for a huge survival hit. You take on a first person perspective of someone dropped into a frozen wasteland after a plane crash.  I've had three or four run throughs (all but one on the Mystery Lake sandbox). The first one was just a feel out, then I restarted with a good sense of the controls and when traveling was a good investment. My first two deaths in this game were both freezing to death, and I felt like I deserved those deaths as I ran out of food and had to go out to search for more resources. Fun, gritty, atmospheric. I was ready to be addicted to this game.The whole time during the early playthroughs, I had noticed wolves, and my thoughts were always, "Man, there are a lot of those." I always managed to keep my distance and keep an eye on them, so they never got to me. But I never enjoyed wolf encounters much. It took the game from a thoughtful, atmospheric survival game with lots of satisfying resource management and time for reflection to a Liam Neeson "The Grey" action game that takes me out of the world and makes me desperate to avoid something akin to a jump scare, since it is for all intensive purposes impossible to win a wolf struggle with any consistency.In the most recent runthrough, a wolf in the dam on Mystery Lake actually did jump-scare me. I was followed by two wolves into the dam, and without a sound or sight of this other wolf, it jumped on top of me and destroyed me.I actually liked how panicked the struggle made me feel, fighting for survival. But based on what I've seen in game and what I read on the forums, wolf encounters are far too frequent, and the struggles far too frustrating to be a major game mechanic. They destroy any resources the player has accumulated, make skill improvements become meaningless, and are a complete buzzkill for the morbid majesty this survival game otherwise does so well.Indeed, that is my biggest complaint: the wolves seem to remove the player from the measured, thoughtful, immersive scrape for survival and make the game lose some of that novel "the elements are slowing killing me" feeling.Maybe my vision for the game differs from that of the developers, and they do want that higher stress, more action packed, more sudden deathy atmosphere that the wolves provide. But if that is the vision, they will lose the following of me and hundreds of others on the forums.If their vision is mine of survival as long as you can on your wits and abilities in a quiet wasteland, then I recommend they change wolves entirely. Far fewer, maybe 2 or 3 total on the sandbox maps. They only attack you if they are desperate and you are weak. The wolf struggles add just a little bit of excitement to the game, and so should be present in just a small dose.I recognize this game is in alpha at the time of this review, and wolf balancing is a major issue on Hinterland’s plate. I will continue to watch it and play it, though if wolves or other wildlife attacks become the “main enemy” of the game, then it will lose my support moving forward.Otherwise, the game is excellent. The mechanics of hunger, exhaustion, thirst, and cold all work pretty well, and are improving as the game develops. The atmosphere and art are taking an excellent direction, the crafting system shows a lot of promise, and the coastal highway map shows the developers will be able to include multiple compelling locations with different survival challenges in each.It should consume a few hours of your life, and if the wolves come under control, it may just be the next addictive hit on Steam.

content:
Posted: February 1
Early Access Review
								I've played TLD ever since it was released in Pre-Alpha, and I have to say it's come a long way since then. TL;DR If you're looking for a survival game that's atmospheric and beautiful, yet simutaneously challenging and terrifying, this is the game for you.Here's the meat:Devs: In a word: EPIC. The devs send out massive updates year on year, adding more flora, fauna, items, crafts, maps - the list goes on. Owning this game is essentially owning the rights to new content on a semi-regular basis. None of that DLC rubbish. Just pure and honest content. The devs make TLD a worthwhile investment.Atmospherics: You can tell Hinterland Studio spent a great deal of effort on the quality of their sound effects. Playing TLD with dolby 5.1 surround sound headphones in the dark room is enough to convince me that I've been transported to a frozen post-apocalyptic wasteland. Aside from sound quality, environmental elements like dynamic weather effects (e.g. strong winds actually feel strong as they sway even the largest of trees) adds a layer of immersion most triple A titles often overlook. In fact, TLD hinges on its ability to deliver quality atmospherics and environments. I found myself sitting at the top of a hill just watching the waves crash against the icy coastline against the backdrop of the sunset for about 5 minutes. It was the most zen moment in video game history, I assure you.Visuals: Don't expect mindblowing post-processing, hyper reflective, overly filtered, mind-numbing graphics from TLD. It simply just isn't that type of game. It represents its own stylised version of reality. It kind of looks like a beautiful watercolour painting, except it's interactive and you get to explore it. It may even turn out to be a master stroke (pun intended) on Hinterland's part to design the game this way - using the Unity engine - as it makes the whole visual representation of the game timeless. In other words, if you play this game in 5 years time it won't look dated in the way some triple As do when it's been a while.Gameplay: Ah finally, the gameplay. Arguably the most important factor in any video game. I'll get to the good parts in a second, but there are couple niggles I have to contend with first. 1) movement feels a bit clunky and unrefined. And 2) the inventory management system is overly complicated and lacks visual representation. It can make it hard to locate items if you aren't sure what category it belongs in. For instance, instead of just having a list of items on a grid, how about an image of the bag with compartments that clearly designate what kind of item would be found there? It's difficult to imagine fitting a rifle the length of your leg inside a bag. You could show it slung onto a silhouette of the character's body, and when it's not there, have a silhouette of the rifle, indicating that it would be there if you had one. Just a suggestion. Another aspect that bugs me is the lack of hand animations. Given the attention to detail elsewhere in this game, it's a little strange to find that Hinterland overlooked this. For example, you become a handless person who can magically reload a bolt action rifle with your mind. Sensational, but immersion-breaking. Who knows, maybe it'll come in an update.It's not all bad though. Rummaging though houses and buildings for resources is simple and streamlined, so it doesn't feel like a chore. There are enough props and containers to make sure you aren't opening and closing the same closets and drawers time and again, and the items available for the user to find are worthwhile. I also love the fragility of the player because it doesn't take much to kill or injure yourself. What might look like a relatively small hop down from a rock might end up breaking your ankle. It makes sense, as you're likely carrying ~30kgs on top of your own weight. Even worse, once you die, there are no reverting saves. When you're dead your savegame is automatically deleted, which makes the prospect of death all the more terrifying as you extend your run. But that's the fun of it.However, my absolute favourite element of this game is its emphasis on exploration. The playable area is huge, with every individual map weaved together via corridors of travel. So if you decide upon say 'Mystery Lake' instead of 'Coastal Highway' as your spawn point, you can always crossover during your run. Each map also offers its own unique level of difficulty, so exploration comes at a cost. But sitting around in a cabin for 40 days will ultimately see you run out of resources in your immediate area, so being nomadic is part of the experience. That doesn't mean you can't be sedentary though - but don't expect to see past 50 days unless you're meticulously resourceful.Conclusion: It's worth every penny. The sandbox nature of survival means that there's lots of room for replayability. The attention to detail will have you totally immersed, whilst the fragility of your character means every decision you make has to be well planned and well executed if you are to live to see the next day. You won't find another game on the market quite like TLD.

Early Access Review
								I'll admit, it was the unique art style of The Long Dark that initially drew me in.  I loved the way the lighting seemed to work with the stark contrast between the whites and browns of nature and the reds and chestnuts of man man objects.  There is no denying the game is absolutely gorgeous, and it succeeds in making you want to kick down your front door and go exploring.However, you had better pray that you can find a hammer and nails to reattach that door before the sun goes down.  The beauty of The Long Dark is also it's most dangerous aspect.  It's easy to get lost in the wonderful landscape that Hinterland Games has crafted, but underneath a black night sky with plummeting temperatures it is only a siren's song.  Wolves will stalk your trail, seemingly alert to your deteriorating condition.  Sometimes, the only way you will know their presence is through their foreboding howls, following you as you desperately seek shelter from the freezing cold and brutal wind.Eating food, staying hydrated, rested and warm are essential to survival in The Long Dark.  You will find supplies like candy bars, pork & beans, beef jerky and military food packets to help you stay alive.  The attention to detail is delightful even if it stands in the way of your best case scenario for living another day.  Canned food requires a can opener to access, unless you want to smash it open and risk losing some of the food.  Your character will make remarks when he/she is hungry, thirsty, cold or tired and you would do well to take care of these ailments before they start affecting your condition.  When your condition meter reaches 0%, you will finally succumb to the Terrible Outdoors.  The Long Dark will give you stats on how long you managed to survive and what you died of before sending you back to the main menu.The alpha version of the game features a Survival sandbox, with a story about a Geomagnetic disaster coming later with the full game release.  For now, purchasing the Early Access version helps the studio identify and fix issues with the game, and helps them fund the overall project through release.If you love open world games with gorgeous visuals, unique gameplay, and you have the desire to see how long you would survive in the middle of nowhere with limited supplies;  The Long Dark is for you.

								Latest update: It's a few months into 2017, and still no ETA on the story/campaign. I want to believe.Update: I'm so damn sick of games sitting in Early Access for years. In real life, I would grab a big stick and use it. Not in The Long Dark; no, you can't use your axe or find any intelligent way to ward the wolves off after your flares run out.- I survived for nearly a month and only found half of the ingredients needed to make a bow and arrow. It's ridiculous that you need to find 2 different types of rare tree saplings just to make a simple bow. How about making a spear instead, or even just a pointy stick?- Clothes degrade at least ten times faster than they do in real life.- Thirst accumulates faster than it does in real life.- Hunger accumulates faster than it does in real life (but is much closer to accuracy than thirst, and it drains accurately while sleeping)However, the temperature balance seems polished and well-implemented, and the ambiance and art style are nice. The main complaint is that the constant threat of wolves is not offset by the common-sense ability to pick up and use a freaking stick, or maybe not be so damn picky about your choice of bow and arrow materials (alternately, maybe maple and birch saplings shouldn't be rarer than the lost city of Atlantis).

Early Access Review
								Right straight off the bat, this game is brutal. In my 2 hours of gameplay at time of writing I've died twice and been attacked by wolves 4 times. Yet I've enjoyed every minute so far, and it really feels like I've played for much much longer.The mechanics are rather simple, and therein lies the games strength. Keep yourself rested,warm,fed,watered & out of trouble to survive, everything you do burns calories, so make sure you have enough to stay fit.The world is stunningly realised and if wandering around aimlessly wasn't so fatal, I could spend a long time exploring the initial map the sandbox mode currently has available.Time for a few minor gripes. Whilst you do need a lot of calories to survive in the cold (approx 6000-8000 a day) the game does burn through a considerable amount more than that. I checked when indoors, with a 'feels like' temperature of 19C (i.e. typical room temperature) with all my winter gear on, I was burning 200+ cal per hour, so almost the expected cold requirement, only at room temp. Whilst increasing this value for gameplay reasons is understandable, I have basically spent my entire play time so far both hungry and eating almost constantly.My only other gripe is the wolves, and the systems designed to combat them. There are a lot of wolves, and they are very aggressive (pretty much attack on sight) and can be warded off with flares. But if they attack you, the only course of action is to frantically punch them, which can get slightly silly if you have a knife on your character.Wrapping it up, overall an enjoyable, robust experience (especially for early access) that could do with a few minor balancing changes to avoid having to eat near constantly just to prevent your hunger level getting worse. Also as it's in the trailer it's not much of a spoiler, yes there is a wolf in the dam, his name his Fluffy, and he respawns.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								So in 2013 I did a race that was considered one of the toughest mountain bike races in the world, The Tour Divide.  It extended from Canada to Mexico over the Continental Divide, unsupported.  We started in Banff, Canada and rode out from there where we were left to our own wits and survival.  Everything I had for the next month was on my bike and that's how I lived.  The Long Dark, while you're not on a bike, is a bit like the race.  You're constantly wondering if you have enough food, enough water, was there a predator lurking about (not wolves, we had to worry about Grizzlies).  In the game, you do this, you figure stuff out and it's fun... depressing, but fun.This is the first game I'm actively avoiding all videos, how-to's and spoilers because I want to figure it out on my own, take my time and enjoy it.  The artistic beauty, grim deaths and isolated gameplay really throw me back in the Tour Divide pushing my bike up the side of a mountain in the middle of the night, alone and freezing.As a casual gamer who lightly plays games, I cannot recommend this enough.  I feel drawn in and "cold" when I play it and it's a haunting comfort to hop in and play. It does come with a few snags and that's mainly performance on my Macbook Air.  It gets a little sluggish in fullscreen but runs fine in a smaller window.  I don't mind.(Also if you're interested, I wrote a book about the Tour Divide race which has some similarities to The Long Dark.  You can find out more at http://www.softpedaling.com).

Early Access Review
								I have been following this game since the Kickstarter last year. (Which I backed) I had pretty high hopes for this game and it showed great potential. As many other reviewers pointed out, when this game first released into Early Access it was almost unplayable. You froze within minutes of starting, or you died of hunger within minutes of starting, or you ran out of calories within minutes of starting, or you died of thirst within minutes of starting or you get killed by a wolf within seconds of starting. Yes, seconds. Once a wolf had you in sights, you might as well restart because there was no escaping or surviving. If you managed to somehow survive a wolf attack, you would quickly die of infection or bleeding out. Why in the hell can't you use your hatchet or hunting knife or rifle to kill it when it attacks you?!? Cooking the food did no good. You still got food poisoning even after cooking the food. RIDICULOUS! Sitting ONE inch away from a BURNING FIRE didn't even help warm you up a single degree, even while you're using one of the pits inside the house. How does a fire in a house not warm you up past 40 degrees?!? Especially when you're basically standing INSIDE the damn fire.But since the latest update, they have addressed ALMOST ALL OF THESE ISSUES! Calories don't burn QUITE as fast. Still really damn quick though. You definitely don't freeze as fast. A fire finally seems to warm you up when you're sitting next to it. Hunger takes a TINY bit longer to kick in and thirst is pretty easy to quench so long as you have even the tiniest amount of water. The wolfs no longer home in on you like a heat-seeker missile. You can actually run away now, but only IF you are far enough away. Cooking the food finally seems to help from getting food poisoning(ABOUT TIME).They still haven't addressed being able to use the HUNTING knife or Hatchet to fight the wolf off. You still have to fight it off with your bare hands, which is ALMOST impossible. Seriously, why have a HUNTING knife if you can't use it when you get attacked?!?The game is beautiful and the artwork is amazing. The sounds and music are both really good. It just needs some minor tweaks to help make it a lot better.I'm glad I waited until after they did a few updates before I did this review, because if I hadn't then it would have just been all negative. But instead I waited to let them get the updates out. This way I got to try it both BEFORE and AFTER the updates. The game has IMPROVED VASTLY with these new updates. I really hope they continue to listen to feedback and make adjustments accordingly. So far, it's working out pretty well.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is everything I wanted Skyrim to be. I loved Skyrim. I still do. But I wanted more realism. I wanted to feel like every little choice really mattered. In Skyrim, you can run through the snow in your underwear, and the only thing you have to worry about is stumbling across a wolf or troll, but you can usually cut them down with a chop or two.Not so with The Long Dark. The Long Dark, even in its alpha stage is as intense and challenging as a game of chess against the game world itself. Every move you make has consequences. Every little thing you do or don't do could mean life or death.You are a survivor of a plane crash in the Canadian North. You have the shirt on your back, a pair of boots, and a few bits of food. You're in a blizzard in the middle of nowhere, and there are wolves on the hunt. Go.Maybe you see a cabin in the distance, in the blinding cold and blowing snow. Maybe you find a hatchet. Maybe you find nothing at all. You're slowly freezing to death, but you must find some wood. Do you have enough calories to go out foraging? But if you don't, how will you melt snow and boil it to get clean water? You're thirsty too. Very thirsty. And the clock is ticking.It's this kind of intensity, this kind of challenge, where consequences loom behing every little choice that's missing in almost every other game I've ever played. It keeps you coming back, again and again, even after you died so many times in the bitter cold. You keep coming back because you learned something, and you just might do better the next time. You just might survive a few more days.A good game rewards you. And this is something that's beautiful in The Long Dark. Because every little choice matters, because every hour of survival is bought with intelligent choices and lots of luck, that one scrap of food or firewood you find in a cabin is worth more than gold to you. You almost want to cheer. The rewards are doled out like breadcrumbs down the trail of life, and you keep searching for the next one. You keep fighting for your next hour of life.You're also rewarded by levelling up skills. You become better and better at making a fire after a few days. You improve in repairing and crafting new gear. The crafting system is interesting and engaging as well. You find an old pair of pants or a sweater that you don't need? Harvest it for cloth and use it to repair the gear you're already wearing. Patch that hole the wolves tore in it. Fix up your hatchet with the scrap metal you found in a locker. Cobble together a pair of deerskin boots with the hides you've scavenged off of a carcass in the woods. It's all so involving, and it only adds to the sense of reward. I made this! And it just might help me survive a few more days.The music is creepy and intense, but it only comes on occasionally, when something of consequence is going down. Otherwise, there's only the wind and woods, creaking trees, squawking crows, and your own breath. The graphics are stylized. It's not a realistic world. It's somewhat cartoony, TF2 style. But it's not a flaw. You can see for miles on a clear day, and everything looks beautiful, like a painting you've somehow wandered into, a painting that's trying to kill you.And thank God, there are no zombies. I'm sick to death of zombies. This game pits you against the real world, a world unpolluted by all the survival horror cliches that have been done to death in by every other game in the past ten years. (Guitar Hero: Zombie Edition? Go f*ck yourself.)If I had to complain about anything in this game, I'd say the item lists need to be expanded. There are only five or six types of food. A couple of each type of clothing. Tools, weapons, gear--they all need to be diversified. After a few hours of play, I'd discovered pretty much everything there was to be discovered. I was no longer being surprised. The rewards were still rewarding, but I would have been thrilled to walk into a house somewhere and find some new article of clothing or type of food I'd never even seen before.The wolves are too over-powered at times, and you spend a lot of time just walking around in very wide circles to avoid them. Some items, weapons, or defense that might give you a bit of an edge on them would be awesome, especially if it took a hell of a lot to earn it.I got stuck in a hole at some point, between two boulders by a bridge. The walls were too steep, and I couldn't get out. I was worried I'd be stuck there and lose my week's worth of gear. But I somehow managed to go into crawl mode and wiggle and squirm until I glitched right through the ground. then I was walking under the earth. All of this could have been avoided with a simple jump function.The game is still in alpha, so all these things will surely be fixed over time. And all these things are forgivable, considering the massive amounts of fun I'm having. It's looking like the devs at Hinterland are putting out an update every couple of weeks. I look forward to the new developments. New regions to explore. New animals to hunt and be hunted by. Maybe even a multiplayer mode, where you can team up with a buddy or two and face the elements together, or hunt each other down in a last-man-standing survival showdown. That would be too amazing for words.All that is yet to come. For now, I recommend this game to anyone who likes an intellectual challenge in their game play. You'll be hard pressed to find this much intensity in any other game you can pick up for only $20. If you enjoy a game that makes you think, strategize, and plan every move in order to win, you'll love The Long Dark. If you're more the mindless hack n' slash type, you might still like it. There is excitment, there is atmosphere, there are scares and thrills. But mostly it's about slow, methodical puzzle solving, where every move could mean a miserable death, bleeding out in the dark, with an empty stomach in the cold bitter snow...

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Right straight off the bat, this game is brutal. In my 2 hours of gameplay at time of writing I've died twice and been attacked by wolves 4 times. Yet I've enjoyed every minute so far, and it really feels like I've played for much much longer.The mechanics are rather simple, and therein lies the games strength. Keep yourself rested,warm,fed,watered & out of trouble to survive, everything you do burns calories, so make sure you have enough to stay fit.The world is stunningly realised and if wandering around aimlessly wasn't so fatal, I could spend a long time exploring the initial map the sandbox mode currently has available.Time for a few minor gripes. Whilst you do need a lot of calories to survive in the cold (approx 6000-8000 a day) the game does burn through a considerable amount more than that. I checked when indoors, with a 'feels like' temperature of 19C (i.e. typical room temperature) with all my winter gear on, I was burning 200+ cal per hour, so almost the expected cold requirement, only at room temp. Whilst increasing this value for gameplay reasons is understandable, I have basically spent my entire play time so far both hungry and eating almost constantly.My only other gripe is the wolves, and the systems designed to combat them. There are a lot of wolves, and they are very aggressive (pretty much attack on sight) and can be warded off with flares. But if they attack you, the only course of action is to frantically punch them, which can get slightly silly if you have a knife on your character.Wrapping it up, overall an enjoyable, robust experience (especially for early access) that could do with a few minor balancing changes to avoid having to eat near constantly just to prevent your hunger level getting worse. Also as it's in the trailer it's not much of a spoiler, yes there is a wolf in the dam, his name his Fluffy, and he respawns.

								The best part of this game is the fight against the elements: the cold, the hunger, the dark.  Getting stuck in a fish-hut on a frozen lake in a seemingly endless cycle of blizzards and blinding, heavy fog. Getting lost in the forest in the middle of the night when you're only 500 meters from home but you can't remember which way you came from.It's very satisfactory to craft better clothing from deer hides and rabbit fur. To find medicinal plants. To find a cave that protects you from the icy wind and make a lifesaving fire. Then make a nice, hot herbal tea that revitalizes you.The art style is beautiful and evocative. There's much to explore: forests, lakes and mountains, settlements, abandoned mines and highways.And then there are the wolves. They ruin everything. Your clothes, and your fun. Fortunately, you can play on a mode called Pilgrim where the wolves (and the bears) don't attack you, so you can focus on survival rather than stealth.The game is quite stable and runs well. In sandbox mode there is a lack of positive goals, but there is a story mode still to come.

Early Access Review
								I started near a lake, with many ice fishing huts littering the frozen surface. I searched them all, taking all that I could find. Some wolves were nearby; best keep my distance.There are some cabins on the shores, I rummage through a few, only to emerge from one confronted by a wolf. I retreat back inside, sleep for a few hours to wait the wolf out, and reemerge. The wolf is gone, but it's getting late and the wind has picked up. There are still a few ice fishing huts to search, as well as a rather large cabin across the frozen lake that I have yet to visit.I begin my trek across towards the cabin, checking out the last few huts. The wind now brings snow. Darkness is quickly descending. I search the last hut, I am only a short distance away from the shore now, but the storm has become a blizzard and I am freezing.I need to warm up. Luckily the hut has a pot-belly stove, which I am able to get a fire going in. The hut has no door, so I stand with my back to the fire, staring out into the whipping wind and snow. It howls at me, daring me to venture forth into its icy embrace. I don't want to indulge it, but I have no choice; my fire is about to go out as I have no more wood to fuel it.I burst from my shelter only to realize I can no longer see the shore. I stumble blindly in what I pray is the right direction. I find the shore, but it is unfamiliar, and too steep to climb. I keep following the shore to the right, hoping I still have my bearings correct. I am beginning to freeze again. I just want to sleep.The incline of the shore decreases, a sign can be seen."Rangers Station"Never have I been so relieved. I burst inside the cabin. Food. Medicine. Tools. A wood stove.I am safe, for now.10/10

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								I woke up in the middle of a blizzard, freezing and disoriented I looked around me, only able to see a few feet ahead in any direction. As I started walking forward I questioned myself, did I choose the right direction? All around me are trees and snow, wind and doubt, in the distance I see a shape taking form, a sign and guard rails. As I get closer I see the remnants of a road winding up a hill on my left, the wind is getting stronger and I can tell im moving slower, im taking a gamble there is shelter at the top of this hill. As I clear the top of the hill I see an outpost, 30 – 50 feet in the air atop a winding red staircase. Struggling to make it to the top of the stair I fall through the outpost’s door and into one small cramped abandoned rangers post. Rifle on the table, 5 shells on the floor, some kindling by the stove and an energy bar. I lit a small fire in the stove, but without proper clothing I never really warmed up. Taking some snow from outside I melted it on the stove, but before I could get it to boil the fire went out. I ate the energy bar and grabbed the rifle, made my way back into the howling wind, down the stairs and started descending down the hill. Im starting to freeze to death, no food, no shelter, no heat, it doesn’t look good. I follow the road heading away from the outpost atop the hill, the wind starts to die down and I can see further into the distance now. Round a small hill to my left and see a building in the distance built into a mountain, ive lost track of the road, lost under the snow, I head to the building. Under the snow I see something red, I get closer and see it is a dead fox, half eaten, mostly frozen. I have no tools, nothing to cut the meat, I have to abandon the carcass and pray there is food in the building up ahead.I open the giant metal door, this is a hydroelectric dam, empty and abandoned, dark and silent.  My body is going into shock, I have no food, no water, no way of building a fire. My only hope is to find a furnace and pray there is wood nearby to burn. As I walk into the main room coming through the front door I can see hulking machinery, up ahead, file cabinets to my right, and stairs going down to my left. It reminds me of something out of a horror movie, pitch black with only light from a small window, something is lighting up the stairs, beckoning me. Im dying, I can hear the wind outside starting to pick back up, I head down the stairs in a last ditch effort to find heat, to find what the light is coming from below. I take 3 steps and see a shadow at the bottom of the stairs, it’s a wolf, and it guarding something, meat… I pull out my rifle and before I can take aim the wolf lunges at me, I cant fight back, im too weak. I die on the floor of the building.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Forty two days since my plane went down in this arctic hell. The wind broke long enough for me to venture outside, my growling stomach told me i had little choice. The deer i'd been tracking slowly moved along picking out what bit's of vegetation it could find, ever wary of it's surroundings. I saw my opportunity arise as it stopped ears perked in the opposite direction of me. My rifle came to my shoulder slowly as not to spook the deer, my breath slowed finger on the trigger slowly squeezing back. For a second i could swear i  caught motion out of the corner of my eye, then it happened. The wolf sprang barely giving me enough time to pivot in his direction. My shot was true and i caught him mid chest. No deer for dinner tonight but i find i'm getting used to the taste of wolf.Let me say that rarely do i ever see a survival game that has pulled me in so deeply, immersed is a word that does not do it justice. Ive actually found myself talking to myself as i move along warning myself not to get too focused on the road ahead and to scan around as i go. Nothing about this game is linear or boring. The graphics are stunning and the dynamics of the game itself work incredibly well. Bravo dev's bravo!If i had anything to request or add to the game it would possibly be allowing the hatchet or hunting knife be used as a weapon itself and maybe adding an option for scrap metal to be heated in a fire for use in making the basic items for tools weapons etc. One could possibly assemble a crude axe that way etc. I see great potential in this game to evolve into not only a urvival game but a hybrid crafting one as well. The elements of basic survival alone make the game more than challenging for any player, adding a primitive crafting system could only enhance the experience.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Wow. This game looks incredible. I've always been interested in getting a survival game, but I never liked how most of them involved gratuitous zombies. If I wanted to shoot zombies, I'd play Left 4 Dead. I just want to survive in a survival game.This title, however, is just about surviving the harsh life in the frozen north (the devs have hinted they may add other "survivors" of whatever catastrophe sent your character northwards, and that they may not be friendly, but they're not zombies)The gameplay is currently only the sandbox mode, with no narrative or guide whatsoever, and just one map so far (though they have more planned). They drop you in, and its up to you to figure out how the ♥♥♥♥ you are going to stay alive. Make no mistake, that's no easy feat. You have to manage a number of different variables, including body heat, windchill, hunger and thirst, exhaustion, wounds and disease, and hostile wildlife. Neglect any of these and they can kill you faster than you can sneeze.In order to get firewood and harvest meat, you need a hatchet. To get that you need to venture to the clearcut lookout, but there are wolves in that area, and you can't go there without a firearm. To get one you can go to the trapper's homestead, but will you survive long enough to reach that place? These are the kind of questions and dilemmas you need to answer in order to survive. It's hard to start off: in 3/4 of my attempts I die within three days, but when I do survive for longer, the victory is sweeter than honey.Its onyl early access, but that means we can help shape the game as it develops. If you are remotely a fan of survival games, purchase this title immediately!

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								So in 2013 I did a race that was considered one of the toughest mountain bike races in the world, The Tour Divide.  It extended from Canada to Mexico over the Continental Divide, unsupported.  We started in Banff, Canada and rode out from there where we were left to our own wits and survival.  Everything I had for the next month was on my bike and that's how I lived.  The Long Dark, while you're not on a bike, is a bit like the race.  You're constantly wondering if you have enough food, enough water, was there a predator lurking about (not wolves, we had to worry about Grizzlies).  In the game, you do this, you figure stuff out and it's fun... depressing, but fun.This is the first game I'm actively avoiding all videos, how-to's and spoilers because I want to figure it out on my own, take my time and enjoy it.  The artistic beauty, grim deaths and isolated gameplay really throw me back in the Tour Divide pushing my bike up the side of a mountain in the middle of the night, alone and freezing.As a casual gamer who lightly plays games, I cannot recommend this enough.  I feel drawn in and "cold" when I play it and it's a haunting comfort to hop in and play. It does come with a few snags and that's mainly performance on my Macbook Air.  It gets a little sluggish in fullscreen but runs fine in a smaller window.  I don't mind.(Also if you're interested, I wrote a book about the Tour Divide race which has some similarities to The Long Dark.  You can find out more at http://www.softpedaling.com).

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have been following this game since the Kickstarter last year. (Which I backed) I had pretty high hopes for this game and it showed great potential. As many other reviewers pointed out, when this game first released into Early Access it was almost unplayable. You froze within minutes of starting, or you died of hunger within minutes of starting, or you ran out of calories within minutes of starting, or you died of thirst within minutes of starting or you get killed by a wolf within seconds of starting. Yes, seconds. Once a wolf had you in sights, you might as well restart because there was no escaping or surviving. If you managed to somehow survive a wolf attack, you would quickly die of infection or bleeding out. Why in the hell can't you use your hatchet or hunting knife or rifle to kill it when it attacks you?!? Cooking the food did no good. You still got food poisoning even after cooking the food. RIDICULOUS! Sitting ONE inch away from a BURNING FIRE didn't even help warm you up a single degree, even while you're using one of the pits inside the house. How does a fire in a house not warm you up past 40 degrees?!? Especially when you're basically standing INSIDE the damn fire.But since the latest update, they have addressed ALMOST ALL OF THESE ISSUES! Calories don't burn QUITE as fast. Still really damn quick though. You definitely don't freeze as fast. A fire finally seems to warm you up when you're sitting next to it. Hunger takes a TINY bit longer to kick in and thirst is pretty easy to quench so long as you have even the tiniest amount of water. The wolfs no longer home in on you like a heat-seeker missile. You can actually run away now, but only IF you are far enough away. Cooking the food finally seems to help from getting food poisoning(ABOUT TIME).They still haven't addressed being able to use the HUNTING knife or Hatchet to fight the wolf off. You still have to fight it off with your bare hands, which is ALMOST impossible. Seriously, why have a HUNTING knife if you can't use it when you get attacked?!?The game is beautiful and the artwork is amazing. The sounds and music are both really good. It just needs some minor tweaks to help make it a lot better.I'm glad I waited until after they did a few updates before I did this review, because if I hadn't then it would have just been all negative. But instead I waited to let them get the updates out. This way I got to try it both BEFORE and AFTER the updates. The game has IMPROVED VASTLY with these new updates. I really hope they continue to listen to feedback and make adjustments accordingly. So far, it's working out pretty well.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								Day 46: I found a bag of Beef Jerky in a little cable off the beaten path, probably some kid's snack on a hunting trip with his uncle. Or at least that's what I imagine. Its been over a month since my plane went down, and the only people I've found are frozen corpses being picked over by the wolves. It seems the only thing I can do anymore to keep remotely sane and inspired to stay alive is to talk to myself during the long hours.  Oh, I had to put the spare wolf pet somewhere out of sight, I woke up in the middle of the night about two days ago to get a drink and about had a heart attack, the light filtering through the windows made it look like a wolf had crashed thru the window and gotten inside, I nearly wasted a round of my rifle ammo.That's about the only positive thing I have to say today, I'm stuck in that little cabin off the beaten path. There's a snowstorm right now, my leg is bleeding profusely, I tore my hat to pieces in order to make a bandage, but I have the sinking suspicion that a bear's mouth isn't the most hygenic place in Canada. So yea, it's probably infected. I'll have to treat it when i get back to the gas station. Might be difficult walking thru the snow with a bum leg and no pants. ... Funny story behind that actually. I spent days hunting deer and drying their pelts in order to have some warm pants, and the bear ate them, and a bit of my leg as dessert.It sounds so absurd to say it out loud... the bear ate my pants. Its like one of those things you learn to say in highschool spanish to make the teacher have a headache ...something something mis pantelones ...*a blood stain signs the final entry in a small journal laying next to a half naked corpse leaning in a corner of a little cabin off the beaten path.*--Really its a fun game where the experiences that kill you are just as fun to talk about as the experiences you survive. Hinterland is doing great with keeping the game coming along with updates and bugfixes. They have an amazing team that really is interested in player feedback.The game has immense replay value, even in its unfinished alpha sandbox mode. Great graphics that I can only describe as water color cell shading ... ish.I like that they're not trying to carbon copy other survival games.I've got nothing negative to say about the developers. Nothing negative to say about the game.Honestly I think everyone should play this game at least once.I guarantee the first time that you're ripped apart by wolves after barely surviving a blizzard after finally finding a box of crackers after panically searching houses for anything to eat will be 1000% times more enjoyable than experiencing those things in real life. ... at least, maybe like ... 1010% more enjoyable even.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game starts you off by punching you in the face, stabbing you in the stomach, and kicking you in the teeth.  If you survive the first week, odds are good you'll go the distance and survive forever until you get bored and start over.  You start off grossly underdressed and underequipped, and the first few days are touch and go.  Maybe you'll find some better clothes before the cold kills you. Maybe you'll evade the wolves long enough to acquire a decent weapon.  If you can tough it out, you'll become the predator, strolling around proudly wearing the wolfskin coat, deer hide boots and pants, and rabbitskin mitts.  If you're particularly savvy with your rifle and flare gun, you'll even manage to sleep soundly in a handmade bearskin bedroll.  Whether you die poorly to the elements, die like a warrior in battle, or survive as a master of your domain, this game will challenge even the most veteran players, while remaining playable even to a novice.My only gripe with the game is that if you do manage to survive for an extended period of time--namely if you manage to acquire the 200 day achievement...it's still friggen winter.  Seriously, are we in an ice age now?  I get it, it's northern Canada, but still.  After 200 days you'd think you might start to see some vestiges of summer.  But nope, always winter.  C'est la vie.Still worth it.
