Early Access Review
								PROS :  1) No glitches / crashes at all that I have noticed.  Not A One. 2) Easy interface system to learn.3) Daunting, hostile weather conditions.4) Visibility limitations that make sense.5) Interesting fatigue/food/water system affects overall condition in ways that make sense.6) Some crafting & use of available resources.7) Good use of sound, nice visual imagery, fluid feel of play.8) Impending sense of danger. Quick changes in weather & predator situations require your attention.9) Appreciation for the 'safe moments', holed up in a cabin with a good fire going, hot food & drink while the wind howls outside.10) Wolves.  Lots and lots of wolves.  Sneaky, devious, crafty wolves ....11) Three different difficulty settings to choose from.12) Good dev interaction on the forums.CONS:1) Needs more crafting & available resource options still.2) No ability to make spears ... yet ... ?  I continue to hold out hope :)3) Combat takes some getting used to (game autoselects your best weapon).4) Act of survival can get rather repetitive / monotonous if you hole up in one area.5) Some actions (ex. fishing) seem more work than they are worth.I've only played this game for a few days, but it's already sucked up nearly all my free time.  Despite the 20 to 30+ deaths I incurred right off the bat going into the hardest difficulty setting, I've had a blast learning the ropes of this environment.  It's got a real living, breathing, feel to it.  I hope they keep adding to that, it will only make it even better.  Wolves are one of the biggest threats, and they can be quite deadly, especially if Mother Nature has already 'softened you up'.  They're also stubborn about dying on the spot, often limping away from a fight and forcing you to follow a blood trail to find your meat for the night.  Or to find more wolves ...  I'm hooked - Great Game !

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Beautiful visually, gives a strong and realistic immediate sense of sudden stranding in a very harsh environment, alone. I like this feeling, the sound effects, the half light, the breathing animations in cold air. It's great.But... I found certain things to be illogical and against the sense of realism I was expecting to feel:1. Clothes need to last longer and be added in layers, it is what you would do and they wouldn't fall apart in a few days2. I understand water has to be boiled to make it safe (assuming some chance of contamination as this a "post apocolytic world", but it shouldn't take hours to melt then boil the snow because it simply does not in reality - too ridiculous, especially when your fire has only 1hr burning time. It can take half a day to boil a few gallons.3. All tools such as crowbars, hatchets, knives etc need to be usable in self defence (wolves...) as well as for "harvesting useful items". They should also wear out more realistically. No axe maker in the world would remain in business if their axes only lasted a few days or weeks.  Making the game hard by doing this and removing realism doesn't make it fun long-term, think retention.4. Should be easier to collect wood, it's everywhere, via using the tools as mentioned above, be easier to go out and collect diamonds than wood in those forests, peesh.5. Food should last longer if prepared/sealed, it isn't the tropics, it would last a long time. Even frozen animals would.6. Map should auto generate as if slowly drawing one through discovery, be a nice touch7. If you don't happen upon a rifle you are defenceless against wolves even if you are carrying knives, crowbars etc, this is totally unrealistic.I sprained an ankle somehow, it was the death of me, that did feel realistic in that I couldn't move fast enough to gather supplies to feed myself, but the above issues take away a lot of the fun for me right now.Fix the above and I'd be hooked, I remain keen :)

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have only played the game for an hour...but let me tell you it has been one nervewracking hour (in a good way).  I have had only had one life in this game and in the short time I've had more fun than many survival games have given me in many hours.I spawned in and the sun is just rising behind the mountains.  Snow is gently falling and I can see a clearing down the side of the hill I am standing on.  I make my way down and find it's a tiny encampent for loggers.  After searching through the trailers I find myself with a few cans of soda, peaches, and a new jacket.  Not a bad take.  Returning to the wilderness I begin to trek into the unknown.  After making my way through the woods and following a railroad it gets quite dark and I realize the sun is actually setting.  Now with a sense of urgency I begin to scramble for shelter.  The wind picks up and the snow begins to fall heavy on me.  I find an abandoned hydro dam and take shelter inside.  It's pitch black so I light my only flare to give me some sense of comfort.  After finding a crowbar I begin breaking into lockers and after finding some beef jerky and a knife I hear a menacing growl.  I turn around just in time to see a rather large wolf lunge at me and pin me to the ground.  After a brief struggle the wolf is now dead and I'm bleeding all over the place.  Turning the place upside down I managed to find some bandages and antiseptic and am able to treat my wound.  Fearing another wolf attack I head back outside and seek shelter elsewhere.  Walking around the darkness for what felt like hours I found a lookout tower.  This is my current shelter.  I managed to get a fire going and got a good nights rest.  Tomorrow is a new day and I can't wait to see how it unfolds.This game even in its current lacking state is awesome.  The sense of immersion is unrivaled.  Going inside the dam was truly unnerving.  The echoes and emptiness in the halls set up the tension that built up to the wolf attack perfectly.  Wandering around in the dark as the storms began to roll in made me feel helpless and that's what a survival game should aim to do.  It's nice to see a survival game without zombies and this game offers a great challenge and a fantastic sense of immersion.  Get it. Play it.  Enjoy it.

								Just finished a 40 day run. Died from food poisoning after eating rotten meat. I don't usually buy Early Access Games, but I wanted to give this one a shot after reading the excellent reviews. The artwork appealed to me, as did the fact that it was a more realistic and zombie-free survival/exploration game. As it stands, although highly enjoyable, this game is probably not worth the full $20 just for the sandbox mode, simply because the gameplay is rather limited in scope at the moment. Pros: Great artwork and overall atmosphereSimple concept that worksHighly immersiveCons: Gets a touch repetitive at timesLacks missions or goals, other than just survivalYou can never "win"... you always die eventuallyFinal verdict: An excellent game, but you may want to wait for it to be finished unless you don't mind sandbox-only gameplay.

								The Long Dark is a first person, open world, survival game being developed by a rather new company called Hinterland. I bought this game back when it was very, very new. And there was, and still is a lot of potential for this rather unexpected gem. I don't often write reviews on Alpha/Beta/Early Access titles, and typically, when I do, they're because you can tell the'll be utter♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I'm pleased to say, that I've yet to be disappointed by Hinterland Studio. The Long Dark, in its current state, has only the Sandbox Mode, an open-world survival that we're all too familiar with, with three difficulties, and the obvious absence of a story-mode. Survival games are now so common, like your failure to potty train your dog, you can't walk more than two feet without stepping on♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ And often, this♥♥♥♥♥♥♥brings about a revolted feeling of disgust and you urgently rush to the washroom to clean the filth away. In otherwords, since the rise of Minecraft, there's been a few gems in the Survival genre, but the majority have been such massive disappointments, you'd think that the only service their dev-companies could do now, is to beat themselves in the face with a club labled bankruptcy. It seems so irritating, to be taunted constantly with these games, of the next-generation "survival", only to discover that its only usefulnes is to help fix the unlevel table in your dining room. I spent the majority of my time at first, learning the game, as any decent person would, and that was by ignoring any sense of a tutorial or wiki. Well, they had the latter, the former might as well as have been named bigfoot. From the start, there were a lot of problems with the game, I can't count how many times I found myself squealing as my face was mauled by a wolf, with my attacks being as useless as an old lady with a foam bat. However, they quickly nerfed the wolves, still ensuring they were a challenge, but not so much that any form of resistence or risk-taking adventure around them could still result in your body being violently eviscerated by ravenous teeth.The landscape and overall design of the world, which gave me the impression that someone spilt a set of depressing watercolours on a Canadian forest, is actually admirably beautiful and robust. Immediately, when you spawn into the game, you're hit with the feeling of desolate isolation, and a sense of ever foreboding dread that the whole world has in fact gone to♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ The devs masterly crafted a mosaic and rather sad setting for such a survival game that few can compare. In fact, I spent a lot of my time risking my life in the subzero frigid temperatures, and the horrendous monstrosities birthed by Cerberus to explore this rather dire landscape, and found it so oddly enchanting that I often starved or froze to death. An ending well fit for such a daring expedition, I might add. In short, the entire survival atmosphere Hinterland Studio built, is very well done, beautifully so, and their attention to detail in such a world is so remarkable that the experience of being in such a terrifying world really affects you. Everything from the wind, your breath, the need for food, water and sleep, and the constant battling of the elements have been so neatly put together that I could sit down and eat the game if it were my favourite box of mixed mac'n'cheese and feel sad yet strangely delighted. So far, there's been little to really complain about. The Devs have really taken their time to listen to community input and respond rather quickly with bugfixes and patches to rebalance the game, something that I hope remains, since I'd rather not have to compare a new company to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥isations of EA or Ubisoft. Honestly, I remember a time where companies were so closely-knit to their communities they were like a pair of siamese twins, and now, we're left with the brooding dead husks that make up EA, Ubisoft, and other alleged AAA developers.However, what kind of review would this be without some complaint. Ones that they haven't been sniping out rather quickly, they also have been rather sluggish in others, whether because of budget constraints or a risky move when they opened the game to Early Access. I contemplated purchasing the game in Early Access, because as we all may know, some companies, and especially certain groups of devs, have burnt us on Early Access titles and you're left caring for the drooling, brain-dead husk of a game as they run off with the money and flash it you in suggestive poses with a sign saying, "Ha Ha, Fooled You". However, being one so often familiar with the feeling of disappointment, and a craving to be disappointed, I bought the Long Dark in Early Access and immediately found a few discrepancies. Initially, they advertised the game, insofar as its mechanics with a world that became drastically altered and terrifying at night, than during the day. Something that at first, made me recall another game, perhaps Minecraft. However, their unique twist to it made me forgive Hinterland for that comparison. You see, the world you're character has fallen into has been ravaged by a Carrington Event, or a large Solarmagnetic Storm that wipes out nearly all electrical based systems across the globe, creating terrifying aurora at night, that send the radioes screaming alive, and the lights flashing on. The storm's impact disrupts mgiratory patterns of animals, sends birds flying around until they die frome exhaustion, and disrupts the hibernation cycle of bears and other animals. As a result, nighttime in this desolate and frozen wilderness brings you into the horrifying embrace of every♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off animal from Quebec to British Columbia, who are all out for a snack, and you look like a delicious New York strip with a side of their favourite barbecue sauce. With all this riveting advertisement, I just couldn't help but buy the game, and immediatelly noticed something interesting, the lack of this solarmagnetic storm, and even the terrifying aurora. Instead, all that happened at night was frostbite. After I found myself comfortably rooted in a home, I eventually lost interest with the game. While they were quick with patchfixes and updates, it made me feel more like I was playing Minecraft: The Canadian Edition, with less green phalli to ruin my day. I stopped in when they made a few major updates, particularily they've been good at adding maps and new areas, and more mechanics that kept me interested for a little while, and then I'd lose it again and go back to bludgeoning people's heads open on one of my favourite FPSs. However, finally they've made the big announcement, and this is why I chose to write this review now. Despite their lack to give us the initially advertised content when I first bought the game, and when I started to wonder if I had made a grave mistake, I saw a beacon in this dark and macabre wilderness. A teaser trailer for their storymode, with the features they promised at the start, and then, I was finally sold. In short, I would recommend you buy this game. With the big announcement for the upcoming story-mode in 2016, and the final major updates involving the auroras and other massively yearned for features, Hinterland Studios has proved that they actually care about gaming and development. They've proven that they care about their community, something we can't say for EA or other Early Access shites, and with a dedicated team to fix bugs and patches, I can say that the wait has well been worth it. I may not be all that interested until those features are finally added to the game, but when they are, I can see my social life suffering in the face of surviving the brutal Canadian wilderness in a post-apocalyptic gem of the survival genre that deserves all of its praise.

Posted: December 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Oh look, a first person survival game on Steam that isn't complete tripe. This game is really difficult and a lot of your ability to survive depends on your perseverance and persistence to learn maps, resource management, and weapon locations. You will die a lot (I have not survived very long at the time of this writing). You can play as a dude or a dudette (yay!) and in both cases, you are subjected to utter hell on earth. Unlike other games, which rely on biochemical warfare, nuclear weapons, or zombies to craft apocalyptic hellholes, this one uses freezing cold. Take it from a Coloradan who used to do outdoor education for elementary students, the cold can and does suck if you are not properly equipped.You start out with your standard survival stuff: fatigue, hunger, thirst, health, and a meter detailing how cold you are or aren't. Lanterns are useful and are rather plentiful in the world, so pick them up. Starting fires can give you warmth, but also consume resources and may fail at the expense of those resources. Water must be purified before hand, or else you will get sick. The main problem I had was locating food, which is difficult to find and can go bad (like in the real world). You need to constantly be moving between shelters and raiding things, which is hard because there are wolves and now bears (have not faced them yet) to harass you. This game is dangerous trial and error, but the most enjoyable kind. If you want a realistic and challenging survival game, check this one out! The visual styles are really nice and remind me a lot of graphic novels with a dash of Telltale. And hey, if you play the lady, you get to have Ellie from The Last of Us as your narrator. You can't lose. ;)

Early Access Review
								"Once more into the frayInto the last good fight I'll ever knowLive and die on this dayLive and die on this day..." (c) - Ending monologue from 'The Grey' Cold, brutal and lonely. These words descibe this game better than any others (at least now). And this is awesome.'The Long Dark' is one of the very few really-really awesome kickstarter projects/Early Access Steam games that could've ever exist. It's atmospheric, it's hard and it's promising. To confirm my words, I'll just present one of the situations.On the very first day of the survival, I made it to the dam. It looked creepy, but the storm was rising, so I just stepped in. I was terrified: I had no light sources, I was law on food and had nothing to protect myself with. And then the atmospheric part stepped in: every sound I made sounded like a gunshot in a closed room. I got that feeling of someone else watching me. I started looting around, went to the far dark room. Suddenly, I heard somthing else. I crawled down and realized that there is a wolf right next to me. There is just not enough words to describe how actually much I was scared, so I just rushed outside. It was a relief for me, I stopped for a second to catch my breath. And then I realized that there is a fog arond me and I hear someone else coming. This is just one of the many. And you don't want to get hudrated, hungry or tired, because if you are in the middle of the cold wilderness, you are probably dead.So, summing up: +Awesome, fantastic atmosphere +Great soundtrack +A large world to explore+ Non-scripted events+Beautiful graphics+Breathcatching wilderness+The only game where you can be Liam Neeson from 'The Grey' -It becomes kind of impossible to survive after the fifth day (approx.)-Becomes a bit boring sometimes As a result: one of the very few games that I'm excited for. Sandbox is already one of the best survivals ever, and I can't even imagine how actualy good the story is going to be. And you might say, that this is getting old and mainstream. Yes, it is. But you will remember my words after you hear that cry in the middle of the night. Must have for fans of such games/settings. 8.5-9/10.

Early Access Review
								This game is awesome. I'll give it 10 / 10 in the future.It has one wonderfull thing, which few of today's games have - it's own, specific CLIMATE. You feel it from the first seconds of play. Things which build up for it are:1. STORYYou wake up in the middle of nowhere, with no weapon, nor food. The heat of your body constantly falling. There's no time to think, you must act. The game pulls you in at the very beginning and keeps it that way.2. GAMEPLAYYou constantly need to do something. You're either hungry, thirsty, cold or exhausted. At some point it may gets little tiresome, because you wish you had more time for exploring things and this beautiful world, but if you carry on, you'll explore it anyway (Sandbox).The game is hard. There's only sandbox mode available with one area, but it gave me 10 hours of solid gameplay anyway. I consider full game with story mode and few more sandbox areas will give at least a couple of times this.3. GRAPHICSIt is made by a renowned artist Hokyo Lim, author of i.a. The Unfisnished Swan (https://www.google.pl/search?q=unfisnished+swan). He's an out-of-the-box thinker.Sometimes, you feel like watching a very good movie. But mostly, you feel like you're actually there. Standing there at the top of the mountain and admiring views. Some people may consider it looking a bit too fairy-tale-like, but for me it is suiting.4. SOUNDThe sound effects are what builds up the atmosphere and they are very real. At some point even the howling wind gives you chills because it sounds similiar to the wolf's howling.The music is heard only occasionally, but the moments choosen to play it build up the atmosphere even more.There are two PC available - man and woman. Man is vioced by the Mass Effect no.1 voice actor Mark Meer. Female - I don't know, but I think she's not a professionall voice actress or at least for me her voices are disturbing.CONS:The game got kind of tiresome after ~10h and a few deaths. There's lot of walking in the beginning and tt's also easy to die. If you die you loose your save. So, if you're hunted down on 2nd day due to distraction, you have to replay the whole part before it really got fun. I think it requires some sort of calibration yet.To sum it up: This game is made by professionals, who left big gaming companies to create offbeat titles. It has great graphics, music, and nice gameplay. When the story mode will be available, it will be unbelievably good. I predict it will deliver one of the best gaming experience in a long time. And I don't mean survival enthusiasts.

Early Access Review
								This is my story of an experience which happened later on in the game, a few parts are fictional to provide more immersion.One cold day I was traveling to a place known as the Desolation Point, the wind was howling and wolfs where strafing through the cold wasteland.I heard about this place called Hibernia which was some kind of wale processing facility before the geomagnetic storm happened, I thought it might be worth a visit, maybe I would find some tools there, a saw would come in handy...As I was making my way to Hibernia I saw a bunch of wolves and even a bear guarding it, maybe the smell of the wale meat was still hanging around. I really wanted to get to this place, I only had one bullet left and I had the feeling chances are of finding some more in this abandoned factory. As I came closer and started to walk slowly across the frozen sea, trying to make as little noises as possible, the wind turned and carried my scent towards the wolves. I pulled my gun off my back and as soon as I had my finger on the trigger I already heard paws and claws on the ice behind me, I turned around and looked the wolf right in the eyes, it was baring its teeth and growling. I slowly started walking backwards, the muzzle of the gun pointing towards the wolf but it did not seem that it wanted to attack me and my pulse started to normalize, but suddenly I ran into something, the chicken wire fence surrounding this place got me caught. More wolves where approaching in the distance and I had to make a decision, do I run towards and past the wolves or do I use my last bullet... The sound of a gunshot is incredible loud if you haven't heard any cars or planes for a few weeks, it made all the other wolves flee, perfect as I needed to gut the wolf because a man has to eat if he wants to survive in this cold hell. It took me almost two hours to skin this poor thing, I didn't want to shoot it, but it was hungry and it was either him or me...My heart just stopped when I heard the breathing of something really big behind me, a big black bear stood not even 5 meters from me, I did not hear him coming because I was so busy pulling the pelt off this wolf, the smell of blood must've caught the bears attention. I slowly stood up, a mistake, the bear made a jump and his paws threw me to the ground, I was feeling his steamy breath in my face and I passed out...Was it the 350kg of pressure on my lungs, the pain of the bear digging his teeth into my shoulder or the fear which made me pass out? I don't know. But as I woke up It took me a few seconds to remember what just happened, I had pain everywhere and my vision was blurred, I looked around and saw my attacker who was just a few meters away feeding on the corpse of the wolf, I was lucky he liked that better then me. I dragged my body a few meters away as the bear noticed me and stopped eating and turned around and started walking towards me, with shaky hands I pulled out a flare and light it up. That was the best thing I could have done, the bear stopped and was afraid to come any closer. I barely made it into the factory and blood is pouring out of my shoulder, luckily I've found this bottle of antiseptic which burns like crazy but at least my wounds wont get infected.I can barely see anything because of the pain and its also very dark in here, it looks like a mattress is laying in that corner, time to rest a bit... The few pieces wolf meat I was able to grab before the bear surprised me will be very useful to keep my stomach filled for a few days while I recover from my wounds.

								It was a cold morning when I loaded this game up. I had the day off and the blinds were drawn. As I pulled a sweater on and sipped some tea, I felt the chill as I loaded the Mystery Lake sandbox mode (the only mode available as of yet).WIth no map and a few supplies, I found myself in a cave that led out into a clearing, with snow blowing. I managed to find a few cabins along a lake, with some food to keep me going. I ate too quick, and stretched myself too thin in the first day. The harsh realities of survival set in quickly. You need to make calm and calculated decisions. Evaluate your needs and priorities. The game builds an amazing atmosphere, reminiscent of being out in the forests of northern Alberta myself. Hearing wolves call, and seeing a buck off in the distance, going about it's life in a world devoid of humans. The short days and the blowing cold outside the window.This is a game that will addict you. It will give you the urge to stop down at your local MEC or REI to shop for a pack saw and a Coghlan's pocket can opener. You'll crave pork and beans in a way you never thought possible.For all its simplicity, this game is an enjoyable experience. Hinterland has delivered that experience with simple aesthetic that transfers a complex atmosphere. One of emotional and physical desolation that instills in you the desire to survive.An update: I brought this game out again after about half a year collecting dust, and they've made some great improvements, added new areas, refined a lot of the mechanics and crafting.I can not stress enough: one of the best things about this game is it is *not* procedural. Somebody actually put work into crafting the environments, and they're crafted well because of it. It does not look like an AI hit copy-paste. The artwork and modelling is fantastic, something a lot of the crafting/survival games right now lack.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								The only real survival game I've played.The long dark is a really phenomenal survival game. Unlike other games of the genre you actually struggle to survive.At one point I had survived for about two weeks and things were going pretty well. I had lots of food, I had plenty of water, good clothes and a nice warm hut to live in. I noticed I was running out of firewood tough, so I went outside and had a look at the weather. It looked good enough and I had a couple of (ingame) hours left before dark. After getting myself some firewood, I started to head back and out of nowhere a snowstorm showed up.I got lost on my way back to my hut and the sun was setting. I wondered around for a while trying to find something familiar but I couldn't see more than a couple of meters in front of me. I realized the longer I stayed out in the freezing wind the less time I had. My character was freezing pretty badly by now. In a last ditch attempt I went back the way I came where I had seen an old wind shelter. It was just big enough to fit in. I crawled in and tried to start a fire. I didn't have any accelerant with me so I couldn't get it going. I tried again and again. The storm wasn't getting any better. And by now the temperature was below -40 degrees Celsius. I came to the realization that I wouldn't get out of this. By now my character was too cold to even try to light a fire. I lit a match and held it up which increased the temperature inside the small wooden shelter by a degree or so. It was meaningless of course.I wrote a few last words in the diary and drifted off to sleep, never to wake again.

Early Access Review
								The Long Dark delivers an experience that has since been missing in survival games: patience and strategy. In fact, the game feels like a rogue-like in the first person. The focus on realistic survival mechanics, such as material quality and time-dependent tasks, makes the game plenty challenging. Meanwhile, the cold environment creates an atmosphere of both tranquility and awe. Without superfluous mobs, character stats, items, and other distractions common to survival games, The Long Dark presents a beautifully refined survival experience.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bout this game yesterday thinking, "Oh this could be interesting." I was wrong. I was VERY wrong. This game is exceptional. Beyond excpetional. I started a sandbox, picked my character, and named her Abbie. Abbie and I started in a lighthouse and from there we spent the better part of 13 hours exploring, scrounging supplues, and escaping the local wildlife. Eventually we found ourselfs at the Trapper's Cabin and I decided that this would make a great home for Abbie. We went in and were very surprised at all of the gear left behind, there was even a rifle to but all the bullets we found along the way to use. Abbie and I then went about gathering firewood, hunting deer and bunnies, and making foraging trips for better clothes from the Mystery Lake.  On the 10th day, We were about gathering firewood and a bunny passed by, so Abbie equiped her bow and we started chasing that little bunny down. After a few minutes and many misses, we finally managed to hit that little rabbit and moved in to harvest it. Little did we know that there was a bear right around the rock the rabbit had died at. So Abbie quickly equipped the hunting rifle and took a shot, but it was too late the bear was upon her. She fought as hard as she could but the damage was done. Even though the bear had left her alive, we were far from home with no healing items to speak of. This was Abbie's last moments. We tried to stumble home but she collapsed in the snow dead.Never have a felt such heartbreak at losing a character. All the work that we had put into trying to build a home was all for naught. The fact that I had connected so much with a character who I never even saw the face of just shows how amazing this game is. I could not recommend this game more.TL;DR First character mauled by a bear after 13 hours. 10/10 Would get mauled again.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								By far the best Early Access game I've ever played. This game is gorgeous, and simply exploring the vast expanse of Canadian wilderness becomes a main driving point as every new cabin or site you discover is like some sort of picturesque painting. I've amassed a considerable screenshot collection, utilizing the handy HD Screenshot (Hud Disabled) hotkey. The beauty is enchanting, but also deadly--which is another great aspect of this game. No zombies or otherworldly threat. Just nature's bites--the cold and the wolves. Those damn wolves... Surviving is a great challenge in either starting point, making each decision important since it is life or death with every hour that passes. A lot of games tout "Survival" as a selling point, but none have managed to really be an enjoyable experience to me until I played The Long Dark. I think the dev team have managed to strike a near-perfect balance of challenge and reward. Note that I've only played this on the standard diffuclty level--I've heard that the hardest difficulty adds more wolves... I'm confident they will change that and challenge the player some other way, as the wolves are notorious♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥in this game. Like I mentioned, however, I think standard strikes a great balance and has been a lot of fun.Be aware that there is currently no narrative story mode--Sandbox mode alone is worth the price during a sale. Throughout the play, you'll encounter hints as to what the story may be... I've had a lot of fun with the minimalism of it all, and to see that sense of mystery last so long is impressive. I still haven't explored every last bit of the lands yet, and now they are going to double the size of the explorable terrain! So, I'll just leave off with that--I'm impressed with this game!!

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								TL;DR: Yes. Yes, yes, yes.Wow! I as a rule dislike survival games. Not my stuff. But I have to say, TLD is a nice - no, SUPERLATIVE change of pace. All the others try to get you in a big hurry, or have some NPC nonsense which ends up always screwing you over, and sometimes even they go for cheap jumpscares. But The Long Dark? It is an exceptional variety of game which deserves its space as one of the best, in my opinion, survival games. It could serve as a nice role model for what a truly good, truly fun survival game should look like, and I feel a successful launch out of early access is all it needs to get its worth in attention. Not only is it a worthy adversary towards others of its genre, the Hinterland team also serves as a great role model for what other indie and early access devs should be. Now, I realize that many are upset about the rather belated story mode; however, I am excited to see what they do with the extra time!Here's why I love this game:- As I said before: It's definitely a change from other survival games like Rust or The Forest.- It's a healthy balance between realistic and reasonable, two aspirations for survival games to reach.- The devs seem to genuinely care for the game, and respond to - or at least heed - the community.- And - and I hate to judge a general game off of this, but must comment about this on The Long Dark - the atmosphere: WOW. The Long Dark, even with its particularly... surreal, may I call it? art style, can completely captivate you, have you listening to the beautiful sounds and looking at the rather stunning world in the midst of your struggle to survive. It's amazing what you can do with pixels.Some things I (personally) would like in the game:- A few more bug fixes. I.e., random fall damage (still happens to me), sound cutting out every once in a while. That is not to say bugs are a major issue; no, no, in fact I wouldn't call them an issue at all, for me (except for those two, of course).- Maybe a map with a few more shelters for individuals such as I who aren't too good at the "actually-doing-what-the-game-is-trying-to-get-you-to-do" - survival.- More... interaction, within the game. Hopefully the story mode will have solved this issue with its NPCs; as of now, there is not much to do but survive and hear your character talk about surviving, and then move and do it all over again (of course, the very fact that a game can get away with that and still be fun is mind-blowing, and shows the splendor of the game).Welp, that was a little long-winded, I know, but I had a lot to say, and I've been holding it in too long. This Halloween update jumped me back into the game, and then I realized how fun it was and felt as if I was letting the hard-working devs down by not letting them know, Hey - your game? It's great. Keep it up.

Early Access Review
								The best survival experience I have found in a game yet.  It is challenging without feeling entirely unfair.  When you fail, you can generally look back at a moment of poor decsion making.  The game play is fairly simple with a basic gathering / crafting mechanic.  The hunting is one of the best I have played with wounded prey collapsing from their injuries at the end of long trackable trails of blood droplets.  The combat system is more of a struggle system and does a fair job of capturing the desperate feeling of being mauled by a wild animal.I wish I knew who to thank for this quote, "It is like living in a painting that wants to kill you."  And it is like that.  The game is gorgeous.  Every sunset and daybreak warrants a screen capture.  The sound effects are splendidly encompassing.  The music is subtle and lovely.  This is one of the rare games that I feel like I am in another world.A great game and must buy for any survival game or immersion gaming focused player.

content:
Posted: April 25
Early Access Review
								Have I not reviewed this one yet? Well in short, it is a very good game. Probably the best survival simulator on the market.In further words, this game is truly excellent, in design, in aesthetic, in gameplay, in approachability. I've done a lot of outdoorsy stuff, and so far this is the only survival game I've played or seen that really captures what it's like to be in the environment. You aren't sprinting everywhere, you're usually just hiking with 40 kilos on your back. You aren't crafting improvized armor and weapons to battle the wolves and bears, but usually cleaning your rifle, and sowing up your clothes at night, so they keep you warm when you're working in the day. Sure you can get attacked by wolves, but most of the time your main worry is hypothermia.That's something else that's great about this game. It doesn't feel like you have a bunch of arbitrary rescource meters that have to be baby-sat all the time. You have the meters (Cold, hunger, thirst, exhaustion), but the game is quick to teach you how to manage them, and it isn't an immediate damning hit to a health bar when one starts to lower. Rather it just reduces your "condition" from 100%. Now I have been able to drag myself back to life with a condition of 15%, but likewise I have gone outside with a good condition, but froze to death because I didn't take necissary precautions. So the game never feels like it kills you unfairly (unless maybe you get blind-sided by a wolf, which is rare), and you always understand what you did wrong. So with the current rogue-like sandbox build, you have this great process of iterarting on previous runs and constantly improving, making it such a relaxing, fascinating, and enjoyable experience.So in conclusion, everyone should buy this. I'd say a solid 8/10 for the genre, and it ain't even fully built yet. I sing it's praises from the top of the firewatch tower where I first found the rifle, and a bottle of much needed lantern oil.

Early Access Review
								Ohh it's creepy...there's this wolf see, Fluffy, and long story short he randomly appears in the dam (baffles many people how he got in, aside from possible window entrance) but he tends to be the #1 cause of death for players.BUT, there's a bigger story than that...I've concluded he's a ghost wolf, died in this dam during an accident while working the night shift. He was security, and his life was pretty good. He had a wife, couple kids, and good health. He enjoyed playing tennis at the local YMCA and building snowwolves with his kids on weekends. But one night while patrolling, one of the valves blew off it's place when to much pressure built up in a damaged pipe, and it got Fluffs (as his friends called him) right in his head. He held out for a little, but unfortunately there was too much internal bleeding. He was a dedicated security officer, and in his death he believes he's still on that night shift. Looking for trespassers, taking justice into his hands against thieves. We rage out on him, I do myself, but is he not doing his job? Is he not more dedicated to his work than we are to surviving? Fluffs, wherever you are...please let me hear you coming so I can bolt out the door X(Anywho...Good game, though I recommend it despite many frustrations I do warn that it's early access and thus frustrations will be common. If you don't like that, throw it on your wishlist and give it some time.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								It’s been over 2 months since the last sandbox update Vigilant trespass (22nd September). When vigilant trespass was released I uninstalled this game because this update added nothing that I had been waiting for and playing this game had become repetitive, boring and unenjoyable. The update before that was a decent update, penitent scholar (23rd of June). That was 5 months ago.For the time that we wait, the updates bring underwhelming content. Vigilant trespass being a prime example. Waiting for 3 months for an update for which the main attraction was a harder version of the same game is not worth it. On top of this, promises for a monthly sandbox update have never been met. Occasionally we get an excuse, this time it was “2/3 of our team is working on story mode”.Story mode has failed to meet 2 promised dates and has been given the "it’s NOT coming out soon, we are trying to make it as good as we can" title. Personally I’m ok with that because this game has amazing potential and wasting that on a rushed story mode would be a disaster. My problem is that the promises should have never been made in the first place. It’s misleading and unprofessional. If you paid builders who said they could make you a house in a year and after you paid, the builders said "we can’t make it by that time, we want to make it as good as it can be and we can’t say when it will be ready", you would be understandably annoyed. What I’m more upset about is the sandbox. There are no dates on when anything will come out. All we have is the roadmap which uses terrifyingly large timescales such as 6 months, and things on that list have been there for over 6 months! I’ve supported this game since its release. Sandbox updates used to add new regions, wildlife, weapons, and gameplay changes. They still took more than a month to come out but they were worth the wait. Now updates come out in 3 month periods, adding almost nothing new to the game, merely tweaking it slightly. I’m sick of it.I love this game. I’ve played it to death. As it stands the game needs more. Not just a story mode, but a massively improved sandbox with WAY more content. I’m sick of waiting too long for too little. If you don’t want inconsistent updates, a game that the more you play the more tiring it becomes because it’s lacking in content and developers who remain ambiguous about the release of content because they can’t keep promises. Then don't buy this game.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								Early access review:After a few stumbling attempts ending in death by falling, hyperthemia, wolf attack, exhaustion coupled with food poisoning and more wolf attacks, I finally got the hang of things.With an ever-present sense of peril, I chose to leave the forrest with all its delicious untrappable rabbits, embarking on a journey in search for better pastures and -- dare we hope? -- a gun. After a few days of scavaging, I eventually found a tunnel through the mountains, leading to a large lake. Along its shores I found a small town and was finally able to make camp on a more permanent basis. There I spent my days fishing and forraging, each day trekking back to my pleasant little homestread. Life was good. On the seventh day I finally found a gun next to a corpse and... it all went down-hill from there.With a sense of delusional self-empowerment, possessing the means to ascend to the top of the food chain, I shot and missed a few wolves. On the 9th day, on my day home from an unusually unproductive expedition, I came upon a bear that had annoyingly blocked my path during the morning. Taking aim, I shot (and probably missed yet again) believing that I could get to a nearby house if I couldn't get it to bleed to death. And oh boy, bears can apparently sprint pretty well, for it quickly pushed me to the ground and mauled me repeatedly, leaving me for dead. Within an inch of my life, I crawled my way back to the house. The next morning, a wolf waited outside my door, making easy pray of my already wounded form. And so yet another story ended.----------Perhaps a little repetative with the same map every time, but as long as you're actually exploring its a very enjoyable experience.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								A great and challenging survival game with well balance mechanics.Died within 24 game minutes my first time playing (24ish real seconds). Spent the next two hours dying, a lot.If you like survival games I recommend jumping straight in with the hardcore mode. Anything less and the game doesn't really pose much of a challenge. Also, try to avoid looking stuff up on the internet. It's quite rewarding when you slowly figure out how things work and you'll kick yourself for your previous stupidity when you do. Really gives you the sense of being some inept survivor stuck in a weilderness that you have no idea how to survive in.Has taken me around 20 gaming hours to finally craft all the available items and get to the point where I'd say I'm an accomplished survivor. I did nearly give up at one point, after a wolf surprise attacked me after around 10 days of game time (around 8 hours real time) and killed me but I persisted and later figured out better ways to survive wolf attacks with some pre planning.There are a lot of tips I'd love to give you, as looking back I realise I spent many hours doing things the wrong way or not understanding a concept that meant I was dying more than I had to, but this is what made the game a challenge. If you can accept that you'll inevitably die many many times but each time you restart you'll be a little better and get a little further, then you'll enjoy the game immensely. Sometimes it can feel like you're spening most your day constantly eating, drinking and sleeping just to keep yourself alive, with only a little time in between to explore. This did very nearly put me off, so be prepared to hit a point of frustration and battle through it. Once you get the hang of it though, you'll learn how better to keep your energy up and make efficient use of your time.Only one info I will give is that the sandbox has three maps. These maps are interconnected from within the game. I assumed they were three entirely different worlds. It was nice to realise that once I was starting to understand the layout of the first map, I could actually walk to a new area entirely and so the fun of exporing would begin again.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Initial Review - 31/12/2014I've never purchased an early access game before but was intrigued by the concept of The Long Dark and the overwhelmingly positive reviews it has received so far. Suffice to say I was not disappointed.The Long Dark is an Incredibly tense, beautiful and engaging wilderness survival game. Although the wildlife and combat are quite limited in the current version, the survival mechanics are very deep as you find yourelf in a constant struggle to stay alive as you scavenge for food/water and try to keep your character warm, healthy and rested,The difficulty options are neat - allowing you to opt for a more ambient experience, a brutal survival experience or something in between - and it's nice to see you can choose your gender and environment before starting.There's alot of fun to be had with this game in it's current state (sandbox mode) and I can only imagine it will get better as new mechanics, modes and environments are added.Recommended for fans of games like Don't Starve but I also encourage players who enjoy exploring vast yet delicate environments to give this a try.-----Review Update 1 - 11/6/2015: Following my review from December 2014, this game has went from strength to strength as the devs have added a host of new environments, wildlife and mechanics. Each update has been of a consistently high standard and I have no doubt they will continue to improve/refine the game as they push towards full release.Each of the sandboxes has a very distinct feel - forcing you to adapt your survival style as you progress - and the transisition areas between each sandbox are unique and challenging. The bears are a welcome addition as are the new crafting mechanics: such as curing of animal skins (which makes crafting of animal-based clothing a little trickier) and the bow and arrow (which provide a nice alternative to the rifle). The general balancing has improved alot since I started playing this - providing a good mix of thoughtful exploration and harrowing survival - and the backpack interface has evolved nicely.The Long Dark is undoubtedly one of the finest products on Steam and surely one of the best examples of Early Access done right.Highly recommended!-----Review Update 2 - 13/2/2016Following my June 2015 update, the Hinterland team have added even more environments: including the oddly-sinister Desolation Point - where the ominous Processing Station contrasts starkly with the cosy Lighthouse - and highly-challenging Timberwolf Mountain - which requires nerves-of-steel to navigate its lakes, forests, slopes and caves.New gameplay additions - such as the flare gun, rope climbing mechanics, ability to pick up stray wood and ability to break down items in the game world (one of my favourite additions since purchase) - serve to deepen the already-refined gameplay; nothing feels quite so humbling as finding a cosy cabin in the middle of a fierce storm then being forced to break and burn any remaining signs of humanity in order to stay warm.Hinterland have overhauled the UI side of the game too with a much improved backpack interface, detailed logbook and stats screen and the ability to create multiple saves at once. You can also choose to start from any region now: a welcome edition for new players who will likely benefit as they attempt to hone their own survival style. You can now play the game with a controller as well as keyboard-and-mouse: the former feels good but the latter remains my weapon-of-choice.Since my last review I've clocked in almost 100 hours of playtime and reached the peak of Timberwolf Mountain: a great achievement indeed. I look forward to the impending Story mode but even without that feature, this game is already more than worth your time and money.Essential!

Early Access Review
								This is a very promising game if you like certain types of gameplay. Let me clarify what type of gameplay this game has so you get the idea of whether you want to play it or not.---------------------------------At this CURRENT moment the game only offers the ability to play in sandbox mode. In this mode you spawn in a random area at a random time of day. The goal is to survive as long as you can and that's about it, however, it's not as easy as you'd always assume. The loot around the area is also random so you may be lucky or unlucky as to what you will find. I don't think you can be soo unlucky that you will die right from the start but you may not find something as valuable as a sewing kit.You have to deal with many issues in this game such as starvation, dehydration, fatigue, injuries, freezing, etc. There is food within the game as random loot as well as raw meat from animals which you can cook on a fire. Having something to drink can be random or you can melt snow to get water and you will need to boil water to purify it for safe drinking unless you have a water purifier. If you carry too much weight you will get fatigued very fast as well as running around everywhere and burning your calories which is another thing in the game. Depending on the quality of your items and what they are changes how well you can survive outside for extended periods of time and being by a fire isn't going to help you if it's windy and freezing outside so going indoors is always a good option.This alone wouldn't be much of a challenge but there are also wolves in the game and they are quite brutal. If one attacks you then you must build up strenth then attack it which can do 3 things: hurt the wolf a little, hurt the wolf enough to make it run away, or kill the wolf. If you are very tired and run into a wolf you are screwed because you cannot build much strength up at that time and you will be overpowered and killed.The weather can be mellow, windy, or there may be a blizzard which will freeze you VERY fast if you are outside.There will be more options and there will be a campaign but at the moment there is only sandbox survival which is still fun.---------------------------------The art style is nice in this game and is different. The sounds are great and this is an overall nice game. Should you buy it? Completely up to you but at the current state $20 is a bit much but there is more content coming and I've been seeing 1-2 updates a day since launch so things are actually getting done and I believe my money was well spent so far.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Day 1: I awake to find myself in a frozen wasteland. Alone, cold and getting colder. What do I do? I need food, water, shelter. Trudging through the thick snow, I decide my best bet is to find some high ground and hope I can spot something that may be of use. As I reach the peak I see a small wooden structure next to a pond. Eagerly I rush down the side of the hill, hoping that I may find something of use. Inside is a can of beans, and not much else. Quickly I collect my prize and scavenge a small bundle of sticks that may be I can use for a fire if I can't find some place to hold up for the night. A little ways in the distance I see a flock of crows cawing, and circling over something. I decide to check it out. There in the snow bank, right under where the black birds hover is a man, dead. Covered in ice and snow. Most likely lost his way in a storm, looking for shelter or food, the same way I am. Is this my future? No, I won't end up like him. All I need to do is find some place to hold up and eventually, surely, help will come. I search his body, no time to pay respects. The sun is setting and I need to move. Maybe he has something that will help me avoid the same outcome as him. A smile spreads across my face. A pocket knife! Jackpot! I need to move now. I think I see something in the distance.Night 1:The house must have belonged to a trapper. Inside was a rifle, with a couple rounds, and some wire traps for small game. I've never hunted in my life, but necessity demands that I learn on the fly now. I tore the cabin apart, scavenging whatever I could use. I'm so cold though. Snow clinging to almost every inch of my clothing. It took a few tries, but I was able to get a fire started in the stove in the corner. Good thing I had those matches on me during the crash. There's only a few left though. I'll need to be careful how I use them. Right now these are the most precious tools to me. Each small stick is precious to seperate me from death. As I warm myself by the fire, I decide to melt some of the snow to give myself a small supply of drinking water. As the water boils I also use my newly found pocket knife to open the can of beans. Heating them on the fire I gulp it down as soon as they're done. Back home this would barely pass as a snack. Here it's a gourmet meal. It's time I get some sleep. In the morning I need to hunt. Other than a small package of jerky and a candy bar I found in the cabin, I'm not very well stocked. Hopefully my first hunting trip will pay off.Day 2:Maybe I should've watched somet hunting shows when I was back home. It occurs to me I know almost nothing on how to hunt and trap. I set up the wire trap in the woods, but unless a rabbit just happens to strangle itself in it I don't think I'm going to have much luck. I'll come back and check in awhile. In the meantime I'll try to track down one of those deer I saw yesterday.The trap is empty. Go figure. My stomach is growling. The candy bar did little to slate my hunger. What the hell am I going to do? I pick up the trap. Maybe I'll have better luck somewhere else? What's that? Out the corner of my eye I see movement. A buck! Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ No way! Maybe someone up there is looking out for me after all! I crouch trying to hide my presents as I bring the rifles sights up. I've only ever fired a BB gun before, but it's the same concept right? I line the sights up, centering them near the deers heart. I let out my breath slowly, as I go to pull the trigger...Night 2The irony isn't lost on me, even as I sit here, the Long Dark creeping in on me. My head hurts, I can hear my own heart beat pulsing in my ears. I killed the deer. One shot. It went down like I was an expert. I even was able to skin it, gut it, and harvest the meat, something I never thought I'd ever do. I had a feast all laid out in front of me. Yet in the end it wasn't lack of food or shelter that will do me in. Fire. God damned fire. Something that the earliest man knew how to use somehow eludes me. I couldn't get the fire started again. I had two matches and both times the fire only flickered and died. I have no way to start it. In a panic I ran outside to go look for something to start it with, but it's midnight and a storm hit. I can't see a foot in front of my face. I'm lost, I think I've been going in circles. I don't remember where the cabin is. I chuckle as I think of how bad I am at this. I couldn't even survive 2 nights on my own. No ones coming for me, there won't be a rescue party, and in the end I'm destined to die here in the snow. I close my eyes and wait for the end. I just hope that the darkness comes for me before the wolves do. PROS:-Fantastic survival simulator, even at this early stage of development. Already have put 4 hours in and will continue to put in more.-2 large maps-Each playthrough feels different-Challenging. 2 days is the longest I've survived so far-Great atmosphere, and feeling of lonliness and isolation-Wolves stalk you, and at night their eyes glow and makes you feel like you're in "The Grey." A+ for that.-No map. I count this as a pro because you have to rely on your own memory of where things are. When storms hit you can quickly become disoriented and lose your way which is thrilling.CONS:-The coastal highway map feels a bit too easy. I came across a town with several houses and have found a virtually endless supply of food, water, and great clothing. Not to mention it's next to several fishing spots. When your supplies are in abundance the game loses it's sense of adventure and danger, and thus loses a large amount of fun-Items are randomly placed every game, but structures are not. This means you can eventualy learn the map and find all houses quickly just from memory. Though it's random what you'll find, knowing where to look eliminates some of the challenge of surviving. -Only animals you'll currently see are deer, rabbits, and wolves. Here's hoping we see some new fauna additions in the future.-Not a lot to do when you're well fed, and stuck inside during a blizzard. A way to level up your abilities with out having to repair/craft something would be nice, like reading books, etc.

Early Access Review
								A great and challenging survival game with well balance mechanics.Died within 24 game minutes my first time playing (24ish real seconds). Spent the next two hours dying, a lot.If you like survival games I recommend jumping straight in with the hardcore mode. Anything less and the game doesn't really pose much of a challenge. Also, try to avoid looking stuff up on the internet. It's quite rewarding when you slowly figure out how things work and you'll kick yourself for your previous stupidity when you do. Really gives you the sense of being some inept survivor stuck in a weilderness that you have no idea how to survive in.Has taken me around 20 gaming hours to finally craft all the available items and get to the point where I'd say I'm an accomplished survivor. I did nearly give up at one point, after a wolf surprise attacked me after around 10 days of game time (around 8 hours real time) and killed me but I persisted and later figured out better ways to survive wolf attacks with some pre planning.There are a lot of tips I'd love to give you, as looking back I realise I spent many hours doing things the wrong way or not understanding a concept that meant I was dying more than I had to, but this is what made the game a challenge. If you can accept that you'll inevitably die many many times but each time you restart you'll be a little better and get a little further, then you'll enjoy the game immensely. Sometimes it can feel like you're spening most your day constantly eating, drinking and sleeping just to keep yourself alive, with only a little time in between to explore. This did very nearly put me off, so be prepared to hit a point of frustration and battle through it. Once you get the hang of it though, you'll learn how better to keep your energy up and make efficient use of your time.Only one info I will give is that the sandbox has three maps. These maps are interconnected from within the game. I assumed they were three entirely different worlds. It was nice to realise that once I was starting to understand the layout of the first map, I could actually walk to a new area entirely and so the fun of exporing would begin again.

Early Access Review
								Early access review:After a few stumbling attempts ending in death by falling, hyperthemia, wolf attack, exhaustion coupled with food poisoning and more wolf attacks, I finally got the hang of things.With an ever-present sense of peril, I chose to leave the forrest with all its delicious untrappable rabbits, embarking on a journey in search for better pastures and -- dare we hope? -- a gun. After a few days of scavaging, I eventually found a tunnel through the mountains, leading to a large lake. Along its shores I found a small town and was finally able to make camp on a more permanent basis. There I spent my days fishing and forraging, each day trekking back to my pleasant little homestread. Life was good. On the seventh day I finally found a gun next to a corpse and... it all went down-hill from there.With a sense of delusional self-empowerment, possessing the means to ascend to the top of the food chain, I shot and missed a few wolves. On the 9th day, on my day home from an unusually unproductive expedition, I came upon a bear that had annoyingly blocked my path during the morning. Taking aim, I shot (and probably missed yet again) believing that I could get to a nearby house if I couldn't get it to bleed to death. And oh boy, bears can apparently sprint pretty well, for it quickly pushed me to the ground and mauled me repeatedly, leaving me for dead. Within an inch of my life, I crawled my way back to the house. The next morning, a wolf waited outside my door, making easy pray of my already wounded form. And so yet another story ended.----------Perhaps a little repetative with the same map every time, but as long as you're actually exploring its a very enjoyable experience.

content:

Early Access Review
								Probably one of the few better early access survival games on steam at the moment.The bigest issue and complaint iv'e had with almost every indie survival game currently in development is how the enviroment is not a danger at all and instead the only danger is other trigger happy players ,which just turns all those survival games (Day Z,Rust , etc) into just very big PVP combat arenas and not much else, however the Long Dark does not have that problem.The Long Dark is a single player survival game, so no pesky human players are around to ruin your day instead the things you have to worry about alot and are in  constant danger from is the enviroment and the animals that live in this frosty land.The game has a very beautiful and unique art style which i can't get tired of looking at, it might not be the most techical impressive game but the devs used such a wonderfull colorfull but at the same time not too coloruf style with some subtle touches on each texture which almost make it feel like you're in a picture book or some sort of animated detailed cartoon but without pulling you out of the game's wonderfull snowy atmosphere, it's really,really nice.Same goes for the sound design, it's very well done, hearing wood creeking as you slowly walk around a dark house while a strong blizzard is blowing outside makes me wanna just wrap myself around a blanket as i play it.Now, onto the gameplay.You have to find worm clothing to make sure you don't freeze in the icy lands of Canada, you have to use a sewing kit to maintain your clothing so it doesn't become useless overtime,you have to gather wood,matches,fuel,old newspapers and use them to create camp fires where you can cook food,melt snow into water and purify water by boiling it so you don't get poisoned, you have to scavange huts and small houses for food,water,tools,clothing,weapons etc etc. but they don't respawn so you have to be carefull on what you eat and what you use since you can die from hunger and thirst very easilly if you don't plan ahead carefully.At the start you'll be eating anything you find but once you pick which house will be your base and you manage to gather and stock some food into it,It's smarter to start eating food you hunt and save up the canned goods for desperate moments, in the current build you can only hunt with a gun(which is hard to find) or catch some smaller wildlife with a basic trap, however even if you don't have a weapon or a trap you can still get some deer or rabit meat since the wolfs hunt too and often leave a few good slices of meat on the bodies for you too cut off and take back home to cook, oh and you can also fish which requires you to cut a hole into the ice in a specific location with your knife or axe.In the wild (as i mentioined them before)you have Wolfs patrolling which you have to stay away from as much as possible, if you get caught with just your fists against a single wolf(or more), you're pretty much a goner allready. Knifes and Axe's will help you alot in those situations and if you're lucky enuf to find a gun with ammo then it's the Wolf/s who should be afraid of you then.You have two fairly big maps to play on at the moment, in the future hopefully there will be more as developemnt progresses, they are also promising a Story mode with some fairly famous voice actors such as Jennifer hale but that's still not in the current build, at the moment all you have is sandbox where you just try to survive for as long as possible and maybe also try earning some achievements to give yourself an objective once you manage to stock up on alot of things.Bottom line :The game is still lacking content but the content it has at the moment is enuf to keep you busy for a good few hours of survival fun, it's in my opinion much better then most unfinished survival games we have at the moment and it seems to occasionally go on a nice sale, if you see The Long Dark 50% off then I'd say pick it up if you like survival but for 20 Euros,ahh I'd say wait a bit for more content but even if you get it for 20 Euros i don't think you'll really regreat it that much, specially if you love these survival games and this is one of the few that's atm in a solid fun state unlike other games.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is an outstanding piece of work for a game not yet even released. The sandbox mode available at early access is a decent game in itself and I am eagerly anticipating the story mode release to add more depth to the experience. I picked this game up during one of the sales and I think it offers excellent value for money in its current state.In a genre otherwise swamped in zombies it is extremely refreshing to play a survival game where you are simply pitted against nature itself. This is certainly more than challenging enough and although the game is a sandbox, there are plenty of goals that will keep you interested. I spent a fair amount of time gaining the achievements and surviving the toughest settings and starter zones, something simply not possible till you've mastered the game in the earlier areas.The game adds real peril and fear with the introduction of the wildlife and it's genuinely scary to be trying to find shelter in the darkness and come across a growling pair of green eyes or when you see the bear stand and sniff the air for the first time.Positives:- This game is a unique experience in an otherwise very predictable genre.- It's extremly well designed and balanced feeling very challenging without being impossible.- It's actually very addictive as the game constantly presents a new threat to your survival.- It feels like you've genuinely accomplished something when you become "sustainable".Negatives:- Graphically, this game is let down a touch and almost certainly due to a lack of budget when it was needed. As a very good game it shines on its gameplay but it is a shame it doesn't have the looks to match.- The game is surprisingly unforgiving in some of its starter locations which might lead to a newer player being presented with a very tough start to the game. Persevere if this happens to you, although frustrating, it is part of the charm.- Some of the sound balancing is a bit messed up. Most terrifying thing in the game? Bears? Wolves? Nope, spraining your flipping ankle. The sound scares the living heck outta me every time.Would I recommend this game?I guess it depends if you like the idea of it, but if you do; this is arguably one of the finest survival titles ever made, and it isn't even finished yet. "Highly" recommended.

Early Access Review
								Great atmosphere with unique visuals.  Definitely challenging.  A world I'd love to spend more time in but the game doesn't seem to want to let me stay in it for that long without restarting.  Unfortunately, it feels like an eating and sleeping simulator right now as the hunger and hydration degradation speeds are insane.  Even if the degradation speeds were decreased, I just don't see how one would be able to play this game for extended periods of time since the resources are just gone when you use them and the map isn't that big.  While I'm on degradation speeds, doing even the most menial of survival tasks reduces your overall calories (your hunger level) by way too much.Still, for what it is, it does it well and is a refreshing change from being chased by zombies.Update (5/3/2016)Still an eating/drinking simulator, and in this case, it's not a good thing.  Realism is cool and all, but this game still overdoes the caloric management.  I get resource management is a key point to this game, but overall, the game just isn't interesting enough to make slogging through the resource management worth it.  Map is much bigger since I first reviewed the game, so that's a great addition.  Also, more renewable resources are available than when I first reviewed it.  You can keep fishing and hunting forever I guess, except that you won't b/c you're going to die long before you ever get "settled in."  I'd still recommend buying this game, as it's sort of the Dark Souls of the survival genre, but prepare for a frustrating experience...and perhaps that's the point of this game.

content:

Early Access Review
								I stumbled out of the damn, unfamiliar terrain stretching before me......four hours of light left......the valley walls grasped at the heavens, the cave swallowed me into its enigmatic depths, then spit me out into yet another desolate forest...but there, before me--a bridge! A hargbinger of sanctuary...a cabin must be close now......darkness was upon me...I desparately needed shelter...I stumbled down the road, finding nothing, until my body temperature was dangerously low. I started a fire, used the last of my firewood, tried to sleep for a few hours...but no, a barking awoke me, there would be no rest for me. I fought desperately, stabbed blindly, until the wolf was driven wimpering away. I was not unscathed, however...my coat was torn, my arm badly sprained. What's worse, I realized a blizzard had begun, whipped snow around my head, and scattering the dead remains of my fire......I fled further into the darkness......I could barely feel my limbs, I needed warmth. I sprinted through the storm, grabbing up whatever twigs I could. In the lee of a hill, I began another fire...I ate, watching my food supply dwindle. The fickle wind changed directions, my fire snuffed out....I fled further into the darkness......Again, I repeated the process, gathering twigs, gnawing at what I had left, grabbing what rest I could, and again, the wind changed......I fled further into the darkness.......Finally, a couple hours after dawn, the storm lifted. By that point, my condition was so bad the world was hazy...whenever I turned my head, afterimages burned across my field of vision.I stumbled around the hill I'd sheltered behind, blinking in the sun...and froze.There, right next to where I'd been stumbling blindly all night, was a town. I edged towards it, overcome......I had survived the night...my salvation was at hand......then behind me, I heard a barking.....I did not even have the energy to put up a fight.I entered the long dark.Would die an ironic death at the loveless hand of the bitter north again...11/10

Early Access Review
								Simply the best survival game at this moment.In theory there is very little to worry about. For survival you need  a few simple things:  Food, water and shelter. These are the key elements in this game. No complex crafting (though there is some crafting and repairing), no complex building. Just plain simple survival.  really?  It is harder then you think. This game does not give in to the easy generation. It has permadeath, and it's hard. Every bullit counts. You have to plan ahead to survive.  You can't forage wood in bitter cold. So you better have some in reserve.  Ah yeah, every match counts to :P . Sometimes it's even unfair how hard it is. Just like real life.Simplicity is the key In everything. You won't find super realistic graphics with grass looking even more realistic then real grass, like in chernarus (from arma/dayz) However, the graphics still look very appealing.  Especially at sunrise, and sunset. Just beautiful.Allthough this is yet another early access , it is a Must buy if you are into survival games.  I bought this game in  sale, but I would pay full price for this game.  It's worth it.One tip for starters:  Don't start on easy mode. Go for stalker, or at least medium mode. Also, don't  use any online maps to find all the locations. Find everything yourself.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm reviewing the early access version. We are still waiting for the story mode.This game is a survival masterpiece. Most survival games (or probbaby all of them) lack the reality. I mean let's say you are alone on an island. Is it reallistic to craft an axe, cut some trees and build a house in few hours (or few days)? It would take weeks for one human to do so and I'm in doubt that this would be possible at all (imagine you need to transport lumber - how?). Another thing - you are getting hungry what would you do? In most games you just hand kill an animal which by chance came near you. Too easy.You won't find such things here. The game is as reallistic as possible. You can't build. You have to relay on what was already built. You can craft only some basic stuff like fishing hook, bow and arrows, skin clothes, torches etc. Hunting is really dificult. Unless you find a rifle (you will still be very limited with ammo though) you will either have to craft a bow (using which is very difficult) or try to get some food by chance. Of course you need to gather wood to boil things etc.Your main evemy is cold. Until you craft some better clothes you can't stay outside for a long time so you need a lot of planning. You will have to explore with a lot of common sense too - never go out too far without a chance of getting back. You will have to account for changing weather. You have no map, no compass and when visibility drops you are lost in a moment.This game can give you a lot of fun for tenths of hours even though it's just a sandbox. Survival and exploration in the most realistic way. We are still waiting for the story mode. My guess is it won't be as deep as for example Fallout but still combining the most reallistic survival with a thrilling story can be perfect. I hope this game can be modded in the future so there could be more missions on different custom-made maps. If you are not sure whether to get this game or not, wait for the story mode. It might skyrocket the fun even more. In one sentence - the most reallistic survival game out there.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								$20 is a steal for this game cause its only gonna get more expensive the closer it gets to version 1.0Survival.  Straight out.  There's no one out there but you and the animals.  The game tracks your hunger, thirst, body temp, medical ailments(sickness/injury) and calorie intake and usage.  Failing to manage all of these correctly will result in the death of you.Inventory.  This is your mini game to keep you occupied while trying to defrost your tootsies.  Clothes, food, water,  weapons and miscellaneous supplies all have a purpose and must be maintained to survive successfully. Animals.  They're out there and so are you.  These towns are only big enough for one sheriff so show them who's boss.  But be warned.  A failed skirmish with a hostile animal can result in fatal injuries.The environment.  This is the star of the show.  It will stop at nothing to kill you with its sudden storms, blistering winds or vast wilderness where one wrong turn could cost you more than just time.  I was in fog so thick I literally didn't know which way to go and I ended up getting lost.For a survival game this is top of its class.  Don't let the art style throw you off.  This is the most realistic survival game to date.  No game makes you feel the desperation of scavenging like this one.  Just hoping to find something to eat or drink.  The relief of finding shelter just before nightfall to keep from freezing to death.  The fear of running in to a small pack of wolves as they feast on a dead animal carcass.  Or the absolute dread when night has fallen and you have inefficient supplies to make a fire.How long can you survive?10/10
