content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is an update of my previous review of The Long Dark.  I highly recommended it in my first review, and continue to do so now.I'm old enough that I was a kid when the first gaming consoles were first hitting the market (Atari, Intellivision, etc.), and I've been playing games since then.  When PC games were just getting started, I got sucked into those as well.  There have been a lot of really good games over the years.  Some of those early ones (think:  Zelda) are still famous today.  For me, The Long Dark falls into that category of "historic" games.  Not because it's old, but simply because it's just that good and just that enjoyable.  It is, however, a single player survival game.  So if you're looking to run around on a multi-player map shooting, stabbing, and lauching grenades and friends and enemies with equal ease, well, this certainly ain't that, as I've yet to even find a grenade, let alone a friend!But if you like survival games - just you versus whatever nature can throw at ya - well, here ya go!  There are no flesh eating zombies here, but the wolves and bears seem to be quite happy to play the bad guy. I've been playing The Long Dark off and on since it first came to Steam Early Access.  Since then the Dev's have slowly and consistently been tweaking gameplay, fixing bugs, and adding content/maps.  They have an overall development roadmap that they're behind the power curve on, but they are and have been consistently and continuously pushing forward.  Updates are pushed through often, and they're incredibly good about communicating with the players - and that communication is a two way street with them.  They listen to player feedback and also communicate what they're working on and what their expected timeframes are.As for the game itself, well, it is WELL worth the current $10 to check it out yourself.But if you just have to have an idea of what you're getting yourself into, here's some tidbits for you:- There are a variety of difficulty levels.  The easiest is quite easy.  The hardest - well, most players won't survive very long.- Death is permanent and ends the playthrough.- There are only a few games that I've ever played that I continually come back to time and again after taking a break from gaming.- There IS a relatively steep learning curve where survival is concerned, but not so much where game mechanics are concerned.  The weather is your biggest adversary in this game, as it limits your ability to harvest food and water. - I love the graphics.  They're not what I would consider HD, but the artwork is amazing.  Go outside on a clear night and look up.  It's really spectacularly beautiful!- There are currently 8 different connected maps/zones.  Each map/zone has the potential for dozens upon dozens of hours of interactive/exploration gameplay, all while trying to avoid becoming a meal for local predators.Of all of the games I've ever played, The Long Dark easily makes my list of top 10, and in reality it's probably in my top 2 or 3.  If you can afford it, plunk down the current $10 (it's 1/2 off right now) and find out for yourself if you like it.  The thousands of positve reviews certainly should tell you there is some survival gaming goodness inside!__________________________________________________________(Old Review)I have nothing but positive things to say about this game.  I've played it off and on since it arrived on Steam.The Dev's are incredibly active with the game and are regularly fixing bugs and/or adding content.  They commuicate regularly and are very accessible through both the Steam and Hinterland forums for help, questions, bug reports, etc.  They are also very receptive to gameplay feedback as they are always seeking to improve gameplay.As for the game itself, it's simply excellent.  It's challenging and VERY replayable.  Once a player gets the learning/playing curve down, survival is not horribly difficult... as long as you don't make any mistakes.  And mistakes can be costly, sometimes resulting in death.  Death is permanent and ends the play through, which simply adds to the challenge because developing character resources that allow more in game freedom (from the weather) takes a lot of time.  The player is on a constant hunt for survival resources, which includes food, water, clothing while being on the lookout for predators such as wolves (quite common) and bears (fairly rare).  Depending on the game difficulty level chosen, play through goes from relatively easy to incredibly difficult.  The game graphics are not high end/high definition, but are quite nice, and a starry night sky in this game is phenomenally beautiful.If survival challenge games are your thing, then I highly recommend this game.

Early Access Review
 10/10      The Long Dark is really cool and really relistic game with nearly endless things to do. In survival mode you can either try to survive as long as you can, or just watch the gorgeous views. In the manifold challenge modes you can try to kill the nefarious bear before it kills yo, or collect massive amounts of food so that you can survive the storm that is coming, and as the reward you get buffs to the survival mode.     This game can also be extremely scary, I have gotten jumpscared by bears, wolves, and even rabbits. If you are on the last bits of your health, trying to walk to the closest nearby house, and you see a bear guarding the house who starts running after you, you feel your heartbeat around your entire body and you feel really scared.     The Long Dark is one of the best games I have ever played, and I certainly do recommend it to anyone who likes real-life-like survival games, or likes snow.     The only thing the game is missing is a co-op mode and player models, so that it looks like that you are walking in the game, not levitating, or that you are holding something, not that the item is floating on the bottom right of the screen.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game will get you, it is not a matter of if, only a matter of when....Day 27.Close call. My starvation had gotten the better of me, I needed food soon or else I would pass out and possibly never wake up. I had taken residence in a lake side cottage some 15 days before, it had, at the time, been a god-send. Food, water, shelter, and plenty of chairs and shelves to break down for wood, I had made it. Now the food was all but gone, my cottage ran cold most nights, and without the ability to distill water (lack of feul; aka chairs) I had a verrrrrry serious risk of disease from drinking the water that, at this point, probably contained some kind of stool. I was nearing the breaking point, but I had just enough supplies to go reset my traps and possibly live throughout the night to try and catch something, it was all or nothing. I wake up on the 27th day, and the wind is howling, I look outside and it seems as though I am staring at a blank peice of paper. Great. Here I go to die. I decide that I would rather die frozen in the ground somewhere ( I could be one of those people in someone elses game perhaps) than starving to death in a shadowed cottage so, I take my chances. The long trek begins, I set off across the frozen lake to the spot I had designated for traps when I had first arrived in the area. I am bundled up with the best clothes that frozen people can buy (very comforting when you are trying not to freeze), and set off, resiliently into the morning (or night, honestly couldnt tell it was such a storm). I make my way slowly through the howling winds, unable to detect any landmarks on the edge of the lake, and am effectively, lost. Finally I spot a small island that I had seen days earlier in the middle of the large lake. Great, I am halfway there. I was numb before I left the cottage in the first place so, at this point, I would be lucky to be able to count my toes on one hand (depending if I had fingers either). Finally I limp through the cold to an outcropping off the lake bed, and I see three rabbits frolicking through what must be 2 feet of snow that has fallen within a few hours. Three small, little, tasty, little, small rabbits. In a fit of anger I run after them, I would just eat them raw if need be, im sure cold raw rabbit meat is super tasty anyways. I run out of breath in about two seconds and am forced into the realization that I still need to set my traps, and that this stranded experience has neither turned me into Usain Bolt, or an experienced, versatile hunter. I set three traps, one for each rabbit I was so longengly looking after, and set off back across the frozen tundra. This was a short lived task however, I hear a howl through the wind, but a different kind of howl. This was not wind, this was the hunting pack. I had seen them skulking around the lakes beaches a few days before, and now they had found their chance to take on little old feeble me. All I could think was, "I walk through the shadow of the valley of death, and I am definitely F****** afraid of this evil". I took off, well as fast as my ice blocks of legs could carry me. I had the general direction of a cottage I had seen a few days ago eariler, in relations to my trapping ground. Luckily for me this hunch was correct, I came upon a small abandoned house with the wolf pack in hot pursuit, and slammed the door in their face. Great! Then I realized that I had a grand total of an axe and a flair in my pack, as well as some currently useless medical supplies and about half a slatine cracker. You better believe that was the best damn cracker I have ever had. I had to wait, the wolves were at the door and there was no where to go. I contemplated my options: 1) Die inside 2) Die outside 3) Chop off arm, give to wolves, then die.Well I went with numbero dos on this one. I ran outside, straight into a wolf. He was one of the ones from the pack but had strayed a bit from them and was more or less on his own. He saw me as easy prey and charged. I fumbled around in my pack for the last flare I had found and chucked it at him right as he was bearing down upon me. Smacked him across the top of the head and scared him off, only he wasnt the only one. Guess who was back. His friends. Well now I am a nice refrigerated raw meat sack to them, and I just♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off one of their buddies, so they were slightly aggravated. I took off across the lake (I could kind of see now, the blizzard had gone from blank page white to more of a constant blast of confetti to the face) and headed for the woods to try and lose them. They slowed but didnt stop giving chase and forced me to look for a quick fix to the situation. As I wheezed my way through the forest, being stalked by the two wolves that were still interested in this easy meal, I finally came upon train tracks of some kind. I saw a derailed train covered in feet of snow and decided to hunker down in that as night was falling. By the time I had pulled myself up and into the train car it was pitch black and I couldnt see my hand in front of my face. I rolled out my sleeping bag that I had luckily brought with me and tried to not freeze to death in the process of sleeping. I woke up at the crack of dawn, essentially dead in every way but spirit. My core body temperature was probably colder than the ice I had slept on. I was, as always, close to starvation and exceedingly dehydrated. I decide to look around this abandoned train car and see if I can somehow survive this disasterous situation.There it is. The one thing that could have saved me. I had on and off been looking for this singular item since the game began. It is the rifle (now for people who have never played this game, the moment you find a firearm is about on par with winning the super bowl 15 times in a row, 20 if it has ammo) and guess what, it has ammo. (I can see the super bowl rings now....) I feel a type of elation that is impossible to describe. I MAY JUST LIVE. Now comes the trying to live part. I make my way down the tracks as I remember my cottage being relatively close to a set of tracks, whethere these were those, I was completely unsure, but its all I had to go on. Then the second best feeling ever in this game, I saw a red flag flapping against the white nothingness of the crisp air and snow, the flag that adorned the top, of a small shadowed cabin I called home.10/10 You feel as though you are the character (minus the frostbite)(SEE COMMENTS FOR THE REST OF THE REVIEW, AS WELL AS MY UNTIMELY DEMISE)

Early Access Review
								I hesitated a lot before buying this game. Being not much of a crafter guy I had misgivings. Furthermore, being in early access and all, I had some bad experiences before. Last, I feared that it would not be that much interesting or challenging. No real ennemies and all that. Boy, I was WRONG!I thought I knew about survival, I thought those zombie games had prepared me. Not in the least, they hadn't.First try, I found a gun, went all rambo after I missed a wolf and decided to track it down. I got lost, got surrounded by wolves and got killed. Ok I learnt to respect them. There were some ennemies after all. New game, I thought I knew what to expect but no, I still hadn't met the most fearsome foe of all: the cold.After I found a very comfy cabine beside a frozen lake I decided to go to one of the small fishing huts. It was 500 meters away, tops. So I decided to dump most of the clutter in my backpack (you know, silly useless things such as spare clothes,wood, soda cans, food in general). So here I go in the bright morning to do some fishing. I did fish, but when I looked up from my fishing hole an end of the world blizzard was bellowing outside. Complete whiteout, I started to get very cold. So I looked through my pack, found some wood and (I was lucky there was a heating apparatus in that hut) started warming up while cooking the fish. Two hours later, visibility still a big fat zero.So started the most adrenaline filled, terrifying moment I've had with a video game in a long time. I decided to hoof it back to the cabine through the wind and the snow.Five meters toward the shore. Ten. Can't see the hut behind me, cant see the shore either, I'm hoping I'm not getting lost. At last I see some trunks. I take a right to get back to the cabine. I"m getting colder, I start shaking then growing numb. Rocks, trees, snow, still no cabine.AT LAST over there I think I can see the roof... No. Just another boulder. At that point I was completely exhausted, badly dehydrated and almost frozen to death. It felt like I'd been going for hours. I kept telling myself "nah, its just 500 meters, that's not much, you must be real close!". And when I could barely walk anymore, my bag seemingly weighting a ton, then I saw it. THE CABINE only 10 PACES AHEAD! I made it. It was really useful to try and memorize how I could use the  shore as a rail to go back but still... I was shaking with relief as my character collapsed in a bed to get ten hours of shuteye.Last thing, I thought I'd never say that but it's the first game to make me go "OMG YES, A FROZEN HALF ROTTEN DEAR! T'IS MY LUCKY DAY!". For a game in early access it has a great feel to it. It already beats a lot of AAA titles, the replayability looks great from where I stand. Buy without hesitation, support the devs!10/10, will go die a silly death ten meters from shelter while getting eaten by wolves again

Early Access Review
								Get this game right now if you like survival games, you will definitely get your money's worth at full price and it often goes on sale if you're cheap. I myself love survivals a lot and have had this game for a while. It can be a bit challenging, but half the fun with any survival game is that it challenges you.Pros:+ Really beautiful art style. Amazing looking for how simple it is.+ Being able to survive for a long time has a really rewarding feeling that is hard to get in many other survival games.+ Game is very stable despite being an EA title. I honestly don't recall running into a single bug and it doesn't require a top notch PC to run.+ 3 difficulty levels have been added, no longer are you forced into one difficulty.+ Lots to explore if you want to. Quite a large world, but you don't have to play all areas if you don't want to, though I'd say that's half the fun. More maps coming as well.+ Steam workshop allows for player made language packs.Cons:- Can be very easy to get lost if you're not 100% familiar with the map you're playing on.- Sometimes you get really crappy spawn luck and you either have to try to deal with it or start over. This is pretty much not an issue on easiest difficulty as resources are so common and wildlife doesn't attack.- No tutorial yet, so some things can be sort of confusing at first.- No customization at all, which is a con for me since I do love customizing things.- When you die, it's over, you have to begin anew.Neutrals:= Very little music, which could be good or bad depending on the person playing. I don't mind it so much, it helps to hear stuff around you.= Sometimes the sound effects are a bit irritating because of the repetitiveness, but overall they're not too bad.= I'm not a big fan of the inventory/conditions/crafting interfaces, but they're functional.= The environment can be very cruel, even on easiest difficulty. This can be a big con for people new to survivals and not good at managing themselves in-game. To me it's just part of the game, though, so at worst this is a neutral point for me.= Map setup doesn't change each play through, other than actual items you pick up (though some locations have exclusive or almost guaranteed spawns so they need to be checked for certain items). This can be both good and bad because it makes the maps predictable once you're used to them, which hurts replayability a little, but also allows replays to go smoother.= No story mode for the moment, but that is in development.= Development has been a bit slow lately, but it's not a huge team and there's a lot to do in the game in it's current state, so I would still argue it's still a worthwhile buy.---The pros greatly outweigh the cons in my opinion. It does get frustrating when you've made good progress and some random fluke of a thing kills you, but for some reason that doesn't make me stop playing it, when most games would frustrate me to the point of not being able to play again by doing that. Perhaps those with rage issues should pass this game up, though.I highly recommend that anyone new to the game uses the community made maps. None of them are 100% accurate and you may need to make note of the differences yourself, but they will give you a pretty good idea of where you're going at first and eventually you won't need them because the maps don't change each playthrough. I still find them useful though for planning where I'm going to go when I start a new game or for when I have to stop playing, I can cross off the locations I've visited so I don't forget.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a very promising game if you like certain types of gameplay. Let me clarify what type of gameplay this game has so you get the idea of whether you want to play it or not.---------------------------------At this CURRENT moment the game only offers the ability to play in sandbox mode. In this mode you spawn in a random area at a random time of day. The goal is to survive as long as you can and that's about it, however, it's not as easy as you'd always assume. The loot around the area is also random so you may be lucky or unlucky as to what you will find. I don't think you can be soo unlucky that you will die right from the start but you may not find something as valuable as a sewing kit.You have to deal with many issues in this game such as starvation, dehydration, fatigue, injuries, freezing, etc. There is food within the game as random loot as well as raw meat from animals which you can cook on a fire. Having something to drink can be random or you can melt snow to get water and you will need to boil water to purify it for safe drinking unless you have a water purifier. If you carry too much weight you will get fatigued very fast as well as running around everywhere and burning your calories which is another thing in the game. Depending on the quality of your items and what they are changes how well you can survive outside for extended periods of time and being by a fire isn't going to help you if it's windy and freezing outside so going indoors is always a good option.This alone wouldn't be much of a challenge but there are also wolves in the game and they are quite brutal. If one attacks you then you must build up strenth then attack it which can do 3 things: hurt the wolf a little, hurt the wolf enough to make it run away, or kill the wolf. If you are very tired and run into a wolf you are screwed because you cannot build much strength up at that time and you will be overpowered and killed.The weather can be mellow, windy, or there may be a blizzard which will freeze you VERY fast if you are outside.There will be more options and there will be a campaign but at the moment there is only sandbox survival which is still fun.---------------------------------The art style is nice in this game and is different. The sounds are great and this is an overall nice game. Should you buy it? Completely up to you but at the current state $20 is a bit much but there is more content coming and I've been seeing 1-2 updates a day since launch so things are actually getting done and I believe my money was well spent so far.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Day 1: I awake to find myself in a frozen wasteland. Alone, cold and getting colder. What do I do? I need food, water, shelter. Trudging through the thick snow, I decide my best bet is to find some high ground and hope I can spot something that may be of use. As I reach the peak I see a small wooden structure next to a pond. Eagerly I rush down the side of the hill, hoping that I may find something of use. Inside is a can of beans, and not much else. Quickly I collect my prize and scavenge a small bundle of sticks that may be I can use for a fire if I can't find some place to hold up for the night. A little ways in the distance I see a flock of crows cawing, and circling over something. I decide to check it out. There in the snow bank, right under where the black birds hover is a man, dead. Covered in ice and snow. Most likely lost his way in a storm, looking for shelter or food, the same way I am. Is this my future? No, I won't end up like him. All I need to do is find some place to hold up and eventually, surely, help will come. I search his body, no time to pay respects. The sun is setting and I need to move. Maybe he has something that will help me avoid the same outcome as him. A smile spreads across my face. A pocket knife! Jackpot! I need to move now. I think I see something in the distance.Night 1:The house must have belonged to a trapper. Inside was a rifle, with a couple rounds, and some wire traps for small game. I've never hunted in my life, but necessity demands that I learn on the fly now. I tore the cabin apart, scavenging whatever I could use. I'm so cold though. Snow clinging to almost every inch of my clothing. It took a few tries, but I was able to get a fire started in the stove in the corner. Good thing I had those matches on me during the crash. There's only a few left though. I'll need to be careful how I use them. Right now these are the most precious tools to me. Each small stick is precious to seperate me from death. As I warm myself by the fire, I decide to melt some of the snow to give myself a small supply of drinking water. As the water boils I also use my newly found pocket knife to open the can of beans. Heating them on the fire I gulp it down as soon as they're done. Back home this would barely pass as a snack. Here it's a gourmet meal. It's time I get some sleep. In the morning I need to hunt. Other than a small package of jerky and a candy bar I found in the cabin, I'm not very well stocked. Hopefully my first hunting trip will pay off.Day 2:Maybe I should've watched somet hunting shows when I was back home. It occurs to me I know almost nothing on how to hunt and trap. I set up the wire trap in the woods, but unless a rabbit just happens to strangle itself in it I don't think I'm going to have much luck. I'll come back and check in awhile. In the meantime I'll try to track down one of those deer I saw yesterday.The trap is empty. Go figure. My stomach is growling. The candy bar did little to slate my hunger. What the hell am I going to do? I pick up the trap. Maybe I'll have better luck somewhere else? What's that? Out the corner of my eye I see movement. A buck! Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ No way! Maybe someone up there is looking out for me after all! I crouch trying to hide my presents as I bring the rifles sights up. I've only ever fired a BB gun before, but it's the same concept right? I line the sights up, centering them near the deers heart. I let out my breath slowly, as I go to pull the trigger...Night 2The irony isn't lost on me, even as I sit here, the Long Dark creeping in on me. My head hurts, I can hear my own heart beat pulsing in my ears. I killed the deer. One shot. It went down like I was an expert. I even was able to skin it, gut it, and harvest the meat, something I never thought I'd ever do. I had a feast all laid out in front of me. Yet in the end it wasn't lack of food or shelter that will do me in. Fire. God damned fire. Something that the earliest man knew how to use somehow eludes me. I couldn't get the fire started again. I had two matches and both times the fire only flickered and died. I have no way to start it. In a panic I ran outside to go look for something to start it with, but it's midnight and a storm hit. I can't see a foot in front of my face. I'm lost, I think I've been going in circles. I don't remember where the cabin is. I chuckle as I think of how bad I am at this. I couldn't even survive 2 nights on my own. No ones coming for me, there won't be a rescue party, and in the end I'm destined to die here in the snow. I close my eyes and wait for the end. I just hope that the darkness comes for me before the wolves do. PROS:-Fantastic survival simulator, even at this early stage of development. Already have put 4 hours in and will continue to put in more.-2 large maps-Each playthrough feels different-Challenging. 2 days is the longest I've survived so far-Great atmosphere, and feeling of lonliness and isolation-Wolves stalk you, and at night their eyes glow and makes you feel like you're in "The Grey." A+ for that.-No map. I count this as a pro because you have to rely on your own memory of where things are. When storms hit you can quickly become disoriented and lose your way which is thrilling.CONS:-The coastal highway map feels a bit too easy. I came across a town with several houses and have found a virtually endless supply of food, water, and great clothing. Not to mention it's next to several fishing spots. When your supplies are in abundance the game loses it's sense of adventure and danger, and thus loses a large amount of fun-Items are randomly placed every game, but structures are not. This means you can eventualy learn the map and find all houses quickly just from memory. Though it's random what you'll find, knowing where to look eliminates some of the challenge of surviving. -Only animals you'll currently see are deer, rabbits, and wolves. Here's hoping we see some new fauna additions in the future.-Not a lot to do when you're well fed, and stuck inside during a blizzard. A way to level up your abilities with out having to repair/craft something would be nice, like reading books, etc.

Early Access Review
								Early access review:After a few stumbling attempts ending in death by falling, hyperthemia, wolf attack, exhaustion coupled with food poisoning and more wolf attacks, I finally got the hang of things.With an ever-present sense of peril, I chose to leave the forrest with all its delicious untrappable rabbits, embarking on a journey in search for better pastures and -- dare we hope? -- a gun. After a few days of scavaging, I eventually found a tunnel through the mountains, leading to a large lake. Along its shores I found a small town and was finally able to make camp on a more permanent basis. There I spent my days fishing and forraging, each day trekking back to my pleasant little homestread. Life was good. On the seventh day I finally found a gun next to a corpse and... it all went down-hill from there.With a sense of delusional self-empowerment, possessing the means to ascend to the top of the food chain, I shot and missed a few wolves. On the 9th day, on my day home from an unusually unproductive expedition, I came upon a bear that had annoyingly blocked my path during the morning. Taking aim, I shot (and probably missed yet again) believing that I could get to a nearby house if I couldn't get it to bleed to death. And oh boy, bears can apparently sprint pretty well, for it quickly pushed me to the ground and mauled me repeatedly, leaving me for dead. Within an inch of my life, I crawled my way back to the house. The next morning, a wolf waited outside my door, making easy pray of my already wounded form. And so yet another story ended.----------Perhaps a little repetative with the same map every time, but as long as you're actually exploring its a very enjoyable experience.

Upgrading your gear can be difficult, because you might need some drops from certain animals that they don't always drop. I also think that the wolves could use more ways to behave. They just always simply walk or run towards you and attack if you don't do something about it.Overall I really like the game. Great play value, but could be better.Value: 9/10This game can be constantly replayed and has endless fun, the developers work hard on this game and post updates often, adding more value to the game. There is a great amount of good gameplay involved that is SLIGHTLY (0.000005%) impeded by constant wolves, but once you get a knife, oh, then its their time to worry.Singleplayer: 10/10Amazing singleplayer. Singleplayer is so far the only mode available, but still one of the best out there in the survival standpoint. All games seem to go for zombies and nuclear fallouts, while this game takes realism to a new level, its just you and the evilness of mother nature.Co-op: - No Co-op yet, I really hope that the developers will eventually bring co-op to the table, as there would be even more fun. Its always more fun if you have great friends trying to survive also. Now, lemme get more in depth to why it has probably not been released: Resources. For two players you will either require double the resources, or have them left for dead to survive for mere days. There would have to be a lot more loot on the map or the friends would have to split up, one on Costal Highway, and one on Mystery lake, which would not be as fun.Multiplayer: -Same with Co-op, there would be great balancing issues, but If the devs could overcome that it would be so awesome to have multiplayer.Content: 9.5/10Hunting, Scavenging, Foraging, Creating Fires, Taking Antibiotics for wolf attacks, this game has already such an indepth system of scavenging and everything. (It even includes infections :D)Length: 10/10Extremely long playthroughs are possible with proper management of health, condition, food, water, and a hefty supply of resources. You can probably sleep to day 50 on just one map alone before resources get extremely low.Story: 8/10Not much is known about the charachters. I know, they are making story mode. I cannot wait until it comes out, especially since they say it will be in episodes and seasons. If they make me pay for them as DLCs...Gameplay: 10/10Very good, open gameplay. Basically an open world that allows for lots of fun.With freinds: -No co-op and multiplayer yet. I hope for them very soon.Graphics: 8/10Strange and Mixed about the Graphics. Its like they tried to go BL style on some things as it looks like they tried to convert a cartoon to real life (Much like the SFM MLP models and such) It doesn't look as good as it could, but its ok. Graphics will hopefully get a huge overhaul to get more realism, or they will focus on a cartoon-like atmosphere. (I do not know which they will go for)Physics: 9/10Physics are ok, every once in a while I have a deer glitch through the rock (No joke I can upload a video of it right now, just add me and tell me to) and other problems. Lemme delve into realism here, because that is what the game is trying to do, you can run up hills, albeit slowly, not as realistic as you would severely hurt your ankles almost instantly, but in this game they survive. (Those are just nitpicking details)Performance: 10/10Here is the problem for me: I run on a 8 month old gaming computer that is still better than most out there that are up to date. I cannot accurately tell you how much memory usage or stuff it uses as I do not check. This is what I can tell you: It runs flawlessly, transitions into houses (new levels/maps) are flawless and only take but a second or two, I have not tried crossing into coastal highway nor have I played coastal highway.Sound: 8/10Sound is good but maybe a little rough here and there.Polished: 8/10Nothing majorly wrong with it but I still have not found the bunker, which is kinda annoying. (Overall great game, just a few flaws. I have heard of wolves invisible, but that is probably a graphics card problem not game problem)Atmosphere: 8.5/10The vast landscape gives you a good immersive feel but could be better if they didn't have so much of the same trees making it all feel the same.Objectives: 9/10Objectives are pretty basic. Pretty much survive. The sub-objectives of that objective are vast and indephth, so the game is really good because of the mechanics and playstyle.Clarity: 9/10No problems with knowing where to go or what to do. (The story line will probably linear and very easy to follow when it comes out. I cant wait!)World: 9.5/10Unparalleled world. Massive world (Split in two so far) with mountains, caves, vast foliage, and tons of wildlife to try and kill you. Although most of the landscape has the same trees and plants so a lot of it looks the same. (More diverse?)Characters: 8/10Not much is known about the characters. Once the story mode is released my rating will probably go up, unless the details we learn are useless and add no effect to the story or charachters.UI: 10/10Great UI, I think It could have a pause feature while in the TAB menu, but that is just me.Controls: 10/10Great controls, can change key bindings to personal preference. (All buttons/actions are customizable)Freedom: 10/10As much freedom as you could ask for. You can do whatever you want, such as going for a nature hike.Influence: 10/10The Gameplay is very dynamic and not linear at all. Your only objective is to survive and you can do that many ways. Scavenging DayZ style, or hunting Forest Gum style (yes I misspelled his name, and yes that was a horrible analogy as it was just meant to be a joke) Could have more maps or loot to make surviving longer possible.Settings: 9/10Settings are great, many different Graphic options (have not tried any but maximum) and key binding changing is easy. Audio and everything else in the menue is also great.Character progression: 6/10No character progression, other than trying to survive.Weapon selection: 8/10Has limited weapons. Shotguns and (better) sniper rifles should all be added eventually. So far only 3 weapons or so.Customization: 7/10No weapon or item customization, only repair or harvest.AI: 8.5/10For the most part the ai is fairly intelligent. Every once in a while are there weird glitches in the ai. Wolves have howl animation which in my eyes is pretty cool.Up to date: 9/10Constantly evolving as it is in Early Access, which is why I am being careful of what I state in this review. Everything might eventually change.Replayability: 10/10Entire game as stated above can be played up until forever if you get enough resources. The fun of surviving drives me to constantly replaythis.Pace: 10/10You can do everything at your own pace. No one rushes you. (Except for your Hunger, Thirst, Condition, Wolve Population and about 70 other things trying to kill you.)Repetitiveness: 9/10I guess some people can find it repetitive to constantly day after day survive in this game, but thats basically how life works, there are rarely any fun moments and mostly just work.Realism: 10/10Realism is very high in this game. Must I say more?DLC: -No DLCs so far, MIGHT be some for the story, but I will be very sad if they make you pay for it. It it is like a free dlc then I will be happy even though its a DLC.Achievements: 10/10Track how long you have survived with achievements. Its really exhilarating and a great feeling of accomplishment. Tip: for extra realism and feeling of accomplishment reset your achievement stats for The Long Dark.

Early Access Review
								Get this game right now if you like survival games, you will definitely get your money's worth at full price and it often goes on sale if you're cheap. I myself love survivals a lot and have had this game for a while. It can be a bit challenging, but half the fun with any survival game is that it challenges you.Pros:+ Really beautiful art style. Amazing looking for how simple it is.+ Being able to survive for a long time has a really rewarding feeling that is hard to get in many other survival games.+ Game is very stable despite being an EA title. I honestly don't recall running into a single bug and it doesn't require a top notch PC to run.+ 3 difficulty levels have been added, no longer are you forced into one difficulty.+ Lots to explore if you want to. Quite a large world, but you don't have to play all areas if you don't want to, though I'd say that's half the fun. More maps coming as well.+ Steam workshop allows for player made language packs.Cons:- Can be very easy to get lost if you're not 100% familiar with the map you're playing on.- Sometimes you get really crappy spawn luck and you either have to try to deal with it or start over. This is pretty much not an issue on easiest difficulty as resources are so common and wildlife doesn't attack.- No tutorial yet, so some things can be sort of confusing at first.- No customization at all, which is a con for me since I do love customizing things.- When you die, it's over, you have to begin anew.Neutrals:= Very little music, which could be good or bad depending on the person playing. I don't mind it so much, it helps to hear stuff around you.= Sometimes the sound effects are a bit irritating because of the repetitiveness, but overall they're not too bad.= I'm not a big fan of the inventory/conditions/crafting interfaces, but they're functional.= The environment can be very cruel, even on easiest difficulty. This can be a big con for people new to survivals and not good at managing themselves in-game. To me it's just part of the game, though, so at worst this is a neutral point for me.= Map setup doesn't change each play through, other than actual items you pick up (though some locations have exclusive or almost guaranteed spawns so they need to be checked for certain items). This can be both good and bad because it makes the maps predictable once you're used to them, which hurts replayability a little, but also allows replays to go smoother.= No story mode for the moment, but that is in development.= Development has been a bit slow lately, but it's not a huge team and there's a lot to do in the game in it's current state, so I would still argue it's still a worthwhile buy.---The pros greatly outweigh the cons in my opinion. It does get frustrating when you've made good progress and some random fluke of a thing kills you, but for some reason that doesn't make me stop playing it, when most games would frustrate me to the point of not being able to play again by doing that. Perhaps those with rage issues should pass this game up, though.I highly recommend that anyone new to the game uses the community made maps. None of them are 100% accurate and you may need to make note of the differences yourself, but they will give you a pretty good idea of where you're going at first and eventually you won't need them because the maps don't change each playthrough. I still find them useful though for planning where I'm going to go when I start a new game or for when I have to stop playing, I can cross off the locations I've visited so I don't forget.

A nechýbajú extrémne realistické zvuky a humor postavy za ktorú hráte + môžete si tam vytknúť členok aj keď zle srupite! Ta hra je tak realistická čo si hneď zamilujete! Plusy - efektívne počasie - Veľkí svet na preskúmanie - Lokácie niesu prázdne - Hard-core - autori na hru nekaslu - môžete hrať za chlapca alebo  dievča - Workshop kde nájdete česky jazyk - Privehovi mód (nedostupný lebo sa na tom pracuje)- Krásni dizajn main menu a Hudu - krásna hudba - grafika je pekná a poháňa ju Unity Engine! - Optimalizácia - Crafting - môžete späť v aute, posteli,  alebo vo vlastnom ukryté s krikou - Môžete si môcť zapáliť oheň s. content:

Early Access Review
								This game is unique compared to its genre. Enough said, Fantastic! Most real you can get, now with that said, I'm annoyed to see people going around trying to beat that generalization up saying the game isn't realistic. It's the most you can get towards it. Yes you have stuff that falls apart fast, yes you get hungry fast. Heck, you are in freezing wheather, in all reality that does mean you are burning calories a LOTTT faster. Maybe the game isn't perfect but it's fun and enjoy it for that purpose, it's a hardcore game and I'd rather have tons of food I have to eat more of than finding no food at all when I need to survive. I'd rather have a can opener that breaks than twnety of them and no worries the rest of my game. (With that, I'd l ike to say stuff doesn't even fall apart that fast anymore, on top of that you can REPAIR things. Which everyone freaks out saying clothes don't fall off you and knives don't break. Um, I never once had clothes fall off or a knife break in game, because I notice it is breaking and fix it. You fight off a dozen wolf attacks and expect your knife to be okay, alright?)For those who don't enjoy survival or don't like exploration or don't like a challenge, that just means you're a book reader going to a magazine store. You're in the wrong genre buying a game you don't like! If you do enjoy all those aspects that this game supplies, then awesome cause I do to and this game just blows me away. It's replay value is higher then you think. If you start and read all about the places and how to play, then yes you probably won't have as much fun, if you just start and learn about it and explore without cheating online you're going to have a blast. I have yet to find every single location and I barely even played on the second map still. They have randomizing locations for loot and a special location that makes it that much more exciting to explore after each playthrough.Wolves is a big one. I love them, another challenge to overcome when trying to survive. If you want to say what the hell wolves don't attack people, then move on. Because a hungry wolf in the middle of a post DISASTER scenario who needs ot eat will attack someone. Which brings me to another part, the mechanics of the wolves are awesome. Because at times they WILL NOT attack you. Instead they see you and run away. Very rare but it does happen. They come at you, you can still scare them away, stand your ground don't rush them, light a flare and they are gone. If you don't ask me that sounds realistic. If you just want to be that character that lights a flare and chases down the wolf and it attacks you, then complain about it saying it's not realistic. Then you sir, are a moron. Any person who understands the makeup of animal instincts will understand that a threatned, cornered animal will fight back. The wolves in this game almost act the exact same way. Their mechanics are perfect tune with this game. I love it.Which brings me to one point, Post DISTASTER! Everyone misses the very first part of the game. Clearly a disaster has struck, and storm where your plane crashes. THIS is why dead bodies are everywhere. This is why it is cold. Not just because you are in Northern Canada. It is a disaster which explains all the destruction and death that you see. So don't go bagging the idea of its location in canada or the cold being unrealistic. The cold... Is amazing. I just one review about not being able to put on layers? Um you can... its called wool sweats under pants. Sweaters under heavy coat jackets. When you find enought of the right clothes you are able to layer them if game allows it. Yes you can't wear the biggest heavy ski vest over another heavy ski vest. It's to prevent the obvious "I'm going to run around with 50 sweaters on and be perfectly okay with absolute no challenge." The mechanics of the game are set, to limit your ability from nerfing the settings, so that you will always have a challenge in the game. Because whether you want it or not, challenge is what keeps a game afloat and enjoyable mulitple times through.Basically said, if you want to enjoy the game for what it supplies, then awesome because it gives an experience you can't really find in most survival games. To me and to it's genre, a hardcore survival game with actual challenge other then threat of CONSTANT PVP shooting and absolutely no other obstacle like you see in all these games around us with literally no genuity or originality. This game sidesteps that completely and instead of becoming an online killing game it has become a single player REAL survival compared to that genre's name now. Basically if you want to be that player that says oh a "realistic" game okay... Then play and go "Omfg wolves attack me, oh what is this I get hungry fast, oh my gosh I'm staring at a screen playing a game this isn't real life this is so not a realistic game" Then you really should rethink your gamer life and learn to understand the fun individual originality that many games, not just this one, give to you.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								TL,DR: If you like survival games, you must play The Long Dark. If you like tough, atmospheric games, play The Long Dark.I've only played The Long Dark sandbox. The story line is in the works and promises to be good. The sandbox is a pure Player vs Environment, and the Environment is a beautiful and cold beast.Since the sandbox has a fixed map, I suggest starting out without reading any materials or wikis (wikies?). Go in blind and learn the area and mechanics. It is intuitive enough to jump in and try to survive. You will die and have to restart. Take what you learned and live again. Even though the map is fixed and you will learn it after a while, the looting and enemies are random. The mechanics are tough enough to give veterans a fun challenge. The cold will punish the foolish, and the cold is always there. After a while you will get better gear and go from surviving to thriving, but death is always close. I feel comfortable with the map and mechanics and I still clench up when heading out to find more gear. Death isn't random. It will come because you weren't prepared or pushed too hard. The cold is always there.Some of the best moments for me were being close to starving or freezing and pushing out to find more gear. You get to a point where you must go forward or die. I've died in many snowbanks or watched myself eaten by wolves, but that great feeling when you find a cabin or abandoned car that helps you live, even for a few more moments, is as real as a game can create. That relief is temporary, however, because the cold is always there.As you can see from the screenshots, the graphics are wonderful. The art direction makes for a beatiful game, but don't let the beauty fool you. The world can be punishing, and the cold is a more brutal enemy than you've faced in a long time. Did I mention the cold is always there?The Devs are responsive and give big updates regularly. They have a goal for this game and are moving there nicely. Jump in on the early access and enjoy the cold with them!I've enjoyed my EA time on The Long Dark, and I know I will be revisiting it many times. I hope you enjoy the cold as much as I do.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game is NOW definitely playable in Alpha mode. They've added some more content and depth to the game, and the biggest factor of all, they finally increased the character's endurance when running (although there is still a lot of running/walking/traveling in this game).Day 23I'm on my way back to the dam's control room to collect a bunch of items i dropped since i couldn't carry them all back in one trip. After filling up my inventory, I begin to head back when i notice that this door is actually usable... I use this new door that leads to the back of the dam. Once out, I begin to look around to get a feel of the new environment. To the far left i see that there's another platform that may hold some promising items. To get across I'd have to hug the dam and tip toe across the protruding ledge. A few steps onto the ledge and I fall off the ledge onto the dam itself (the dam isn't completely vertical but at an angle)! I take only 15% damage, sprained my wrist (of course never my ankle when falling for some reason), and my clothes are a little ripped, no serious harm done. I'm off the ledge but still on the dam, so I take off all my clothes to prevent any damage to them. I take little jumps down the dam, slowly but surely. Eventually, I make it all the way down and begin to find my way back up to dam's door so i could try again. I tiptoe across the ledge once more. Yes ! I'm across the long part of the ledge. Now all i need to do is turn the corner. There's 8 more steps I need to make before i can be safe on the platform. Sure enough I fall again ! This time the injuries are more severe. I'm left with 12% hp left ! But I will not give up ! I head across to the other platform once more. Success ! I scour the platform and find nothing of value. Brrrrr... It's cold... What is this?! I'm suffering from hypothermia! FML I FORGOT TO PUT MY CLOTHES BACK ON !! My hp is slowly ticking down... After putting my clothes back on, I race across the ledge once more, to  the dam's back door. WTF !?!? I LOCKED MYSELF OUT OF THE CONTROL ROOM?!?! WHO DOES THAT ?!?! I'm panicking ! My life's slowly dropping by the percent. Down to 8%... My vision's blurry and my character begins to wobble. He's blacking out and coming back. I attempt to make a fire, but no, it's too windy ! I run around the place looking for cover from the wind ! I travel down the  mountain on a path and finally manage to get the fire going, but am left with 4% hp. I throw some logs onto the fire and warm myself up entirely. I check the time, there's 4 hours left. I've got to reach some kind of shelter before nightfall or else i'll freeze to death. Perhaps I messed somthing up and the back door actually does open? Still blacking out and wobbling, I decided to head back up to the back door to check again. I take 4 steps. OWWWW, burning damage inflicted !! I WALKED OVER MY OWN FIRE ! IS THIS HOW I'M GOING TO DIE?? KILLING MYSELF BY WALKING OVER MY OWN FIRE??!!? Thankfully, I'm left with 2% health and minor burns... I travel upwards, towards the door, but alas, the door does not open... The only way to go is down the mountain and follow the frozen river. My character's still disoriented, I'm having trouble walking and navigating my way through this maze of a river. I take every turn, only to be led to a dead end. It seems like there's no way up and out of this river system, so i push through looking for some kind of exit... I finally reach the end.... I found the tunnel system. It seemed to be the only way out, so i went in. Bad idea. 10 Steps in and i literally could not tell which way was up or down. I see a frozen corpse. Ha, i guess he'll have a friend pretty soon. I personally, begin to get motion sickness. I'm lost and i honestly can't tell if i'm going forwards into the cave or going back to where i came in from..... I give up... I exit the game and decide to reload from my last save spot (where ever that is i do not know). It happens to be the moment i entered the cave. I quickly turn around and exit. Surely there has to be another way out of this river system.... Welp, time to go online and look for a map ! There's no map. I did however, find out that there are two entrances/exits to this river system... The cave and A MFING WINDOW ON THE OPPOSITE PLATFORM TO THE DAM'S BACK DOOR!!!! I begin my journey back through the river/maze.... I'm beginning to feel tired... I'm forced to drop some inventory.... A dead end.... Another one.... Eventually i see open space. There's no mountains ahead. Sure enough, the dam appears. I travel up the moutain pass and reached the back door. Okay... I could barely cross the ledge at 100% health.... Now i've got to do it at 2% health.... I'm still wobbling, my screen is still fading in and out. I tip toe across the ledge and make sure i hit every wall there is to hit. I'm safe on the platform. I search for the window and slide my way inside of the dam. I recognize this area.... It's the deepest room inside of the dam and darkest..... I'll need a light source through the entire dam... I have a few matches and a flare.... I light the flare and race my way through the dam. I pass through the piles of items that i was supposed to retrieve. I pass through the door that started the entire journey. A few more minutes and i reach the front door of the dam. I drink and eat as much as i can. I check the time, less than an hour left of daylight ! It's a race against time ! I leave the dam with nothing but the clothes on my back and the single flare which only has 30% of it's original life left. I'm outside and it's dark. The time says less than one hour of daylight, but that's only referring to the temperature... I walk straight until i see the railroad. I place my feet on the railroad and look towards home, but i can barely see now. It's too dark ! I walk backwards, i've lost the railroad ! i look left or was it right? I see the way that isn't home and look the opposite direction. I see the bridge and railroad so I begin to walk. It's a long trek home. My flare dies out. The icon that tells me i'm suffering from lack of sleep appears. I march on. I reach a checkpoint, the trees that have been cut for lumber. I see that familiar corpse on the left side of the tracks.I reach the next checkpoint. The derailed carts. I walk around the carts and around the branch that blocks the way. From here on it's a straight path until home. I literally can not tell If i'm moving or not. I can only trust that i am. I march on. Waiting for some sign, for that opening in the mountains to the left that signifies that my cabin is there. I march on. Finally, i see the opening ! i see the black silouhette that resembles a house. I recognize that flag figure flying proudly atop the house. I run towards the house to the side i know the front door is on. I put my face against the side of the house and move left and right searching for the door. Is my face even against the wall or is it on the fence of the front porch?! I don't know, i can not see ! I try the back door which has no fence to protect it. I can't find that one either ! I back off from the house, trying to position myself to where i know the back door is, but i lose the house itself !! I see nothing but blackness. Am i touching the house or is it the mountains behind the house?!? I can not tell.... In time, i'm able to see that familiar silhoutte once more. I reposition myself and check my inventory to see if there's ANYTHING that can light the way... Apparently I left some matches in my backpack !! They must have been too light to throw away ! Thank god I was too lazy to toss them out ! I light a match against the wall of the house and am able to find the back door.... i light another match inside of the cabin so i can locate the stairs.  finally i'm safe at last.... I rest for 6 hours, not wanting to die of thirst or hunger. I wake up well enough to sleep for another 12 hours. Alas, I am home and rested, ready to journey once more...

Early Access Review
								A fantastic game, and still in its early days. I highly recommend if you enjoy survival simulators, exploring beautiful enviroments and managing a characters very life, than purchase this game and help these independent developers continue doing what they're good at.The visuals of the game are beautiful, the art style suits the tone and really helps to immerse you into its cold, icy world.The developers have really nailed all the little details in the game, small things that I suppose are not usually thought about but make a world of difference each time you discover one. Crafting could also be improved upon as I find it quite basic and I tend to search for new items rather than build my own.As for one example of these little details: I found myself wandering aimlessly, time was running short and night was approaching. My character was fatigued and hungry. I saw a church tower in the distance, made my way to it, hoping to find refuge from the hammering storm. I found little supplies, and a man, a daunting frozen statue, sitting on a bench where he had prayed for help, or death to come quick. Hope left me of surviving another night about this time.I am in love with the atmosphere, the immersion, the weather patterns and the dangers (from the wildlife and the weather itself). I found myself wandering in a snow storm, I ended up falling through thin ice, getting all turned around and ending up back at the same small hut i'd started in, gaining nothing but a loss in important stats (hunger, cold, tiredness).The fact that in its current state, it has no real purpose other than to see how long you can survive, has me wanting to go back for more only shows how addicting it can be to put yourself in the shoes of a lost survivor, desperate to see that next sunrise.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game is NOW definitely playable in Alpha mode. They've added some more content and depth to the game, and the biggest factor of all, they finally increased the character's endurance when running (although there is still a lot of running/walking/traveling in this game).Day 23I'm on my way back to the dam's control room to collect a bunch of items i dropped since i couldn't carry them all back in one trip. After filling up my inventory, I begin to head back when i notice that this door is actually usable... I use this new door that leads to the back of the dam. Once out, I begin to look around to get a feel of the new environment. To the far left i see that there's another platform that may hold some promising items. To get across I'd have to hug the dam and tip toe across the protruding ledge. A few steps onto the ledge and I fall off the ledge onto the dam itself (the dam isn't completely vertical but at an angle)! I take only 15% damage, sprained my wrist (of course never my ankle when falling for some reason), and my clothes are a little ripped, no serious harm done. I'm off the ledge but still on the dam, so I take off all my clothes to prevent any damage to them. I take little jumps down the dam, slowly but surely. Eventually, I make it all the way down and begin to find my way back up to dam's door so i could try again. I tiptoe across the ledge once more. Yes ! I'm across the long part of the ledge. Now all i need to do is turn the corner. There's 8 more steps I need to make before i can be safe on the platform. Sure enough I fall again ! This time the injuries are more severe. I'm left with 12% hp left ! But I will not give up ! I head across to the other platform once more. Success ! I scour the platform and find nothing of value. Brrrrr... It's cold... What is this?! I'm suffering from hypothermia! FML I FORGOT TO PUT MY CLOTHES BACK ON !! My hp is slowly ticking down... After putting my clothes back on, I race across the ledge once more, to  the dam's back door. WTF !?!? I LOCKED MYSELF OUT OF THE CONTROL ROOM?!?! WHO DOES THAT ?!?! I'm panicking ! My life's slowly dropping by the percent. Down to 8%... My vision's blurry and my character begins to wobble. He's blacking out and coming back. I attempt to make a fire, but no, it's too windy ! I run around the place looking for cover from the wind ! I travel down the  mountain on a path and finally manage to get the fire going, but am left with 4% hp. I throw some logs onto the fire and warm myself up entirely. I check the time, there's 4 hours left. I've got to reach some kind of shelter before nightfall or else i'll freeze to death. Perhaps I messed somthing up and the back door actually does open? Still blacking out and wobbling, I decided to head back up to the back door to check again. I take 4 steps. OWWWW, burning damage inflicted !! I WALKED OVER MY OWN FIRE ! IS THIS HOW I'M GOING TO DIE?? KILLING MYSELF BY WALKING OVER MY OWN FIRE??!!? Thankfully, I'm left with 2% health and minor burns... I travel upwards, towards the door, but alas, the door does not open... The only way to go is down the mountain and follow the frozen river. My character's still disoriented, I'm having trouble walking and navigating my way through this maze of a river. I take every turn, only to be led to a dead end. It seems like there's no way up and out of this river system, so i push through looking for some kind of exit... I finally reach the end.... I found the tunnel system. It seemed to be the only way out, so i went in. Bad idea. 10 Steps in and i literally could not tell which way was up or down. I see a frozen corpse. Ha, i guess he'll have a friend pretty soon. I personally, begin to get motion sickness. I'm lost and i honestly can't tell if i'm going forwards into the cave or going back to where i came in from..... I give up... I exit the game and decide to reload from my last save spot (where ever that is i do not know). It happens to be the moment i entered the cave. I quickly turn around and exit. Surely there has to be another way out of this river system.... Welp, time to go online and look for a map ! There's no map. I did however, find out that there are two entrances/exits to this river system... The cave and A MFING WINDOW ON THE OPPOSITE PLATFORM TO THE DAM'S BACK DOOR!!!! I begin my journey back through the river/maze.... I'm beginning to feel tired... I'm forced to drop some inventory.... A dead end.... Another one.... Eventually i see open space. There's no mountains ahead. Sure enough, the dam appears. I travel up the moutain pass and reached the back door. Okay... I could barely cross the ledge at 100% health.... Now i've got to do it at 2% health.... I'm still wobbling, my screen is still fading in and out. I tip toe across the ledge and make sure i hit every wall there is to hit. I'm safe on the platform. I search for the window and slide my way inside of the dam. I recognize this area.... It's the deepest room inside of the dam and darkest..... I'll need a light source through the entire dam... I have a few matches and a flare.... I light the flare and race my way through the dam. I pass through the piles of items that i was supposed to retrieve. I pass through the door that started the entire journey. A few more minutes and i reach the front door of the dam. I drink and eat as much as i can. I check the time, less than an hour left of daylight ! It's a race against time ! I leave the dam with nothing but the clothes on my back and the single flare which only has 30% of it's original life left. I'm outside and it's dark. The time says less than one hour of daylight, but that's only referring to the temperature... I walk straight until i see the railroad. I place my feet on the railroad and look towards home, but i can barely see now. It's too dark ! I walk backwards, i've lost the railroad ! i look left or was it right? I see the way that isn't home and look the opposite direction. I see the bridge and railroad so I begin to walk. It's a long trek home. My flare dies out. The icon that tells me i'm suffering from lack of sleep appears. I march on. I reach a checkpoint, the trees that have been cut for lumber. I see that familiar corpse on the left side of the tracks.I reach the next checkpoint. The derailed carts. I walk around the carts and around the branch that blocks the way. From here on it's a straight path until home. I literally can not tell If i'm moving or not. I can only trust that i am. I march on. Waiting for some sign, for that opening in the mountains to the left that signifies that my cabin is there. I march on. Finally, i see the opening ! i see the black silouhette that resembles a house. I recognize that flag figure flying proudly atop the house. I run towards the house to the side i know the front door is on. I put my face against the side of the house and move left and right searching for the door. Is my face even against the wall or is it on the fence of the front porch?! I don't know, i can not see ! I try the back door which has no fence to protect it. I can't find that one either ! I back off from the house, trying to position myself to where i know the back door is, but i lose the house itself !! I see nothing but blackness. Am i touching the house or is it the mountains behind the house?!? I can not tell.... In time, i'm able to see that familiar silhoutte once more. I reposition myself and check my inventory to see if there's ANYTHING that can light the way... Apparently I left some matches in my backpack !! They must have been too light to throw away ! Thank god I was too lazy to toss them out ! I light a match against the wall of the house and am able to find the back door.... i light another match inside of the cabin so i can locate the stairs.  finally i'm safe at last.... I rest for 6 hours, not wanting to die of thirst or hunger. I wake up well enough to sleep for another 12 hours. Alas, I am home and rested, ready to journey once more...

Early Access Review
								Amazing survival game! Exciting and realistic in its survival mechanics, and I can't get enough of the beautiful art style. The Long Dark is really life-like- like I said, it is realistic. You must survive the wilderness almost like you would in real life: breaking down branches to make tinder for a fire, melt snow for water- but must boil before drinking it to make it safe, gather animal meat for eating and hides/guts for crafting gear, but every hide and gut must be cured indoors for 5 days before you can use them. Then while crafting- it is not instant when you click 'begin crafting' (you have to work on a pair of deerskin boots for 12.5 hours). Right now the sandbox mode is the only one available, which is self-explanatory. Soon to come is the story mode (which, from the latest teaser trailer, looks super exciting) so the game can only get even better from here. If you like survival and/or adventure & exploring games, this game is a must have.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is the Oregon Trail of first person shooters.There's really no other way of describing it.  Though it's not really about getting from one specific place to another, it's about exploring and surviving when the odds are entirely against you.  Hours in you realize so many small choices are life and death: using that cloth to repair your clothing, keeping you warm, or tearing them up for bandages, in case you are attacked.Or staying where you are, which is safe, but your food sources are running out, or hiking through the blizzard down an unknown path hoping to find game, something to eat, or an abandoned house to raid.Even the miniscule amounts of ammunition you can scavenge adds to this:  do you use your last three bullets hoping to take down the wolf at a distance? Or do you get closer, improving your chance to hit, but giving it a chance to charge you?It ook a few hours to fully get the experience, but once I got it, I was hooked.

Early Access Review
								While this game is far from perfect, I have to say it is probably my favorite survival game. You really have to push yourself to find the balance for exploration and hoarding. One of the first things you notice about this game is that it is fantasically, deceptively beautiful. I have lost myself in the art of the game only to find myself wandering off a cliff or into a den of wolves. There are only a few things I have issues with, the main being weapons. This isn't a first person shooter or anything, but one of the only weapons in the game is a hard to find/maintain gun. You can find knives, crowbars, and axes, but cannot use them for defence against wolves. The developers seem to always be updating and improving the game, so this could easily change. Overall, I think this is a fantastic game for casual or intense gamers.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								I wrote my original review (included below) for The Long Dark based on only a couple weeks of play, and so I felt it was a good idea to come back and update this review now that I've spent over 85 hours with this game.In that time, the developers successfully upgraded the engine from Unity 4 to Unity 5 over the course of a few weeks, bringing added multi-core cpu and gpu support and increasing overall performance, therefore increasing the range of computers that can support this game.  In my case, I have been playing exclusively on a custom-built rig with the following specifications:  ▪ AMD K10-8750K ~3.7GHz 4-core + R7 APU ▪ Gigabyte GA-F2A88XM-D3H microATX motherboard▪ Corsair 16GB DDR3-2400 RAM ▪ Crucial MX100 512GB SSD (Windows 7 installed) ▪ Crucial MX100 256GB SSD (Linux installed - at this time The Long Dark is not natively supported in this OS)▪ AOC E2727SHE 27" LCD monitor w/ 1920x1080 resolutionWith the above system I have been able to play The Long Dark using the Ultra graphics setting, and all effects enabled, without any significant performance issues aside from occasional, slight stuttering in certain interior environments that are using special lighting effects.  I also stream the game from this computer via Steam on my late 2006 MacBook Pro over my local network (whenever I don't feel like playing in my office) with no significant performance issues.The first thing that you should bear in mind is that this game gets continuous attention and responsive updates from the development team.  I am confident that Hinterland Games is committed to completing this game and feel that my money was well spent, enough so that I purchased a separate copy for my oldest daughter when she expressed interest in playing.  A big plus is the rapid release of bug fixes following each new release, and special effort is repeatedly made to assist those who have lost their loot in the process of upgrading to the latest version.The Long Dark is very immersive, enough so that I have felt it in my fingers, hands, wrists and arms when the main character sprains an ankle.  This is primarily due to the spectacular voice acting.  Some people may be a little put off by the stylized graphics, but I do not find that they detract from immersion in any significant way.After being punished by my first few tries playing the game in Voyageur mode, I switched to Pilgrim in order to explore the maps and get a feel for how the game should be played.  Upon exploring the majority of the maps (and the new connecting area released since my initial review), I decided that I was no longer being challenged by the game and returned to Voyageur mode, which has since been a constant learning experience.  My longest run so far has been in Voyageur with 41 days completed at the time of this writing.This is a survival game, and as such it approaches survival in a way that (in most cases) makes sense.  Some notable exceptions are the ability to carry a mug of coffee in your backpack without spilling it, the ability to craft a bow and arrows but the inability to fashion a basic spear, and the amount of food that must be consumed each day in order to survive might seem excessive.  These exceptions do not detract from my experience, however, and do not necessarily reflect the final version of the game when it is released.That said, the player is rewarded by finding, repairing and crafting better gear, tools and shelter, all of which dramatically raise his or her chances of survival.  That said, it is still quite possible to make a bad decision that leads to your demise, and therefore every decision should be made with care.The sense of danger that remains prevalent in Voyageur has been more than enough to keep me interested, and even though only Sandbox mode is currently available, the little stories that are created in day to day play are cool enough to share with others later.For example, I discovered that wearing a wolf coat may surprise and frighten off a wolf, but it will come back to attack you when you are not expecting it.  After learning this the hard way (and surviving the event), I unexpectedly came upon another wolf who was frightened off by my sudden appearance.  This time I found a safe place to wait for the wolf to return, and after it failed to reach me, I successfully dispatched it with my rifle.  As I was building a fire in preparation to harvest the wolf's meat and fur, I was surprised by the arrival of a black bear.  I ran back to my safe place and shot it twice, the second time directly between the eyes.  Now I had more than enough food to last me for several days, and also the opportunity to harvest the necessary materials to make a bearskin bedroll, but I had to act quickly before the body began to decompose.If you are at all interested in survival simulations, I cannot recommend The Long Dark strongly enough.ORIGINAL REVIEW:Bearing in mind this game is still in development, I've been hooked for over two weeks and played this to the exclusion of everything else during my spare time.  I like the pace, I like the challenge of surviving the elements, I like the concept of a massive CME knocking out the power worldwide, I like the option to choose a difficulty level without completely eliminating the challenge of the game, and I like the exploration elements involved.  The artistic styling of the renderings is simply gorgeous.The ability to unlock maps by discovering them is a nice touch.  I can't wait to see what the story mode will have to offer when it becomes available.   I hope the devs will make it possible to play either gender in story mode as well as sandbox mode, because the voice acting by Jennifer Hale for this game is superb.

Early Access Review
								The first time I played this I didn't realize you could melt snow to drink and panicked I would die of dehydration so went out in a -45C blizzard and found a can of orange soda. Died of hypothermia.Kel loves orange soda. 10/10Got a LITTLE better and just slogged through surviving for 19 days, my current best. It's not a lot, but I have EXTREMELY bad luck and getting to aim a gun and shoot at the same time when my mouse pad locks up up all the time means wolves keep slaughtering me - that and I always seem to leave my shelters at the worst possible times, y'know, like when I'm starving to death to look for food.Though you can survive without food for a few days, I think the hunger mechanic is a little over the top, I understand all the extra calories you'd burn in such a cold environment and walking on snow and yadayadayda, but it is a little annoying to be starving just hours after polishing off 9kg of deer meat (not all in one go, but tbh I don't think it would've lasted much longer anyway.) This dude must've been in eating competitions and have t-shirts from every steakhouse in the US for how much he needs to eat to stop complaining! Overall I do really love this game, it's interesting and just plain different, the permadeath is an element I love and hate at the same time, but it really does make the game, you HAVE to survive. Sometimes it's luck, where you start out, which caches are open to you, whether you catch any fish during a 5 hour stretch and whether a big bad wolf will flip it's biscuits and attack you three times in a row so every item of your clothing is ripped to shreds and you're out in North Canada wearing, assuringly, nothing. Yeah, I'm sure a lot of you will read this and assume I'm horribly bad at the game and maybe I am, but you gotta try it for yourself and see how well you fair! It's like nothing else and you kinda enjoy being such a horrible masochist to yourself.Good luck out there, it's f***king cold!

Early Access Review
 This game is overwhelming, I don't even know where to begin.  It's brutal, cold, and poetic. The artstyle is perfect for the experience, mostly cold muted tones.With a good pair of headphones, and a decent enough imagination you are absorbed into this vast and quiet world. Without modern technology, you are no longer the top of the food chain, and mother nature is quick to remind you of this with her unrelenting winds and snow. Survive long enough to wonder what the point is, or die early on as one of the countless victims of nature's beautiful wrath.The game mechanics are pretty awesome and detailed. You're walking uphill? You slow down. Downhill? Speed up, but be careful not to slip and hurt yourself. Wind's blowing and your take cover by a big rock, standing on the downwind side? Good job, you're sheltered from the biting wind. Good job indeed because the biting wind is as bad as the biting wolf. If you're survival savy, you might just live past the first month. Or you might just fall into the long dark.The game gets regular updates, mostly small tweaks, but a few big ones here and there. The community is also quite pleasant. It's well worth the $20 for the alpha. If you want it, get it fast before the price goes up :P Love this game, all the ups and down. Be prepared to feel cold though. I have to play it with a blanket on. TLDR; Get the game, you really won't regret it.
