content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								[h]This review is based on Early Access Gameplay. Because of the changing nature of the game, parts of this review are very likely to change.[/h]When you first start the game, you are greeted with a disclaimer:This game starts by greeting you with a disclaimer."The Long Dark is a post-disaster survival simulation. Although we strive to provide an experience steeped in realism, the game is not a replacement for proper wilderness survival training. As the result of the geomagnetic disaster which serves as part of the fictional foundation of the game, we have taken liberties with the potrayal of wildlife behaviour. Hinterland Studio Inc. does not condone the wanton destruction of wildlife."And then you are taken to the main menu, with a delicious quote from one of many inspirational people that set the tone of the game.Since this game is in early access, there are parts of the game that are being worked on or missing entirely. The Story Mode is nothing more than a button at this point on the main menu, which tells you that it will be available upon the game's final release when you click on it.So you're forced to play in the Sandbox.Which I love - because you pick a starting location, and then from there you let your own story unfold.And what is the Long Dark? It is entirely Man vs. Nature. And nature will always win. It's simply a quesiton of how much you can take.Taking place in the Canadian wilderness after a geomagnetic disaster that throws everything out of balance, you find yourself fighting for your life against frigid temperatures, debilitating weather patterns, starvation, fatigue, disease, and wildlife.This game is so spot-on with its survival requirements, that it reminds me of my own small adventures in the area around Lake Pend d'Orielle in Idaho. To combat the dangers of cold (read: exposure), you first need shelter. You start with little more than the clothes on your back and your mostly empty backpack, with a gallon of water and maybe a couple snack bars or a sewing kit to start you on your journey. That hoodie and jacket aren't going to keep you warm in the zero-degree gusts of wind blowing in your face for long. A car is better than being outside, but not by much - you'll be far better off in a house or a mineshaft, but sometimes you will have to make do with the lee of a rock.I so want to continue on with a lecture of what you need to do to survive - but both in this game and real life, it's not just knowing what to do, it's having the tools to prevent whatever might befall you. And that's part of what I love about this game - there's so much that can happen, from eating only half-cooked venison you hunted yourself and getting sick, to falling too far and breaking a leg, to freezing to death in a building that was the only source of shelter but was still far too cold, and you couldn't get that fire going in time. Or, perhaps, a chance encounter with a bear that was going so well - but went south far too fast.And that's the thing. All the dangers in this game are purely what you might face in nature - save, perhaps, getting charged by wolves. There's no special monster, no group of cannibalistic tribesmen, no mechanations out to kill you simply to provide a focal threat. Because nature is fearsome enough.And yet, there's so much to love about nature. The visuals in this game are simplistic on the Unity engine - but it's a distinct, appealing world, desolate but so vibrant all at once. There are crags with frozen rivers that you just can't help but look down; iced-over forests that sparkle in your eye; and vistas provide some amazing views, especially if there's a frozen lake nearby where you can see the ice stretching off to the horizon.And when you find your flow - not if, when - you'll be able to appreciate those beautiful moments more and more, as you find the systems that tax your character's body less obtrusive, less wanting to kill you as you find your own place in this frozen paradise. Your choice whether you wish to keep some of the modern amenities, or go full tribal and make your own clothes from animal hide and fashion "primitive" tools that get the job done just as effectively as the factory-made ones we use today.I enjoy Miasmata, but The Long Dark is the survival game I'll be coming back to again and again five years down the line after I've played through it a dozen times. Especially since the developers keep adding more to the systems of this game, fine-tuning things that are working but need that extra bit of polish, and adding whole new systems that could easily turn the tide for or against you in your next playthrough and make it more interesting. This is easily my favorite singleplayer survival game of all time, and I'd be hard-pressed to find one better.Can't recommend it enough.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								This review is written as of May 10th, 2016. It's my first review.The Long Dark is a single-player survival experience that takes place in a cold wasteland following a "geomagnetic disaster". You're cold and alone, and the game truly captures that. It has fantastic visuals, a lovely soundtrack and ambience that will make you think you're really struggling for life in this doomed world.You scavenge for food, clothing, fuel and hunting gear. You have to pry open lockers and crack open safes for the next meal. If you've run the house dry, you plan your trek to the next one between the snow storms and the migrating wolf packs that are hungry and hostile. If you're out of food, you may have to try to hunt your own, but be careful; the wolves may either take your prey, or choose you for their next meal.The game as it currently stands has an open-world sandbox that will let you choose your own "adventure", of sorts. A story mode is in the works, but by and large, many of the players (myself included) are simply in love with the sandbox mode. I've already spent over 400 hours playing this game before it has even launched. I've definitely gotten my money's worth.I highly recommend this game. The developers appear to be on top of the game, interacting with the community and listening to their feedback, as well as taking care of major issues with hotfixes as soon as possible. I don't think this game will fall by the wayside like so many others have before it.Good luck and, if you buy the game, try not to die!

Early Access Review
								The first time I played this I didn't realize you could melt snow to drink and panicked I would die of dehydration so went out in a -45C blizzard and found a can of orange soda. Died of hypothermia.Kel loves orange soda. 10/10Got a LITTLE better and just slogged through surviving for 19 days, my current best. It's not a lot, but I have EXTREMELY bad luck and getting to aim a gun and shoot at the same time when my mouse pad locks up up all the time means wolves keep slaughtering me - that and I always seem to leave my shelters at the worst possible times, y'know, like when I'm starving to death to look for food.Though you can survive without food for a few days, I think the hunger mechanic is a little over the top, I understand all the extra calories you'd burn in such a cold environment and walking on snow and yadayadayda, but it is a little annoying to be starving just hours after polishing off 9kg of deer meat (not all in one go, but tbh I don't think it would've lasted much longer anyway.) This dude must've been in eating competitions and have t-shirts from every steakhouse in the US for how much he needs to eat to stop complaining! Overall I do really love this game, it's interesting and just plain different, the permadeath is an element I love and hate at the same time, but it really does make the game, you HAVE to survive. Sometimes it's luck, where you start out, which caches are open to you, whether you catch any fish during a 5 hour stretch and whether a big bad wolf will flip it's biscuits and attack you three times in a row so every item of your clothing is ripped to shreds and you're out in North Canada wearing, assuringly, nothing. Yeah, I'm sure a lot of you will read this and assume I'm horribly bad at the game and maybe I am, but you gotta try it for yourself and see how well you fair! It's like nothing else and you kinda enjoy being such a horrible masochist to yourself.Good luck out there, it's f***king cold!

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								I think the complexities of social living in the modern world lead me to find great peace in the simplicity of this game.  You are stranded in the wilderness and are only concerned with survival.  You must find shelter, keep warm, gather food, purify water, avoid hostile wildlife.  There are many ways to do these things, and many challenges that arise organically within the world.  A routine trip through familiar territory can turn deadly if a blizzard strikes, freezing you and closing in your visibility, testing how well you really know the landscape.  You can catch a disease that takes weeks to cure as you struggle to maintain your normal routines with a dramatically weakened body.  A surprise encounter with a bear can leave you critically wounded and desperate while damaging the warm clothing you've come to take for granted.  But all of these obstacles can be overcome, and if feels triumphant to do so.  So often the simple beauty of the game's environment makes you stop and just admire.The upcoming story mode promises to add a whole new dimension to this game, but I can strongly recommend it even without that promise.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Graphics: 7.5Gameplay: 8.5Replayability: 8At first i was unsure of the game and almost refunded the game but after saying screw it I decided to head back in for my 3rd game, the best way to review this game and let you know of some game elements is through my story so far.I woke on a small ice island in the middle of what was once the sea. I looked around looking at the sheer artistic beauty of this Canadian wasteland and saw in the distance a small green hut and ventured forth across the ice to it and upon arrival was met by great luck with a hunting rifle and a bullet being inside this small hut. upon exiting i see a large cabin on top of a large island and move towards it cautiosly, luck doesn't last forever. To my suprise i enter the house with no problems and inside find several days worth of supplies, a lantern, 5 more bullets, some better clothes and some food and drinks. I spent the night in this homely cabin and spent the next day exploring other green ice fishing cabins returning to my house at night. Knowing I would have to leave I cooked my raw food and kept my tinned produce for the days walking.After a short walk collecting a few bits of food and drink from a gas station I venture up a snow track lane and walk off to get to a small ranger station to see my surroundings. I reach the station and look out spotting a new place to discover, but I here footsteps behind me and a bear begins to charge me! I ran from the killer bear and when there is some distance between us I start to fire my gun at it's face striking 4 times before being mauled and thrown about by the bear like Leonardo Di Caprio in the Revenant. After a minute of being maulled in a brutal and beautiful animation i accept my death when the black screen comes only to discover that my clothing may have saved me. I'm bleeding and have just 30 seconds to heal myself. Frantically, through blurred vision, I grab my rifle off the floor and my peaches, the bear just 15 metres away, and sprint to a nearby rock so i can bandage myself. A moments respite.The bear begins charging again and I sprint down some rocks spraining my ankle, thankfully I see a trailer to dive into for safety the bear right behind me. I get in and rest for a few hours to heal. Upon leaving the trailer I begin to celebrate, my fight with the bear was won! The bear led on the ground dead from blood loss and i begin my newest chapter. A day later a wolf attempts to attack me but i quickly light a flare and throw it at the wolf scaring it, feeling like Liam Neeson I Crouch down and put a bullet in the wolf's face. The same evening another experience with a bear went much better the last of my bullets in the bear I run into a building and sleep.Day 10 now I have become a survivor and I now wear the pelts of the bears as my clothing.

								Survival diaryDay 1Always thought I will end up surviving zombie apocalypse, but Mother Nature used a plain old herself on humanity, and now we're in a constant winter state. Hoped to escape somewhere on ecvator... Joke on me; thanks to that storm my plane crashed in Canada! Of all places... I scraped all I can from crash site (wasn't much, but at least I have some food, water and a badroll). Hell it freezing! I was outside for only 3 hours and already can't feel my hands, no shelter either, only trees and snow. Here's an idea: Instead of wasting time writing down this useless diary, I should just harvest some of those sticks and try to start a fire.♥♥♥♥ you nature! Three attempts to lite a decent fire and all failed... I am going to die here! Frozen to death...Now that was unexpected; When all hope was lost, I found this nice lil lighthouse. it's so warm inside. I also found food, better clothing and to me luck -- a bow and two arrows. On my way here I saw some deers and rabbits, might go hunting. It's not like I can survive on crackers and soda alone.Day 2Night was quite. Unlike day that met me with ravaging storm! But storm or no storm, I need food, after moring meal I only left with two granola bars... Still have enough water though (not a big problem actually since I can simply melt snow, and in case of lacking water purification tablets -- just boil water on a same fire).Ha-ha! Tremble in a presence of mighty hunter -- me! I shot two deers; Meat, guts and hide... Now if only I had a workbench here, could've craft a decent pants and maybe a fishing rod. But hey, at least I won't go hungry today. The cold was a big problem however. It's warm inside, but I better make sure I have enough fuel to keep stove going for a while.Day 3♥♥♥♥ me running! I heard wolfes howling and walking outside this night. Everyone are hungry nowdays, so I better make sure to be extra carefull.Nothing much happened today; found some mushrooms, shot a rabbit, gathered some sticks. You know dear diary -- I think tommorow I will go exploring nearby territories. Maybe there are other survivors, or at least abandond village somewhere. Day 4Exploration ho! I have bow, supplies, sticks and lantern -- nothing can stop me.Nothing but freaking blizzard! Can't see♥♥♥♥♥♥outhere. So I took an advantage of my skills, build a sick snowcover and made a fire. Think I heard wolves outthere... but it maybe just my imagination and it's simply wind.Ow-ow-ow-oweee! No it was not ♥♥♥♥ing wind, those were ♥♥♥♥ing wolfes! A whole bloody pack of critters. Managed to kill two and scare the rest, but one took a bite out of my hand. It hurts badly. And I don't have propper medcine to treat bites.Day 5I thought, I was going to die, but it seems luck again at my side -- found a gas station with workbench, first aid kit and a nice stack of food, broke down some boxes and chairs into wood, and even found crowbar and saw. I moved my body all day, stoping a few times to take a quick bite out of beef jerky, refill myself with water and warm up (I am getting quite good at making fires outside). Still no signs of any other living humans or any large cities or vilalges. Screw you Canada, you suck. I actually found some humans, hardly alive -- most were froze to death, but at least two looked like they were kileld by IDK wolfes? Posted: November 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								CHECK OUT THE WHOLE REVIEW AT ETHNOGRAPHIX: https://ethnographix.squarespace.com/ "Extinction is the rule. Survival is the exception"  - Carl Sagan I was raised in Alaska so, not at all ignoring my own subjectivity, I'm just going to say that this is one of the best survival-genre titles out there. Even from the early access days of The Long Dark, I could tell, based on the awesome attention to detail in the quasi cell shaded yet realistic portrayal of bit-like pixels, that this game was in a league all its own. Erie, quiet, and insightful; these quotes are the first and last bit of civilization you'll encounter that isn't a frozen corpse for the entire game. Your life will consist of three essential goals at all times:Stay rested, warm, and fed. Your chief adversary, like in the real wilderness of the Great North, is Old Man Winter himself. A tireless and incremental devil who will constantly whittle away at your desire to continue forth; lulling you into a cold yet eerily peaceful death. Crafting, hunting, trap laying, and scavenging. It's all here. The game consists of a number of "levels" that are teeming with wildlife both apex and otherwise that will keep your head on a swivel as you search for firewood you can gather or breakdown from chairs, boxes, and the like. If there's an idea you've had for a harsh winter survival title, The Long Dark has likely done it. You need to play The Long Dark just to see how immersive and harrowing it is to believe for yourself.So huddle close inside the abandoned car you found alongside the desolate highway of a frozen lake as the wolves circle nearby. Let the The Long Dark take you to the edge of Humanity before the inevitability of death wraps its cold fingers around you. CHECK OUT THE WHOLE REVIEW AT ETHNOGRAPHIX: https://ethnographix.squarespace.com/

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								So this game is pretty cool, pun intended. great concept for a game, I’m a 44-day survivor so far. I have almost died 4 times, 2 by bear mauling’s, freezing, and falling off a cliff. There are a few things I would like in the game, as I am from Montana and know a thing or two about winter and extended camping. 1. the ability to make jerky or pemmican so all the meat I get doesn't go to waste. 2. the ability to make a sled to haul things, i.e. wood, dead animals. so I don't have to harvest where it died...like real life. the ability to move the stoves you find in fishing huts to cabins or the fire barrels to better locations that make more sense. (you want to warm a small room vs a giant dam for example) Oh and some of the tasks take WAY too long.  even ones you think are ok I find annoying. 5 min to break down a branch into 3 sticks?? I can do the same task in about 10-15 seconds real world without a tool. 27 min to tear up a cardboard box?? really?? 1-2 min tops, with my hands, and more moveable/harvestable objects. I also think you get tired a bit to quickly...even when you do nothing but read them books you find. should have a better fatigue meter vs being actually tired. If a football player runs 100 yards he should not need to sleep for 3-4 hours to be rested again, it’s just fatigue. Also, why are we limited in rifle to an old .303 British rifle. the Canadians have better technology than that. bring in a .444 Marlin for them bears...heck even an old Winchester .22 long rifle would be sweet for the rabbits. maybe a pistol of some sorts....357 or a .44 mag. As far as the skills that get better with use. surprised there is a rifle skill but no bow skill. and how about Endurance? If I have to carry 50-60 lbs. on my back and person all the time I am going to get stronger and such. the Mountain men of old used to carry 100lbs of gear on them without breaking a sweat. strong as an ox and tough as a honey badger. With all this said, I am still enjoying the game

Early Access Review
								What's to like about something that puts you deep into a sense of discomfort? It's lonely, barren and relentlessly cold. I've literally had to put a cardigan on, so well does this game depict the harsh brutality of an arctic winter. As far as sandbox survival games go, this one is one of the best so far. Perhaps it's the simplicity or the sheer level of difficuty. Regardless, I've started the game multiple times, each time trying different tacticts but I keep failing. It's not so heartless that it doesn't give you a glaring reason why you failed. So we keep retrying. For those who've played The Forest, imagine a similar experience but without the ridiculous bugs. Which brings me neatly onto the standard of this game which is essentially an early access title. It's polished already and I've not been privy to any bugs at all. There's just some limited content, but otherwise this is a fantastic title with a bright future. Thoroughly recommended.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								I teach a survival simulation course to children and adults.I work at a camp where we have a variety of programs that we offer to grade-schoolers who come and take field trips at our site. Among the fun ones like "Log-cabin Building" and "Pioneer Cooking" is "Survival Simulation". What does that look like? Very similar to this game. We are open in the spring and the fall and are in the northern United States and often find ourselves doing this in the snow. As a matter of fact, on first looking at it, I was convinced that some items had been taken from my manual. But that was silly. Smart survivalists all say the same basic things.Before I take the children out, I give them a quick lesson on all the things they will experience in the simulation. How to find water, how to find or create tinder, kindling and fuel for a fire, what a fire needs to live, what we need to live, how to build a lean-to, how to find what direction the wind is coming from, how to build an S.O.S. signal and how to create a splint, stop blood loss and treat shock. Pretty rushed though, but that's OK because we are going outside and going to practice everything that I just showed them.So, at our camp, we have "The plane crash" in a wilderness area (no houses around sorry) and the burning wreckage is going so hot and heavy that the survivors only have time to grab five items out of a long list of things that was on the plane. We are looking basically for them to chose: Matches, Knife, Metal bucket, Rope, Tarp and not choose things like: Flashlight, Popcorn, Toilet paper, and the like. They only have a few minutes before the plane catches all the way, and then sinks into the bog.The main good news during my Survival Sim is that there are no wolves. Not real ones at least. The pretend ones come later. We do, however, put them to the test. There are around ten children usually and they are given fifty "Life Points" per group, each child accounting for five of those points. I will give them twenty minutes to find water, get a fire going and bring their water to a boil. Fire accounts for: Light, Heat, Ability to melt and boil water, Ability to cook food, Safety, Ability to dry wet clothes, and most importantly: Hope.If they fail at the first task the rest are ultimately harder. And I take away half of their Life Points. Then I have them search for food, erect a shelter, someone "has an accident" and breaks their leg and bleeds everywhere and goes into shock, and then I have them build and S.O.S. and get into the shelter before the wolves come.Usually around half of the children die. But we go inside out of the snow and discuss what happened and they write down the things they did that were successful and the things that were not.All of that prepared me for The Long Dark. In the game, I found myself learning new and inventive strategies that I did not know I was able to invent. I felt as if I were a child and the game makers were myself, being patient and ever so helpful. Wait. No. There was no help. Only the savage fangs of the wolves. And the snow. The long dark? The long snow-blind, wolf-infested, frozen-soul dark. Dark and dirty... And damn cold.My first experience with this game was my wife screaming from the other room. "Oh my gosh honey! This is totally you!" she went on and on. She was so happy to have found something that looked like I would play it over and over. That was two weeks ago. It was to be my Christmas present... Heh. I've been enjoying it a little early.Enjoying it? Obsessing over it? Living it? I caught myself looking up dog-food prices the other day. On the top of my review, it shows how many hours I have played of this game. Does it really reflect the thirty hours I've spent scouring maps and watching youtube videos? No. You ♥♥♥♥♥rdly hour-counter. How dare you scoff at my lack of total commitment! I love this game and have recently purchased it for my brother and one of my closest friends.Do I recommend this game? Yes. Only if you want to live.

Early Access Review
								I have only played 5 and a half hours.This game is an 'Early Access' title.It is visually gorgeous, and far more solid than you are expecting.Let me quickly relate two memorable experiences to you, in the hope you may find they strike a chord with your tastes......I knelt, freezing, behind a tree beside a lake. I knew I was harming my health. And I also knew the longer I crouched there, the shorter my life would ultimately be. I was starving. I was desperate.But the black ghost out on the ice, the shapeless tear in the pristine white and powder blue world, crippled me with fear.The wolf stalked back and forth, paralysing me into a kind of suicide. I needed to raid the ice fishing huts. But I just hid there, enslaved to dread.More than the cold and the starvation, the wolf robbed me of the only fuel I had.It tore my hope from me......I found the corpse at the top of the stairs, slumped with it's head against it's knees. It wasn't the first body I'd found. The wilderness was dotted with half-buried cadavers, partially covered by the scouring blizzards, as if mother nature herself was trying to offer them a small shard of dignity. None of them really spoke to me of anything other than failed last attempts at survival. The need to keep walking. The hope of discovery.But the corpse at the top of the stairs....Why? There was a small amount of food present. There was fuel present. There was a bed, so even death needn't have been so vulgar for him. But...why? He had more time, all he had to do was reach out and grab it.But therein was the answer.He chose to surrender. Hopelessness overcame him. Who knows what memories of family life haunted him? Who can say what grief brought him to his knees and slowed him to a crawl? What bleak misery shrouded his soul as he lowered himself to the ground, closing his eyes for the last time?But I do not know how to feel about this.Do I curse his weakness as I struggle on, lauding the bravery of the ones sealed in the snow face-down like silent witnesses, turning their backs forever on a scene too horrible to contemplate?Or do I honour the bravery of his conclusion, his stark realisation that there is no tomorrow in this dead world, there is no tearful reunion, there is no bright safe dawn?I found the corpse at the top of the stairs.And I also found endless questions in my own soul......Please support the developers by purchasing this game.Thank you for reading.

Early Access Review
								This is a fantastic game, and even unfinished, it's well worth your money.  I'm really looking forward to the story mode and more maps, but wandering around figuring how to get from one area to the next just scavenging is a thrilling challenge.  It's already good enough as is to warrant a purchase, everything else the developer is putting out may as well be just some neat extra perks.I have yet to find a gun and can barely defend myself when attacked, and the stress of seeing a wolf off in the distance near a building you need to get into is nothing compared to the paranoia of losing track of it in some nearby woods and then hearing a low growl behind you.  The survival aspects of the game are very simple to manage, just temperature, fatigue, hunger and thirst.  My biggest criticism is the hands off approach with things like foraging for materials.  You go into a menu, set what you want to do, the screen fades out, some time passes in game and you're done.  I'd like it if there was more effort required on the part of the player.  Like if you needed firewood, you had to take your axe, go up to a tree and interact with it to chop it down.  As is the game is somewhat exploitable, since you can go out the door of a chosen shelter, not take a single step, open the menu to harvest firewood, turn around, walk back inside and suffer absolutely no danger from the environment or the elements, which is counter to the whole point of the game.Besides that minor gripe, The Long Dark is shaping up great, and I look forward to continue surviving.

Early Access Review
								If you spend very much time on Steam, you will see a LOT of early access games in the store. Unfortunately, most early access games have been long forgotten by the developers and in turn, the players lose their interest in the game. The game never releases, then becomes stuck in an early access purgatory while the players weep in sorrow and the devs get same sex lapdances in dark, diesease ridden taverns, enjoying their stolen fortune. But the developers of The Long Dark care for their game, and keep their goal fresh in their minds. They sincerely want to release their completed game in full quality.I started playing The Long Dark in hopes it would be entertaining enough for me to not lose interest within the first minutes, and I have to say, it was very enjoyable. I dont want to spoil much about the game, but it is a constant fight for survival against many different dangers. the world is filled with tons of places to explore-buildings, trappers shacks, abandont towns, caves, forests and bunkers. You must eat and drink to stay alive, all the while you also have to be wary of the weather and evil creatures that lurk in the wilderness. I call the creatures evil, because they usually attack on sight. Most people complain about this in their reviews, claiming things in the game to be unrealistic. Thats true, wolves dont generally attack without reason, and people usually dont get hungry 2 hrs after eating a 3 pound trout, But isnt this why we all play video games? To escape reality? Its why I do at least. Please try the game. If hardcore survival isnt your thing, you can play it on peaceful mode, where animals dont even attack you. Its lovely.

Early Access Review
								DISCLAIMER: I REVIEWED THIS GAME WHILE IT WAS IN EARLY ACCESS (it still is), SO THE GAME ISN'T FINISHED YET. There's something about The Long Dark that makes me love it. I don't know if it's the graphics, the gameplay mechanics, or even the survival experience of it all. The graphics have a calm feeling to them, and they're beautiful. When you die, you have to restart the entire game, which is great. You can be a boy or a girl, and you get to pick one of two maps. There are three different survival experiences you can choose from. One is based on survival, and the other is based on exploration. The third option is a mix of the two. You will get eaten by wolves a lot, but that just makes it more fun. This game is true survival in the Canadian wilderness. If you drink unpurified water (yes, you can drink toilet water in the game) then you can get sick. You can also get sick from raw meat, or getting bitten by a wolf. Then, you have to have the right supplies such as bandages and pain killers. The game has a nice crafting element in it as well, which adds to the survival experience. If you're buying this game thinking you'll get something like Rust or Minecraft, you're wrong. This is a unique game, and I can't think of a single other game like it. This is one of my favorite games ever, and I highly reccomend it.10/10 Stars

A Year Later in ReviewThis game has grown so much in the last year that it is almost hard to believe it is the same game. I don't speak for it in terms of graphics, it remains to be stlylistic and purposeful in that realm in which I love; but I mean mechanically, the UI, the intenisity, the realism. It no longer feels like a narrative in which I had to craft in my own head as I struggled across these limited maps--it now feels like a world, a whole world of explorable territory in desolation and meager tugs of inspiration. A year has passed and I only recommend this game even stronger. I can not wait for it to be officially released.November 2014 ReviewThis is a breath of survival game fresh air. The art style is pretty great and the loneliness, the atmosphere, the choices for time management in order to survive that pressure you--these are all the things that make simplicity great. I hope it continues down the hyper-realism route. I put a few hours into it and saw everything it has to offer AND enjoyed it. I am only recommending this game for as long as the Devs continue to develop! I am often wary of dropping dimes on early access games. And it takes place in Canada, ey?Play this game and survive long enough. It only takes one stupid mistake. For example:I had found the best cabin ever, it was stocked full of everything I needed, but I needed to eat and drink. I had gotten a bunch of deer and wolf meat. I cooked all of it, but one (ran out of fire).I quickly opened my inventory and twitch clicked to my pile of meat... I had eaten the ONLY uncooked one.My face turned white as it filled with idiocy and immediate regret.I got food poisoning. I had nothing I could do. I tried everything. As the night became day and having tried sleeping it off, I decided to accept my fate and ran outside to find a wolf to fight it to the death. It killed me, but I had the last laugh, because now that wolf had food poisoning as it ate my flesh. hahaha.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								I enjoy this game very much, but i must say, if you don't play on easy, this game is gritty and challenging and instills real instinctual fear into you, something most games lack. The overall graphical design is beautiful in my opinion. The devs knew they couldn't make everything hyper-realistic, so they went for a cartoon-like design, which, you don't really notice unless you pay close attention to things.   There are some flaws to the game, mine being that you can't improvise weapons, i.e. swing your hatchet at a wolf unless it is already on top of you, and you can't hunt anything until you find a rifle or craft a bow, you can snare rabbits but i haven't bothered with that. I often find myself complaining about how often i feel fatigued so quickly and how a couple hours can't do much to restore yourself in the long run. But i then think that these factors that make me (irl) able to operate on 5 hours of sleep, couldn't be possible in a survival situation, let alone subzero temperatures.   But my favorite aspect of the game is the weight and pressure of risk that goes into nearly every decision you make. Such as, you may plan to go out and get firewood the next day, but tommorrow comes and a blizzard rolls in, and you know that if you dont get firewood you could freeze to death or dehydrate. I once choose to go out and gather a couple logs just to last me, and what seemed like 30 meters away from my home felt like a vast tundra. The weather can make it impossible to see, you can get lost, and wander into a wolf, and what was planned to be a simple run for wood, turns into a nightmare. Starvation leads to some pretty tough risks too. You may decide to go out to fish, and then get snowed in a fishing hut, with no wood and you freeze. Or you may take the chance of attacking a wolf in order to take its fresh deer kill, or even try to kill the wolf.   Every action has consequences, and those consequences can instill legitimate fear into you. But it is nonetheless beautiful and stunning and it brings you somewhat closer to mother nature, despite her relentless effort to kill you. It's gritty and real and I highly recommend it.

								I shimmy up a rope, wind beating me into the rock face. A blizzard of huge proportions surrounds me. As I walk away from the recently-climbed rope, I gather sticks and things to burn. I find the tail section of a cargo plane, or an airliner, and I start a meager fire. I know this fire will only last for a pitiful 30 minutes before the blizzard's harsh cold consumes it. I boil a cup of coffee, leaving the fire with 7 minutes.As it crackles away, I drink the coffee, and await death, but then... The storm clears, and I'm on a panoramic summit of a large mountain, I can see the wings and engines of the same plane scattered across the land, a wolf chases a deer in the distance. I see a case with a flare gun in it, I take the flare gun, load a flare into it, and fire it, hoping for a rescue.This was only my most recent experience in The Long Dark. It's a very cozy, very immersive game, and survival only adds to the feeling of 'being there.' Buy this game as soon as you can, it will change you.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is a very niche game. So before buying it, you should ask yourself: "Just what kind of game do I want to play?". As someone who thoroughly enjoys survival games, and had become rather good at staying alive (at least most of the time), The Long Dark provides new challenges, and a new atmosphere. To me, there are key points to consider when you are contemplating getting The Long Dark. These are the sense of realism, the atmosphere, the art style (for those of you who care about that), and, of course, the challenge.Realism: As far as games go, TLD is very, very realistic. So much so that it can be a double edged sword. Perhaps the main goal of the game is to keep your calories up, while avoiding death via cold, wolves, or even bears. Or falling off of cliffs. As far as food consumption goes, the game is about accurate. You need to consume roughly 2000 or so calories per day to stay healthy. I am currently in a trapper's cabin leaving snares out for rabbits, because I used all of my ammo for my rifle, and lost my only arrows for my bow. The constant need for food is a pressing matter, and realistically done. The same applies to the cold. The cold itself will make you cold if you're unprepared (not wearing adequate clothing), but the wind will expedite the process. What was interesting to me, is that I found that by standing by a wall of other surface while the wind was blowing (on the other side), it actually created a wind shield. This can become very important for when you need to build a fire. You can't do so in the middle of a gale of wind. The realism as far as mechanics go is really solid. However, then there is the other side of it. Playing TLD is not a rapid paced game most of the time. You often choose to walk to avoid burning necessary calories, you will often have to stop traveling and find shelter when a blizzard comes in, and avoiding the hostile wildlife is often better than fighting, as things can go wrong really fast. What you end up with, is a very realistic experience. This is a battle against the elements, not tangible foes. As such, the game can sometimes feel like work. It can feel slow and lonely. You have to be ENTIRELY self-driven. If you are the type of person that likes this level of realism (like me), then you will likely enjoy this aspect of the game. If you are the type of person that prefers faster paced games, then TLD may not be your cup of tea.Atmosphere: The atmosphere of TLD is phenomenal. From the sound of the wind, to the voice actor's brilliant work, to the gradual lighting of a sunrise or sunset, TLD have a fantastic atmosphere. I first really noticed during a blizzard in the game. I had gone inside of a camp ground cabin to avoid the cold. As I stood there, I could hear the wind raging outside, the house creaking under the wind, and my character's labored breathing (I had sprinted to the cabin). The general lack of background noise is often a boon as well. It is just you, surviving-not thriving, but surviving-in the middle of nature. When the background music occasionally surfaces, it only adds to the feeling of cold and isolation. The atmosphere is a strongpoint for TLD.Art Style: TLD uses a paint-esc art style (I'm not sure what you would name it). It is consistent, and achieves a good effect. Rather than focus on core realism, the art style comes across as realistic, without having to be as graphically intense. If you truly care about the art style though, watch a video rather than read a review :PChallenge: The challenge is always there in TLD. Whether it's food, warmth, or safety, you will unlikely become a Fat-cat while surviving. Thanks to a sort of leveling system for various skills, such as fire-starting of carcass harvesting, your character will gradually get better at survival skills. This is a boon. There is also a wound and sickness system to watch out for, and bleeding to death or getting mauled by a wolf sucks. My one complaint, however, lies with the perishability of food and items. Things spoil in TLD. This normally wouldn't be an issue. However, when you pick up matches, canned food, or even a freaking sardine can, you would expect those to last for a dang good long while. Instead, as if your character has some kind of entropic aura, everything you touch (aside from tools) gradually goes bad. I found this out when I examined my canned food stockpile and it was all going close to rancid. Even lighter fluid goes bad. You can maintain certain tools, light a lantern, a hatchet, a gun, etc. But your means of doing so are limited, and I am sure that once my magnifying glass, fire striker, and matches go bad (because in this game a magnifying glass breaks via using it), I will end up shivering in a shack and eating raw rabbit meat, as I fist fight wolves for the rabbit's intestines. It's not a pretty picture.All in all, The Long Dark is a fantastic survival experience that I would strongly recommend. If you are willing to overlook the attrition rate of items, it will make for a wonderfully good time.Pros: - Great atmosphere - Very realistic - ChallengingCons: - Things spoil that shouldn't (at least not as quickly as they do) - There is not yet any true long-term sustainability (as far as I am aware)I would give it a 9.5/10

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is an interesting one. Despite the plethora of first person survival games on Steam, and everywhere else to be honest, this game changes the formula. While most games might have a focus on crafting and an overall threat of zombies and alike, this game takes the divergent path. The crafting system is somewhat muted and can be played entirely without, and the only real threat is the elements. While there are prowling bears and stalking wolves among the vast frozen wastelands, they are easily scared off with a flare or a torch, or even a gun. The real enemy is nature itself, as the player is made to survive the cold, harsh winds, freak blizzards and minimal shelter. The gameplay essentially breaks down to traversing the areas looking for shelter, food, water, and other essentials in order to keep death away for another day. The tricky part about this is that in each area the food and water are minmal enough to make it so players feel the need to move on in order to survive. While one can subsist on melted snow and the animals of the area, eventually either boredom or lack of rescources will cause the player to move on. This is where I find the one real problem I have with the game. Because of the need for exploration, I found myself often moving through areas quickly in order to find more useful materials. This is good for the first few hours because I was always seeing something new. Then I died, and respawned. The problem now was I had to traverse the same landscape I had. This wasn't a major problem because the game is well varied in each area. There was certainly never a moment where I could become complacent, because the game doesn't let you. The moment you think you have the game down, it decides to rain the all singing all dancing♥♥♥♥♥♥show of this games brutality upon you. Allow me to demonstrate: I was backed into a corner with a flare in front of me and a rifle in my hand, two bullets to my name. There were, conveniently, two wolves ahead of me. The ultimate gaming challenge of "but I might need it later" was on my mind so I hadn't fired. Then my flare died, and the wolves began inching towards me. As I fired my first shot, the other wolf broke into a sprint. I fired again and missed. Now I was fighting off a wolf with my knife and barely got it off me in time to survive. I then walked back to my cabin with a scrap of clothing still intact and blurred vision, staggering through the snow. About half a mile later I collapsed, and faded into "the long dark". This game is wonderful. The graphic style hides the low budget well and the sandbox nature meant I never felt I was retreading the same path. The surprising depth of this game kept me pushing forward, and so I would give this game a 9/10.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								Review: Play the hardest mode on your first run (just what I did) to get an idea of how brutal this game is. I survived for under 3 minutes and then got mauled by a wolf. This game is also the most realistic survival game out there that I could find believe it or not. No base building, no no no, you gotta make-do with the crap that's already there. It is an amazing experience too.My story/experience with the game: On the hardest difficulty, I got to a point where i was missing two things. Food and heat. I needed tinder, but going outside to retrieve some was suicide. I'd get frostbite and die, probably not even returning with proper tinder, as it wasn't too common where i was sheltered at. I also needed food, but i had to go outside for that too. I was too cold to risk finding another settlement in an attempt to find nourishment there (which may not even be there anyways). I finally got to the point where I couldn't wait any longer, and ventured outside. About a minute after attempting to gather tinder (and failing) I saw a deer get murdered by a wolf. I slowly crawled up the slope it had been slain on and the wolf was gnawing on the carcass. I waited around ten minutes for the thing to mosey off, but it didn't. So i lit my only flare and tossed it at the beast. It ran and I went to grab some meat off the carcass, which would've taken around an hour. I tried to light a fire, but alas, still missing the materials to do such. So I simply took the risk and began harvesting meat. I stopped in the middle of it because I had just realized if I kept going I would freeze to death. I don't know how long I was going at it, but when I stood up I swear I couldn't even feel my legs. I saw my shelter and began to stumble down the hill towards it. It was about 75 feet away, but it felt like a kilometer having to drag myself to it. I kept stumbling backwards, left and right and falling over uncontrollably. By the time I made it to the door I couldn't feel anything, yet I knew it was all over. I knew my time was coming very soon. I got up to open the door, but stumbled backwards, fell over to my right, and struggled to even grip the knob correctly before getting in, taking another minute away from my shortened time left. I finally got in, pulled out my lantern, and set it up on a bench in hopes that it would warm the room enough to help me recover. I struggled to reach the fireplace, and opened it. I was going to attempt to start a fire, but then i remembered I had no tinder. I scrambled around for one last option, and finally thought to make a torch. I struggled to piece it together, but once I did, I squatted in a corner and hoped that the lord would help me or a miracle would happen, because I didn't think much else could save me now. I still kept getting colder and colder, and at that moment I thought "No, this can't be the end, I can't die in the middle of nowhere in some cabin! I need to find help and I need to get back home! What about my family?? I've got to do something!!!" and something I did. I threw myself around the tiny shack furiously, in a fit of rage and in hopes of generating some warmth. I thrashed around inside the building for like fifteen (realtime) minutes, before the world began to start fading in and out of darkness. I finally calmed down, got back into my corner, and looked around the room. I didn't think much. The only thing I could do at that point was reflect on my life. I shed a tear (an actual tear) as I thought about all of the things I could of done better. I regretted so much. I wished I would've paid more attention to my children, wished I would've respected them more, and most of all, wished I would've been able to give a final "goodbye"...The light of the room slowly faded into darkness, and the only thing I could see for a solid thirty seconds was the fire emitting from my torch. Everything became calm, and I started to feel peace flushing through my veins. I stared at the fire...It was...pretty...the light guided me....and I couldn't look away...."You faded into the long dark..."9/10 would die tragically in the wilderness and shed man-tears again.

								At this point I'm just going to paste a response I wrote to why someone should get this game versus another game I won't mention. I just left in the part talking about this game so far.The Long Dark - Hell of a fun game right from the start...graphics are different that what most of us are used to...but I like them; they seem to work with the feel of the game very well. This game is much bigger than I first thought after playing for a few days. There are several zones... there is a wiki about them somewhere...ought to have a look... plus maps online. The concept is excellent and it delivers and you learn that more and more as the game continues...with weight of objects playing a real role, temperature playing a real role, item durability playing a real role, needing to eat and drink cooked and fresh food and water very important. I could go on and on about the good things they have done in this game. The modes are great...just want to explore and not get attacked by wildlife? There is a mode for that. You also need to be careful how you travel you can sprain your ankle, wrist, break something or just flat out die if you don't travel right. Lucky for players there are bandages, antibiotocs, and antiseptics.....bad enough injury...you will also need to sleep...very cool.A ton of detail to player experience...very impressive. My one ♥♥♥♥♥? You can't save games incase you screw up....I've never been a fan of that...you die...you lose it all and start over. Took me two days to come back because I was so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off when I found out. I hate that mechanic and think even a 'noob' mode ought to be made with saves or maybe if you fall and break a leg you always walk slower, maybe if you get too cold you wake up with a lung problem that causes you to get winded faster...etc... until you essentially can't play anymore because your character can't do much... I don't know I think that would be more fun than....start over after a ton of hours of collecting only to fall 10 feet to your death....in the snow...anyway..Yeah, it's a great game besides the perma death thing being crammed down your throat...in every game I've played like that I've never played again after my first death...except this one. That says something about this game. It is an exceptional game imo at this point...and with the detail to which the devs have paid attention to the game I only expect it to get better.---- I will add....best value for the dollar I've had in a long time...got it on sale a while back for around $10 I think... easily worth full price imo.

Early Access Review
								I've got 13 hours.In those 13 hours, I have to keep warm, fill my belly with enough nutrition, avoid the wild beasts, and work on my equipment.Oh, what's this? Someone left a rifle bullet! "That will come in handy!"Damn! A blizzard just started! No way can I go outside, not in my torn jeans and skiing jacket... If only I remembered where I shot the wolf yesterday... But the wind was blowing and I ran towards my safehouse... Once the storm passes, I really have to find the wolf carcass, get its hide and try to make a coat from it.Damn, only 8 hours of daylight left, and I still haven't eaten anything today...=========================The Long Dark is a very stable game, no crashes or graphical glitches whatsoever. The number of locations is solid and offers 100+ hours of exploratory fun.  Locations are plastically hand-crafted and filled with useful landmarks - you will get lost from time to time, but after a while, you'll remember the easy to miss path that begins directly behind the fallen tree, or the two collided cars.For hard-core challenge, try to make your own maps based on landmarks; otherwise, download the detailed maps available in the Guides portion of Steam community hub.There's a reasonable variety of plants and wild-life: cat-tails, mushrooms, rose-hips, trouts, bass, rabbits, deers, wolves and bears.The animals act in a way that differs from real-life, which is explained by the game lore. Depending on your difficulty level, you can either walk carelessly among the animals, or you need to be very careful, maintain a supply of torches and practice your hunting skills.An important component of this game is the crafting of equipment and clothing; this part is still being overhauled [early access], and new "recipes" are being added.My first character survived for 94 days before tragically dying, during which time he suffered repeat injuries, got mauled by 4 different bears, fell into water, got food poisoning... ... but at the same time managed to visit all the iconic locations, locate all parts of the crashed airplane, make a complete set of animal hide clothing and an animal bedroll, and had over 100 kilograms of cooked meat stashed around the world at key safehouses for repeat visits. It was a satisfying struggle for survival.Highly recommended!

With a unique setting that forces the player to be constantly planning ahead, you're very rarely on easy ground. Even something as simple as trying to get firewood needs to be thought through, with exposure to the harsh sub-arctic elements being a constant drain on your abilities, not helped by the near constant presence of wolves. While this becomes less of a factor later on, as the difficulty plateaus and players become complacent in their means and abilities (a problem with open-world survival games as a genre), the presence of permadeath and the ease that one mistakes slides into many mistakes can keep players on their toes even as their time in the sandbox enters in-game weeks. The tense and desolate atmosphere helps accomplish this as well, with a mostly silent soundtrack that focuses more on the sounds of the world around you. Borrowing from games such as Minecraft, the music kicks in at random and for short bursts, which can accentuate an otherwise normal in-game moment. When the ambience isn't being drowned out by the sounds of a crackling campfire or the harsh winds of a blizzard, it helps ground the player as a solitary figure inside of a vast landscape. basically it's a very neat experience and while it's very much a Survival Game, it manages to nail the atmosphere and setting in a way that sets it apart from the crowd. combined with gameplay mechanics that work semi-realisticly (it's still very gamey, what ya gonna do) and maintain an appropriate level of stress on your resources, it takes the Survival genre places I'm surprised nobody had executed this well before.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a really interesting game, with hardcore survival mechanics that work extremely well. This is probably the best survival game since the likes of The Unreal World and Deus. And no zombies! (although someone will probably mod them in at some point) Be warned though that at this stage of the Alpha, the game is almost unplayably difficult. If you do buy the game at this stage, be warned that you will die a lot, and very quickly. The gamemap is sparse - I've died several times simply because I couldn't find any shelter or resources. It also needs plenty of balancing, crafting options, and even things like a map before it will be more playable. The core mechanics are sound however, and I'm looking forward to seeing how this game develops.Edit: I had decided to explore, looking for a gun, or another source of food. I'd ransacked the cabins on the lake, and my supplies were low. I was in a small clearing late in the afternoon when the wind picked up. Fast. I was cold, tired, hungry. Unable to move fast, the sun was setting, and it was getting colder. I marched through the snow, desperately looking for shelter. The only thing available was a small shack, mostly destroyd, only two walls standing, with a pot bellied stove in the surviving corner. It would have to do. I spent the next few hours scavaging wood from the structure to feed the fire, and trying to get some rest, desperately huddled in the corner with  the slight warmth barely enough to stay alive. Finally I decided to risk it - the storm wasn't breaking, and I couldn't find any more wood for the fire. I packed up, and went out into the storm. It was a long trek, I wasn't sure of the direction in the dark, I had to find real shelter. Finally, luckily I found my way back to something I recognised - a clearing that looked familiar. Hope rising, I followed it back, and sure enough, the camp cabin appeared out of the darkness. I had survived another night. Emergent gameplay ftw.After a few hours of playing, I've got to say I'm more and more impressed. The lack of a map - something I thought was a huge flaw is actually a big plus: This is the first time in a long time I've actually had to learn a map, rather than just glance at a minimap, or a little arrow on the screen pointing me where to go. It's extremely satisfying, and a cool throwback to games like Morrowind. I hope that when a map is implemented it doesn't have the 'You are here' icon most games have now. The game is not actually as difficult as I first thought - just has a steep learning curve, and, as said before, is unforgiving to mistakes. Just remember that the biggest killer is the cold - you can survive hunger, thirst, and tiredness for quite a while, but cold is something that will get you quick. Other features - brilliant voice acting and sound design - the sound of wind whistling when you're in shelter is the most realistic I've ever heard and makes me feel cold hearing it. Graphics are stylistic similar to Borderlands - a good choice as it doesn't try to be photorealistic which would obviously balloon the budget and system requirements, but it also makes buildings a little hard to spot against the rocks - maybe higher contrast colour would be better for buildings?Ultimately my opinion hasn't changed that this has the makings of a great game. You'll have to click into a more 'old-school' style of gameplay as the game doesn't hold your hand, but honestly, that's a breath of fresh air.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Survival-Crafting Alpha releases seem to be a dime-a-dozen on Steam lately, so does The Long Dark stand itself apart?(TL;DR? We talk about the game and all of its features and shortcomings HERE on Steampunks) (Coming soon)	Though the story mode is the main feature promised once the game exits Early Access, we’re given a taste of the scenario that lands you in the game’s events. You’re a solo bush pilot, navigating his or her way over the Great White North when a geomagnetic disaster devastates the landscape, enrages the wildlife, and knocks your plane out of the sky. It’s a simple but effective setup that pits you in the classic man vs. wild conflict in a terrain so compelling that we’re honestly surprised we haven’t seen more often in the genre. There hasn’t been much to go on, but it’s obvious that the episodic narrative on the horizon will be a warm welcome. For now, there’s a lot of satisfaction to be found in creating your own stories of survival in Sandbox Mode.There are distinct exploration styles that players can adapt and combine in order to forge their path. Most are likely to spend the bulk of their early playtime scavenging through abandoned settlements for food and supplies while simultaneously beholding the sights and sounds. This type of point-and-click-while-smelling-the-roses playstyle is very reminiscent of Gone Home, though here players are piecing together what objects are most valuable to their longevity rather than uncovering a core narrative. The potential for that type of story progression to fuse into the existing gameplay is certainly viable once the game is complete.Hunting and fishing become available once you’ve persevered long enough and found the materials necessary, though sometimes this can occur from simple luck of the draw. The game places higher emphasis on discovering treasures and keeping the key items in your inventory in top repair after you’ve found them, rather than gathering loads of materials and crafting towards better equipment over time. That isn’t to say there aren’t craftables, but for now these remain as mostly clothing items to keep you warm, rather than tools such as improved firearms, hunting knives, or hatchets. As it stands in the current build, these tools need to be found in the randomly generated mix of items spread throughout the map. It’s once these items are collected that the game starts to really switch gears, and will become the preferred playstyle for most. Explorers eventually become well equipped with a hunting rifle, fishing tackle, flares, and other necessities. There’s a certain pride to experience in building yourself up to be a self-sufficient hunter. Evolving from vulnerability and feeding off scraps to feeling like a legitimate threat to the wild carries a big payoff. Most of all, it quickly becomes the most likely way to keep your stomach filled.The game measures your survival in almost every imaginable way. Hunger, thirst, cold, and fatigue can all be observed from the in-game quick menu, and are rapidly and appropriately impacted by your decisions. A separate calorie counter keeps track of the energy left in your body, meaning you can intake low-nutrition food items to spike your blood-sugar, but these won’t hold you over for the long haul. Unsafe water sources need to be disinfected through the use of collected additive pellets or boiling, or their consumption comes with the risk of infection. First aid supplies can be found and created in order to tend to these ailments and keep up your condition, complete with medication, bandages, antiseptic, and painkillers. Your warmth is affected by the quality of the clothing articles you find and their condition, meaning you’ll be rewarded with being able to spend more time in the great outdoors once you find and sew up some proper winter gear. This becomes vital since actions such as fishing and foraging for wood are time-lapsed, with the effects taking place on your person after the fact.When these features all come together, keeping every part of your well-being in check derives a legitimate sense of desperation. Almost every action you take is based on the necessity of the situation. It’s a real accomplishment for an Alpha development, and it manages to do so without a single zombie. Other than the need for a graphical user interface regarding your player’s clothing, the only problem we found in all of this was the somewhat ghastly strength of the game’s only aggressive mob, the wolves. More often than not you’ll find your play-through at the mercy of their jaws, even if that’s only because you had to make a risky move to go find more supplies. They’re the dreaded creatures that they should be given the context, but it still feels disappointing to have a good run come to a sudden conclusion from a blindside attack. The non-optional permanent death may sour some to the experience, especially in this respect, but it feels necessary in creating the true survival immersion that these other features go so far to create. Separate difficulty settings allow for play with more or less punishing hazards, giving you the freedom to choose if you want more of an adventure experience.The finely crafted exploration extends its way into the game’s artwork as well. The visuals are unmistakably Canadian in a way that has to be seen in order to be given proper justice. The distinct palette combined with the carefully placed polygonal edges and etched shapes make you feel like you’re exploring a genuine piece of Inuit artwork. Fine tunings like the rhythmic puff of breath in front of your face or the feel of your stride stiffen as you enter thicker snow constantly remind you of the harsh nature of the surrounding climate. Daylight casts through the windows of the cabins in which you seek refuge, revealing specks of dust flickering in the sun. Some of these dwellings even proudly carry their national flag above their front door. The attention to details like these help cement the feeling that you’re stranded in the real Canadian north instead of a powdered sandbox filled with things to keep you busy. Some individual textures themselves may not exactly amaze anyone, especially the graphic-savvy, but they still make for endearing log cabin interiors, and beautifully ominous outdoor scenes. Animations with many objects leave a lot to the imagination, mostly due to the lack of hands or any viewable body part. Certain interactions such as lighting fires and reloading rifles could really benefit from this extra attention, but omissions like these can be forgiven due to its Early Access status.The choice of music implementation is scarce and careful. Sparse atmospheric tones are brought in occasionally as you stomp around or discover a new locale, highlighting the experience. When the entire recipe is brought together it can make for some remarkable cinematic endeavors despite not yet having any real narrative backbone.The Long Dark is certainly a refreshing treat after a recent sea of mediocrity overtaking the survival/crafting genre. As this brand of game continues to grow, we can only hope that more titles take inspiration from this piece and create finely-honed experiences of realism that remain faithful to existing real-world culture.SCORE : 8.8/10

								The Long Dark has a feel to it that I've never experienced in any other game, hence making it a bit difficult to define. content:

Early Access Review
								I awoke in a mountain passage, it was freezing and I needed to find help or shelter as quickly as possible. I headed down the pass, taking my chances. I luckily came across a camping office. I spotted wolves in the distance so I made haste towards the door. Inside, the air was stale, but warm. I searched through the dusty office taking everything and anything I could find.After getting warm and some rest, I decided to head out again, due to my creeping thirst. I spotted a derailed box car in the distance, already beginning to freeze I headed over and investigated. Inside was Corey the corpse, a young gentleman much like myself. I lit a fire so we could get warm, and we shared many tales and good jokes. But it soon became time to leave, as it seemed Corey had not bathed in some time, and so we wished the best of luck to each other and he lended me what he could. I headed off. It was starting to get dark, and I could hear the wolves howling. I made my way across a train bridge, and spotted a hydro dam. The wind started picking up, and I wasn't taking any chances. Inside however was vast goods to be indulged in, from sewking kits to med-kits, from canned beans to denim jeans. Upon reflecting on my good fortune, I heard a faint whisper, "This is my dam, you're not welcome here mister". All of a sudden I was thrown to the floor, and was quickly helpless as a wolf aggressively made me feel unwelcome, its teeth pierceing my flesh. Soon it was over, feeling my life spilling across the floor. In my last few moments, Corey walked toward me through a bright door. "Come on...It's time to go".10/10 Good times

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								I remember watching the trailer for this game when the Kickstarter page was up a good while ago. The trailer was enough to get me excited to pledge, but I couldn't afford it at the time.Now, I'm finally able to put my (basic) boots on and walk the cold winterland of northern Canada.Currently, the game only has Sandbox mode unlocked (Story mode isn't available in Alpha).In Sandbox mode, you're the sole survivor of a plane crash (no, not Malaysian Airlines), and you're simply supposed to survive in the unforgivable climate of northern Canada. There are no monsters or ghosts. Your only enemy is the climate, yourself and the wolves that inhabit this God-forsaken area.Simply put, you run around in a fairly small map (they are to expand it and add more areas in the future) where you need to survive by looking for edibles and beverages. You are to avoid wolves unless you can kill them (with a rifle, which is the only weapon the game has at the moment). You can hunt deer and gut them for meat that you can cook by a fireplace or stove. You can explore and loot multiple indoor areas and exciting outdoor environments at the moment.The whole survival aspect of this game is masterfully done with multiple parameters such as your condition (overall health), calories (energy), hunger, thirst, fatigue, and cold. To keep your calories up you need to stay away from the cold and eat/drink. To maintain your hunger and thirst, you have to find food and drinks. To rest, you must find a bed or roll out your bedroll. And of course, to not freeze you have to find amd wear warm(er) clothes, start fires and stay near them for some time, and stay indoors for as long as you can before having to go on another search for supplies.Combat in the game is something I haven't gotten to explore too much as I haven't been able to get my hands on a rifle yet. And as it is the only gun, I can't tell you what it's like to shoot in this game, yet. However, I've been attacked by wolves mutliple times and I can tell you what I think about the melee combat; it's nice at the moment. I like that you can build up strength for an attack, and then hit the wolf. It seems a bit unrealistic to be able to kill a wolf with my bare hands by punching it (since I'm not Chuck Norris), and to have that aspect be unrealistic in this otherwise realistic game feels a bit odd and out of place.I also like that when you fight with a wolf, you have to tend to your wounds by following some simple steps.Visually, this game does it for me. I love the way this game looks. It's very simple, yet it's gorgeous. The colors of the sky can be absolutely stunning! However, the area that you play in is very white as it is snow covered which can get a bit boring after a while to run around in and look at since a lot of the areas are very similar in the game.The map is rather small, which is one of my biggest complaints. It's easy to run around the entire map and then have nothing to do. However, the odds that you'll survive long enough to not have anything to do are low, but when you beat the odds the game becomes rather dull quickly as you've looted everything and you've seen all that you can see.To conclude, this game is well worth it's money. While it's in Early Access (and you should always be critical of games in Early Access) it definitely delivers some great gameplay for what it currently is; an Alpha. I trust the developers enough to keep releasing great updates and keep us players and followers up to date with what they're working on.If you enjoy the survival aspect of games like DayZ and the Forest, but without zombies and monsters, then this game is for you.I'm looking forward to see what more they'll add to this experience in the future!

Early Access Review
								If you're into survival games at all, stop reading reviews and just get this game already!I've played several survival games (The Forest, Don't Starve, zombies) and this is by far the best and most addicting of them all.There are 3 difficulty levels, the easiest is great for starting out because wolves and bears don't attack you on sight. Stuff you need for basic survival needs (hunger, thirst, warmth, tiredness) is fairly plentiful on most maps, so you can horde up on things and be set for several days of just exploring. It's challenging but accessible; if you die it's always obvious what you could have done differently.Here's one of my memorable stories from this game: I was out exploring one day when I noticed a wolf chasing a deer. I sprinted over to the scene of the murder, chased the wolf away (I was on Pilgrim difficulty), and harvested all the meat etc. for myself. But it took over 2 hours and by the time I was done a blizzard had come through, making it impossible to see beyond about 10 feet. And in my frantic rush to steal the deer, I didn't pay attention to which direction I ran, so I was totally lost, cold, and quickly getting colder. I wandered around for what seemed like forever until I finally stumbled onto a familiar birch tree all by itself. Eureka, that marks the way home! By now I'm numb and starting to risk getting hypothermia. The wind is whipping and the snow is coming in sideways. I sprint down the forest clearing until tired, rest while walking, and then sprint some more, to the frozen lake where my cabin sits on the far side. All the while my character is occasionally saying things like "Oooh it's cold" and "I don't think I'm gonna make it."As I finally approach my cabin, I'm frantically clicking on the door trying to get it open and get inside ASAP. Once inside, I bee-line to the fireplace (walking, because I'm too exhausted to sprint anymore) and get a nice big fire going. The orange glow in the room, the crackling and poping sounds of the fire, and my warmth meter rising rather quickly now, all combine for a symphony of artistic brilliance that actually makes me shiver as I sit at my computer, as though I actually DID just come inside from freezing temperatures and lit a nice warm fire.Get this game. Just, yeah.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is a true survival experience, though not like most other survival games, The Long Dark boasts a beautiful world that will leave you speechless, behind this beautiful world lies a disturbing world in which you have to overcome hunger, thirst, cold and fatigue, you must hunt for food or scavenge nearby buildings for clothing and other survivalequipment, you must either fight or sneak past wolves to help you navigate your way through this unrelentless world and look for a place to rest and find food.Melt snow for water, use purification tablets or boil the water to make it safe to drink, heat up coffee or cocoa for extra warmth and cook food for added warmth and fatigue, loot vehicles and corpses for extra supplies and cut the meat from an animal carcass for even better food, go fishing in the nearby lake or take your chances at the dam, everything you do has an advantage and a disadvantage, stay indoors and the wolves will circle the area or you'll run out of food, stay out too long and they will hunt you or you'll freeze to death.In The Long Dark you are tasked with the goal of surviving for as long as you can, hunt the safe house or explore the world in this beautifully built world with atmospheric sound and superb voice acting from David Hayter (Metal Gear Solid) and Jennifer Hale (Mass Effect) who both gave you audio clues to whether or not you are Cold, hurt or hungry, as wellas when it's getting Dark or Light.The Long Dark is an indie title developed by Hinterland studio with some of the crew who have worked on some triple A titles such as Mass Effect to name one of them, they are constantly updating the game to bring new features, items and maps, The Long Dark currently has 2 maps which can be explored on one save by travelling past the dam, both mapsare visually stunning and are full of danger with a lot to explore.My verdict on The Long Dark is that it's a stunning game with some of the best voice actors, the gameplay is amazing and will have you playing for hours on end and is a true survival experience.For more reviews follow our Curator Page

content:
Posted: January 23
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark may be one of the most polished Early Access titles I have ever had the pleasure of playing. Each difficulty level renders a different level of challenge for the player and gives the sensation of playing a completely different game. The easiest difficuty allows the player to wander and discover the handcrafted world at their leisure. With each increasing step up in difficulty, the game becomes less about exploring and more about desperate survival. The limited resources truly give the player a feeling of desperation and helplessness. Depending on what the player wants out of the game, the game can be as challenging as they want. The art takes some getting used to but quickly becomes a very enjoyable viewing experience. I have spent a great deal of time simply taking screenshots every couple of minutes. Hinterland Studios has done a phenomenal job at building the world.  The sound design is top notch as well, roof tiles rattling in blizzards and snow crunching under your feet as you hike through the frozen fields. The character voices are also just present enough to remind the player of their basic needs without repeatng too often. While it is still in early access, I would wholeheartedly recommend the game in its current state and with the quality of work so far, it can only get better from here.

content:
