Early Access Review
								Where to start?This game is incredible, and probably what the survival genre need. The graphics are one of a kind, and kinda minimalist which is something I'm always fond in videos games (but some people might find it weird or odd, specially when a wolf is trying to eat you). The sound design work is incredible, if you have good heaphone I swear you think you are in a real blizzard. The voice acting is great for what we can see of it, but it's just sandbox so it feels random and out of place sometimes.Yeah, by the way, you will pay quite a lot for just sandbox and a bunch of challenge that can be done the eyes closed. Because the game is trying to be realistic in its survival part (which is great), it's really easy to understand how all of this work and what you need to do to survive. In 16h I "finished" the game and felt like I had played whatever could be played of it. But it wasn't scary back then to have this feel, the story mode was supposed to be published later this year. But it didn't. And Hinterland made a point to be either rude or complete dimwit in their PR. At first I really believe they just wanted to publish a game that was exactly like they wanted. But soon the update for the sandbox mode got bigger and bigger. "it's great! Don't complain!" Oh, yes, I didn't complain at first even if my eyebrow rised a little. Because apparently they are just a bunch of programmers. It's the perfect argument for the late release. But it doesn't make sense, if you are so outnumbered, to work massively on your sandbox when it has been two years people wait for a story mode. They make enough money with it, and the sandbox being not so bad, people don't complain. I'm not saying they don't work on story mode (even if three years later I'm starting to think yes), but they obliviously neglect it. And when confronted to the facts, they just evade the question.So, yes, I have given up on the game and regret deeply to have bought it. Not so much for the late release, but more for the way Hinterland handle it. This studios doesn't take their customers seriously nor their engagement.And they doesn't accept critic of it. Sure, there was going to be delay, it's an indie game after all. But not three years. Three years with pathetics excuses is just another Day Z or War Z. I'm a big kickstarter fan, and backed a lot of game. There were almost always delay, it's even logical to have them, but they always at least tell you were they are in the developpment, and don't make any more money until it is released, pushing them to actually publish it and not just wash their hands with the money of a sandbox. And they keep you updated on it. Look at Prey for the Gods. They are even less than Hinterlands and yet they do incredible work in taking their fans seriously and respecting them at least by keeping them updated on the progress (for Christ's Sake they even did a update to explain why there wasn't one in two weeks).So believe me, if you want this game even though Hinterlands are a bunch of ****, wait for the story mode being released, because you will get bored real soon in the sandbox if you are not completely stupid and can comprehend gameplay mechanics. It will probably have a rise in the price, yes, but simply don't buy it on Steam and it will be even less pricy than it is now without the official release. TL;DR: Game is awesome but just sandbox so you "finish" it really quick if you are not an idiot, studio is a bunch of as**** who seems to not care anymore for story mode since sandbox is making enough money and good reviews. Waiting to buy it for the release will force them to work on it more (if at all).

content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark has a lot going for it, but it ultimately playing it feels irritating and a bit boring.The good - The world, while not incredibly realistic-looking, has a painterly quality that's quite beautiful. The setting feels realistic, and it's difficult to survive. Finding supplies or bringing down kills feels satisfying. There are some nice realistic touches and a strong effort toward producing a genuine survival experience. The lighting and weather are beautiful and really impact gameplay.The bad - To me, more realistic details and animations would help round out this game. After an animal has been harvested by the player, its corpse should look different. Fishing should have animations, not just a picture of the fish caught appearing on-screen. Players should not need to eat such massive amounts of food. The player should be able to climb or jump a little, at least. But the biggest thing that keeps me from playing more often is how slow the player walks. I know people walk slowly in snow: I grew up in New England. I get that. But walking in snow is annoying and tiring and slow in real life, and these aren't things I'm looking for in a game. I literally get hand fatigue just from having to hold down the forward arrow for such a long period of time as I walk forward. A building you can see clearly can feel like it takes an eternity to reach - even on ice. The story mode would be a great addition, and I hope it includes the plane crash scene with the ability to scavenge in the wreck. I think The Long Dark still needs to find the right mix of realism and fun. Overall it's a good start, but I've grown tired of it after a week or so, so I can't recommend it right now.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Wow! That's the first thing that came to my mind moments after I fired this up. For such a small footprint, this game nails what it sets out to do...to provide an immersive survival environment in which you can't help but be pulled into. To begin with, this game is absolutely beautiful aesthetically. Beyond this beauty lies imminent horror, as you quickly grasp the reality of your situation in game. There is no hand holding here, but that’s what you would expect given the “survival” moniker stamped on its front cover. The Long Dark succeeds at an extremely high level where other games that fall within this genre have sorely missed the mark. Yes, it’s frustrating once you recognize that there’s only one end game in your demise, but I believe therein lies the genius at the root of its design. TLD will invoke many emotions throughout your short time in its environment. Bouncing between depression, despair, elation and achievement is all part of the dance. I recommend you dress warmly before taking the leap into TLD, as the lines between reality and fantasy will quickly become blurred. All this, and we are still in early access. I cannot recommend the experience waiting for you inside enough.

								This game is simply amazing. With all the areas to explore and things to discover, it has an immense replay value. The art-like graphics and simplicity of the game make it one of a kind. The Long Dark is also a very rewarding game. Every day that you survive gives you a sense of accomplishment. The longer you survive, the more resources you have to work with. Then comes the disappointment. It comes when you've worked so hard to survive and then just like that, you're dead. It's like surviving 53 days and 7 hours, with all your stuff neatly arranged on the shelves and tables, and then not being able to see anything so you can't get to your medicine in the bathroom after a bear attack. Anyways, all around the game is very fun and will take all your time. Highly recommend it to anyone who likes a good challenge.

								If you are into base building/survival crafting games like Rust, 7 Days to Die, etc ....  I dont know how you'll feel about this. 								Awesome game concept, and pretty good execution so far.  But someone definitely needs to educate the developers on the realities of wilderness survival... content:

Early Access Review
								After 75 hours of play, I guess I can say that it is a really good one. At first, you have to understand how to survive: the first few tries are extremely hard and seems like it's impossible to survive a week in this environnment. But when you undrstand some basics rules, you can make it to a 100 days without problem. And it's at that moment that the game become boring. At that point, the only interest is to know how many days you can survive doing exactly the same thing over and over again. So, the pros:- You have at least 20 hours of play trying to figure out what to do to survive. The anxiety that comes from it is really awesome. And that is the main reason I recommend this game. - The map is really good and fun to explore.- The developpers listen to the fans to improve this game and every updates are made in the right direction so far. - Really good immersive environment. Cons:- You can survive way to long if you know how to avoid the wolves. So it's not that much a battle against nature, but a battle to avoid wolves, you should not die from anything except that. - For now, every ways to get food (trapping, hunting and fishing) gets repetitive and boring quickly. - Alpha stage... it can change a lot in the next few months. - Most of the time, you sleep or walk and nothing is happening. - Lack of ressources diversity for now and not many things to craft. Overall, good games, that should continue to improve. I recommend it mostly for the first 15 to 20 first hours of play, after that, it depends on how much you like to do the same thing over and over again.

content:

Early Access Review
								What a wonderful game! I'm really looking forward to the finished release of this. The sandbox is amazing. Having said that, I have some comments after about 15 hours of playing in standard mode: 1. Lots of other people have mentioned the balance issue with wolves, so I won't go into it except to say that I broadly agree with them. I especially think that if I win a fight with a wolf, it should not be able to automatically run away. I earned that pelt, damn it. 2. If I find a human corpse, there should be an option to butcher it. Yes, this is distasteful, but when you're starving meat is meat. History certainly bears this out. 3. More flexible crafted clothing options would be nice. For example, I could make a coat out of deer, wolf, or even rabbit (with a whole lot of rabbits), and each kind of pelt would have different properties. 4. It shouldn't be necessary to melt snow before consuming it as water. I'm a veteran hiker and I can tell you from experience that eating snow hydrates. It also leaves you feeling colder, obviously. I recommend allowing people to eat snow off the ground, but with a risk of hypothermia (and the usual possibility of bacterial illness). 5. More diversity of animals. Bears, musk-oxen, foxes, caribou, and lynx are all found in northern Canada. It would also be a nice touch to add in tern nests with eggs as a discovered food source.

								A survival game without the zombies for once!Although still in early access (at the time of this review), this game still provides hours of fun.  It's realistic and unforgiving - just what you would expect of a survival game that plops you into the middle of a Canadian winter. Willson says you got this keep shooting!!!, 7, 8.... Bear is on top of me... the bear smiles... I smile back.. the Bunnys for shoes smile back at him too... WIllson smiles back... content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm not kidding when I say that this game is frustrating. But it is so frustrating that it is good. It's like one of those puzzles that you just have to keep working on, not because it's a particularly interesting puzzle but because... Actually I have no idea.Let me illustrate for you how a typical game goes (for me). You start, somewhere where you have no idea. Yes you can google for maps, but you still have no idea where you are. OK, so you try to find some landmark that you can remember from the last however many times you've died. Great! A shack with a door! It's got a stove inside! Yes!Everything goes swell for a couple of days. You scout out the local area, discover some fishing huts and loot a whole bunch of cabins. Then you start running out of supplies (food, wood, whatever), so you decide to venture out a bit further.Then a blizzard hits and you're lost in 360° of white. Or you're heading out to fish, and you get attacked by a wolf or a bear or whatever. You might be able to stagger back, frostbitten or actually bitten, to shelter and live out a couple more days, but you know it's game over.And then you try again. Because the game is that good. The concept is brilliant and the execution great. The game is early access, and the promised Story Mode looks like it could be good, but it is ready to play and enjoy now.I also just wanted to comment on the visuals. It seems to me that, a lot of the time, you look at the screenshots for a game and they're all cinematic. Not so with this game. The visuals are entrancingly beautiful. Day time, night time, if it weren't for the fact that the outside is genuinely going to kill you, I would be perfectly happy to explore around just to immerse myself in the environment.All told, The Long Dark is a great game and I highly recommend it.Please note that this review is based on the Early Access version of the game, specifically the Timber Wolf Mountain update. Things may change before the game is complete. I'll update this review when the game is complete.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Needless to say I haven't spent an exorbitant amount of time playing this game, but I thought that I'd share some of what I've experianced during my first playthrough.First off, I'm a stickler for good graphics and was initially put off by the splotchy, water colored look of The Long Dark. Call me vain, but I that just what I tend to like. But I was pleasantly surprized by how well it works for this game. With my gaming PC down at the moment, I did my first playthrough on my regular laptop, with the graphics set a low for better performance. Even then, they wern't bad due to how the game is designed. Within two minutes of playing, I was no long conserned about how the graphics looked, but was more focused on staying alive.The weather is cold and unpredictable, going from standstill wind to biting cold fronts with subzero wind chills. You're always on guard as to how much firewood you have scavanged and are forced to move through the in-game world to find other suplies, due to thirst, hunger, exposure, and fatigue. There is no stumbling onto a well stocked cashe and riding out the apocalypse in some bunker. Food is a major concern as well, because you're constantly burning calories by moving around, gathering supplies, and just trying to stay warm. Finding a candy bar or a can of soda is like hitting the lottery. Without a high caloric intake, you won't be able to carry as many supplies or have the energy to move through the frozen wasteland. Often you'll come across some decent gear that you don't need, and will need to make a decision as to either take it, and deal with being encumbered, or leave it. Sometimes you might be able to break it down into a useful componet, but that takes time, and time costs you food, warmth, and daylight.Daylight. You can see for miles during the day, but when the sun goes down, it's pitch black. You can't see your hand in front of your face. You need to find flares or a lantern, and it leaves you terrified when outdoors. Hearing random sounds in the woods, the not so distant call from a pack of wolves, or suffering the freezing, subzero temperature drops... you must find a place to hunker down well before sunset. Something that struck me the most was the complete lack of people in the game. Starting off, I had the feeling that I'd probably see some NPC somewhere, sometime, but the longer I played, the more it sunk in: that I was truely alone. I figured that at somepoint I would come across someone that I could possibly trade with or talk with to figure out what happened in the world. If they were there, I couldn't find them (I know, probably might have something like that in the actual story mode, not the sandbox Alpha version). This caused me to be pretty excited when I thought I saw a person, and I had to carefully run down the side of mountain to get to them. Turned out that it was a person, or at least used to be. All I found was a frozen body not too far from a ditched car. Almost felt bad as I scavanged his corpse and stole his wool socks. I thought that this added so much to the game and made it strangly unique. Similar games might not have NPC's but you can play online with people off your friends list, but here you're utterly and completly alone. Having to rely solely on yourself made this game in my opinion.Eventually my adventure came to an end as I knelt shivering and tired by an old potbellied stove in a random ice-fishing hut, desperately trying to keep it lit, while a wolf stalked and howled just outside. Running out of fuel, freezing, hungry I made a mad dash across the ice to the shoreline fishing shacks as the sun started to rise, just to be knocked down and mauled by the wolf, who had so patiently circled my campsight all night. Dead by bloodloss from a wolf attack 20h 41m.I was thoroughly impressed by this game and would love to see it fully developed with a complex story mode. There is so much potential and I would highly recommend this game to anyone who asks. For $20, I'll get more use out of this game than I would a large pizza lol. Here's to dieing in most horrible fashions imaginable and to the chance of living to see another day.

Early Access Review
								Extremely immersive and very, very well done, a game that actually makes you gasp with relief when you see the faintest glimpse of your cabin through the blizzard, hunch over your keyboard with finger taut on the W key as you slowly fight your way to shelter through the whipping winds, and sag in your chair when you finally reach the door and get inside. Decently realistic and detailed too. The accelerated timescale (12x IRL time) and set duration of some actions means you have to plan ahead with quite some shrewdness. All items have durability which decreases over time depending on use and abuse. And of course, to keep your character healthy, you must keep track of body temperature, fatigue, hydration, and caloric intake. Every action has its consequence, and you must weigh your choices carefully - just as you should, if you had to survive indefinitely in the wild.  And best of all, it's damn beautiful. Love the art style.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								I don't write reviews very often but this game definitely deserves it!It features very thought-out mechanics and a polished feel of gameplay and visual/audio design. The decisions of what to simulate in a realistic way (weather, hunger, etc.) and what is still meant to be a game (wildlife behavior, balancing of timed actions) are chosen so well that I feel absolutely immersed in this game world - which is what I want from any survival game!It's also nice to HEAR what's going on in the game world. The sounds make such a difference to the immersion and TLD also pulls this off in a great way. Visually, too, of course. The textures and models are kept in a style that's doable for a small studio and still look great. Also the effects and lighting are really well done and support the immersion further.I also love that the different areas of the game are connected and can be explored in one playthrough (if you survive long enough). Though it's a sandbox the gameplay feels meaningful, with looting, crafting, exploring and the occasional fight or hunting trip. After a time you try to be a as self-sufficient as possible because man-made resources start to deplete (since you looted it all) and it's great that the game supports this instead of just spawning new loot items after a time.Not to mention that Hinterland steadily pushes new updates and adds, tweaks and improves content.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let me start off with a simple pros, cons, and mixed chart:Pros:- Very vivid, beautifully detailed game. Mainly artsy and has a hand-drawn feeling to it (because it is!)- Realistic, for the most part, has many considerations to take into account such as hunger, thirst, warmth, fatigue.- Very fleshed out mechanics, an example would be: You are out at night, hauling home supplies from a second base. You are freezing to death, and low on condition, so you strike up an outside fire. Little do you know, it takes time for the ambient temperature to warm up and actually provide you with warmth. You drop plenty of health waiting for the fire to gain traction and heat up, and even then, you need to huddle by until your cold meter drops.Or:You are out in a blizzard, and doing this absolutely shreds your clothing durability, so you must hurry. There is a home against the wind, quite a ways out, and a house a little bit farther, of the same variety. Which do you go to? The best choice would be the slightly farther one, because running with the wind, downhill, or on a snow-clear surface (or all together), you run slightly faster. Imagine you are running on a downhill road with the wind. Rather fast, right?- Plenty of tool and clothing variety, and tiers of protection and tools- Wildlife interaction, and many methods to exploit them for food, such as using a torch to scare a wolf away from a kill.Cons:- You WILL die. This may be intended, but you literally cannot live forever no matter what. It starts gradually. You run out of canned food, so you must hunt. How? With the rifle? It eventually breaks. Use a repair kit? Yeah, you can fix it until the kit breaks. Use your hands? Sure, but you will run out of materials. Magical rifle? Too bad, running out of bullets. So you decide to hunt other ways. Fishing? Only as long as you have tools to break ice. Snares? If they don't break, which they will eventually. Going after used carcasses? If they aren't frozen. Alright, you got a little bit of food, around 1.2 KG's, or 3 pounds. Use some matches to light up a fire indoors? Tough luck, they have decayed or have all been used. Firestriker? Gone. Magnifying lense? Gotta go outside bud. So, now you have a blazing fire. You manage to collect wood with your hands and keep it going, and the wolves manage to stay away. But now the deer are hunted out for a while, and you have to wait until a kill comes nearby. You are too low on food to wait, so you go out to hunt wolf. Use the rifle? Broken. Use a knife or hatchet? Broken. You decide to fistfight it. Clothes on? They slowly get torn up throughout many hunts and blizzards, to the point you are naked and it is too cold inside. Clothes off? You prolong them slightly longer. So, now you killed a wolf, you harvest it, cook it on the same fire, but now your condition is extremely low due to being naked with no weapon. You go inside to sleep and heal, but it is too cold. You sleep until you are frozen to death. The end. So no matter what luck and abundance, you will die from some factor. This is very annoying.- Wolves are too hostile. Yes, the game has a disclaimer, but a single wolf chasing you down and trying to eat you immediately is ridiculous, and especially considering the main male character is roughly one hundred and eighty pounds, at my guess, the wolf would be absolutely destroyed by a kick to the head.- Wolves are too strong. Explained in the above.- Hand-to-hand combat currently consists of clicking very fast, then clicking again to release it and damage the wolf. Then you do this is a few times or more, depending on weapon, then it runs. From there you have to chase it down. From there it is likely a second will spot you. RIP. There needs to be a better combat system IMO.- Deer and wolf barely give you any meat, especially considering calories. You get about eighteen to twenty pounds off a deer, and fourteen to sixteen off a wolf. For perspective, to heal from 35 condition back to 100, in eight hour increments, requires about three steaks, maybe a fourth right away when cooking is done. Each steak is 2.2 pounds. So after healing, you are left with about two to four steaks with a wolf, and you can burn those calories just sleeping all day.- I fear that story mode will not be released until sandbox finishes, which does not seem anytime soon as the game has endless potential.- Very monotone cycle of forage, make a base, eat, drink, boil water, cook food, sleep, go out for items, come back, eat, drink, sleep, eat, drink. I know survival is realisticly just this, but a player can not get the real life feeling of constant threat of horrible death by starvation. There needs to be something to actually do.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------VERDICT: I believe that game has tons of potential, and it is highly playable already, so I do recommend it as of Early Access, this April 17th of 2015. I do, however, fear it will be in Early Access for a long while ahead, and while you can certainly act as if it is a finished survival Sandbox game, there is much to be desired in the long run.

Early Access Review
								Great game for the survival genre. I have enjoyed it so far. I actually pirated the game before hand to try it out and ended up buying it on here. Once the game gets bigger, I suggest a demo or something.Pros-Graphics - really nice artistic type look instead of the usual gritty realistic visuals-Realism - you have to watch what you eat, make smart decisions, even one wolf encounter at the wrong time can leave you dead-Constant updates- The devs are constantly updating the game which is good to see for Early Access. Keep it up guys!Cons-Realism - it would be nice to have actual animations when doing things in the game instead of just loading bars. this disrupts immersion some for me.-Can be monotonous- Once you die a couple times, the exploration aspect has worn off a bit. The game didn't get really fun for me until I found the hunting rifle. -Non Procedural world- A random generated world be amazing for this game.  After you've seen the same place 20 times after 20 deaths, it's not so exciting anymore.Overall, I enjoy the game. Is it worth 20 dollars? Maybe. Once the game is released, yes. Of course with Early Access, you're usually investing in the game instead of buying the finished product. I made the investment and am happy so far. Can't wait to see how much more the game evolves!Thoughts and suggestions--One big gripe I have is with the temperature and freezing. I moved to Canada from South Carolina, USA and the -5C weather doesn't make me freeze to death. Even the -20C weather wasn't terrible as long as body parts were covered. May just be me being nitpicky but that seems off to me.-Needs random generated or dynamic world at the least, either that or y'all will end up adding plenty more regions.-More content as always

								Overall... i have a lot to say, but dont have enough patience to write it. so ill focus on the basics. The map size overall is a little disapointing as well. I found myself walking in circles a good amount of times within the hour and a half i played. I could also add that I never saw a wolf once in that time period, and that seems to be the main component for fear and survival in this game. but aside from all of that i would love to keep up with the game to see if it improves, which i know it will. It happened with the Forest whenever i got it Early Access. It sucked. Everything glitched and i fell through the floor, you couldnt build anything really. Now, a couple months later, you can build treehouses! and they dont glitch!!! Theres not even a story mode in the forest and theres one coming up in the actual release of The Lonely Dark. So my suggestion is if you like a game to a certain extent to where you dont mind it being ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the beggining, then go ahead and get it. but be prepared. if you dont like it that much then just wait a little while. Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is by far a great game that needs only develop some of it's realism aspects, but as it is, this game is a solid piece of work that I truly hope succeeds and is played for many years to come. It's a nice mix of the survival aspect we see in other games with the cold splash of reality many video games fail to deliver upon.The game has one con, that being the lack of multiplayer or co-op, and it will never probably be added for the sole reason that the game's current mechanics will have to be changed, and because of that it has very little replay value. I understand what they're trying to go for with the whole individualism approach, which at first was a welcomed relief to an already over saturated co-op based genre, but after awhile the game just begins to feel repeatative. The addition of new maps is cool, but until the campaign is added in it's probably not a game I'll be visiting again for awhile.If you find the game on sale or are a fan of the survival genre, then I'd recommend the game. It definitely excels at making you feel like you're all alone in a vast world as death slowly, but surely, creeps towards you.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								There is a good game here. It is innovative. It is done extremely well in spots. As far as the survival genre, it has the potential to be in a class by itself. After saying that though, you should know what it is you are getting into. In places the game is exciting, immersive, and beautiful. It can actually give a jolt when a wolf drops in unexpectedly. The buildings that you find while exploring look beautiful. The landscape, when it is free of trees and the developer put some thought and design into it, is very beautiful and thought provoking. Walking into a clearing and seeing the sun rising while a flock of birds flys over you in a v formation is pretty cool, indeed.  Where the game does not do so well is what it seems to have the most of. The trees can span for what feels like actual miles. What seems to make that fact worse is there is single digit tree models. Therefore you go through literally hours and hours of looking at exactly the same tree. Take the fact that the encumberance mechanic makes you walk like you are carrying a gallon of milk with your sphincter, and you can see where this might get pretty boring and frustrating really quick. Also, no map function that I am aware of. The weather keeps throwing blizzards that leave you snow blind. Forget about setting a base and then exploring. Get ready to get lost, see the same thing and double back, see the same thing and double back, see the same thing and double back, etc for infinity. I'm sure with a little more investment you could possible set your own landmarks or drop food on the ground to make a trail. But dang, I just wanted to play a game. I found a perfect little base (Max's last stand). It was great. But I didn't have the rifle and needed a couple other tools. Went walking for a bit feeling confident I could find my way back. Next thing you know blizzard hits, walk for 2 hours seeing the same trees, sprain ankle by bumping a tree, become hypothermic, hit by blizzard again, weight limit decreases to 15, start walking like I'm keistering a pine cone, etc. No rifle found, never found my base again, found bow with one arrow, shot twice with no reticule, bow broke, could probably draw all three tree models from memory. Quit game.  I like this game. I would recommend it as I feel there is enough here for the twenty dollar price tag. But if you expect to have fun then you might be disappointed. Fun isn't necessarily what I felt I got out of it. It would be fun if there was more to find while exploring, and less trees. Or more variation. Also a map function is almost expected in this type of game. Not to have one really sucks. It wouldn't really break the immersion if where you had already discovered was mapped, a la minecraft. Setting up your base would be much easier this way, and would lead to prolonged gameplay/ greater enjoyment for the user. Traipsing through hours of trees to find more hours of trees just isn't fun to me. A reticule for the bow would also be nice. Also for the twenty miles of trees, is there only one dang rifle? I found so many rifle rounds. No rifle. I found a huge farm. I was like "This is it, no farm in the wilderness exists without a rifle". No rifle. Another cool base. Dropped all my gear into a bookbag lying around. Forgot to pick up my bedroll. Left. Remembered bedroll. Went back to find it. Never saw farm again. Wandered for hours till sleep deprivation. Weight limit decreased again. Testes attached to Mjolnir. Also work that encumberance out, please. My goodness, once you have close to the full set of tools, you are already at the limit. A few food items, some wood, and instant turtle. It does have it's moments. With some improvements, could be best in class.

Early Access Review
								By far the greatest game I've played on steam... AND its still an early access, which means it can only get better. I adore this game: the atmosphere, the art, the chill I get when staying up the play the game till early hours of the morning. I don't think I can recommend it enough. The body heat mechanics and weather work perfectly in sync and I haven't run into any problems yet. This game can get tense. I remember gripping my keyboard as I urged my character to go forward. It was before I reached the coastal highway and I had no food and no wood. In game I was close to freezing to death as irl I sipped at a warm mug of tea, close to tears, since I had down so well so far. And then it happened. I saw a shadow of a trailer through the blinding blizzard and I can assure you, I've never been happier. I found enough food and wood (for heat and water) to hole up in that little safe haven for 10 days waiting for that raging blizzard to calm down enough to continue. But my god was that blizzard beautiful. Deadly, sure, but gorgeous. The world fell dark and for the first time in the game, I felt extremely alone. What if I saw a bear? What happened to everyone? Why am I alone? Those questions circled in my mind. But when there wasn't a blizzard and the setting or rising sun set a golden glow on the world, I felt at home. Peacefully happy and it aww at how this game was developed. Haunting questions didn't circulate my mind this time, instead I mused what other gorgeous weather phenomenons I'd experience. I go to this game all the time: when I want to have a break from my hectic life, when I have free time, when I want the tense survival experience of being alone in already isolated world. This is the only steam game I have ever deemed good enough for me to a review on, the only steam game I'd pay way more than it's worth for, and the only steam game I keep coming back to without ever getting bored. Please get this amazing game and start your own beauifully tense experience.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game right here, is one of the best survival simulators I've played in quite a while. Not only are the graphics beautiful,(which can also be played on most laptops/computers with decent fps), but the atmosphere is incredibly astounding. If you play this game with headphones on, you're in for a good time. You'll get to experience some very realistic sounding noises,(heavy breathing when you run, occasional lines your character says, and most importantly, the atmosphere around you.) Even during blizzards, you can't help but appreciate how great it sounds. Aside from graphics/atmosphere, the gameplay is great. The crafting system is creative. In terms of diffuculty, this game varies. Play on easy, you get easy. Play on normal, your experience will be a bit challenging. Play on hard, prepare to punch your computer/laptop in frustration. Aside from difficulty, you're given the chance to play in different maps, which are all conected to each other. (Each map is harder to survive in from each other.) Personally for me, my favorite part of this game, is the danger. The danger in this game is REAL. Trek on a journey to your next safe house, and you just might get burried in a blizzard. Step out in the open at the wrong time of day, you might freeze to death/run out of supplies, etc. Make one wrong step, break your ankles and tear your clothing, exposing you to more cold, and slowing you down. So many things could go terribly wrong, forcing you to really play your cards right. The replay value in this game is great, where you can waste hours upon hours trying to survive as long as you can. All in all, if you want a TRUE survival experience,(and you like the cold,) this game is definitely for you. Personally the price is certainly fair and worth it. I would rate this game a 9/10.

Early Access Review
								While this game falls into the generic "sandbox crafting survival" niche everyone is so fond of looking down on, it - thanksfully - doesn't strictly conform to most criteria. It's not about the vicious cycle of mine-shoot-kill-loot-craft, rinse and repeat. The Early Access plaque it's been having for a couple of years is mostly related to the Story Mode which it still lacks, whereas the game's been here all this time along in the form of the Sandbox mode. If you want the original story, wait for it. If you want your own little experience, try this out.One might argue that this one is a "Dead Souls of a crafting survival genre" in that you'll gonna be dying the first N tries, N being a two-digit number. Don't let that put you down. Don't google all those user-created maps for game locations, because ultimately game content is a limiting factor on replayability for some, and part of the game is about getting familiar with your immediate surroundings and doing proper orienteering - without ingame maps or compasses or whatever, mind you. This is exploration game, after all, with usually no end goal set in stone. Well, apart from not dying.Have good headphones of you. Audio gives you so much spatial awareness here, and ambient sound quality is so good, you'll be recalling the game for the next couple years of yours when you're in your bed bed trying to sleep and you hear wind howling behind your window. I'd say the latter alone a clear and definite indication that this game is worth it.PS: don't look up the name Fluffy if you don't want to spoil your pants-crapping experience at some point. If you're easily scared, though, go for it, though Fluffy will not be pleased.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is one of the only games I've ever written a review on Steam for. Why? Because this is a game that deserves to be played. The survival genre has seen a boom in the last year, but none so eloquently capture the real struggle of surviving in a harsh, unforgiving environment such as The Long Dark. This is a game that - unlike most - can and should be played without a walkthrough, taking in the breathtakingly stylized visuals, scavenging for food and supplies, and figuring out how to survive in the wilderness all on your lonesome. If you want to play a game where your main objective honestly and truly is to survive, this is the game to do it.Having said that, you should know this game is in Easly Access and in the alpha stage. You should expect to find bugs, and you may be put off by the learning curve associated with the game. In the current build (v .183), there are several complaints with the AI (Hinterland doesn't seem to understand what balance is), as well as some real issues (e.g., AI behavior not being reset such that a wolf will be in a constant state of aggression at the bottom of the stairs even after resting for hours). Because of this, the game can be incredibly unforgiving in a way that may or may not seem fair. As well, story mode is not implemented yet, and the sandbox has "only" two maps. This isn't much of an issue, as the equipment you find acts on a weighted-chance loot table, where the gear is randomized with certain stuff more likely to show up in certain containers (e.g., you're more likely to find a flare in a metal box in an industrial area than in a cabinet in the kitchen). However, there is a noticable lack of wood-burning stoves in buildings despite this being the cold wilderness.The mechanics are actually quite nice, such that you organically learn to do new things (as a player). There is a certain level of "skills," such that your chances of starting a fire are low to start, until you do it enough and it becomes easier. However, from the player perspective, it works very organically: you, like the real you, slowly learn the right ways to approach situations, when the right time to go out and forage is, how to find starters and fuel for fires, and so on. As well, all of these actions take in-game time and it becomes imperative to properly manage what you're doing for the day, planning resource gathering and management to maximize time spent alive. The Long Dark makes me excited because it does what I've been looking for in other games. It makes me afraid to leave the safety of the cabin, despite knowing that I have to if I want to survive; it forces you to face its world, and doesn't coddle you. If this game is on your wishlist, you should just buy it now. It's worth the asking price, especially if it's on sale.

								The  Long Dark is a survival game. Not a zombie survival game, not an apocalypse shooter with survival elements, it's plain old survival at its purest. It drops you in the middle of the Canadian wilderness and says "Good luck, jerk, watch out for wolves." It has a little blurb at the beginning about it being apocalyptic, but other than the occasional frozen body and a few abandoned buildings you'd be hard pressed to tell.It works because the survival system is surprisingly intuitive and the game feels smooth and surprisingly refined for early access. I spent less time trying to figure out systems and more time thinking about survival. Unlike other survival games *cough cough* it doesn't feel clunky, which makes the survival elements feel more relevant.Only complaints so far is that the animal AI is a little bit overly simplistic and due to the fact that there's very little randomization (even in loot locations) and only two maps, replayability is currently a little low. I'm sure both of these will be addressed by the devs as the game grows.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Thank bloody christ for game that invovles a catastrophe but not zombies. For that matter, I'm glad the catastrophe isn't another god damned virus outbreak or nuclear war. Granted, I'm sure we'll just end up killing each other with Mother Nature sitting back and eating her cous-cous or whatever the ♥♥♥♥ a metaphorical mound of dirt would eat, but while we still have our imaginations and aren't♥♥♥♥♥♥♥leashed by another corporation, I like the idea that a massive snowstorm has rendered a little Canadian town absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing useless. Long story short, a super massive sun spot appeared causing a huge geomagnetic storm. This one is so strong that it eliminates all life forms (except rabbits, foxes, deer, wolves, fourteen types of fish, and you) leaving the land barren and hopeless (except for the dozens of intact homes, perfectly fine flora, and a mostly intact railroad system that probably just needs some good elbow grease). You must survive by scrounging the land for food and water. Yet, you know what else you have survive against, which probably makes this game one of the best I've seen? The ♥♥♥♥ing cold. (Sidenote: I refuse to a believe a Canadian can't handle some snow). I'll get into the cold later, but let's examine the food and water. You have a very standard hunger and thirst meter. You have a fatigue meter, too, but at the moment, I think sprinting and scripted-event foraging are the only things that really drain your fatigue in any significant degree. Anyway, so you gather food to stuff your face with, and you drink plenty of water found conveniently in toilets all over the abandoned - yet oddly undisturbed - homes (Yum yum!). Run of the mill. It's nothing new, but it's done rather well.The cold: every time you step out of any structure you are stricken with the winter winds and will continuously suffer - for a lack of better terms - damage. You find ways of warming yourself either by ducking into homes, foraging for extra thick coats and gloves, or by starting a fire somewhere (I think). However, as simple as this sounds, the cold feature is what makes me god damn ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the most. It's one thing to have simple enemies (Seriously, ♥♥♥♥ those wolves), and it's another thing to have basic survival needs (technically, Minecraft had a food meter). However, it's another thing to have the entire world be against. Why? Because it gives you a sense of urgency. Taking Minecraft for example, there's no real threat once you've armed yourself well enough; get enough enchants and weapons and you can make the Wither your freakin' butler. In The Long Dark, you can better prepare yourself, but in the end, you're still suffering the cold. It's like holding your breath now versus when you were a kid; you can probably hold your breath longer now because you've better control over you body, but in the end, you still need to breathe. No matter how well you prepare yourself, there's always a threat. There's a sense of urgency and need when you're outside in the harsh cold. You have to complete an objective, or you're just wasting energy in the cold. "But Jay, you can just catch more food, yeah?"Well, yes, but oddly, there's seems to be a finite amount of resources available. While food may infinitely spawn thanks to deer and rabbits, means to make fire or bullets or such seem to be limited. Clothes, too, aren't entirely infinite. So, there's a vague idea present that may suggest your death is inevitable, and yet, the idea is obscured enough that it gives you hope; that just because one person died on day 15 doesn't mean you will. What does all this mean?The Long Dark doesn't give you a chance to just wander around and waggle your♥♥♥♥♥♥at everything. You have to find shelter; you have to find food; you have to find tinder; and you have to conserve your resources or the last bit of bait you'll have for fishing will be your very own♥♥♥♥♥♥sicle slathered with O'Canada maple syrup.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is a "Post-Disaster Survival Experience." Experience is the only word that can be used to describe this game. Among the rabble of poorly thrown together "survival" games that have flooded the market recently, The Long Dark stands out. It's a harrowing, depressing, lonely experience. Something most other survival sims fail to capture. In The Long Dark, you truly feel alone, it's you against nature. Wolves, Bears (and I'm sure more to come) all want your blood, should you wander too close, not only that, but mother nature wants to starve and freeze you to death. The game plays very well, making you choose whether or not to press on for that little longer in the hopes of finding some supplies, or to set up a makeshift camp and pray that you survive the harsh, freezing night. Considering this game is only in early access, and is still in it's alpha stages, I have incredibly high hopes for it, the devs are brilliant, constantly updating, and fixing the game based on customer feedback. The Long Dark is a brilliant survival simulator, with an amazing cell shaded style that completely captivates the player, and immerses them into the cold, bleak environment that will surely cause their end.(Also, it's a survival game with NO ZOMBIES. +100000 to the devs.)

								I've owned the early access release of The Long Dark for about a year now and it is hands down one of my favorite games. After longing over 90+ hours on my computer and a couple 50+ more on my girlfriend's, it's fair to say this is my go-to destress game after classes. 								I got lost in a snow storm, and stumbled through a forest. I couldn't see 3 feet in front of me. I came to a clearing and discovered an abandoned cabin. In the cabin I warmed myself by the fire and took a rifle from it's spot on the shelf. Stepping outside the cabin the next morning, I spotted a deer in the snowy meadow. I lifted the gun and shot the deer. I inpected the deer, but I had no tool to harvest it. I ventured into the forest, hoping to find something useful. I stumbled upon the body of some pour soul who seemed to have met his match in the wilderness. I took his hatchet, now ready to harvest the venison.Returning to the cabin with some new tools, and some fresh meat, I hunkered down for the night, crafting and cooking, and finally slept for a few hours. I woke up, and decided to get some firewood, after all, I was running low. As I foraged for some logs to feed my fire, I fell over dead, claimed by the long dark.This is a very good game, although unforgiving. Once you get going, it is very satisfying and interesting. The atmosphere is what gets me, though. The erie wind and the calming snow. It is very unsettling. I love it.

								Im writing this after my first playthrough.I watched the video and  read many reviews before deciding to play the game .i managed to survive for 2 days and 5 hours. I started out in the highway area.There were several wolves far enough away that i could safely travel the raod and access many houses.i got a decent amount of food and  supplies to keep warm for a bit and keep fed .My main problem was  i was finding mostly canned foods which required a tool to open them .I decided to venture onto the lake where the wolves were because i saw several cabins on small islands and i was hoping for a tool that would be useful .I got halfway onto the lake when 2 wolves spotted me .They started chasing me and as luck was on my side a blizzard came on suddenly and i lost them and made it to the first island with  a cabin .No such luck with any tools save for some sewing repair kits. I continued to go from island to island after resting till dawn from the first night .More supplies but no  knives or axes or even a can opener. I went out onto the ice and  started a fire in an ice fishing shack and cooked some fish and brewed some herbal tea.After the fire died down a wolf found me an attacked me.I fought it off but had to use most of my supplies of healing items to stop the bleeding .I made it back to one of the cabins on a small island and  tore up several unneeded  clothing items to repair my damaged  worn clothes  using the sewing kit .Then i rested till day 2 .At this point i went back to the road and follwed it up to some train tracks .I decided to  follow the tracks .They ended up taking me  to the mystery lake which is the other starting point in the game .My fatigue was getting high and i spotted a dam .I decided to duck inside to see what i might find .I found a lantern immediately  on a shelf and picked it up .As soon as i picked it up , my fatigue level was so high it said you are encumbered and then i heard a howl.I turned around and  a wolf inside the damn attacked and killed me . 								I've spent a decent amount of time playing this game over the past couple of days and i must say I'm a bit blown away by what I've seen so far.  For a long time I've looked for a very realistic survival game that preferably was in first person and this game is definitely it.  It is obvious that the survival elements of this game are extremely well thought out and the player must survive in a manner very similar to what one would have to do in real life. Now I have spent most of my time playing on the "easiest" difficulty because I have neglected the violent aspect of the game in favor of pure survival.  This brings me to the wolves.  Throughout the game (even spawning in buildings sometimes) wolves are freaking everywhere.  You still see the beasts in easy mode but they run away (like a wolf would possibly do for real) instead of mauling you to death because thats exactly what they do.  If you can beat the wolf off you'll have likely sustained injuries that makes medicine and first aid required though this seems to be less common than simple death at least for the novice.  In short, this is an excellent game but it can be punishing in multiple ways.

content:

Early Access Review
								A survival game without the zombies for once!Although still in early access (at the time of this review), this game still provides hours of fun.  It's realistic and unforgiving - just what you would expect of a survival game that plops you into the middle of a Canadian winter.  You must find food, shelter, clean water, and warmth all while steering clear of hungry wolves that make your life much harder - or much shorter.Beware that this is a one-life game!  Once you die, you start over.  There is no going back to the last save before you were mauled by that wolf, or foolishly walked out into a blizzard without pants on.  Let this make you more wary, stealthy, and smart about every action that you take.It's a lonely adventure, as you're the only living person around, but it's worth the trip.  The stylized graphics are really quite beautiful - reminiscent of a painting.

Early Access Review
								While I'm normally loathe to play, let alone recommend an Early Access title, The Long Dark is not only well into a playable state. Not only is it playable, but it is exactly what a wilderness survival game should be: cold, unforgiving and lonely. Your survival will depend on your ability to make snap desicions, your ability to spend your resources well and your ability to navigate. The Long Dark is not without its flaws however: it is not exceptionally well optimized, I experienced fps drops on a  machine that ran the new Wolfenstein at 50-60 fps, navigation can be a chore as the shadow system is not working properly though there is dynamic lighting, hunting is a little less realistic than it should be and it is a little jarring, on medium difficulty wolves survive .303 headshots. All things told, the game is an 8.5/10 in its current state, and it looks like it's only uphill from there. A definite buy.As of writing this review I played 113 minutes, surviving a 5 days ingame.

Early Access Review
								Overall a very good survival game capable of producing some very tense moments, whether it's cresting a hill and coming face-to-face with a hungry wolf or fighting through a snowstorm hoping to find a deer carcass so you don't starve to death.Pros:- Great atmosphere: the map isn't extraordinarily large, but even after 15 hours I still get turned around in snowstorms and get lost.- Very effective UI: looks good, is fairly intuitive, and does everything it needs to do.- High quality voice acting.- Unique and interesting graphics: the environment art especially is very good, frozen corpses could look a little better.Cons:- No jump button: for the most part, you can get where you need to go but there have been times where I've been stuck behind a waist-high obstacle.- Loot spawns could be a little better: most times I find a nice assortment of loot, but from time-to-time I die simply because the loot I need just isn't available (for example: I ran out of water because there literally were no matches / firestarters / magnifying glasses anywhere, I searched for multiple real-life hours and was unable to melt snow or cook tea - just bad luck but could be implemented better).I would definitely recommend, and am looking forward to future updates.

For example when I was crawling through the cold night without weapons and hardly clothings, sure a wolf is near but not sure where he is, a plastic bottle next to my computer made a little noise. I was shocked and froozen, my heart stopped and gf thought about to call the doc. So do not play this game with a weak heart!!Or whenever I see the poor bunny in the snare I pray to him. (I do not want him to forgive me, because there is no excuse, but I explain his poor soul that I am in an emergency myself and swear to live  100% VEGAN  again as soon as I'm back into civilization.)I am very sure that you will not regret buying this masterpiece of a game, especially if you can withstand to read about the mechanics in the forums. (It would work like a spoiler and take out fun finding it out yourself what in a real life situation like that you would have to do.)PS.I promise I will never ever eat snow in real life again (because "the cold would kill me"), but in exchange happily consume every coke i find next to a froozen ice hole at -20 Celsius!!

content:

Early Access Review
								FIrst off; This is an EARLY ACCESS GAME. As with any game in development it is not perfect, however I highly reccomend it even while it is in this stage because watching a game change over time and get better is amazing, and it's even more amazing if you are able to contribute to that process through the forums. Secondly, buying early access games means you're helping fund the developer to finish their vision!TL;DR: The Long Dark is a good looking game with a lot of potential to be hugely addictive. It is a good buy for the person who enjoys atmospheric games and/or survival games. Now, onto The Long Dark.So far in The Long Dark I've only played around with Pilgrim mode because I wanted to feel my way around the controls and the gameplay first, and I am really enjoying it! Visuals:The visuals are clearly unfinished but they have a certain allure in the state they are now. I really enjoy that everything has the feeling of a watercolour with foggy blocks of colour and overlapping textures. I really hope they stick with this art style as they update the textures in later builds, making it more refined and varied, but staying within the realm of expression over realism.  The animals, when you manage to come across them, are a little bland, but that's a minor point. Light sources are kind of inconsistent. Outdoors and inside of lookout towers you can see the sun and the incoming light is correlated to it, but once inside a house or other seperately rendered building the sun is irrelevant and every house is either lowly lit during the day and not lit at all at night. Audio:The sound in this game is actually very good. There is occassionally background music that helps set the mood, but usually there is nothing but you and the wilderness ambience. For some people this may be a turn off, but it is very easy to play your own music in the background (as I sometimes do), but for the most part it helps put you into the survival mindset. There is a lot of quiet contemplation as you walk around the empty wilderness trying to find food and shelter, and exploring to kill the boredom. One issue I've noticed is that you hear all of the sounds from outside even when indoors. In later builds it would be nice if the wind of a storm is cut back when inside, but increases when you get near windows and doors to indicate the storm, etc. Controls and Menus:The controls are a little unintuitive at first. Coming from Skyrim, for example, has me wanting to press Space Bar or E to interact with things, but although you move with WASD you interact with the mouse buttons. Maybe that's just me, but I hope to see the UI improved over time. The menus are a great start to be sure, but something about them is lacking for me. I am excited to see how they progress!Gameplay:In game the pattern can get a little repetative; find a building, loot it, sleep in it, move on, find another building, loot it, etc.Until you reach a point where you have sustainable food and materials you do a lot of that pattern. Even then, it's still more interesting than making a single base for several days. As of right now there are no boredom killers and that's the biggest hole this game faces. When the need ot survive is there, it's interesting; while exploring, it's interesting; when just passing time, it's easy to lose interest in. All of this being said, it's worth checking out if you're into survival, mood, exploratory, and atmospheric games. It'll definitely be one to watch out for as it finishes!

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is one of the only games I've ever written a review on Steam for. Why? Because this is a game that deserves to be played. The survival genre has seen a boom in the last year, but none so eloquently capture the real struggle of surviving in a harsh, unforgiving environment such as The Long Dark. This is a game that - unlike most - can and should be played without a walkthrough, taking in the breathtakingly stylized visuals, scavenging for food and supplies, and figuring out how to survive in the wilderness all on your lonesome. If you want to play a game where your main objective honestly and truly is to survive, this is the game to do it.Having said that, you should know this game is in Easly Access and in the alpha stage. You should expect to find bugs, and you may be put off by the learning curve associated with the game. In the current build (v .183), there are several complaints with the AI (Hinterland doesn't seem to understand what balance is), as well as some real issues (e.g., AI behavior not being reset such that a wolf will be in a constant state of aggression at the bottom of the stairs even after resting for hours). Because of this, the game can be incredibly unforgiving in a way that may or may not seem fair. As well, story mode is not implemented yet, and the sandbox has "only" two maps. This isn't much of an issue, as the equipment you find acts on a weighted-chance loot table, where the gear is randomized with certain stuff more likely to show up in certain containers (e.g., you're more likely to find a flare in a metal box in an industrial area than in a cabinet in the kitchen). However, there is a noticable lack of wood-burning stoves in buildings despite this being the cold wilderness.The mechanics are actually quite nice, such that you organically learn to do new things (as a player). There is a certain level of "skills," such that your chances of starting a fire are low to start, until you do it enough and it becomes easier. However, from the player perspective, it works very organically: you, like the real you, slowly learn the right ways to approach situations, when the right time to go out and forage is, how to find starters and fuel for fires, and so on. As well, all of these actions take in-game time and it becomes imperative to properly manage what you're doing for the day, planning resource gathering and management to maximize time spent alive. The Long Dark makes me excited because it does what I've been looking for in other games. It makes me afraid to leave the safety of the cabin, despite knowing that I have to if I want to survive; it forces you to face its world, and doesn't coddle you. If this game is on your wishlist, you should just buy it now. It's worth the asking price, especially if it's on sale.

								To call this game immersive just doesn't do it justice. There are so many details that make The Long Dark what it is.You shiver when you're cold. Your stomach grumbles when you're hungry. You move slower going uphill or against the wind, and breathe hard after a run. You are in the environment, you are part of it.You have to balance the rewards of exploration against the dangers. Wolves will hunt and kill you. You will get lost and freeze to death in a blizzard. But you need to find the necessary tools for survival: clothing, weapons, medicine.There's a sense of progression without the usual tropes of XP leveling and unlocking skills. You'll learn more about survival, about the map, about your limitations. You'll settle down in a homestead, find a gun, stock up on food and supplies. You can start to live comfortably. But don't get cocky; make one mistake and you'll die, and all that you've worked for will mean nothing.This game is poetry.

Early Access Review
The best survival game on steam....or...well...on anything.Yes, this is very opinionative, but let me tell you why I love this game so much and what could be improved about it, hopefully in the future.Pros:	 Simplistic yet beautiful environment, while snapshots may show it looking kinda plain, they also do no justice for the pure beauty of the game and its situations. Holding out a lantern while standing on a hill and looking out to huge, tree covered mountains while the sunsets certainly looks really good. Realistic. The most realistic survival game I've played to date, it has no zombies or cannibalistic tribesmen. But rather nature itself. Yeah, wolves and bears may not actually attack people, but a wolf attack happens more often than being cannibalized by demons/zombies. Every single thing you do matters in your life or death. Plan ahead. This game is almost all about planning, think about where you're going before you head out, look at the weather and make sure its clear if you're going for a long haul, check your equipment to make sure you can get there and back without freezing to death. Take enough food and water to last you for a while, no one knows if a blizzard might come as soon as you make it to your destination. Realistic crafting. You really earn your bows, and since you wouldn't really know how to make a gun irl, thats the case in the game. Each deer killed was deservingly so and gives you a good amount of meat for several days. It actually updates, they didn't dump a half broken game on you and say that they're not going to fix it unlike tons of other games that are on early access. Updates come about once every 1-2 months and they are pretty damn big, adding things as game changing as bows, a smelting system, new maps, ect. They're not just "Here's something small" every so often then stopping and never returning. Some what difficult, but in the best kind of way. Keeping everything together and living through all of the possible threats (Freezing to death, starving to death, staying awake too long and dying from exaustion, dehydration, falling through ice, wolf/bear attack, ect.) can prove a huge challenge to pass through, but each day you get through feels like you actually made it through a real day on your own in the wilderness. Killing a wolf and taking its pelt, guts and meat not only feeds you for several days but you can craft great gear out of the pelt and guts to live even longer.Cons:	 I've had some, very very slight performance issues, so I'd reccommend you have a computer that isn't actually a toaster. Even still, my computers been breaking and not so good to start with, but I run it just fine, so it doesn't require much to run decently. Perma-death. Its an aspect of games that I don't really enjoy, I understand why its in the game, because it adds to the realism, but I don't enjoy losing progress in games. But if you don't mind that kind of thing, this could be considered a "Pro" to you. Its done very well to make you feel as if you lost your life was due to your own mistakes, so there is no unfair deaths. That and theres leaderboards and achievements for people that like to really get high in the number of days that they stay alive, some even getting over the year mark. But as someone that plays this somewhat casually, it'd be nice to have an option of living after a wolf tears me to shreds.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								There is a good game here. It is innovative. It is done extremely well in spots. As far as the survival genre, it has the potential to be in a class by itself. After saying that though, you should know what it is you are getting into. In places the game is exciting, immersive, and beautiful. It can actually give a jolt when a wolf drops in unexpectedly. The buildings that you find while exploring look beautiful. The landscape, when it is free of trees and the developer put some thought and design into it, is very beautiful and thought provoking. Walking into a clearing and seeing the sun rising while a flock of birds flys over you in a v formation is pretty cool, indeed.  Where the game does not do so well is what it seems to have the most of. The trees can span for what feels like actual miles. What seems to make that fact worse is there is single digit tree models. Therefore you go through literally hours and hours of looking at exactly the same tree. Take the fact that the encumberance mechanic makes you walk like you are carrying a gallon of milk with your sphincter, and you can see where this might get pretty boring and frustrating really quick. Also, no map function that I am aware of. The weather keeps throwing blizzards that leave you snow blind. Forget about setting a base and then exploring. Get ready to get lost, see the same thing and double back, see the same thing and double back, see the same thing and double back, etc for infinity. I'm sure with a little more investment you could possible set your own landmarks or drop food on the ground to make a trail. But dang, I just wanted to play a game. I found a perfect little base (Max's last stand). It was great. But I didn't have the rifle and needed a couple other tools. Went walking for a bit feeling confident I could find my way back. Next thing you know blizzard hits, walk for 2 hours seeing the same trees, sprain ankle by bumping a tree, become hypothermic, hit by blizzard again, weight limit decreases to 15, start walking like I'm keistering a pine cone, etc. No rifle found, never found my base again, found bow with one arrow, shot twice with no reticule, bow broke, could probably draw all three tree models from memory. Quit game.  I like this game. I would recommend it as I feel there is enough here for the twenty dollar price tag. But if you expect to have fun then you might be disappointed. Fun isn't necessarily what I felt I got out of it. It would be fun if there was more to find while exploring, and less trees. Or more variation. Also a map function is almost expected in this type of game. Not to have one really sucks. It wouldn't really break the immersion if where you had already discovered was mapped, a la minecraft. Setting up your base would be much easier this way, and would lead to prolonged gameplay/ greater enjoyment for the user. Traipsing through hours of trees to find more hours of trees just isn't fun to me. A reticule for the bow would also be nice. Also for the twenty miles of trees, is there only one dang rifle? I found so many rifle rounds. No rifle. I found a huge farm. I was like "This is it, no farm in the wilderness exists without a rifle". No rifle. Another cool base. Dropped all my gear into a bookbag lying around. Forgot to pick up my bedroll. Left. Remembered bedroll. Went back to find it. Never saw farm again. Wandered for hours till sleep deprivation. Weight limit decreased again. Testes attached to Mjolnir. Also work that encumberance out, please. My goodness, once you have close to the full set of tools, you are already at the limit. A few food items, some wood, and instant turtle. It does have it's moments. With some improvements, could be best in class.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'll start off by saying the visuals are amazing. The survival mechanics are very in depth and well-integrated into the environment you play in. Things such as wind chill, the amount of calories it takes to chop up a table for firewood, the fact that you cant just start a fire with one match and a log (you need a starter, tinder, and kindling, and even then sometimes you get unlucky and it wont't start), all make it apparent that there are some great minds behind this project.However, it is brutal. If you don't get some sort of purchase and I mean fast, the game will destroy you. In some ways this is good, seeing as they are going for realism, but in other ways its a bit too fast. The hunger and thirst guages, for example, get to critical levels after pretty much every time you sleep, which you have to do or else your exhaustion guage goes up. I get the idea that they want you to constantly be absorbed by a feeling of desperation, but when my character is on the brink of death from starvation after one day without food (people can go up to three weeks without food), it actually pulls me out of my immersion by drawing my attention to something not very realistic, reminding me that I'm only playing a game. Of course, once you start starving and can't sleep enough to restore your exhaustion guage, your survivor is basically moving at a crawl, which makes it almost impossible to find anything that will keep you alive, especially since your vision becomes so blurry you can't even see where your cursor is to pick up anything. At this point, I'm already out of my immersion state, so I usually just quit the game before I die, and that's the biggest problem. The whole point of the game is to stick it out as long as you can before the long dark, but there's such a tiny chance of you making a comback once you're at this point that you don't want to bother crawling around for five minutes, unable to see and waiting for your health to disappear.The reason I do reccommend this game is for everything else that there is, and for the awesomeness that I believe is yet to come. In the meantime, I sincerely hope some of these problems are patched, because it kills me to see a game so nearly perfect but not quite there.

								The Long Dark manages to make me incredibly anxious the entire time I'm playing. I often find myself swearing profusely at my screen as I inch across the snowy wilderness, angry at myself for not having left my resource-collecting expedition just a minute earlier than I had so that I might have missed the storm that caused me to walk for ten minutes in the wrong direction. I find it incredibly easy to immerse myself in the experience of being alone in the wilderness, and that's what I like most about this game. Survival is difficult, and once you're dead, that's it. No starting from a save point, no retreiving that rifle that it took you a week to find, you have to begin again entirely. And it's by no means an "easy" game. It takes planning, and a great deal of wandering around at the brink of death to get good at this game.

								Great game for the survival genre. I have enjoyed it so far. I actually pirated the game before hand to try it out and ended up buying it on here. After you've seen the same place 20 times after 20 deaths, it's not so exciting anymore.Overall, I enjoy the game. Is it worth 20 dollars? Maybe. Once the game is released, yes. Of course with Early Access, you're usually investing in the game instead of buying the finished product. I made the investment and am happy so far. Can't wait to see how much more the game evolves!Thoughts and suggestions--One big gripe I have is with the temperature and freezing. I moved to Canada from South Carolina, USA and the -5C weather doesn't make me freeze to death. Even the -20C weather wasn't terrible as long as body parts were covered. May just be me being nitpicky but that seems off to me.-Needs random generated or dynamic world at the least, either that or y'all will end up adding plenty more regions.-More content as always

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								I awake from a tragic plane crash to realize I am stranded in a snowy forest. I am already starting to freeze from the brutal temperatures of this world. Due to my knowledge from most survival games, I decided to try knocking down a tree. I came to realization this is not any survival game, but an extravagant and realistic adventure. Suddenly, I notice that I will die of hypothermia if I don't take action. I begin to run off into the unknown to hear a dreadful snarl to my right. A wolf leaps upon me leaving me to fight it with my hands. My blood began to trail behind me in the snow after managing to scare it off. My hearing begins to fade as my senses drift off. After 1 hour of being in a snowy forest, I die.Time to try again.I awake in the same situation, in a new area, mainly surrounded by large hills. The sight before me was fantastic. There were many downed trees and stumps in a clearing. There was a deer, a mountain, and upon that mountain, a manmade structure. At last! I have found shelter! Within the viewing tower, was a rifle, medical supplies, a fireplace, bed, and more. I helped myself by making a fire with some supplies I found and resting. I felt invincible. That was until I heard noises outside. Frozen in panic, I ducked down, took out my rifle, and snuck outside. I shortly concluded that the sounds were just the wind causing the building I was in to creak. As soon as I felt safe, in the distance, I heard the howl of wolves. I realized I ate my food, used up my firewood, and had nowhere to run. The structure I was living in surely wouldn't support my life, judging by the fact there was a man's corpse at the bottom of the stairway. I had to leave.After wandering around, the cold and my poor injured ankle from taking a fall off a short cliff, there seemed to be no hope. As soon as I was about to give up, a hidden hatch came into my view. My excitement began to climb higher than ever, as I climbed down the ladder.As I type this to you now, I am in the underground room underneath the hatch. My food and water supply is efficient. The amount of adventure and fun that I have picked up from this game has led me to write a review telling you how much I love it. I am positive I will continue playing along with the development and following the full release.Keep in mind, this game is in the alpha stage, as an early access game, and has a great performance. If you may think there is not enough in this game, I can see your reasoning, but there is still an excellent future for The Long Dark. I still think there are an incredible amount of objectives and strategies that may be used for entertainment.Also, keep in mind that when I wrote this review, I was in the middle of my first time playing it, and only, at the time, had about 20 minutes in it.  Plus, a story mode is planning to be added.This is NOT a stereotypical survival game. Great graphics, (for an alpha game). No zombies. No punching down trees. There are realistic features and it expresses the challenging aspects of survival. You don't just have the danger of starving or dehydrating, but you may be attacked by wild animals, you may die of hypothermia, or be crushed by something collapsing. Who knows.Trust me. This is a masterpiece, and if you love survival games, or any games, The Long Dark is for you.

content:
