Early Access Review
								This game is by far the most perfect survival game. I've always loved the survival aspects of other games and wished there was a game that focused just on survival. Well, here is it. The atmosphere that consumes you as soon as you enter the game captivates the sheer panic of a survival situation. You're alone and you have the whole world to yourself, do you really think you can survive?I love the whole idea of the Sandbox mode. It gives you a chance to do a little better each time. Items seem to appear randomly after each new turn so each new game differs. My only problem with this is I'm afraid it will eventually be too repetitive after so many play-throughs. This happened for me playing Don't Starve, a game that has a similar style of gameplay.However, unlike Don't Starve, The Long Dark is beautiful and the atmosphere that completely engulfs you cannot be praised enough. When you first enter the game you have no idea what's going on, but you see the snow surrounding you and the wind blowing against you and it almost makes you feel cold. It puts you in a state of mind of survival. The soundtrack is morose and melancholic, appearing almost randomly at intervals, furthering pulling you into thought of your inevitable demise.My biggest hope is that the developers listen to suggestions of what Alpha fans think can improve the game, with only a few minor tweaks this game could easily become one of the greatest survival games of all time, if not #1. The only issues I have with the game are minor glitches and lack of content, nothing that couldn't be fixed with the future developement of this game. I really hope the developers are smart about this game, look through a fan's perspective and create content that truly matters to us. I'm extremely excited to see what the future of this game has to offer.The Long Dark is challenging and fun. If you're a fan of survival games or just survival in general, you need to check this game out. The graphics are pretty good, but the well place audio really takes center stage. However still in the early stages of development, it has extreme potential to become something extraordinary.

Early Access Review
								After 75 hours of play, I guess I can say that it is a really good one. At first, you have to understand how to survive: the first few tries are extremely hard and seems like it's impossible to survive a week in this environnment. But when you undrstand some basics rules, you can make it to a 100 days without problem. And it's at that moment that the game become boring. At that point, the only interest is to know how many days you can survive doing exactly the same thing over and over again. So, the pros:- You have at least 20 hours of play trying to figure out what to do to survive. The anxiety that comes from it is really awesome. And that is the main reason I recommend this game. - The map is really good and fun to explore.- The developpers listen to the fans to improve this game and every updates are made in the right direction so far. - Really good immersive environment. Cons:- You can survive way to long if you know how to avoid the wolves. So it's not that much a battle against nature, but a battle to avoid wolves, you should not die from anything except that. - For now, every ways to get food (trapping, hunting and fishing) gets repetitive and boring quickly. - Alpha stage... it can change a lot in the next few months. - Most of the time, you sleep or walk and nothing is happening. - Lack of ressources diversity for now and not many things to craft. Overall, good games, that should continue to improve. I recommend it mostly for the first 15 to 20 first hours of play, after that, it depends on how much you like to do the same thing over and over again.

Early Access Review
								What a wonderful game! I'm really looking forward to the finished release of this. The sandbox is amazing. Having said that, I have some comments after about 15 hours of playing in standard mode: 1. Lots of other people have mentioned the balance issue with wolves, so I won't go into it except to say that I broadly agree with them. I especially think that if I win a fight with a wolf, it should not be able to automatically run away. I earned that pelt, damn it. 2. If I find a human corpse, there should be an option to butcher it. Yes, this is distasteful, but when you're starving meat is meat. History certainly bears this out. 3. More flexible crafted clothing options would be nice. For example, I could make a coat out of deer, wolf, or even rabbit (with a whole lot of rabbits), and each kind of pelt would have different properties. 4. It shouldn't be necessary to melt snow before consuming it as water. I'm a veteran hiker and I can tell you from experience that eating snow hydrates. It also leaves you feeling colder, obviously. I recommend allowing people to eat snow off the ground, but with a risk of hypothermia (and the usual possibility of bacterial illness). 5. More diversity of animals. Bears, musk-oxen, foxes, caribou, and lynx are all found in northern Canada. It would also be a nice touch to add in tern nests with eggs as a discovered food source.

								In a sea of terrible early access survival games this one shines. The Long Dark is an in-depth survival game where you must survive against the elements and natures animals. But you've got to be careful. Wolves and bears roam around and you have to not be spotted otherwise they'll try kill you. 								   This game is awesome, and has a lot of potential. I enjoy survival games, but was sick and tired of zombies in every game. So this game was just right for me. There's a lot to keep you busy in game. It is challenging enough and there is a lot to explore.    I made it 14 days, but then the same thing that happened to another reviewer ('Jesus'), happened to me.    This was my best game so far. i had accumulated many items at my 'house'. I was going out and exploring all shelters on the map. I finally made it to the 'abandoned lookout'. I found the rifle and was ready to leave but wolves were nearby. After fighting a couple wolves and having to run back into the lookout; I licked my wounds and was ready to set back out again. When I would walk back down the stairs, there was another wolf; and it would not go away. This lasted for a couple days. (I tried saving and exiting game also of course) I was running out of food and water so I knew I had to face him. I waited for a good break in the weather and went down to fight him. I was in pretty good condition; no fatigue or anything. For whatever reason this wolf seemed to kill my quicker. I barely got one hit in and that was it, I was like 'wtf'. I was pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at first and I still don't understand why it killed me quicker; felt like I barely had a chance. (unless there is a setting/mechanic that allows the wolf a chance to kill you quickly) That might be something that needs to be looked into. (and of course the way the wolves waited for me at bottom of stairs)   That being said, I would recommend this game to anyone. There's a few things that need tweeking but I would buy this game again without hesitation. A really fun (but unforgiving) survival game that requires you to manage time (there's only so much daylight) and resources; and always has you looking over your shoulder.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've always been a big fan of survival games, ever since way back in 2002 when I was playing the isometric desert island game Schiffbruch. I was thrilled with Minecraft game out, and not long after that, we had games like DayZ. By the time DayZ became popular, the market was flooded with survival games of various quality (usually of poor quality, see War Z). They also almost always contain zombies, and to me, the whole zombie thing is overdone and unoriginal.When I look for a survival game, I look for a quality game where the devs actually care about the players and improving the game more and more over time. I look for a game that isn't rage-inducingly difficult, but not too easy and would get boring within a short period of time. Another important aspect of a survival game for me is the quality of its single player mode. I almost never, ever play online for various reasons (bandits, cheats, hackers, mods who don't seem to care). So the single player side of a game is very important for me. Unfortunately, a lot of survival games these days put the majority of the emphasis on the multiplayer experience, if they even design a single player mode.The Long Dark is one such game that meets almost all of my qualifications for a survival game I would enjoy. It's unique, plays well, is challenging but not too easy, and is a completely single player experience. Your enemies aren't zombies in this one, but are instead hostile wildlife such as wolves, and even nature itself. You'll be going around trying to keep warm while also satiating your hunger and thirst levels, all the while being ever diligent to look out for wolves, which will mess you up big time if they get ahold of you. Something I like about the game is that it doesn't hold your hand, and doesn't put emphasis on combat. There's only one weapon right now, a hunting rifle, and good luck finding that. Even if you DO find one, ammo is very scarce, so you'll be either finding ways to avoid wolves, scare them off using flares, or making every bullet you have count.My only complaints are as follows:- The limited weaponry. It's fine to not focus on combat, but if I run out of flares, I'm pretty much screwed if a wolf comes out of nowhere and attacks me. I'm especially screwed if I don't have any bandages. It'd be great if there was at least some way to fend off a wolf without being taken down by one first, such as using the hatchet offensively, or using the knife during the quick time event with the wolf. Perhaps even bows and arrows would be great. Such things wouldn't put significantly more emphasis on the combat, but would help balance things out.- Speaking of wolves, holy crap. Even when I'm extra careful and on the look out, I almost never see a wolf until it's too late. It's like they just pop up out of nowhere, and can spot you from a mile away unless you're carefully sneaking. I won't complain about how every wolf is always hostile, since I understand the devs wanting to put that in the game, but some minor variations would be nice. Maybe one out of every ten wolves or so won't immediately attack you, or will run away or something.That's all I have for now. If you want a true single-player survival game that challenges your wits and resolve and perfects you through trial and struggle, get The Long Dark. It's currently in Alpha but there's every reason to believe the devs are constantly working on improving the game. So, if you have any suggestions, feel free to throw them at the devs.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have some pretty limited time invested in the game so far (day 6 on guy 3), but I have to say it is really stunning. It is dense, atmoshpheric, dark, dangerous, and spooky without the need for survival tropes like monsters or ghouls. The premise is very simple: survive in the Canadian Wilderness in winter; but the execution is so much easier said than done. The cold is a constant threat as you remain vigilant for predators, structures, and supplies. The only hinderence to the game's approach is the random number generation. Yes, I know very well that that is the nature of RNG, but generally more limits exist to maintain balance and not produce huge extremes. On a given run you may have three hunting knives a rifle and a cabin with enough food to last you to 2025; conversely, you may become dehydrated and famished within hours and unable to survive a wolf attack. While the random chance adds serious replayability and really does make it seem like a new game each time, not all new games are created equal. Despite this minor annoyance (which is also one of its great strengths), the game holds up extremely well, especially considering where it is in the development stage! Pick it up while it is on sale!! Oh, and have fun inside the dam...

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Long Dark is a "Post-Disaster Survival Experience." Experience is the only word that can be used to describe this game. Among the rabble of poorly thrown together "survival" games that have flooded the market recently, The Long Dark stands out. It's a harrowing, depressing, lonely experience. Something most other survival sims fail to capture. In The Long Dark, you truly feel alone, it's you against nature. Wolves, Bears (and I'm sure more to come) all want your blood, should you wander too close, not only that, but mother nature wants to starve and freeze you to death. The game plays very well, making you choose whether or not to press on for that little longer in the hopes of finding some supplies, or to set up a makeshift camp and pray that you survive the harsh, freezing night. Considering this game is only in early access, and is still in it's alpha stages, I have incredibly high hopes for it, the devs are brilliant, constantly updating, and fixing the game based on customer feedback. The Long Dark is a brilliant survival simulator, with an amazing cell shaded style that completely captivates the player, and immerses them into the cold, bleak environment that will surely cause their end.(Also, it's a survival game with NO ZOMBIES. +100000 to the devs.)
